reviews.review: Suggest. I would suggest to visit to everyone. The exterior of the building is quite impressive, so even if you do not want to go inside then there is a lot going on outside - even the view back to the city is nice.I went inside as well, which was very enjoyable, but it requires a lot of time to spend. It was Friday around 14:20 when I visited the place. The administrator said that I could wait 40min to get in for free ( apparently they have this kind of promotion, but not sure if it works everyday). I would suggest to get in as I did - before 15:00 as there was really no one present inside and after everyone is getting in and it gets too crowded.

Incredible preservation work of Church interiors. The painstakingly preserved Pyrenees church interiors are well worth seeing. It is wonderful that these have been preserved for posterity. If you are seeing three or more museums buy the articles BCN pass at any of the many information booths.

We expected more. I have taken my 10 year old daughter there and was quite a bit disappointed myself. First of the museum is very heavy on religious theme, and I found an uncomfortable gap between Renaissance and the Modern art.The building was amazing though and we have seen El Greco, which is one of my favourites.

Great View. Perched above the city; it is a great view. Sit on the steps with a coffee and listen to the guitar player. Wander the grounds for hidden adventure. For those with tired legs, escalators take you to the museum front door. The museum is wonderful. Return at night to see the Magic Fountain.

Stunning art collection in a beautiful building. The Romanesque frescos are beautiful and the modern art collection is fascinating. I particularly liked the furniture by Gaudi. The building itself is worth the visit

Suprising gem, for art lovers a must to visit !. This is our favourite museum in Barcelona by far ! Free entry with the Barcelona travel card the museum contains great art from many fantastic Spanish artists many of whom we were unfamiliar with before our visit. The collections of furniture is also very impressive. Highly recommend to all art lovers.

World leading in Romanesque art, but much more than that. Images dating 900 years back and taken from small Catalan churches 100 years ago are exhibited in a very visitor friendly way. The combination of "Christ in Majesty" (room 7) end two very fine paintings by Antoni Tapies was an outstanding experience. The Gothic collection and the works of the Thyssen collection (Madrid) is also interesting. Don't miss the portraits by Dali and art from the Civil War on the first floor and visiting the outdoor top floor terrasse with fine Barcelona and Montjuic views. Finally MNAC in the autumn/winter 16/17 has an interesting special exhibition with paintings by Lluisa Vidal.
Museum. Quite interesting but is better to go and watch it from the outside, to see it lighted up with the magic fountains is the best way to observe this amazing architecture
Good exhibit by Lluisa Vidal.. The museum is a delight to visit, and the exhibit of Lluisa Vidal opens a window onto an unknown, but very interesting Modernist painter.
Cool. Fountains are a sight to see, beautiful buildings, lively area, excellent at night, some of the best views of Barcelona.
Beautiful architecture. Unfortunately we visited on a day when it was shut. However, the architecture and the views from the museum are so stunning that it made the visit totally worth it!!!

A fascinating collection. Perhaps the most impressive museum approach in the world from Placa Espanya. I have visited the museum 3 times and it never gets old. A varied collection from the Roman era up to the modern, paintings, sculpture, furniture. There is a wonderful view from the plaza in front of the building.

My Favourite Museum. The MNAC is absolutely stunning and one of the best museums I have ever visited. It is at the base of Montjuic and is one of the most scenic spots in all of Barcelona. Admission gives you a 2-day pass so you don't have to worry about trying to cram everything in one visit. You can also climb the mountain which will allow you to see the Olympic Stadium on the way, as well as the old military fort atop Montjuic. Come at night to watch the Magic Fira show! This is surprisingly fun and seeing the castle lit up at night is just as if not even more impressive than during the day. One of my favourite sites in the entire city! *1-2 hours if not going inside the museum, 3-4 if going inside
Excellent Museum. Especially liked the history of Catalan modernism. Great art and well presented. Only downside was the restaurant was closed for a private event.

It's a museum in Spain....and it is nice. I had a free day to explore Barcelona and this was close to my hotel so I took the long walk up the hill to see it. The grounds are nice and the fountains were working when I started my trek to the entrance.Overall, it is nicely divided inside with many nice things to see. I enjoyed the free wifi so I could share pictures with family. One could easily spend several hours there and I did. I would visit it again.I went on a Friday morning so it was fairly quiet inside but I could imagine weekends are busy. Have fun!
Beautiful building. I loved the waterfall which was turned on late in the afternoon a nice place to walk around, on a higher level
Excellent National Museum of Art, Catalonia. This is by far an absolute must see when in Barcelona. Hint: leave at least half a day to view all the superb works of Art.
Nice in sunset. My suggestion is visit here in the late afternoon and waiting for sunset shot from the Olympic park. (very beautiful sunset light)

Beautiful gallery with great variety of art!. Lovely gallery. Wonderful exhibition of medieval church murals and special exhibition. Underrated site in Barcelona. And free for over 65s. Rooftop restaurant looks lovely tho closed when we visited. Recommend a visit.

The info on how they remove the paintings from the old churches is fascinating.... There is a video on how they actually remove the paintings from the old churches to reapply them in similarly shaped structures in the museum and it is fascinating. Also, take the elevator up to the top for spectacular views of Barcelona.

amazing view of the city from the terrace. I love museums, but this one didn't grab me. Some of the art seemed duplicative, especially in the medieval section. Maybe it appeals more to natives and those with a relationship to Catalunya.

Come for the view, stay for the art. On a hill offering fantastic views of the city, the art inside isn't bad either. I wasn't too thrilled in the medieval galleries, but the modern and art nouveau rooms were quite good. Tip: it's free on Saturdays from 3-6pm and the first Sunday of the month.

perfect for a rainy day or a really hot day for that matter. the museum is HUGE so bring comfy shoes! there are two levels that include modern and contemporary art, art from the middle ages, gothic art and many more. It is not interactiv so you can easely get bored especially the kids, so if you have older kids with you , let's say 8 years and up, you can ask them to look for imps, devils or other such creatures in the paintings, this will make it more fun for them. I didn't like the fact that the art pieces have no english comments or descriptions making it necesary for you to get the audio guide if you want to understand something of the whole lot.There is a big gift shop , a coffee shop and a restaurant inside!

Educative and budget-friendly. Disclaimer:We purchased the "BCN Art Passport" for 30 E which gave us admission to 6 museums, this one was included.The exhibitions and art were great, the inside was especially interesting, while the view from the terrace is breathtaking (and free!). Definitely a must-see, very close to Montjuic Fountains and Placa D'Espanya
Amazing. The tour was really good, you need to plan ahead and buy the tickets by the tour hours. Was really fun and interesting

Superior museum....a must visit. . Stately building inside and out. Middle Ages well represented, modern art and masters. Rooftop restaurant with a breathtaking view of the city; reservations a must or eat in the cafe. Impressive rooftop; cafe just soso.

Very nice Museum with views. This Museum is located on the top of a hill with beautiful views of the City. It is accessible from the metro, however, a walk up the hill with partial escalator assist. The Museum takes several hours to see it all. The only negative is that nothing is written in English.
Great Location. Fantastic views of the City, handy for the Arena, and the Olympic Park - which is definitely worth a visit. Superb Fountain show at night in front.
Barcelona's art. This shows the art from another site in Barcelona. You have a special view on the plaza de España and in the background you will see some mountains. A wonderful view!

Largest collection of Romanesque art in the world. Here are Romanesque, Gothic and Modernist works from the Catalonian region with some works between the Gothic and 19th century. The entrance floor is divided by the central lobby. The left side houses the Romanesque collection. The Gothic and works to the end of 18th century are displayed in the right hand side of the lobby. The first floor houses works from the 19th century onwards along with a selection from their coin collection.In this museum rescued artefacts from Catalonian churches make up the largest collection of Romanesque art. These are principally frescoes which have been removed from their original locations. To give them their proper context they have been placed as if they were in a church. So for example apse paintings are displayed in a space built to the scale and contours of a rounded apse. Some frescoes show damage but a number are quite striking. In addition there are sculpture, paintings and some liturgical items.On the right side of the lobby in the Gothic section, there are more sculptures and architectural elements. There are also more paintings on panels, as opposed to frescoes. A number of the paintings look very well and show some influence of Netherlandish artists. On this side are also works from later centuries up to the eighteenth and also from other countries. The artistic centres had moved from Barcelona during that time so there is little Catalonian art between the Gothic and 19th Century on display.The top floor has works from the 19th and 20th century. Principally painting and sculpture it also has photography, furniture and stained glass. In terms of quality, the Romanesque and Gothic works are the best in the museum and are more deserving of time. There are some good items on the top floor but it is not as good as those below.Entrance is included with the price of a Barcelona card, which includes special exhibitions.There is a small cafe on the ground floor and a restaurant on the first floor overlooking the hill towards Place d'Espanya.
Disappointed. It was not nearly as good as we expected. We rented the audio tour which only had about a dozen pieces with commentary. Do not rent this! It is heavy and worthless.
good collection. Also a great view from the top over Barcelona. Beautiful buidling with a good collection of gothic, modern etcf.

Something for everyone. Beautiful museum inside and out - the fountain show on weekends is nice. The collection is varied, including incredible Art Deco furniture. Very good gift shop for chic, well-priced gifts.

Wonderful 11th and 12th C frescoes and more. This was one of the last things we did and we almost were too tired to do it, but pushed on and ended up loving it. There is a restaurant there, so if you time things right you can do the museum until 7, have dinner at 8 and look out over the Font Magica fountains that evening at 9.

Outstanding. In the magical neighborhood of Montjuic, after a long walk, you find this amazing huge palace, that is the Museum. If you don´t want to get it, just visiting outside is already great enough.
Visit is a must. I wasn't to excited about the visit beforehand, but I have to admit it is well worth it: even just the romanic section, with the detached frescos should not to be missed.

A place to get lost!. This s free for seniors, which was great for us. I wanted to look at the contemporary area, but we could only find one painting! So I'm glad we didn't have to pay. We searched and hunted, and found lots of romantic and medieaval paintings, all rather the same and religious, but notwhat I was really after.The shop was good and well stocked and we enjoyed a snack there. Its a place to spend a long time if its your thing, and huge enough to get lost in.

Excellent museum. My husband and I visited this museum on day three of our visit to Barcelona. In addition to the fantastic art, the museum has one of the best views of the city from high atop the elevated area. There are quite a few stairs. A gentleman was playing a guitar which was a perfect addition to the view.

Amazing architecture and stunning views. I did not go inside but the architecture is stunning, there is a beautiful park to wander around and the view across the town is amazing. There is also the added advantage of external escalators for those less able to climb stairs.

Great collection....fabulous views. This is a great collection. Many artists we don't hear about at home and they are terrific. Great painting, sculpture, poster design, furniture design and more. Nicely laid out...always interesting.If you have the time and notion then head to the roof terrace. If you think the view is good from the front of the building, just wait!The great thing is, if you have a Barcelona card then you get in for nothing.Good gift shop/book shop as well.Cafe is good too.The restaurant looks like it will be good...This is one museum you don't want to miss.
Beautiful building. Have to purchase the guided tour but worth it. This explains everything you need to know. Good value
On tour of Barcelona . Got off red bus stop and visited this lovely musaem , loved it and the walk up to it was amazing with fountain

So worth the visit!. This was my second time to Barcelona, and I really wanted to see more than just Gaudi on this trip. I loved this museum. It really opens your eyes to the Spanish people and their history. I love seeing really ancient works of art. And they are here in this place!! We took the funicular up from the metro. I recommend doing that. or you can also get off while on a hop on hop off bus tour. Also the surrounding areas outside are beautiful to see as well.

Wonderful Display. This museum reviews Catalonian art from the early middle ages to the present.The building itself is beautiful and offers one of the best panoramas of Barcelona.For me, the Gothic and Romanesque sections were fascinating - wonderful wood and ivory carvings plus frescoes that have been removed from walls (amazing skill!) and rehoused in the museum. Also the section devoted to "Modernismo" that included furniture and other items.Really, you need more than one visit to do this museum justice.When you need a break, there is an excellent self service café plus a classy restaurant on the roof that takes in the view.
Very interesting . Well worth a trip. Easy to get to and the walk up to the museum is great. Views at the top are cool. Some good exhibits and artefacts to explain the history and art of catalonia.
Great view of the city . Very interesting collection of art. Fantastic view of Barcelona from the rooftop. Must take bus or taxi up to the museum. You can walk down to the plaza.

Beautiful building inside and out. Very interesting. Good if you are into religious art, but not much modern art, the building itself is very beautiful. At 12 euros each a nice way to spend 2 to 3 hours on a very hot day lovely and cool inside, there's a nice cafe in the auditorium.

Another big European museum and art collection. This one doesn't have anything that really stands our above or beyond all the big city museums. It's got it's old italian art, roman sculptures, impressionists, etc. and if that's your thing you can add another one to your list. It's big enough to take 2-3 hours, and if you are an art lover it will be worth your while.

Huge and beautyful. It's a really huge museam and it needs at least 3 hours to explore it in a hurry. the whole area is amazing and should be walked around. I surelly recomend to visit the roof and enjoy the view. It has so many exhibits from the ancient years to nowdays.
A wonderful museum.... A stunning building, fabulous exhibits and helpful staff. What's not to like? As the museum is constantly bringing in new art, we can't wait for the next visit!

breathtaking veiws. check the time table as certain times are free to visit the museum. it is quite a walk up to the museum but it takes you through the gatespass the Magic Fountain (Font Magica) which turn on late afternoon and dance to the music go to the top floor sit and watch the vista but then instead of going down go around the back to the hidden walk way showing the staduim etc

A must see. A wide collection--no disappointment whatsoever. So much to see, including the lovely architecture. It's quite a lot of steps up to the museum--great exercise! But there are also escalators outside for those who cannot do the walk. Many steps inside the museum as well. BRING BOTTLED WATER! Put it in your backpack or bag--you'll need it on a hot day. I made the mistake of not taking any and paid the high price for a small bottle once I'd made the climb up. Food there is quite pricey and not worth it. Spend the day, but then walk down to the street to find better food--and less expensive as well. Lovely fountains outside--and superb views from the top. Many photo opportunities!

Beautiful building with some great Catalan art. I had been really looking forward to visiting this museum, despite the fact that my husband has a shirt attention span when it comes to modern art. We got the tube to Espanya and walked up the steps (lots and lots but thankfully there were working escalators in stretches). The museum is a stunning building surrounded by a beautiful park, the botanical gardens and the Olympic stadium, and overlooks Barcelona so there are great views to be admired here. There is also a nice little cafe right outside overlooking the fantastic view and, thankfully on a scorching day, in the shade. We hired an audio guide but apparently some form of identification was required and we were not carrying our passports with us. I asked if we could write the name of our hotel, room number and street, and our names, and they seemed happy with that - we must look trustworthy then! The indvidual tours are separated into Renaissance, modern, etc but I found it quite difficult to negotiate the menu. What would've been very helpful was to have been able to search by the room number. Also, a lot of the religious triptychs, which would've benefitted from further explanation were not listed in the audio guide. In fact the pictures actually on the audio guide were quite limited. The modern art area is upstairs and there was an evening event being planned in the main room which looked like it was going to be a spectacular evening for those attending. There is a lift to the next floor. I loved seeing the Gaudi furniture (as did my husband - he appreciates a fine bit of woodworking) and the work by Fortuny (we are staying in a hotel with a street named after him and a statue of him too) was the first time I had seen his work. The Picasso was interesting and the posters of the civil war years were suitably bold and stirring. There was some Miro but there is a museum devoted to him further into the park. When we returned our audio guides, the staff destroyed the piece of paper we had signed so at least we can be sure we won't be chased for not returning them. A spectacular building but a difficult audio guide to follow. The shop had some nice posters/postcards in it. I was a little disappointed with the Thyssen rooms as I had expected some stonkingly priceless old masters and a lot of it was devoted to "religious works", but perhaps I'm just a heathen!

Excellent Modern Art collection. Be prepared to spend a few hours in there admiring the works of art. I personally loved the modern art section the best. Art taking us back in time and conveying how History was shaped is a wonder in itself. The historical mural paintings have been well preserved and transferred to the museum. A good visit.PS: Do not miss out on the view of the city from the cafe at the top. Relax for a drink or two and soak in the vibrance of Barcelona.
Excellent museum. A wonderful museum with a great variety of Catalan art. Located on monjuic it offers excellent views.

A treasure trove of Art and History. This is a real treasure in the city of Barcelona. Even if one did not go inside the view from the National Gallery is worth the trip up. You should really allow at least 2+ hours to see this place.

Gorgeous museum free for seniors. Excellent collection, well curated, with clear, concise explanations. Truly a course in art history! The first floor terrace provides a wonderful 180 degree view of the city where we relaxed with snacks.

Explore this whole area. The area around the museum is well worth a visit, day and night, to see the best of it. Very special at night - atmospheric with the illumination of the fountain and the assembled crowds.
Free and Must See!!! Beautiful colourful fountain!. We were fortunate to have arrive during the weekend because the fountain was only open on Friday and Saturday! The display was mesmerising.

Fresco heaven. If you love frescos then don't miss MNAC. The museum is great value, especially if you arrive on the hop on/hop off bus..you get a discount booklet. The audio guide was really good too. Loved it!

A tip for travelers with mobility issues. We would agree with all the positive reviews of the museum and of the views from the roof. A minor scare though: We took a cab to the museum, but couldn't catch one from the museum going back. The main square where cabs and a metro stop can be found is several long, steep flights of stairs down the hill from the museum. Before panic set in, however, we noticed that a whole series of escalators -- not very visible at first -- go all the way down to the big square. No idea how they work in rainy weather, but they were very welcome the other day.

Great museum .... Bought the art ticket and was able to see 4 museums for low price (I think it was 30 euros per person) and saw this Great little museum with some nice works of art ...the space is beautiful as well

Really nice museum. It's not a huge museum but you could spend half a day here easily. It's in a very beautiful building and the view out front overlooks the whole city. The Olympic area is close by too so between the museum, a nice lunch somewhere, and the surrounding area, you could easily spend the day.
One of the best!!!. It all starts outside & then it just gets better. There collection of Spanish artists is as you would expect, first class. Around every corner there was something unexpected.

Good if you are fond of these kinds of art. I was wondering whether to enter it or not. I decided to do it because of the names of Velasquez, El Greco, Tician and Rubens. As I was expecting though, each of them has no more than one or two pictures. There is also some Salvador Dali and one piece of Picasso. The other part also has its masterpieces but if you are not a gallery type it may become boring (especially after the second hous). Otherwise, you will probably enjoy it as there is a great variety - from a range of mural religious paintings to coins, sculptures, Renaissance and modern art. The building itself is a great piece of art.
Superb. We visited only the world famous section on Romanesque art in preparation for a week in the Vall de Boi region. Excellent collection of romanesque frescoes and sculptural art. Well presented.

Unexpectedly good. We'd read some mixed reviews of this museum, so relegated the visit to a late Saturday afternoon (post 3 pm), when entry is free.Three hours later, we were trudging solemnly down the steps towards Espanya, annoyed that we'd had no time to see the Modern and Roman sections,The collection is housed in a grand, sometimes architecturally confused but utterly beautiful building constructed for the 1929 International Exposition, near the Monjuïc castle, the Olympic Stadium and the botanic gardens - if you're in a group with split interests, those less interested in art won't be stuck for diversions nearby. The permanent exhibits in the Mediaeval and Renaissance section are limited in number but offer a fantastic cross-section of (sometimes tenuously-linked) Catalan art through the ages. Cecco Bravo's 'Eva Temptada', Huguet's 'Mare de Deu' and Goya's 'Allegoria de l'Amor' were each worth the €12 entry fee (ticket valid for two days).One word of warning - the descriptions are almost exclusively in Catalan and Spanish so, if you have neither, it will almost certainly be worth purchasing an audio tour or guide book. We left disappointed only that we'd left ourselves so little time to spend here. When you go, take your camera - photos are permitted without flash inside, and outside the views are quite spectacular.

GORGEOUS.. Art Museum, is one of the highlights as well during my stay in Barcelona, left this attraction till the last day visiting this part, was sunny and worth it, at Night don't miss this place too for the Magical Fountain.

Wow! This is a site to see. The view from here is outstanding and the art work inside is exquisite. If you visit Barcelona you really should take a few hours to see this. Most of the exhibits are unique. There is a great display of Romanesque and Gothic art plus some great masterpieces from different ages.There is a great restaurant inside. This is a real surprise. It has stunning views all the way to Tibi Dabo. The artwork is of an exceptionally high standard. Gems just keep on "popping up"! Until we had been here we didn't appreciate the art from the people of Barcelona and the Catalan region.
Great views. Some of the best views in Barcelona. I can't remember if it's just a certain day but after 3pm (15:00) the museum is free.

A must for an art interested person. You can spend hours watching various examples of art in this palace-look-a-like museum which houses a good collection of Catalan masterpieces.
Entrance is free on Saturdays after 15:00.
Beautiful place.. Very beautiful place with interesting arts displays. Nice, cool, not very crowded. Very good place to visit on a hot summer day, and the best part is it's free!

Could have stayed longer. Didn't give ourselves enough time to explore this fully. We were too tired and hot. However if we hadn't been so rushed we could have seen so much more. Our fault not the museum's.

Romanesque Collection a Must. We restricted our visit to the Romanesque collection, and were entranced. The museum occupies the 1929 Barcelona Exposition main hall, but the interior spaces have been reformed to fit the collection, which consists mainly of frescos removed from churches in the Catalon Pyrenees in the 1920s and 1930s. One walks through a series of spaces that recreate the shape and sizes of the respective original churches. The frescos, complemented with wooden altarpieces, stone work, and some ecclesiastical vessels and other objects, date from between the 11-13th centuries. Absolutely stunning.

Museum experience. I guess for people who are interested in art it will be more memorable. Don't get me wrong, I liked it but it was a lot out of my interests but still it was good to try something you for a change. If you go you should be prepared to climb lots of stairs.
Great cultural visit. Great and beautiful art exhibit. The building is awesome. Must go to the rooftop bar relax, drink a beer and enjoy the view, one of the best of Barcelona...it's a hidden gem !

Great exhibition and wonderful building. We walked around all the galleries and took pit stops in the central hall. My favorite was the modern galleries and I loved the variety on display for example the printed adverts and photography.We made the most of the free Saturday afternoon and were surprised that more people didn't do the same but then again it is a huge building and it didn't feel busy.The grounds are lovely and worth taking a walk around. We had planned to visit nearby Joan Miro museum but we were a bit foot sore.
Nice big with long walk. Spend evening with many free shows outside. Go on selected free day..Must to terrace for excellent view

Beautiful exhibition!. Beautiful exhibition of medieval, modern, gothic and Renaissance art - pleasing everyone! Make sure you allow 2.5-3.5 hours for this museum as you don't want to rush it. Entry is free all day Saturday so make the most of that if you can, we came in the afternoon around 3pm and was not overcrowded which was amazing.

Great museum. This is one of the best museums I have visited. It is huge and if you live arts you may feel like spending the day inside. It is possible to buy a two days ticket if you wish to split the visit in two days. There is a cafeteria and a restaurant inside, both expensive. The rooftop walk offers an amazing view of the museum own fountain below and of Barcelona city Reachable by metro plaza españa stop just in front of the museum .

Housing some of the Catalonia's beauty. This museum is set on a hill overlooking the Plaza. The museum is a lovely afternoon's treat. Though it is not the Prado it contains comparable art from the region.

Magnificent location overlooking city of Barcelona. The walk towards the Museum from the Metro - 20 minutes
consists of steps/escalators pass gigantic fountains resulting in
panoramic views over the city
The Museum is housed in a significant building with a grand
ballroom equipped for presentations etc.....the layout of the
exhibitions is excellent
If you love medieval art.... Good for a review of medieval art, shows a lot of local pride, but some might find it boring. Great views of the city.

Very variable museum. I was disappointed. I read it had a fantastic collection of Romanesque and gothic art. In truth the Romanesque art looks like looted murals from churches, all displayed without context or explanation. There are rooms and rooms of parts of wall paintings. After a while it's more interesting to work out how big a fragment needs to be to be saved. Perhaps a couple of square feet? To decorate the rooms with some contemporary artefacts would give it all more context. The two painting bequests were very good and well worth a journey to see.The modern art on the first floor was merely of the quality expected in a local or provincial museum.

A Fantastic Museum. The museum building has great architectural features that can often be found on a magnificent Italian mansion. The most notable exhibitions here are its vast collections of Romanesque and Gothic art pieces. Going through one exhibition hall after another inside this big museum could be quite tiring for many visitors, as I noticed that some were soundly asleep sitting on the couches placed at many resting areas throughout the museum. Kudos to the museum staff for providing such comfortable couches for visitors who have already had a long day visiting other wonderful places that Barcelona has to offer.

Great place and great location!!. Very nice museum with alot of beautiful paintings and arts! If u love arts, then ya this for sure will be worth the visit!! outside of the museum it's so beautiful and specially during night time too! Make sure u have your camera with u during your visit cuz u will for sure take alot of pictures :).

Visiting MNAC during night. Being there for a gala dinner was first of all a surprising invitation. On the way there you may use the escalators to the entrance, where you discover the beauty of Barcelona during the night. The building of Museum is extraordinary, and the modification for the gala was smart and luxurious. A night with friends and partners that is too difficult to forget. That's why pictures exist: to remind you.

Not open on a Monday, but worth the trek. Like many attractions in Barcelona this is not open on a Monday, nonetheless the walk around the building, the views and the approach to the museum is worth the tripWould suggest checking that the places you want to see in Barcelona are open on the days you want to visit!

Excellent view . The Magic Fountain (Font Magica) is a beautiful walk, the vibrant music and the city views. Wear comfortable shoes as there is alot of Walking to the top of the museum. In addition bring water because it is really hot and humid in September.
Take advantage of the free hours. Worth visiting if you save the 12 euros and take advantage of the free entry times (i.e. 3pm-8pm every Sat and first Sun of the month).

Nice view!. It's so good to go up and before going inside the museum, just take a look of the city around you.
Don't forget to take water with you. Summer in Barcelona is very hot!
So Much to Digest. Amazing place to visit and learn about the history of the country. You would be remiss if you didn't take the time to visit.

A museum not to be missed in Barcelona. Everything about this museum is impressive and beautiful. It begins with the imposing main entrance which is accessed from the plaza Espanya. The museum dominates the hillside and once you reach the top (escalators are available) the view looking back over the city are outstanding. There are certain dates / times where admission is free, we took advantage of that. Inside, everything was top notch; from the art to the architecture. You can easily spend all of most of a day here if you wish to see it all. If you are at all an art lover or just someone who enjoys seeing a great museum, this is a must see stop on your visit to Barcelona.PS - the museum can also be accessed from road that goes across the hill it is located on. Local and tour buses bring you nearly to the entrance door.

Brilliant, my favourite sightseeing activity on this trip. We visited this museum twice on our trip as there is so much to see, and even then we hadn't seen all we would have liked to see. The first day we went around the collection of medieval frescos preserved in the early twentieth century by peeling them off the walls of churches in Catalonia to avoid them being destroyed. These are partly displayed in areas corresponding to the shapes and sizes of the churches they were taken from so you see them displayed as generations of local people saw them for hundreds of years, the colours are still vibrant.On our second visit we went through the collection of modern art where I particularly enjoyed the furniture and decorative arts from late 19th/early 20th century, including some Gaudi furniture designed for Casa Battlo.The museum is free to visit of Saturday afternoons, otherwise we paid 16.80 for a family ticket (the children were free but this was still less than the price of two adult tickets so some kind of discount applied) and the ticket would have been valid for a subsequent visit on another day. Good gift shop with a range of items reflecting different aspects of the collection, at fair prices, although it's a museum gift shop so on the expensive side.

Second stage of escalator easy to miss. On a hot humid day, having taken the first stage of the escalator up to the National Museum of Art, we were having second thoughts about trudging on up to the top. We spotted a lovely fountain a short way along a path on the right. Just short of the fountain we saw an escalator which goes all the way to the top. For senior citizens expecting to get free entry, note that it only applies to EU citizens. For everyone else it's 12 Euros to see the collection.

outstanding. 12 euros to enter. Free if over 65. Easily possible to spend a whole day there. Amazing religious artefacts and a very good modern art section. Good cafeteria. Not crowded and cool. One of the best art galleries I have visited. Stunning location.
Impressive. Majestic and imposing... the water cascade was picture worthy... it was made fun as we were taken by the company for a pre cruise tour..
Absolutely gorgeous site!. Loved the building, the fountains, and area and the amazingly breathtaking views! The little cafes in the area were also very quaint!

Renovations done carefully to retain the old structure. This old building has been restored to mretain the old look on the outside but the internal works updated to modern standards.its a perfect example of careful preservation of a cultural building.the works are simp,y impressive.
Vast and interesting. This museum is huge. Be prepared. The art is not that special but the views from the hill are amazing. Avoid the hawkers. The (expensive) restaurant views are great.

Beautiful Exterior. Walk up from Magic Fountain (Font Magica), beautiful walk, with out door escalators. We enjoyed the beauty of this building and the area around it. You can also pass by and visit the Olympic grounds. We just visited the exterior and enjoyed our visits.

Good variety and splendid setting. The museum has a diverse collection set up in a beautiful building. Make sure you see all of it and stop by the "sala oval" and the rooftop viewpoint as well. If you don't have time to actually go inside the museum, you should at least explore it from the outside; the view is spectacular from all angles.

Spectacular! Must see!. This isn't a sight we planned to visit however it was a stop on the 'hop on hop off' tour bus and we are very happy we got off. The fountains and waterfalls are amazing and the building is grand. An absolute must see and guaranteed to get some great pictures.
beautiful building. impressive structure with a great view of Barcelona. There are a lot of photo ops outside - this is also well situated to other art attractions.

Museum coffee shop staff is rude to customers and charges rip off prices. I visited the Museum on Wednesday, 24th August around 17h and also had a coffee at the coffee shop right by the main entrance outside the Museum. My teen nephew purchased a tiny little bottle of water (0.33l) for 2.70 EUR which is obviously a pure rip off, taking into consideration that you usually purchase 1 L of Water in Spain for 1 EUR. So I brought the bottle back and asked for possible refund which the old coffee shop staff member refused very rudely verbally and physically. When I complained about his unappropriated behavior and asked for the official complaint form (which all shops in Spain have to provide by law to the customer upon request) he refused it and continued being rude. This man has no clue about customer service and should not be allowed to serve any customers, especially in such an important touristic sight like this Museum. Moreover he did not give any cashier receipt of the purchased water which is also against the law. I do not recommend to take anything at that coffee shop if you do not want to be highly overcharged and insulted by the old waiter. What a pity for this great Museum to have a Coffee Shop provider with such horrible staff mistreating their customers.

Walking distance from the Crown Plaza. Beautiful museum architecturally. We visited from the outside as we didn't have time to enter. It is a magnificent structure and is accessible escalators to the top. there is a small cafe below to sit in the shade and marvel at the site

Great collection. Only for the view from the top of the mountain over the city, you would want to go there. The museum itself is very big with some very interesting collections. At my time of visit it was very calm so you could easily enjoy all the artworks. It has collections from all styles and times so it has something to impress everyone. The building itself is a masterpiece an sich, be sure to enjoy this also.

Amazing Collection and Views!. The walk- with escalator help!-up to this majestic building is merely a preamble to what awaits inside. Magnificent Romanesque frescoes and altarpieces rescued from isolated Pyrenean churches during the early 1900's before they were stolen and spirited out of Catalunya. Many are displayed in recreations of the apses they originally adorned. It is a nearly spiritual journey just standing in front of this history and imagining what effect they had on the original country souls who worshipped them...We then moved on to the upper level of this magnificent building- clearly designed to impress for the 1929 International Exhibition-and the Modern collection.Nicely laid out by periods, the breadth and quality of Catalan art is truly amazing! Although Picasso- not even Catalan- gets all the press; Major works by Miro, Casas, Tapies Etc. are evident around every corner. One morning just grazed the surface- might stop back tomorrow!
great views. great viewsnice artreally bignot that crowdedgo to Olympic stadium after thatwell worth half day spent

The museum with the hidden gem. This beautiful museum will take your breath away just by its magnificent architecture and grand halls. The exhibitions are good, but the real gem is the roof terrace. It has the most stunning view of Placa Espanya and the city. And being able to sit there with a glass of cold wine absolutely made the day for us!

Excellent collection, great building, nice roof top views, no English descriptions!. MNAC building is a gem by itself, standing on the foot of the Montjuic. Enjoy a long walk around and then pay a visit to the permanent collections of the museum. If you have time check also the temporary exhibitions. We visited the museum by paying the admission fee but it is free on Sundays after some point of time (check the official site).The exhibits of the museum are well placed, lots of effort has been given to display them in harmony to the building. Different parts may interest you, for me the Medieval period and the modernistic parts were the best. Great paintings of El Greco, Picasso, etc can be found there. One disadvantage could be that there is no English description on the tags of the exhibits (Castellano and Catalan are available, which may be no problem for some of us but I can foresee that for others it could be one- check whether there is an English audio guide instead...). At the end of your tour enjoy the great 360 view from the terrace with a drink! You can see pretty much everything from up there! MNAC is accessible via metro and buses, it may not be suitable for little kids (it depends!).Even on the high season period, the place was not crowdy and you could enjoy your visit!

Great modern art section. It was a nice walk up the many stairs to Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya and the museum itself was worth the climb and the entrance fee. Especially the modern art section with Picasso and other great artists.
Great. Very good gallery, a good selection of work from different eras and great to have a drink on the roof terrace afterwards.
Best Place in Barcelona.. Best place to visit in Barcelona.Stunning View and Nice walk. You have to visit it in case you are in Barcelona.I enjoyed it a lot with my wife.

Good value. Beautiful building we climbed the stairs on a Monday only to find it closed, the next time we got the funicular.Very extensive collection but be warned the notices next to the painting are only in Catalan and Spanish.

Very beautiful. This museum is a stunning building with great architecture. All the rooms were big and very quiet also. The art and the sculptures inside were also very special. If you take an elevator from the big hall, you can go to the top and see the whole city.

The views. Went on a Sunday for the free entrance. The modern art collection was fabulous. The view from the top of the steps and walk down was just as lovely. Even if you can't do a free Sunday , please treat yourself to a visit.

Stunningly beautiful!. Three minutes from our hotel, this was a must visit! The museum is absolutely magnificent with all the rooms structurally laid out and all the various pieces of art well preserved. There are food/drink stalls right outside and you may find it economical to purchase a coke or water for 1 euro being sold by individuals rather than the store for 2.25 euros. There are various waterfalls but the two big ones are spectacular. Right at the very top of the staircase, just outside the museum, there are exquisite views and numerous spots to catch that perfect picture!Words cannot describe how great a museum this is. The rooms are well laid out and the actual art is impressive,and the fact that they are so well preserved is amazing . I think it is important in any country to preserve their art and history and Barcelona has done a great job. The museum exterior is breathtaking and the view is spectacular. We did pay extra to go to the rooftop, but personally I think the view is just as good from the top level,so save your Euros! The waterfall on our way down(after 2 hours) was working and was a fitting end to another great day in Barcelona.

One of the diamonds amongst the sweaty slum that is Barcelona. This is definitely worth a look, stunning building and views. From here you can spot other diamonds in the city and the endless streets of awful buildings don't seem as bad.
Fabulous building and grounds.. A great day out great art lovely building very welcoming. The setting and views are wonderful. Nice coffee shop for a light lunch .
Amazing building! definitely go. The building is so grand it is hard to put into words!! Its truly a fantastic sight! Worth going. We looked around the Modern section which was great too.

WOW!! Took our breath away . . Words cannot describe how great a museum this is. The rooms are well laid out and the actual art is impressive,and the fact that they are so well preserved is amazing . I think it is important in any country to preserve their art and history and Barcelona has done a great job. The museum exterior is breathtaking and the view is spectacular. We did pay extra to go to the rooftop, but personally I think the view is just as good from the top level,so save your Euros! The waterfall on our way down(after 2 hours) was working and was a fitting end to another great day in Barcelona.

Great classical and contemporary art . This museum features at from the Romanesque medieval era onwards. I loved almost all of it. At the end of started getting a bit too abstract for my liking so I just rushed through. The museum has different settings based on chronological order (when it comes to styles of art) so if you only want to see modernist art, it's easy, just go to the wind featuring that art. The signals are really easy and straightforward.Great place, definitely worth the visit. It took me about three hours to see all the permanent collection. Three hours well spent!

Superb World-class Museum. The museum is on top of a hill overlooking Barcelona - great viewsThis used to be a grand palace. Internal is fantastic.Collections are priceless and museum layout is great. Pictures allowed!

One of the most beautiful and grandiose complexes in the world. *Important clarification: I didn't enter the museum itself (such attractions are simply not among my main interests), the impressions are about the whole area, from Placa Espanya to the Olympic complex behind MNAC.*And the impressions are unforgettable. Already at Placa Espanya observatory I realized that I'm going to be honored by one of the most grandiose sights in my life. And walking several hours through it, ending with a sunset at the mount where the Olympic complex is located, absolutely payed for itself.
There are only few ART MUSEUM JEWELS of this Magnitude. While not as impressive as the Prado, this museum is a must and also one of Spain's greatest treasures.

Spectacular. The collection here includes many great artists. The view from the front step is perhaps the best view in Barcelona The building itself is worth the visit. We came twice to see the whole collection and were lucky enough to catch a free classical guitar presentation as well. The museum is free to seniors (65+).
large museum. You can visit this palace, and see it from the outside. Its very big and very impressive. Not very old, but all the same, impressive. Inside there is a museum featuring catalonia.

Good museum . The first thing to say is that the view of this building from the outside is outstanding. The beautiful pillars at the start of the street catch the eye and as you look past them you can make out 4 columns and the magic fountains and then above the building itself. Grand hardly describes it! Once you climb up the many steps the view is great (there are some escalators). Inside the staff are helpful and it is a reasonable entrance fee of around €15 for an adult. There's an option to pay a small additional fee for headphones to help describe the exhibits in multiple languages. The exhibits are well presented and in particular the Romanesque items are very interesting. The inside of the building is air conditioned and visually stunning. There is a restaurant with an amazing view of Barcelona (I didn't eat there so can't comment on the food etc). Recommended!

GREAT CITY VIEW. This museum provides a great view of the city. It sits atop a hill that is high enough to view the entire city. There are different viewing levels in from of the museum that allow for different vantage points. We did not go inside the museum because we did not have enough time, but this would definitely be a return location.

A majestic and imposing complex. We took the metro to Plaza Espana and walked up the wide long avenue toward Montjuic Hill. As the Palau came nearer you can appreciate what a majestic building it is. When we reached the top there are nice quiet walkways, buskers and some colourful pigeons on display. From here you can take a short walk and catch the cable car to the castle. Well worth a visit.
Worth the drive. We got off a hop-on-hop off bus to see the museum.It was a great choice. The outside is old world, the inside a typical museum. The view was fantastic.

Terrific Museum but would take a week to see everything!. We only went to the Romanesque and a little of the modern art. Both were excellent. The cafe downstairs had good food at reasonable prices. We wished we had more time to visit all the other halls.

A Great Museum on top of the Hill. Very nice museum full of great items, you will enjoy it because it is full of great pieces, it consist of several wings, you will be surprised of how many hour you can spend there, Also and I don't know why there was an empty Huge hall that looks like a hall that will be used for something in the future, however there was a huge pipe organ that I was amazed to see, overall very very impoortant place to visit

An imposing edifice. Call me a philistine but I did not go inside this museum. I hadn't, in fact, planned to visit it at all but had just happened to be passing.So, although I cannot comment on the exhibits within, I can say that it is worth a visit purely for the sake of the building itself. It resembles a grand palace more than a museum and sits in an imposing position, high above the elegant and expansive Placa D'Espagna area of the city.I would recommend including it with a visit o the vast Montjuic park, which sits on the hillside above. Having visited the park with its various attractions, you can do what I did and meander down the hill, taking in this and, perhaps, the Olympic stadium and village.

Fountains. The fountains are not functional on Thursday and Friday. That is the day we chose to go there n didn't' this see anything. There were many more like us. So don't get carried away and choose the right

A must see. If you are an art lover, it's a must visit museum. The are is divided by periods and you can find your liking. Note that with the ticket you can visit the venue two days in a row, so if you had to take a break- just go back the next day. I loved the modern exhibition the best. Enjoy.
Amazing. Try to visit the museum on a Saturday afternoon. You will pay no entry and you will have the chance to admire Catalonian art from the Romanic and Gothic times up to our days.
Amazing. Just amazing gothic art and museum. The art is spectacular, the Gaudi furniture beautiful. Location is great, cool and comfortable.

Good art collections. Great building and amazing views over Barcelona. There's a good variety of art collections and we liked the Gaudi furniture. Had a quick lunch in the cafe inside which was quiet. Visited with the Art Pass which was good value and fast tracked us through the queues.
Very good. Great place to visit, the magic fountain is at the bottom of thid which is also a must see at night when it is on.

Lots of religious and Gothic art, including chapel murals. The coolest thing this museum had was complete murals taken from chapels throughout Catalunya. One chapel we saw in Andorra had a recreation of its mural, and then we came to Barcelona and got to see the original, which was very cool. They had a video showing the process by which they transported the murals into the museum for preservation. There were multiple large rooms recreating the experience of viewing the murals in a chapel and to help keep their integrity.There is also lots of Gothic art. There are a ton of Mary statues, and a lot of triptychs. There's also a whole wing of modern art we kind of breezed through.The museum itself is located on Montjuic directly up the hill from the Plaza Espanya. It's a great view down from the museum.

Great museum. The architecture of this place was amazing. The art exhibits were terrific, especially the Gaudi furniture and art nouveau posters. The galleries are really well laid out. Don't forget to look up at the domed ceilings and there's a massive pipe organ in a rear meeting room. The tables and snack bar at the outside front of the museum allow for views down the hill and across the city to Mount Tibadao. And the waterfalls as you go down the stairs and escalators to street level are wonderful. Go see it for your self.
For art lovers. If paintings and such are your thing, go and see this. The collections are very good. You can choose from a variety of time periods, from Roman to Modernist artists.

Detailed review. Building where museum is situated is amazing inside as well as outside. Huge comfortable leather armchairs, pleasant temperature and totally free and fast wifi. There is also a huge old auditorium with elevators to take you to tribunes and on first floor there is a mural done by Miro. There is a restaurant and couple of cafes with lunch buffet, but they may be too expensive. Best part is you don't need ticket to access these parts of building! So I would recommend to those going to Parc de Montjuic (best to get there by bus 55 from Placa Universitata) to visit this place while walking downhill to Placa Espanya.But, if you are an art lover, there is medieval and renaissance art at ground floor and modern art at first floor. Highlights are Picasso's Woman with hat and fur collar and Thyssen-Bornemisza collection and there is also a lot of Ramon Casas's paintings. You will even find two paintings by Dali and three by El Greco. But I suggest skipping medieval art. With ticket, you are also able to visit rooftop by elevator and view of building and hill from there is great.
best for romanic art. The building itself is a must. Inside There are the best set of masterpieces of romanic art over in the whole world. If you're interested in you must go.

360 Degrees View. The best museum I attended in Barcelona! Try to set aside about 3 hours here. So much to learn and enjoy the pieces in this museum. Best part is the 360 degrees view on the roof top. Buy a drink and stay on top and take in the view! I came back with my kids in the evening and stayed late for the sunset and the Magic Fountain Show. Such a long and full day I spent here in Barcelona but well worth the time!

Art + Gorgeous view = Very nive combination. The museum is not free, we purchased our tickets online. You can buy the museum tickets only or museum + rooftop. I strongly suggest you buy both. The view from the rooftop is breathtaking and you also have a paying bar for drinks if you wish. Tickets for both are about 12 euros each.If you love art and even you just like art, you will enjoy this museum. It has different sections that go through different periods of time. Each section is great but I personally preferred the renaissance era.There's also a restaurant there with the same view as the rooftop but it's on the expensive side. You have a cafeteria that's serving affordable food and starting at 1pm, you have the lunch buffet which is the best option if you wish to eat different things.

Several Catalan art galleries in one. Give yourself at least 2 hours here but 4 would be better. If you only visit one art museum in Barcelona, make it this one. It is free on Saturdays after 15.00 but is not expensive. You get large and reasonably discrete Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance, Baroque and Modern (say after 1880) sections, all of them interesting and of good quality. This IS Catalan art from around , including sculpture and (for the Modern) furniture and you won't see this sort of thing in this sort of profusion outside Spain. The Romanesque - from c1070 - includes frescoes and other wall paintings, taken from the original buildings (churches etc typically) and recreated in that format (eg basilica). There are works by Rubens, El Greco, de Zurburan, de Ribera and Velasquez representing the renaissance/gothic period, amongst others. Collections gifted by Cambo and Thyssen-Bornemisza are shown inact but as part of the general flow of the museum. The Modern collection is particularly Catalan and very interesting in terms of style and subject matter including the Modernista and Civil War periods.My second time here - I think I enjoyed it even more than the first time.

Impressive collections. The building is so impressive and has a great view over the city. There wasn't a line at the ticket booth. The gallery focuses on Catalonian art and there are 4 collections (2 modern wings, a Roman wing and a Gothic/Renaissance wing). You can do up to the roof and the views are spectacular.
Free?. I don't know if it's supposed to be free, but we got in for free, and it was AWESOME. We loved the modern art sections. We were there 3 hours until closing and wished we got there earlier.

A big exhibition. It is a huge collection of the art of Catalonia. From the Roman ages to the modern art, you can find everything there. It is worth to go to the rooftop, because the view is amasing. The Roman temples are also great.

Long winded, but great views. Some beautiful pieces, I'm sure it caters for all tastes. We enjoyed the upstairs more than the down. The pictures and furniture were beautiful. The Gaudi, Jujol and Picasso pieces are worth the entrance money alone. I would advise anyone going to visit the roof top viewing gallery.The building itself is stunning to look at and it's fantastic looking at it as you walk up to it.

Day Trip. What an amazing building to hold the art work of Spain from the 11th Century up to the modern day. After walking round, make your way in the lift up to the roof terrace where there's a bar and amazing views.
never got in to the musem. get to the top and get a beer at the museum stairs.great view on the plaga espanyayou can also have a walk around the musem area it is very quiet and nice place

Lovely museum. This museum is worth a visit for the wonderful terrace views alone but has a superb selection of various genres of art. We focused on the Romanesque era and spent hours in that area alone.

MUST EXPERIENCE at LEAST OUTSIDE area even if MUSEUMS are not your CUP OF TEA!!!. We were very impressed and AWED with the Museum, Waterfalls in front and FOUNTAIN in front of waterfalls ALL from OUTSIDE. We are NOT Museum lovers. BUT the OUTSIDE experience was more than worth the visit.

A very imposing building.. Noted for its Romanesque murals and Gothic art. A great place to visit if you are an art lover especially of Catalan Modernism....Gaudi, Casas leading up to Tiepolo and Velazquez. If not, just enjoy the architecture and gardens outside and the views through the Venetian Towers.

Loved the modern art and the views. Spent a few hours wandering through the museum. I loved the modern art section. I didn't get the audio guide which might have helped me enjoy the other sections more. The views from the rooftop are fantastic too!!

Cultured. This was an amazing museum to visit, the grounds were breathtaking and the exhibits themselves were very interesting. Getting free entry because I am a student was also a bonus. Would recommend visiting.
Beautiful. My daughter and I loved it!! The most amazing art and sculptures I have seen. Definitely worth the view over Barcelona alone! You have to go!
Stay out if you do not speak catalan or spanish !. Impressive building, nice Architecture and then you get it to find out that almost nothing explained in any other language ... Disappointing ...

What a view!. We didn't go into the museum but Trekked up the stairs to the top and the view over Barcelona is incredible! You can grab an ice cream at the top and just take in the sights- it really is beautiful! You can walk behind it and look at the old Olympic sight too which was pretty. The building itself is beautiful!

Romanesque wonder. Visiting the Romanesque art here was one of the highlights of my trip to Barcelona. I left the teenagers at home and went alone. Extraordinary frescoes are preserved here from many churches across Catalonia. The Gothic art exhibition was also good, but was far more generic, and did not have the extraordinary local style of the older work. Look out also for the good select of art posters in the museum shop.
Corporate event. This is a great location for an event, our event was on a Monday when it is normally closed. Great location and views.
fascinating museum. The caliber of its displays, going from the present back before Medieval times, is very high. Its contemporary sections are better than much (not all) of Reina Sofia in Madrid.

Great Museum. This is a lovely museum located on Montjuic Hill with a beautiful frontage - this encompasses a wonderful water cascade and the famous Magic Fountain of Montjuic. In addition, the front steps offer a fantastic view of Barcelona and the surrounding hills.The entrance fee is reasonable, especially as it offers access for two full days to the museum. The museum offers a comprehensive insight into many key aspects of Catalonian art. During our limited visit, my husband and I visited and very much enjoyed the Romanesque and Modern Art sections. Lovers of Gaudi should note that a portion of the Modern Art section is devoted to his work.All in all, a lovely attraction which should be sought out by all lovers of history and art who come to Barcelona.

Excellent but.... Very interesting art, especially wonderful the many "pieces" of Romanesque churches that have been transferred from crumbling old churces in the mountains of Catalunya to this museums. Can access for free on certain days/times (don't remember which ones!). Information provided could be much better, both in terms of explanations next to the artwork and in terms of audioguide.

If you want to see an incredible amount of same religious "art", then this is for you. Honestly, this was just so dull. There were endless portraits, mosaics, statues and artefacts of Jesus and Mary etc, arranged by the time period they were made.If this is your thing, then you'll love it as there are many, many examples, over and over again. So many that we were sure that we had got lost and were looking at the same ones again - yaaaawwn.The all too brief, modern art section was much more interesting, but certainly not worth the entrance fee.The view from the roof terrace is exceptional though.We won't be back and wish we hadn't wasted our time there.

Best museum. It can be a bold to call this the best museum in Barcelona but to my opinion it really is. If one has bought Barcelona Card, this attraction is for free and it's really worth.The museum is huge enough and has many paintings that are very beautiful.One can go to the balcony and have a wonderful view of Barcelona and the Magical Fountain.The palace itself where the museum is located is very beautiful both from inside and outside.I totally recommend go there and visit it.
Best Views. Amazing building, with so much architectural detail.. Oh what views!!! Get you cameras ready and snap ...

Beautiful place.. We really enjoyed the beautiful walk up to the Museum. There are escalators in a couple of places, but not all the way. If you are unable to handle all the steps, you can approach by bus at the rear. The Art inside was great, and the roof view was terrific for photos.
Beautiful building and great art museum. The area, outside of the building and the view is beautiful and worth a visit in i self, but we also really loved the art collection inside the museum

Not a difficult climb. I expected Montjuic to be a mountain accessible by cable car, but it is quite easily reached by foot with escalators along the way. Great view from the top, Olympic stadium at the very top.

Stunning. The approach to this building is spectacular together with the view on reaching the top. Thankfully there are escalators both ways. The building itself is magnificent and the art exhibitions are first class. A privilege to view so many important artists' work. There is a cafe and a restaurant with outstanding views. (Admission is free for the over 65s.)

Beautiful place to walk and see the city from a high. Although we didn't go in - this museum is centred in a beautiful location with a big build up to the top (where the museum is) which features lovely water fountains and a fantastic view over the city. There are a lot of places to sit and lots to see (even if it's just architecture) - especially good on a sunny day.

Beautiful building. The walk up to the museum is a treat too but could be a cardio work up for some although there's escalaters for those who want the easy way. Tge views from in front of the museum are lovely and it was just pleasant sitting having a coffee at the café up there listening to a jazz saxophonist busker playing quietly. Tge building inside is a cool vast space to explore. Behind the museum is the Parc St Joan and then the Olympic stadium for those who like that kind of thing.

Don't miss it. Well worth the trip up to look at both the paintings inside and the view outside. You need at least a couple of hours to look round and experience the artworks and I would have ben happier to stay longer if it was a wet day but the rest of Barcelona beckoned. The tourist buses bring you up here but you don't have to go back down on one as the journey down by several escalators is brilliant.

Beautiful day out. . Had a great afternoon walking up and around the museum. It was very hot but an escalator is their to help. It's very expensive for water at the top but my top tip would be to take your own. It is a beautiful view. The garden is spectacular. It is very popular place for wedding photos.

Magnificent art collection.. We were impressed with the beautiful building & the Catalunyan art collection. There was so much to see that we spent the better part of a day there & had a lovely lunch in their main restaurant over looking Barcelona. Nice surprise that admission to the museum was free for seniors.

Fabulous building and grounds. Visited last weekend. The modern art exhibitions were exciting - not so much the Gothic, but it's a personal choice.
The building itself is stunning, inside and out. Beautiful gardens and water features, breathtaking views across Barcelona. Inside bathed in light and incredibly restful.
MNAC is close to the Olympic Park which is also well worth a visit.

Panoramic view from its grounds. We had no time to see this museum; however, the view of it walking from Plaza de Espanya keeps you going until you reach it! This was how we experienced the trek up: We passed and admired the beautiful circular monument, followed by two tall attractive towers on each side of the "Calle" that leads to fountains on both sides of the road. We climbed either through inclined wide paths or escalators lined by shaped greenery and flowering shrubs or stairs to the four pillars. Then we climbed through escalators and stairs to the entrance to the museum. It was enjoyable despite the heat, distance and climb. Once you reach the entrance to the museum and turn around, you will be treated to a worthwhile panoramic view of Barcelona, including the mountains in the north that extends to a glimpse of the Mediterranean Sea on the east!

Free on sat arvo. Barcelona had many great museums - as budget conscious traveller came here when saw was free entry on Saturday after 3pm. Lovely collection and building itself is beautiful. Stunning to view from outside and nice view of city. Is a lot of steps up from metro L3 Espanya stop but worth it.

Unique modernist collection. Is a beautiful building. Exhibits are on two floors. On the upper floor is the collection of 19th and 20th century Catalan art with a focus on the 19th Century and the modernist movement. Some great artists none of whom I had ever heard of. On the lower level is the collection of Romanesque and Gothic. A huge area is devoted to 1,000 year old frescoes from local churches in which seemingly the whole walls have been brought into the museum - these are quite amazing. There is also a restaurant and a fine snack bar in the museum. A highlight for me was the roof walk - there is an elevator near the entrance and takes you up for a circuit of the roof (complete with a bar!) fantastic views of the city and surrounds.

Don't miss it. A significant collection of art. Extremely good organized. Amazing building. All these words could be said for many other Museums. What is exceptional for the National Museum of the Art of Catalunya is the look from the Museum to the City. It is unforgettable. It deserves to go to Barcelona only for this view. You can see the whole city, Sagrada Familia, Espania Square, and more, and more.

Imposing building and impressive art collection!. This imposing and lovely museum was the perfect place to hold the Information Theory Conference Banquet dinner. After the attendees explored the museum's impressive and outstanding visual art collection, dinner was served in the beautiful Oval Hall.

Wonderful Art Museum. My wife and I have been to many of the major art museums in the world and this one definitely rates a visit on many levels. For the art lover there is the collection which is impressive and focused on art from Spain and can easily take 4 hours or much longer. Then there is the gorgeous building and the views which are the best views of the city. The food and view from the second floor restaurant are both very fine.The museum is about a ten euro ride from Las Rambles and I should mention that admission for seniors is free. We were there on a Friday during peak season and the museum was not overly crowded.

Wonderful collection. If you want to challenge yourself, take the stairs up to this impressive museum. If not, escalators are available. Come to see the extensive collection of Catalan art and history! A great museum in Barcelona!
A beautiful Palace situated in Parc de Montjuic. An advisor. The Museum has a beautiful collection of gothic art. The exposition of Morales was very special and walking around was very pleasing
summer in Barcelona. The museum was really nice and the fountains leading up to it wonderful. The first Sunday of the month is free!

The way up and down alone would be woth a visit.. This is another great trip for a week in Barcelona. On the flanks of the Mount Juic you are provided with great views over the city. Inside you will have an amazing exibition of art throughout the centuries. Some pictures you would not expect like a Rubens or a Tizian or Tintoretto. The modern part is inspiering. So if you like Art take some three to four hours for this one.

Interesting and enjoyable!. The museum was great. We moved so slow we didn't have the energy visit the modern section, but all we saw was very interesting. I didn't know much about church paintings before and the museum was really set in an educational way. It was nice how much they had translated to English.The museum was very well air-conditioned and the cafe inside was nice. Not too much people.

Amazing Magical!!!. The view, the place, the museum, the fountains just amazing... must go definitely! We were standing from placa espana looking at it from that far and were like wooooooo! They have escalators to get to the peak so it's very easy, see the waters flowing, up there you here musicians playing! Grab a drink, relax to a bench and have some precious time!!! Before all this off course you can go see the museum inside but we had better time outside!!!!

A Must Destination In Barcelona. We have visited most of the museums in Barcelona with my 14 year old daughter. We didn't like some of them like MACBA and CCCB. However this was the best museum we have ever visited in Barcelona. We spent approx. 8 hours in the museum and the result was an absolute satisfaction.

Better than many of the usual Barcy tourist spots. This was a worthwhile visit even though I don't pretend to be the arty type! Through the ages, it starts with wooden panels and wall murals carefully salvaged from old churches, cleverly brought to life in micro locations within the Museu building. Takes 1 or 2 hours to go around depending on how arty you are... Worth finding your way up to the top terrace for panoramic views of the city.
Amazing views. We did not go inside but it is worth walking up to the entrance to get the views over Barcelona and see the various waterfalls and features - and have a drink break!

Wonderful musuem. We spent the entire visit in the Romanesque section. It is exceptional. Our entrance was free because we are "pensionistas." It was a Sunday and we didn't notice it closed at 3 PM until the announcement was made so we didn't get to see as much as we would have liked. Nice restaurant with a view of the city.

Great place to spend a few hours . Great views from this vantage point, especially from the roof. Great Spanish art and interesting history especially the restored murals. Enjoyed this museum and thought it was good value.

Spain-2016. This Museum is Highly if you are interested in Spanish Art. When we attended it had a New Program of Art related to Spanish Artist from parts of Spain. There are so Many Spanish Painters that unknown outside of Spain so this is a place where you can Discover them.
Great Visit. Enjoyable Visit, Plenty to see, very informative. nice staff. map provided. When visiting there was music finals in the musue, which added to visit....
beautiful place with great views. this is a beautiful building and the fountains are gorgeous. didn't go inside but its lovely to walk around and see the surroundings and the great view from the top
Quite a walk but well worth it. We enjoyed walking up to the Museu, the garden and structures. We didn't enter the museum but we enjoyed the view from the top

Nice setting. Beautiful building in an amazing setting with great views over the city. Worth a trip even if you don't go inside. Wide variety of Art and sculpture. Had lunch at the cafe on ground floor food was good.

Absolutely stunning architecture and views. I didn't visit inside, just the exterior. The actual building is gorgeous and the views from the grounds are amazing. I highly recommend making the trip to the Montjuic area just for the views and stunning architecture
Must see. Check out the reconstructed Romanesque murals. They alone are worth the trip up to the museum. Lovely gardens and place to hang out.

So pretty. This place was just stunning, we got a tour bus here. started from the top and walked down the view just got better and better. There are escalators so anyone with trouble walking it's Easy to get around. I would recommend just going here for amazing pictures.

Must see. We were very impressed by the view of the city seen from the museu entrance. It`a a very good place to stay and admire Barcelona from another point of view. We went there at ~ 2:00 pm and it was kinda crowded but that wasn`t a issue. You can include this attraction (and also the Olimpique Stadium) in the same day with Montjuic (it`s verry accessible to arrive by foot).

Great museum in a magnificent building. The MNAC (Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya) makes its home in the Palau Nacional, which was built for the International Exhibition of 1929 and converted into a museum in 1995. On the ground floor are exhibitions on Romanesque and Gothic art, as well as a smaller section showing Renaissance and Baroque art (mostly paintings). The section of Romanesque art is the most outstanding here, because of the murals of Romanesque churches from the 11th to 13th centuries. These murals are quite numerous and most of them are very big too. On the upper floor there are exhibitions on modern and contemporary art (including modernisme) as well as a small coin collection. The architecture of the Palau Nacional is worth seeing in its own right. Take a closer look at the magnificent entry hall and the huge auditorium in the center of the building. The museum shop is also worth visiting.

Immerse yourself in Catalan art and culture!!. The Museu Nacional d’Art de Catalunha has a SUPERB collection of Romanesque mural painting and an extensive representative artists of Catalan Modernism, Gothic art, great European Renaissance and Baroque painters. This is an excellent way to immerse yourself in Catalan art and culture. Allow 1/2 day to see and enjoy the Museum. TIP: Consider a cappuccino and pastry inside at the Museum Cafe or a meal at the Òleum Restaurant - both are excellent!

Nothing on Kelvingrove. The art gallery as a building to me was far more impressive than the Sagrada. The art inside however was not to my particular tastes. One of the most expensive attractions, doesnt offer much for the money, and the toilets were the worst facilities we seen. My fiancé reckons she's seen nicer toilets at festivals.
Worth the view. I didn't even go in the museum, the view at the top is worth everything. My family and I accidentally got in for free, but I think the price is around 8 Euros.

Not usually my thing but this collection is amazing. I have never seen such a varied collection of all sorts of art as is housed in this magnificent building. The most amazing exhibit for us was the collection of rescued frescos from old Catalan churches which would have been lost forever. The technique is astonishing and the end result awe inspiring. PLEASE visit this wonderful collection for a change of pace in this popular city

Wonderful museum with stunning views of the city. One of my favorite places in Barcelona. Lovely museum with a fabulous collection. The rooftop offers one of the best views of the city. It's enough to just sit on the front steps and take it all in, but I recommend you visit the inside of the museum as well.
Make sure you visit the roof top. I just went to the roof top to enjoy a glass of wine and the view.Nice view, took lots of pictures from there and photos of this stunning palace as well.
