Lots to see. Has both modern and older art. Ticket gets you two days so you can visit again if you want. I liked that there were lots of explanations of the art for non art specialists like me.

Beautiful Museum with Great View. The museum is laid out well with different this to see. It is on top of hill at Espanya Square and a great view. Architecture is interesting. The fountains are below it.
Free on Saturday. Amazing number of different artists and styles--the signinficance is apparent and very different from the Picasso Museum which is also a must see. This was free on Saturday

A museum worth visiting inside and out. If you're feeling athletic, you can try taking the stairs to go all the way up to the museum! If not, then you're saved from getting jelly legs even before you reach the museum's doors by making use of the elevators running up the side of the ginormous multi tiered fountain that makes up part of the museum's spectacular facade. When you get to the top, don't forget to turn around and take in the scene of Barcelona before you- it's a gorgeous scene. The museum is admission free from 3PM onwards on Saturday! There's no fear about missing any part of the exhibition, as all sections of the museum is labelled with banners and are clearly defined. This is a big museum and there are many different art styles/genres/movements housed at the MNAC so most likely you will find something you'll like here. One of my favourite moments was having Picasso's "Woman in Hat and Fur Collar" all to myself for a good whole 5 minutes.

You don't need to be an art lover.. Frankly, I'm not. However the overall ambience, layout and items displayed makes for an extremely worthwhile couple of hours.Art lovers, on the other hand, will rejoice as there's a lot to see including an amazing area containing various Gaudi architecture/design.P.S. Cost is 12 Euro.

Beautiful and inspiring . I didn't know what to expect when I came here, but it is worth the view over Barcelona alone. The walk up is easy enough, there's some escalators up the lower parts, and then lots of stairs to get to the top! But it's definitely worth it! Once inside there is so much to look at, you can easily spend a couple of hours here. Definitely worth a visit, I found it so inspiring and interesting, to see works of art from hundreds of years ago in pretty good condition.

Make sure you go up onto the roof area. I loved this museum - so much to see (both the art and the building). Then I noticed what looked like a roof access on the museum plan and I investigated. The view from the roof was amazing and it was possible to walk around the roof area and see the museum from a different angle. There were only a couple of other people up there which surprised me.
Simply amazing. We took the mountain elevator here and had a wonderful time strolling around taking in the views of Barcelona.

Superb Art Gallery. We were lucky as the fountains were on when we arrived and the setting is beautiful. There are places to store your pack packs so you can wander freely up encumbered . There is a wide range of picures to look at and the amazing thing is that for seniors it is free. There is a coffee shop to have a bit of a rest and comfortable sofa in the vestibule . After you've enjoyed the paintings you can take in the gardens at the back or even the Olympic area. Well worth a visit

Well worth a visit. This place can be got to via the RED tourist bus route. Very impresssive from the outside, with stunning views over the city from the outside, especially when on the roof, where you can also overlook the Olympic Stadium and Comms tower. Some interesting art collections, and very airy inside. Approx 12 euro to get in, but cheaper if you can find some discount coupons.

Just go!. A beautiful building forget about the wonderful art, a great visit.As most places in Barcelona charge entry fees visiting the National Gallery is well worth the entry fee, €12, give yourself plenty of time to wander around,minimum two hours needed.There was a cafe located in the palace where you can take a break between galleries .Here Seniors receive free entry!

Ms. Great collection of art through the ages. Adult attraction of course. Good for a poor weather day to bask in the brilliance of the masters like Picasso, Rubens, Chicharre(sp?)and on and on. Funny though, that when we entered the room with ancient crypts, the lights went out briefly in this highly modern and imposing museum. See the huge magic fountain in front from thurs thru sun for an awesome light display, starting at 830 repeated till 11.

You could spend a whole day here!. This is an incredibly large art gallery with a vast collection. I found it very interesting but since I appreciate more of the contemporary I was delighted to find a wonderful Miro and Picasso! Worth spending a few hours here.

Incredibly pretty.... My family and I walked from our Hotel at the Apollo to this location and was taken away by the view. Many pictures were taken and the inside, even under construction, was very pretty. My only disappointment was that on a hot day, the fountains were not running. It would have definitely added that extra wow factor if the fountains were running.
masterpiece of different periods. it really worths a visit.paintings,sculptures,etc from important artists.you need at least 3 hours for a quick view...choose saturday after 15:00.its free...
Beautiful museum with lots of big paintings. Free of charge on Saturday after 3pm, worth a walk from Metro to the Museum. Great collection of paintings, enjoy very much during our visit.

Fantastic View. We didn't go into the museum but the view from here over the city was brilliant. Magic fountains are situated here as well these look just as good from the top as from the bottom and there are escalators from top to bottom for those who would find the steps a struggle.

The primary Museum. We spent most of a day here including a break for a lunch. The collections are vast and you need to select those that interest you or you will run out of time. Staff and guide booklet excellent. Access up the avenue is out of this world.

For the art lover. The art gallery is set in the most beautiful building that is art itself . A varied collection of religious art , general art, modern art , Guadi pieces and we were lucky enough to see a Picasso while we were there worth a look

Incredible, but Specialized Museum. This museum is absolutely incredible, but it is absolutely not a kid friendly environment. I would even say that it isn't even adult friendly unless said adults are really into art from the Catalonian area. It offers incredible views of the city, but those views can be found elsewhere.

Superb Romanesque & Gothic Art. For lovers of medieval art, MNAC is unmissable. And the Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection, formerly housed at the Royal Monastery in Pedralbes, is excellent. You can see and savor much in 2-3 hours. Tip: There is an elegant restaurant that typically requires advance booking.

very good collection. The collection of the museum is prety vast and various. You can easily spent there all afternoon watching different piece of art. The building is very spacious and you feel a lot of comfort walking through the rooms. The museum has several collection that would take you through the time. I recommend this place in order to get to know BCN and Catalonia art better:))

Spectacular. We took a cab here and were left off at the bottom the enormous stairway. After the awful climb we found a driveway on the top of the hill, so let the driver take you around the back to the top. Leaving we had to walk about 1/2 mile to the main street and pray a cab came by.The collection is housed and a large spectacular building. The art is mostly good but variable in quality from adequate to great, but all really enjoyable. The coffee shop is terribly overpriced. I highly recommend a visit but don't climb the massive front stairs.
Stunning. Great views from here down to the old bull fighting ring. Brilliant architecture, but the museum is closed on Monday's.
Gorgeous inside and out!. I was there for a gala dinner and they really put on a show! The architecture is beautiful inside and out! The view from the veranda outside is magnificent!

Most enjoyable. Beautiful display of art. Spacious, free admission every Saturday which makes the visit exceptional!! Interesting area; spend time not only touring the museum, but walking around the area.

Magnificent place to visit. This museum has so much to offer. The art pieces are chronically displayed fr. Medieval time to 20 century..very rich collections. You can easily spent 3-4 hours here. BTW, we had lunch at the museum restaurant, the food was excellent and price was very reasonable, not to mention the million dollars view fr our table. Also, the fountains are so beautiful, every angle is awesome for taking pictures. A must visit place in Barcelona.
Great. Just spend time here. It is well run and very informative .you are given head phones to tell you all you will need to know of what your looking at.

yes. you should go there -- or get a taxi depending on where you stay. I wasn t too much into the "old" masters of the 14 to 8 century. But I was absolute amazed by the "modern collection" -- worth every minute. Spend some time walking back towards the port area, either take the cable car across at the end of the terrace or turn left before getting to the cable car station and walk through the older parts of the port area -- very interesting "real Barcelona" street life.

Wonderful !. One of the best museums I have ever been to.Got there at 10 am,had the whole place to myself til 11:30. Staff engaging & will answer questions. The modern art is tops. Great statues. See everything,go to 2nd floor.

building and view are just gorgeous. Building is gorgeous and views are just magnificent. Art inside is nice but mostly forgettable. Well worth the trek up the mountain to see. Great pictures. Nearby funicular a must.

One of The Better Art Museums in Europe. Situated above the Magic Fountains this museum rivals the best in Paris. The building itself is a work of art and the contents are many of the great names in classic art. If you are in Barcelona this is one of the top place to see and be.
Well presented, with a range of exhibits. This museum is impressive to see from the outside, and once inside there are five major areas of exhibits, all well presented and spacious.

A it of a walk up there but worth it.. A must for history lovers. However, most people will enjoy the visit. Superb architecture, buildings and statues. From the outside totally gorgeous views of Barcelona. A great way to spend an afternoon.

Visit the Rooftop Terrace!. I don't need to restate what everyone else has written regarding the art museum itself. The art is beautiful, and the we easily could have spent another 1-2 hours (on top of the 3 hours we already stayed) looking at the different pieces in the gallery. The first gallery on the main floor was a bit redundant (while beautiful, most pieces depicted the same scenes). However, you ought to go here for no other reason than to visit the terrance. For just 2 euros, you have access to the terrace, with stunning views of Barcelona. There is a bar up top with beer, soda, and wine. My wife and I stayed here until nearly sunset on our last night in Spain and it was the perfect ending. This is a must in our opinion.

Catalunya's own Louvre. Either way you approach (down from Montjuic or up from Pl. Espanya) this museum is just jaw-dropping. Just the building itself and the surroundings worth a visit. Oh and the Magic Fountain... The exebitions are vast and one would need at least a week to comprehend it!
Auditorium is lovely. Pleasantly surprised by this place - the Dome ceiling is very impressive and the art also - nicely divided into 4 sections
Beautiful architecture and art. I could have spent a day here. There is a nice collection of regional art. It's a great destination on a rainy day.

beautiful outside and inside very interesting. a wonderful museum and if it is a rainy day you can easy spend a Whole day here because yes it is a lot to watch.beautiful building from outside and very much to watch inside.
be sure you have good time when you visit this museum
Amazing Romanesque frescoes!. A beautiful old structure renovated in a most interesting way by contemporary architect Gae Aulenti. Truly a world class, not to be missed Romanesque collection.
Amazing building. An amazing building and free admission excellent video on how wall paintings are transferred from the original location to the museum also great views onto plaza espanya

Absolutely amazing. You can get here by train (and then a 10 minute walk) or by a series of escalators (found out too late!) It is spectacular, for anyone from a country with a short history its mind blowing. Art works from centuries ago! You could easily just walk past the Picaso... Dont miss it. Take your own water etc with you or you'll pay a fortune. There is a resteraunt that we would have booked had we known, it must have stunning views over the city at night, or in fact during the day!
Great trip through Catalunya art history!. A fascinating look at history and religion through the art of the region. Some amazing installations of ancient chapel frescoes!

Fantastic. This was for me the best deal in Barcelona. SENIORS ARE FREE. Once in follow the sign to roof top terrace and restaurant. Even if the restaurant is closed follow the sign up to the terrace, quite a few stairs. When you get out you are at the top by the dome. The view is magnificent. There were only three of us up there. They have tiered seating with lounge cushions to lie on. Bring a snack and lie back and enjoy. The museum itself is also very enjoyable, not too big and lots of seats to take a rest if you want.

Best Art Museum. This is the best art museum I have ever been to. I was in Barcelona for two days and I came here in the early evening on both days. I spent hours here. The modern art was my favourite. Was amazed by the ancient art as well, many things are hundreds of years old I think! It's amazing to see. The entire building is magnificent, the staff are all really friendly and there are beautiful fountains outside. There are escalaters to help you get up the steps. We walked the long way round through the park from the other side which is a really cool walk if you are into that! We walked miles through the streets, following the signs and looking in local boutiques, and we walked up a steep hill and there were escalaters further up to help you get up the hill if you need a rest!! What a brilliant idea! Then we walked through the park to MNAC. What a lovely park as well, weird vandalism on a sign on entry to the park that said "Tourists go home! Tourists ruin the city", which wasn't very welcoming.

Cool Off and Enjoy. Mostly Romanesque panels and rescued early Christian frescos dominate this museum. These are a valid reason for a detour to this museum: and it is well laid out. Escalators take you up from the Plaza Espanya lower levels so do not be put off and also you will get to see the fountains and waterfalls.

Great place, great location.. If you are interested in art, you should definitely go there, as it's one of the best museums in Barcelona. If not, you should also go there, even if you don't go inside. The location is great, the building is beautiful and the views you get from outside are really nice.

Too much to see in one visit. We were at the museum for a good 2 hours plus, and didn't get out of the Gothic and Medieval areas. Fantastic art, from paintings to sculptures, mostly religious motifs in the area we saw. It's not a quick run-through; take your time and see your fill, and then come back again.
Special Musuem. The museum pieces are fabulous. We spent an entire afternoon here as it has so many things to see. The collection of art is as good as any we've seen throughout the world.

Modern art exhibit. We only viewed the modern art exhibit, which begins with the latter 19th century through contemporary periods. The exhibits focus on distinctively Catalan and Spanish art. It was very interesting to be able to compare these artists to the more familiar French and American artists of the same period with which we were more familiar, with the exception of Picasso and Miro.

Fine easy to maneuver museum. A gratifying selection of art from medieval to modern. All Catalan based but all impressive. Your ticket is good for 2 days so it's worth a visit spread out over a period of time.

A large art gallery/museum with mainly Catalan works of art. This is a massive building atop a hill and it can be seen from afar if you are staying in a high rise hotel. It is below Montjuic Castle and Placa Espana. Just in front of it is rage Magic Fountain that operates on weekends at night and is apparently quite a sight. When we were there it did not operate and 1 night it rained so we did not see the fountain. The large building is on a hill and thankfully there are escalators that take you almost, but not wholly, to the top. It was built in early 20th century. The museum has a massive dome and looks a bit like St Pauls Cathedral in London. In different. The museum has a large collection of murals and religious paintings from Catalan and Pyrenese churches. There are a series of Romanesque paintings from 11th to 13th century. There is also a collection of panel paintings. There are also wooden and stone sculptures mostly of religious tinge. There are also collections of Gothic art from the Catalan provinces from 12th to15th centuries and well preserved. There are also paintings from the Renaissance and Baroque periods. There are paintings by El Greco, Tintoretto , valazquez, Titian, Tiepolo, Rubens, Cranach and Goya. There are a few Modern paintings including those of Picasso. Of course there are numerous Catalan artists not known outside of the area but there is a large collection of modern Catalan art. Overall it may not be Prado, Louvre or the National Gallery but this art gallery is well worth a visit.

great!. This luxurious museum has several permanent exibitions covering period from Roman to modern times. There is really a lot to see, and you must plan at least 3 hours to run through. If you want to see all, plan to spend whole day. And it has a great view of Barcelona

Very pleasant Museu!. This Museu has a very interesting collection of Catalunya art. It is ,however located up a lot of steps with only a couple of escalators to help reaching the entrance. There is a street near by that taxis use which will get you really close too the front door. It is worth the effort.

More like a place than a museum. We stopped off on the hop on hop off bus tour to take a better look at this as it looked so impressive. Don't be put off by the number of steps, there are escalators up most of the way.The views across the city are stunning, and it is worth visiting for that alone.Inside there is a fantastic collection of art works and artefacts. Well worth a visit.

Wonderful gallery. We did this on our last morning. It's an excellent gallery, well laid out and fascinating. It shows the development of art from medieval to modern and has some beautiful pieces. I wish I'd had all day . The setting of the gallery is fabulous too. Don't miss this as we nearly did. It was free too!!

Roof terrace €2 views are outstanding . If you are not into museums like us you must still visit here and pay €2 to go to the roof terrace. (There is a small sign on the main desk regarding this)The building itself is impressive but the views from the top are incredible. There is also a seating area so you can relax and soak in the sights. When we went up it seemed to be very quiet.

Unexpectedly fine collection. Didn't expect such a wonderful collection in Barcelona. The building is worth a visit itself. Large collection of religious icons. Recreations of architecture from where mosaics were taken. Includes photos and films of Franco oppression of Catalunya.
Wonderful Museum. Location, location, location. Add to that an impressive building and some lovely works of art and you have the makings of a wonderful day out in Barcelona.

Magnificent MNAC. Siting high above the city captures a number of points. The view is amazing, especially from the restaurant upstairs. The works of art are great and the adventure getting there by bus or walking up or down adds to the whole experience

Very impressive. We spend a couple of hours in this wonderful museum, but could have stayed longer if we would have had more time that day.With the Barcelona Card, entrance is free in this museum.The collection ranges from roman and gothic medieval art to art nouveau and so much more. Perfect for a rainy afternoon

A surprise hit. An amazing collection of art from very early frescoes that have been carefully preserved and moved from outlying churches, a gorgeous Fra Angelico, some really interesting civil war posters, and furniture designed by Gaudi. The space itself is beautiful. Save some time to savor this unique collection.

Atmosphere!. What I definitely like in a places that some of them make you feel so nice and calm.That one on Placa España became like this for me.The green parks, fountains, museum an Spanish Village.You can spent there all day enjoying the view and fresh air!

Gorgeous Building; Fascinating Exhibits. The building and surrounding grounds are, in my view, the most breathtaking in Barcelona. The museum is relatively inexpensive for the art on display, and great attention has been put towards curatorship. The Renaissance galleries are sublime, although the Romanesque Medieval section is limited by mostly incomplete works of art.

Majestic view not to missed from the entrance of the museum. You'll have to take the metro to this place via Parrallel station then there'll be one train specially serving you to Parc de Montjuic station.Upon alighing Parc de Montjuic, we had a very nice walk along the park. Its a high side of Barcelona so you'll be treated to the beautiful view of the city as you walk towards Museu Nacional.Its just "wow" after "wow" when we arrived the museu.. Breathtaking views, majestic structures, beautiful fountains. Great place for phototaking for sure.

Great place to visit!. It may not have the "most important" works of art such as Uffizzi but it is really well prepared and interesting museum with many awesome things to see. Free entrance on Saturdays after 3 pm. No crowds so you can enjoy the exhibitions in peace.Plus the building itself is great.

Art lovers, don't miss this!. The national museum of Catalonia shows already in is name a form of Independence of Spain...The Museu Nacional d’Art de Catalunya is located in a place, constructed for the international exposition of 1929. However, it opened his doors only in 1934 with a Medieval collection. A renewal and opening of the news rooms of Ramanesque art started in 1995 as the Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya,. The renewal ended in 2004 with the integration of modern art. The Mural Paintings, art of Gaudi, Casas, Gothic Art and great European Renaissance and Baroque painters are a must see! Tiziano, Velàzquez, photography are complements of the exhibition.The major strength, quality and versatility of the collection allows you to have a 360º experience: Before, during and after your visit.Of course and not the least, there are always complementary collections. As you notice, Barcelona is not only a weekendtrip, you can always come back and discover more...

Amazing building. Walked in off the street and was amazed at the architecture inside. Didn't see any art/paintings as we were encouraged just to walk in -didn't pay - I suspect to see the galleries payment is required. Worth a visit if passing.

The Structure itself is a work of art. We did not get a chance to see all the art inside but the design and decor of the building is majestic. Just walk up to it and you will feel as though you are witnessing a something more than just a museum.
Awesome . Such an underrated place that is a top must when visiting BCN. The museum is divided into four parts which covers genres from Gothic to Modern.

HIdden Treasures. Not to miss are the dozens of Romanesque wall paintings rescued from remote churches in the Catalan Pyrenees, preserved, and remounted in the precise format of their original space. Rich colors, imaginative, cartoon-like representations of evil suffered by martyrs, or warnings of the punishment awaiting those who stray. Probably the finest collection anywhere in the world. Will be a revelation to those unfamiliar with this period and locale of Christian art. Not to be missed by art historians. Allow at least 30-45 minutes to fully appreciate them.. Be selective about the rest of the museum, but don't miss the huge auditorium next to the gift shop.

Don't Miss the Wall Frescos. Friends in the art world recommended seeing the Wall Frescos and they were right. It's easy to make a surgical visit in to see them - they are off to the left as you enter. But don't hurry past the Madonna and Childs lining the hall as you leave the exhibit. They are stunning.

The only nice thing is the building itself. If you are into religious or modern art, this place might be of interest to you. As we aren't in either, we found our visit to be very long, despite spending much less time (1:45) than expected.The building itself is spectacular though... from the ceilings, the wideness of the structure, the amphitheater and the domes.All of these areas are part of the common areas and can e visited for free... so we would recommend sticking to this and spend your time elsewhere in Barcelona.

Marvellous Museum. This is a beautiful building with some amazing art and great exhibitions. We went on a Saturday afternoon after 3.00pm which turned out to be free which was an added bonus (all other times there appears to be an entry cost).We spent a good couple of hours meandering around looking at the architecture, exhibitions and views from the museum in equal measure. It wasn't too busy and was actually quite peaceful and relaxing and very enjoyable.The central hall which they use for concerts has the most amazing and huge organ which is definitely worth a look.I really enjoyed this place and would recommend it.

Once of the best Museums in Barcelona. This was the old King's Palace before being changed into a museum. The collection includes all things Catalan from paintings to furniture. The views from the steps once you reach the front doors is accross the whole of Barcelona. Visit the great hall as it is impressive. Entry is feee for anyone over 65 (you may have to prove this but normally anyone over 65 looks accordingly). They are very friendkly and helpful. Also there is at least one day a month when it is free to everyone. This maybe later in the afternoon or on a Sunday so check before going and save yourselves a few pennies.Tip: If you have walked up the main steps to reach the museum descend by leaving the main entrance and turn to your right and godown that way as it follows a nice Moorish cascade through a few fountains.

Impressive and gracious building. The day we visited happened to be national museums day so entry was free. It is a truly magnificent building. Be prepared because there are an awful lot of stairs to walk up to get to the entrance. There are escalators which help along the way. I assume there must be elevators somewhere. The collections are well-organized so you can easily decide where you want to focus your time. I think that some more translations could have been useful but I was able to get the gist with my minimal Spanish.
The views!. I didn't go inside but the view at the top of the stairs is absolutely phenomenal. Definitely worth the stair climb! Can't comment on the inside.

Great range of art. Housed in a stunning building with great views out over fountains and Placa de Espanyol. The collection is arranged by centuries while most of the information signs are only in Spanish you can guess what most of the titles of the paintings are. There are cafes outside the front door on the terrace or in the huge auditorium in the centre of the museum.The really good news is that there are escalators to bring you up the hill to the door of the museum.

WONDERFUL WORKS OF ART. We went here on a rainy day and the hike up to the top in the rain was slow going but when we finally reached the top I felt like "Rocky". The museum is first rate with many styles to suite any art lover. The collections were very colorful & family friendly. They had many children enjoying the museum on the day we were there.

rooftop surprise. This is a lovely museum with some great pieces. Would be good if they also included some english & other languages on each piece displayed. By accident we discovered you could go up to the roof top. The view up there is fantastic and you can enjoy it with a beer or a champayne.

This museum is a work of art!. The national art museum of Barcelona is worth a visit! First of all, it is a beautiful facility located in a beautiful and scenic area with amazing views of Barcelona wherever you turn. The artwork contained within its historic walls is nothing short of amazing and the access you have to the invaluable pieces is unprecedented. If you are visiting Barcelona, put it on your "to do" list!

best place to get a free view of the city.. Got off the hop off at the lower end of the fountains and walked to the top. There are moving stairs to help with the climb. from the top there is a great view of the city. You can board the hop on from the back side of the porperty

Cool, calm culture. I enjoyed this gallery much more than I expected to. It was astonishingly unbusy and everything is laid out with plenty of space. I only really looked at the Renaissance/Baroque and Modern/Contemporary sections. Context and interpretation is minimal, but I enjoy looking things up later. Memorable, sad photos from the civil war - I would have liked a closer look at the face of the mourner at Lleida, but photo too high up for me to see. With a bored teenager in tow, the roof terrace was a big hit. (I also enjoyed a glass of Cordonui Cava €4 while sitting looking at the city). Oh, I had a small moment of panic when I couldn't unlock the door of the loo off room III/25!

Simply beautiful. We went to Barcelona for a 4 day trip which is definitely not long enough as there is so much to see. We took the bus tour which takes two different routes around the city and decided to hop off here. Not knowing that there was man made waterfalls, fountains and other attractions. The waterfalls and fountains are amazing. So happy we got off and saw this beautiful attraction.

Go even if it's for the view. Wonderful exhibition, most beautiful building and amazing view of the city. Like anywhere in the world, watch your bags. We witnessed a bag snatch but the undercover security and police were there to quickly resolve the issue, recover the bag and load the perpetrator into a police van. Well done to them but onus on us to be more vigilant as travelers.
Beautiful view. the building and the view is amazing.. very centrally located. great view of the city..the museum was also interesting..

stunning!. Such a stunning building from the outside with all the water fountains and inside. They had some really neat exhibitions going on though we didn't see any. The access to the building is free so you can see the inside of it which is pretty neat itself even if you don't check out the exhibitions.

Rainy day. We decided to visit this museum, because the weather was not nice.
They gave us discount since our children are 8 and 9. And except coins exhibition nothing was interesting for them.
Building is amazing and the view.

Gorgeous building, interesting collection...awful staff. This would be getting a 5 star rating from me if it wasn't for the awful experience in the cafe and the bathrooms.Firstly, the building itself it gorgeous as is the setting, even if you're not an art fan it's worth visiting the building for the views from the high vantage point over Barcelona and the beautiful architecture. The modern art collection is good, a lot of lesser known Catalan artists but any art lover will enjoy a wander around this gallery. It was free entry on Saturday afternoon after 3pm so we didn't have to pay.However, we stopped at the central cafe in the middle of the museum to grab a coffee and a cake - on top of being exorbitantly priced the rude staff member sneezed into her hand and proceeded to handle my food and coffee right in front of me. When I asked her to change them I was sneered at and told it's just allergies - quite frankly if I hadn't been seriously depleted of caffeine at that point I'd have told her to stick her coffee. The bathrooms resembled something I would expect to see at a dodgy venue at 4am - most of the toilets were backed up and flooding all over the floor, absolutely disgusting and certainly not what you would expect to see at a museum in the afternoon. Such a pity these incidents spoiled an otherwise lovely experience.
Majestic looking. Very centrally located and gives you a great view of the city below. The museum was also interesting with good displays.

A great place to learn of Spanish art, especially, the Catalan sons. My wife and I spent a greater part of a day traipsing from room to room to enjoy the works from the men from Catalan. Many visitors, including us, got to enjoy a cup of coffee in front of the entrance, enjoyed the expansive view looking across to the beautiful mountains from afar, drawing our sights nearer to the busy ring of traffic at Placa de Catalunya, or the changing street performers down the steps. It was a great day with a perfect weather in May.

Unfortunately disappointed. I was actually quite excited in coming here on the Night of the Museums, a unique night when one is delighted with the free admission and the extended museum opening hours (until 1 a.m.). If you're walking then it's a quite the walk (and a steep one) from the closest subway at Plaza Espana to the actual museum. The views of Barcelona are splendid though. I expected a lot more than I saw. There is an emphasis on lesser known Catalan artists that is noteworthy but a distinct lack of better known artists such as Miro and Dali (although Miro has one large mural and he has his own foundation/museum). As for me, I saw no Dali and only one Picasso.
amazing. .. this worth a visit too. its overlooking Barcelona when you are on the top.the building itself is marvelous, the museum is beautiful inside, well lit and inviting.

More about the building and view than art. This place has a bit of an identity crisis as it's the one of the most photographed buildings in Barcelona, it's lights shine across the city every night, and yet not many people venture inside. We did go inside and straight up to the roof which offers more spectacular views and a Moët lounge which....just has Moët cushions to sit on. No champagne...in fact no bar at all. Seems like a missed opportunity as you could chill there between different exhibits. And they could be making a fortune selling drinks!As for the exhibits we only did the medieval sections and they are clearly directed at locals, not tourists. Nothing labelled in anything else but Spanish and when we purchased our ticket they didn't warn us or offer us an audio guide (you really need one if you don't speak Spanish!). One room was mainly religious sculptures from wood - the other was paintings taken from real churches and transported to the museum for preservation (seems sad they are all there out of their homes). We didn't do the modern section. For only 12 euro it's well worth going inside, having something to eat, spend an hour on the roof (it's quite big), maybe do one or two exhibits then be on your way. There is also a pretty fab theatre in the building so if something is on, that would also be a good way to see the space.

mediaeval frescoes to make the trip for. Late 19th century and early 20th century art - including Gaudi furniture - all lovely.Earlier art also worth seeing, but...the frescoes rescued from Pyrenean village churches are a marvel. Displayed on re-constructed models of the church interiors they are FABULOUS.

It's all about the terrace!. After three weeks in Europe, it's hard to get overwhelmed about another museum or church, no matter how spectacular or different from the Super Walmart at home. The point of this museum which is quite compelling on it's own by the way, is the mind bending view from the terrace on the roof. Ignore the over priced champagne and just sit and enjoy the memory for a lifetime tableau in front of you. It really doesn't get any better than this!

Excellent views and building. Accessed by tourist bus. Highlight is the view. Building is awe-inspiring. Very interesting exhibits and excellent facilities eg cafes, toilets, lockers, posh restaurant.

Must see for art lovers. I really don't know why more people don't visit this museum. It is not as busy as the other places in Barcelona such as the sagrada familia or Casa batllo. However, the views from the museum are wonderful especially when the waterfall and fountain is on. The art inside the museum is really interesting. Renaissance, art nouveau, Romanesque etc are all displayed in separate sections .As always, with most places in Barcelona, arrive early.

Heavy on medieval art. I've been here three times now and have seen different exhibits. It's a wonderful space both inside as well as outside. It has a large collection of incredible medieval paintings and sculptures. There is much more to see than that period alone. Very recommended if you are a lover of art history.

Fantastic place to visit. This is a great place to visit, lovely fountains but you need to time it right to see them as they are only on for so long each day. From here you can visit Espanya square.Stunning views across the city from the museum, definitely worth a visit

Well worth a visit. This is a fascinating example of Gaudi's early architecture. It is a family house, most of which is open to visitors. There is a free audio-guide which provides essential background (there are no notices in rooms). We were lucky enough to hear the organ playing. The roof terrace provides interesting views of the city and shows features more usually associated with Gaudi than some of those in the house.

Wonderful City View. Great exhibition of Catalan culture and history -- many varied works of art through the generations was worth the visit for sure. Pleasant place to spend if a rainy day. Fountains are very beautiful as is Barcelona from here.

Beautiful Building Inside and Out!. This building is visible for miles depending on where you are, The approach to the building is spectacular - street lined with water fountains capped at the far end by a large statue and fountain. Looking towards the building you see a waterfall in front of the building flanked by staircases leading to the courtyard of the museum.There is a fee to see the art exhibits but the grounds and public areas inside are free. If you are not into the art works, the building, grounds and all the area leading up to it are a must see. Inside the building the structure is equally impressive. This is a must see place!

Wonderful View of the City on the Roof. Their art collection is not that great. They don’t have any super famous or well known pieces of art housed here. BUT it was still worth every penny to go to the roof and see the beautiful view of Barcelona. If it wasn’t for the rain, I would have stayed up there way longer. The actual museum building itself is also worth seeing and grabbing a photo of. When the fountain and waterfalls are turned on, it’s one of the most impressive buildings I have ever seen.

good place great view. very nice museum with original mural 11-12 century from catalonia churches . very good view downstairs on barcelona and musical fountain . very simple to come with hop-on-hop bus-special stop. the only thing that should be translation in english or you have to take guide!

A revelation. An amazing collection that is worth a day to explore. I did not have time to see the modern collection, but will be back to do so. If, like me, you knew nothing about Catalan art this will be a revelation.

Awesomeness . Beautiful fountains, amazing architecture and sculptures are the kind of things that you will see when you are approaching to this place. Once at the entrance, prepare to be amazed, the regular exposition is quite cool, good place to spend a day surrounded by art

Art and Architecture in a Magnificent Combination . Approaching through beautiful fountains, this museum is amazing. The building itself is bold and expansive. Art is displayed is several galleries against the intense colors of Spain. Be sure to visit the roof for glorious views of the city.
quick visit to the museum. Visited the museum after getting down from monjuic. Free entry after 15:00 on Saturday. Beautiful both inside and outside.

Good to visit on a rainy day, if you like a historic view on Catalan art. We visited this by accident as the weather was very bad with a lot of rain. The museum was a surprise and is good to visit if you want to see how the Catalan art evolved from the medievel to today. Maybe not the most renowned art work but it gives a beautiful view on what they have done over timeNote eat before you visit the museum. The food is not good and there are long waiting lines

Amazing-my favorite museum in Barcelona. Take your time for exploring the ground floor, there are artworks from romanesque, gothic and renaissance periods. There are paintings of old masters such as El Greco, Rubens, Tiziano, and many others. (Also there was a statue of Rodin.) First floor is dedicated to modern art, there are furnitures and nostalgic advertisement posters as well as photos and paintings. The museum has an amazing view, since it is located above a hill.

Great Way to Spend an Afternoon. Have to love this place. It is much less popular than Sagrada Familia or the Picasso museum. No fighting crowds. The museum itself is extremely well done and the café is a nice touch. The art is extraordinary and voluminous. Lots of pieces from 19th century Spanish painters. I understand the medieval artwork is among the best. The setting of the museum on a hill overlooking the city was the icing on a great cake.

A beautiful building. While there is lots of beautiful art inside the building itself is a week of art to be enjoyed from several angles. Be prepared to walk a lot of stairs. In fact I call Barcelona the city of stairs.

Peaceful views. There were too many people in many of the other attractions In Barcelona but this place was an oasis of peace. We ate lunch on the terrace outside and watched the world go by. We got there via the open top tour bus which was worth the money to get around the city. The museum had interesting art works, look out for El Greco ...amazing!!
Impressive building, mediocre art. This was included in a six museum ticket we purchased. The building was fascinating. The artwork wasn't. We spent less than an hour and that was plenty.

Beautiful setting for some amazing art. The MNAC is an incredible building. Walking up from Placa Espanya, the museum is the culmination of an impressive set of waterfalls and vistas. Inside the building, the main hall and rotunda are both works of art in the own right. The collection is also very good. Highlights included the Romanesque collection, modernisme furniture, and the El Grecos. I thought the modern paintings left something to be desired but overall the collection was stellar.
Great view of Barcelona!. We did not enter inside the museum, we only came for the views of the city. But it was so worth it. Great location and view :)

Look out not in!. This building does not disappoint, and frankly outshines the second rate contents of the museum. Apart from some interesting Gaudi furniture, and surrealist photographs, the collections could be comfortably overlooked. But go to the inside to see its spectacular staircases and columns and the central hall. This space acts as concert auditorium and has a most wonderful ceiling. The restaurant has the most gorgeous outlook with panoramic views of the city through large pictures windows where you can see the Tribidado on a clear day. You can also take the lift to the roof terrace and see the same view for free.
if you want to change of Gaudy. modern museum. A very important collection of frescoes of the middle age at the ground floor. the roof offers a beautiful view on Barcelona

Very beautiful location. What a great location - I would highly recommend adding this to your tour book. Just know that there are a lot of steps to this site if you are coming from the fountain. Bring your good waking shoes.

Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya. This was breath taking beautiful. We did not go inside because there was so much to do on the outside. The pics I got from this view of the city of Barcelona are in trigging. So much to see and this is a MUST see ....

Not to be missed!. This museum should be one of the key stops for a visit to Barcelona. First of all, because of the location, in Montjuic, overlooking the city and the port, in an area filled with parks, museums, and delightful sightseeing.The museum claims to have the best collection of Romanesque frescoes in Europe, and I would recommend starting there, as you enter up the stairs and to the left. You can then decide what else to see, because there is a lot and quite impressive, no matter the period you are interested in. This is quite an enjoyable visit, and quite close to other must-see attractions like the Miro Foundation or the Ethnological Museum, the Poble Espanyol or the Monjuic castle. Take your time, enjoy the Montjuic area during the day and at night try to catch the Magic Fountain show or visit one of its theaters and Cava/tapas places.

Beautiful art and building. Breathtaking building, inside and out. The gallery features some fantastic pieces by many important artists. I particularly enjoyed the collection of Art Nouveau lithographs. I would recommend three hours spent here at least to view the collection.

An unexpected treat. We wandered into this gallery on our last day in Barcelona as we saw they had a modern art collection on the 1st floor. The exhibits were wonderful, ranging from sculpture and furniture to photographs. It was the photos that I found to be the most moving. Many from the early 20th century and a whole room devoted to the Spanish Civil War. The building and setting are superb. Set atop the Parc de Montjuic overlooking the majestic fountains this museum is at the centre of so many great sites. Entry is free to those over 65, remember to carry proof of your age.
Great view to Bacelona city center. Fun to walk up all the stairs and experiece the view. Would go there again and have a drink in front of the museum.

Beautiful! . Absolutely beautiful building although we did not go inside it! It particularly looks spectacular as a back drop to the magic fountains in the evenings! There are lots of steps up to it but well worth the view when you get to the top! It's set in a lovely area of Barcelona!

Free on Saturdays after 3!. Arrived around 5pm after a walk down from the castle and past the stadium. Wanted to catch the magic fountain so it made sense to spend a few free hours in the gallery. It was all amazing!

This is a great place for photos without having to go in. We did not go into the museum--I'll be honest. But this is a great place to take pictures--from the bottom as well as from the top in front of the entrance.We arrived late morning at the fountains weren't working. We came back in the afternoon and they were working! We're guessing that they only operate the fountains in the afternoon, but we are not sure.Since you're here, you can also visit the Estadi Olimpic de Montjuic, Palau Sant Jordi, and the Torre Comunicacion. Don't underestimate these places because there are some amazing vast spaces you will see here.

Wonderful Visit. My company held a private dinner at this facility and it was magical. The inside is something to see but the view looking down back over the city at night is what makes it worth the drive to the top of the mountain.

It's a Must. I would say what I love about this museum is that it's both an attraction in and of itself. I would say a good majority of people are just admiring the endless steps up the mountain and the actual building itself. I was a bit afraid that going inside it would be crowded because it was Saturday. There were a lot of people but it wasn't overwhelming.Personally my favorite part of this was the 2nd half of the modern art section. You get a step by step explanation of art movements from Guadi to almost present day. It specifically looks at these movements through a Catalan lens. You not only get to see how Catalunya fit into Spanish culture but also the world. There are really amazing rooms that give a clear explanation of how Catalunya's art world reacted to the rise of Franco, fascism, the actual civil war itself, and the aftermath. For me this was the most interesting part. It is simply a must.

If you enjoy the history of Art then this is a must see. This art museum is exceptionally well curated, you are led through the history of Catalan art from the tenth century to the present day in an informative yet friendly manner with information for the novice as well as the student

Fist day in Barcelona. Raining and cool, but a beautiful building and the waterfall is peaceful and serene. Even though it was over cast was able to capture some great pictures of the city below. Highly recommended.
Must see. Museum is set above Barcelona where a great view and picture opportunity. Has a nice gift shop and a small eatery where you can get a bite outside.
Nice view. Other than the building's imposing site in the heart of the city, I was not particularly impressed by the exhibits. There are other places far more interesting to visit.

Interesting, comprehensive and impressive. Palatial museums can often be overwhelming especially after visiting another museum (nearby Miro), but there are good displays of art and treasures, while the architecture is amazing. Also it was nice lunching(over priced) on the entrance veranda while being serenaded by monotonous buskers.

Amazing view from the roof and beautiful art. The building itself is beautiful, you can see it from the Placa Espana beyond the magic fountain. It also has it's own pretty fountain and grand steps to the entrance. The museum houses some Dali, Picasso amongst others. The grand hall is beautiful and open free to the members of the public. You can also get a lift to the roof for a spectacular vista of Barcelona.
Beautiful. We didnt actually have time to go into the inside which i terribly regret but the outside of it is absolutely stunning by day and night. In of the prettiest buildings I have ever seen!!
Best Romanesque Museum EVER. This museum is free to the over 65s! We spent hours in here over two separate days marvelling at the exhibits Snack bar was good value too.

Impressive Art Collection. We went there on a grey day and stayed for about 4 hours. The museum exhibits paintings from different eras, on the ground floor you find Romanesque (mainly mural paintings) and Gothic art, whereas the first floor is dedicated to Modern Art, including: neoclassical, realist, romantic art. There is also a section about Modernisme and Noucentiste. The museum is very big and it's impossible to take in everything on one day. If you buy a regular ticket (12€) you can come back within a month. If you have enough time, you could get an audioguide, since most written explanation is only provided in Spanish and Catalan (especially on the ground floor). With the ticket you also get access to the roof terrace which provides you with excellent views of Barcelona.
Incredible building and collection. We went on Sat. late afternoon--free admission. Good look at the religious art of the early Catalan area.

Great museum!. Do yourself a favor and take a cab. They're cheap. Then go on the day it's open for free (check the website, but it's saturday after 3pm) Great musuem with plenty to see. You may even spot a Picasso or Dali
Must see!. I love art and this place is very good!Roman,Gothic,Modern what ever you want you can find here! Saturday afternoon free!
Amazing place. For those who are interested in art. Many works of art contained in the beautiful interiors.Beautiful view from the roof

Great fountains. If you start out at the Arena walk up to the museum . You'll pass some great fountains and when you get to the top good views of Barcelona . Carry on past the museum and the oldMy pic village and Olympic stadium are just behind . Carry on up the hill and you come upon the Botanical gardens which are well worth a look . On exiting the gardens carry on up to Monjuc park go in the castle and get the most amazing views of Barcelona . Take the cable car down and go for a beer or an ice cream it's a helluva walk but worth ever minute

First rate art gallery. Sitting atop a hill overlooking a big part of the city is this art gallery. Nice gardens, large interior space, lively view of the city. Entry fee is reasonable. Lots of medieval and Renaissance work downstairs including many restored frescoes from monasteries etc. Comparatively small collection of the baroque period but a decent modern era collection upstairs. It's a little hike from the main plaza below but it's worth it. Would also recommend checking out nearby gardens.

Gorgeous Museum . At Museu Nacional visitors takes on an uninterrupted journey through a thousand years of Catalan art, from the 10th to the 20th centuries through its four permanent collections of Romanisque and Gothic art, Renaissance and Baroque art, Modern art, photography, drawings, prints and posters.

Spanish art.. Worth the visit, and free (though you do have to obtain a ticket!)
Whilst very large, over 2 floors, there is a lift. Very interesting and the views are spectacular.

Massive. This place is absolutely crazy. The parks around it are massive and the walk is well worth it. Its massive in size so I reckon you could spend the better part of a day there and at a slower pace.
Majestic. A truly majestic place, almost breath taking. Wonderfully kept gardens, and a great site to see whilst in Barcelona. Would certainly recommend it.

Awesome. Outstanding works of Art to be seen here.There were four main sections in this Museum that we covered.One was Renaissance, Modern Art one and two and Romantic.A huge place to go to with comfy armchairs when tired of traipsing.Lots of varieties of superb local and international artists. Worth a visit by any means.Some of the colourful pictures were a joy to look at.Great roof terrace that sits atop of the building with outstanding views of the fountain and Plaza de Espana.Also has a restaurant and a vast chamber that looks a bit like the Albert Hall.They had a misery gallery as well? Dark and shady figures depicted?Free entry to EU people I think the receptionist told us. (Maybe we looked like EU pensioners)!

Great Medieval and Modernista Art. Went to the museum to see the Medieval and Modernista sections and the exhibits were amazing. The museum was well presented and most things were explained in English. Spent a few hours there and would go back to check out the modern art sections that I didn't have time to see this time.

Nice place , marvellous paintings, great sculptures in the hallway. Good architecture of the building, I enjoyed the paintings (less the contemporary ones, but that is personal taste) , couldn't finish visiting it because it closes at 18h. So be careful about that ... :)

Beautiful building. The art is interesting and there's a lot of explanations to give context to the displays. However the real treasure is the building itself. So very beautiful. View from the hill is also amazing.
The museum uphill. You you are around Placa de Spagna take a chance to walk uphill and see this magnificent museum. Easy to reach with the bus 150 and the hop on hop off tour buses.
Just nipped in. Great building, only saw a part of exhibitions but loved the building and its interior! Great shop with art prints and many other lovely things.
Wonderful night. All saturdays you have the spectacle with water and lights full of music! It's a must when you go to Barcelona. Pictures dont show what you really see in that place!

Exquisite museum in a gorgeous setting.. Museu Nactional housed a spectacular collection of religious art. It would have been 5-star except it was too heavy in only this direction. In spite of that, the visit was exceptional.

Fabulous building. One of Gaudi's early commissions, this very unusual mansion is quite stunning in its creative design for a wealthy industrialist with ten children. Allow at least one hour to appreciate it.

Great Art Museum!. We were so impressed with the variety of wonderful art here. Had planned to spend two hours but didn't want to leave. We left after four hours only because our feet were giving out. You'll see Medieval-Gothic Art, Renaissance and Baroque Art, Modern and Contemporary Art. We don't normally gravitate towards modern art, but liked what we saw here. Each piece is marked with the artist, name of the piece, and date. Don't miss the Cambo Bequest and the Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection. Cafe is expensive - 3.50 euros for one can of Coke. You can bring in water, but only drink it when you aren't in a gallery. We took a taxi to the entry level from the center area of La Rambla for 8.60 euros and had a short walk to the entrance, but plenty of other public transportation options. Not overly crowded on a weekday. Incredible views of Barcelona! Free for 65 and older with birthdate ID.

Stunning views. Even if you just visit to see the views up to the museum from the bottom of the hill, and from the museum looking back down and over the city, it is well worth the visit. However, it is definitely worth seeing the Romanesque frescoes exhibition as the many 12th century works are simply incredible. As we sat on the steps at the top, enjoying the gorgeous city views and the warm Catalan sunshine, a brilliant guitarist (Gaby Sellanes) played Rodrigo's Concerto d'Aranjuez – it was a truly perfect moment, and we bought his CD just for the memory of it!

Loved this place.. Don't you dare skip visiting this place. The Museum is just incredible. Once you finish with the tour, go for a walk to the museum's park. Stay to enjoy the fountain show, which, if I'm not mistaken, happens every hour. It is worth your time.

Best Romanesque art, Spanish Civil War era art, amazing other collections. Planned to spend 1/2 day or bit more here but ended up spending 2 days in awe of the various collections in this museum. Romanesque is outstanding--whether you're religious or not. Gothic too. Of the moderns, we most appreciated the Spanish Civil War section since it's hard to find these artists or anything focused on the Civil War anywhere (but you need some energy when you get there, not good if tired). Cafe has some good items but very overpriced. Restaurant looked good but their timing & availability didn't work for when we needed to rest. If you're over 65, you can go for free so you might not want to buy tickets ahead.

Stunning Building and Grounds. The building itself is a commanding presence in the area, looking down a long boulevard that also has the Magic Fountain on it. The collection of Modern pieces that were on display were varied and interesting. The gallery is well designed and will keep you interested for an few hours or more.It's a great place to go and watch the sunset or just bask in the views out over Barcelona from in front of the museum.Strongly recommended.

Ocean Fantasy in downtown TO. This is a place for both adults and children. Worth the price. Just go. There are more fish than you can imagine including sharks and jellyfish without a brain (just like some humans actually). The artificial habitats are beautiful.

Beautiful building.. We didn't go in the museum but instead walked around the building and the area. Even if you don't go in, its a great place to walk around, take photos and spend a couple of hours people watching.

MNAC was our favorite Barcelona activity.. The building in itself is an incredible work of art. You will slowly climb the stairs from below, with the view getting better and better, until you reach the front doors of the museum. You can go up to a rooftop terrace, but I don't personally find the views of the city by day to be as aesthetically pleasing as the views of the buildings in the neighborhoods. The Romanesque art collection from the 11th to 15th centuries is arranged in order by dates and it absolutely blew me away. The artists in those times seemed fascinated with torture. I am not well educated in the arts, but by the time I left this museum, I had a hunger for more knowledge (and I am a grandmother)

Beautiful museum !. I spent three hours at this lovely museum which has amazing architecture. Its well laid out and everything is labelled ( sadly sometimes only in Spanish and Catalan ). They have several types of art and therefore would be a delight for all art lovers.

Interesting albeit limited. This very impressive building houses an eclectic, but not very extensive, collection of modern art, mostly by Catalan artists (fair enough). There are some fine works – depending on one's individual taste, obviously. It offers an opportunity to discover a new artist or two of interest. In my case, for example, Ponç (see photo).There was also an informative exhibition over 20+ rooms of the influences which led up to and helped shape Modern Art, inc nice posters and furnishings. Though 'Modern Art' here seems to extend only as far as 1930-40s, no Warhol or Lichtenstein.
Don't go on a Monday - it's close on Monday. outside is very nice, nice place to just sit and take in the sites.We went on a Monday and it was closed :(
Beautiful place to see. Loved the view from up there. You should go there by day and night as you'll see the dancing fountain by night
On the Most Beautiful Places in Barcelona. On the Most Beautiful Places in Barcelona - in the heart of the beautiful and magnificent Montjuic Hill.
Very nice!. Very nice put in place museum with both traditional and contemporary paintings.Not so big, you can visit it in a couple of hours.If you want more details, the audio guide is recommended.

A definite gem. On a rainy morning, we went to visit the former Palace and now the National Museum. It wasn't crowded so we definitely enjoyed the quiet timeThere is a great collection of the Modern Art that is displayed in this vast building. After about an hour we walked the grounds of this spectacular building , thoroughly amazed at the spectacular and grand waterfalls and fountain, We continued down the stairs to the site of the Olympic stadium and were within a 20 minute walk to Tickets for an incredible Tapas lunch.

I just fall in love here !. I visited in december. The museum have medieval Romanesque Art abou 16 rooms, i have seen a lot of medieval art in Italy so I did not spend much time here. But if you haven't seen this kind of art this is a great place to have a taste of it. I really loved the medieval gothic art areas, i do love renaissance and baroque arts so I really enjoyed the rooms 32,33,34. I liked the Combo Bequest and Thyssen Bornemisza collection. On Sunday or Saturday the museum is free which was GREAT!. They have free wi-fi and a elevator that goes on the roof. There is a nice walk on the roof and the view is stunning, I do advice you see it during sunset.From the top you can see the small arena where around 17.30-18.00 is starting a free dance-theater performance. It is kind of PIna Bausch but i believe it is even better, you can enjoy the performance on the auditorium area. And I really did love it. Ones the Museum closes you can sit outside and listen the fontains rumor. An hour after the museum close there is a Majestic Fountain, fontain and musick and light performance from the top of the museum. This place will really make you fall in love with Barcelona, with the beauty, the theater, the art and the water and muck....It does make you fell grateful and full with love!

Breathtaking. The fountains and Museum together are a site you have to see! I couldn't take enough photos of the beauty!! My friend and I actually accidentally stumbled upon this place coming from Mont Juic and are so happy we did. You have to check it out and best part.. ITS FREE besides going in, which we didn't!

Worth a visit.... Thoroughly enjoyed the museum and fountains at night. The interior has amazing artwork, however the lack of English translations on the notes made it a bit difficult for us to fully enjoy. Definitely worth a visit.
place of interest. amazing place on top of the hill,beautiful architecture and worth the visit to the museum.has good view of the city form the top

Overwhelmingly good!. I have visited literally hundreds of museums and art galleries over the years. I am always amazed when I come across another one that exceeds my expectations. This museum is definitely one of those. The organization and curation of the exhibits is outstanding. This would be a great place to bring a novice to introduce them to the chronological development of art in this part of Spain, and in fact, in Europe as a whole, from Romanesque to early 20th century. The ground floor areas with Romanesque and Medieval/Renaissance art is absolutely full of interesting and significant pieces. They may not have any particularly famous works, but my personal feeling is that we are bombarded too often with the same images, by the same famous artists. Looking at the work of lesser known artists re-awakens the senses and leads to a realization that talent and originality has existed in many countries and gone by largely unnoticed. The upper floor is wonderfully curated. The mix of media, photography with furniture with paintings and ceramics works very well. The thematic layout, focusing on the self portraits, interiors, exteriors etc helps the viewer see connections and understand cultural themes and ideas. Good café inside in an enormous hall area, reputed to be one of the largest public spaces in Europe! Also great views from the café outside. There is a good, up-market restaurant on the first floor that looks like somewhere for a more special lunch!I had to go twice to this museum (one ticket allows two entries within a month) and I still haven't finished. A good excuse to return to Barcelona!
amazing at night. surreal place at night, wow amazing building and amazing show of lights. something you should visit when you visit Barcelona. electric stairs for lazy people.
A wonderful musuem. As you walk towards the museum set up high on the hill ,this wonderful building is grandiose ,a must visit

Lovely building. I'm not interested in museums but my wife is and i have to say it's worth going. The museum is very modern and has a vast range of paintings etc, to see. It's worth just standing outside to look at the building. Be aware that although there are escalators to bypass the many steps to the entrance. the final bit is steps only, so those with mobility issues may struggle. Oh, and the cafe doesn't serve breakfast tea! Not good for us brits!

Grand. Amazing views of the city, pricey entry but great collections. Beautiful museum yo walk around, light, airy etc yet huge, we visited a couple of areas, gothic and modern, but wouldn't have had time to do the whole thing.

Most humanist art museum I've visited. Not only the collections of Romanesque and Gothic art are superb, the museum makes every effort to make art pilgrims feel home. The personnel is welcoming and encouraging, they do not disturb art experience by telling to move away from pieces on displays. There are sofas to rest. The collections are well-structured, the building itself is fascinating. The best of the best is the summary notes for every section: engaging, laconic, sharp, with no pathos.

Don't miss this one. We found the collection to be interesting and varied. I especially liked the grouping of the art to be very interesting. Art was displayed by theme instead of tightly chronologically or medium or other criteria. It made the visit very enjoyable and informative. In addition, the descriptions for the art were also in English and very eloquent at that. Some were so interesting and informative I wound up taking picture of the description more than the art.Combined with the great plaza leading down from the Museum and the Olympic park nearby, it made the trip a 'must do' for me.Don't forget to go up to the roof platform. It goes almost all the way around the rooftop. Great unobstructed views.Tip: As with every major attraction in Spain, tickets are sold on a timed entry basis. Absolutely book tix in advance online. Otherwise the wait can be long, and you may only get a ticket to enter 2-3 hours later, or you may not get in at all.

Your eyes will not believe. Unbelievable and extremely magnificent this massive building. The fountain in front will take you miles away, mainly if you visit in the evening where you have 'The water dance show '. The Museum is fantastic inside and outside, you will spend hours knowing what the most famous Spanish artist left for us to admire. I do recommend you to arrive early and stay till evening for the Fountain water show.
Good art museum. This museum is not too big, and does not have too many of works as big capital art museums, but it has some nice art pieces.
Nice city view. Went here just for a stroll and have i nice view of Barcelona. Many stairs but there are escalators so quite easy to reach the top.

Awesome!. Brilliant walk but be careful of people selling selfie sticks!!! They are everywhere! Worth seeing especially with the magic fountain and olympic stadium next door. Olympic museum was very good.

Don't miss the place. The view from the top of the Palace is unbeatable. You do not have to buy tickets to the museum to enjoy the view and the lobby of the palace. The Hop On Hop Off bus has two stop for this beautiful palace. The fountains only run on Fridays, don't miss them.

A museum that will make you spend either 30 min or 5 hours of your day!. The outside view is exceptional on a sunny day. The panoramic view from the lobby is breath talking but once you get inside you, the most astonishing sculptures and painting are magnificent! Make sure you start your visit in the morning if you go on Sunday as the museum closes at 3pm.

Impressive Atop The Hill. This is a beautiful museum with a fantastic art collection! While they do have a very impressive Romanesque and 16th century art exhibit, which includes El Greco by the way, my favorite part of the museum is their "Art Modern" display. They recently redone this whole section very successfully to show all the different types of media side by side, allowing the viewer a broader view of 19th-century Catalan visual culture. I was very impressed and highly recommend this museum to any art lover visiting Barcelona. Fortunately for me, I went after 3:00 Saturday and got in free and first Sunday of the month is free as well.
Surprisingly excellent. Brilliant, we said we'd stay a couple of hours-we were there 5.We would go back again and well worth the price of entrance. Beautiful views from the top.

Lovely building, excellent views from the roof, mildly boring museum. Walking towards the museum is a lovely experience, and I would recommend the walk even to those who choose not to go in. It's a nice place to sit outside on a sunny day. My partner and I did not enjoy the art in the museum personally, but going up to the shaky lift to the roof is a must, there are excellent views of the city from there.

Wonderful, especially the Romanesque. The first few sections of the gallery tell a wonderful story of Romanesque art as found in the churches of the Pyrenees. The displays mimic the original church settings and are very atmospheric. Other sections good: modernist exhibits worthwhile. Nice and spacious throughout.
Beautiful Place. A beautiful place to visit, be it if you intend to visit the museum. You have great view of the city & able to see numerous iconic building from afar.

Beautiful building. I think the view of the building and the surrounding area is enough for a trip there. It's near Plaza Espanya and right by the lucky fountain. I really liked the views. Definitely worth a climb.
Gorgeous Museum. We stepped off the tour bus and unexpectedly found this. The view from the bottom to the top is amazing. Definitely recommend this as a Top 10 of Barcelona... My personal favorite.

Nice mix of exhibits. Not necessarily a world class museum but a worthy stop if you're in Barcelona and looking for some culture. The highlights for me were the furniture by Gaudi (the reason I skipped Casa Batllo and La Pedrera) and some pieces by El Greco (my first time seeing, and loving). The building and surrounding area around is beautiful, you really can't help but pull out the camera.

Museum focusing on art from Barcelona and Catalonia. The museum is good and objects are displayed well. The main focus is on art from Barcelona and the region of Catalonia with limited works from further afield. It covers almost 1000 years of art history.

Beautiful Building. If you love Religious art then this is for you. If you are not crazy about it then you might still enjoy the beautiful building. It is very large so it never feels crowded. It has an awesome rooftop view, and several restaurants and snack bars.
Amazing musuem. Lots of very cool exhibits that took you through the past of Barcelona. A must see! Surrounding area is beautiful as well!

Impressive. Plenty of Art for all art enthusiasts. They have a roof terrace if you don't mind the climb, which offers great views of Barcelona, and the front of the building is pretty impressive too, stairs leading down, and great views as well. Their is plenty of master pieces to look at from known and not so well known, it holds a lot of pieces from Catalonia artists their Modernists section is truly amazing.

Interesting.. We came to this following our visit to the fountains, it sitting atop the hill behind the fountains. A very lofty site is aided by a series of escalators which are a great help for people with walking difficulties. A good and varied display in several galleries shows much of the best of Catalonian art. You should see the huge gallery to the rear of the building. It houses one of the biggest organs we have ever seen.
Unexpected . I usually don't museums but liked this one awesome surrounding from he top you can see replica of Greene towers like colosseum must go

Fairly good collection. The modern art collection on the upper floor is curated as a guide to the evolution of the major movements in modern western art, as manifested in Catalonian, Spanish and other European art. It's understandably focussed on local artists and concerns (eg Spanish civil war) which is great for those who see a lot of art elsewhere and enjoy the dive into the specific. Worth a look.

Better Than Average Art Collection; Amazing Building & Vistas. The Art Museum is housed in the National Palace (built for the 1929 World Exposition); the grand building will catch your eye from quite a distance. Set up on a hill near Montjuic Park, just to walk around the grounds and take in the vistas of Barcelona is worth the effort. Inside you will find many different genres of art but is well known for the Gothic and Romanesque styles- much of it from old churches in Southern Spain.
Surroundings lovely. We did not go in but all around and the views are terrific. The gardens are worth a walk but we also went up round the back and continued up the hill.

The Pearl of Monjuic Hill. The building of the Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya (shortned as MNAC) is a true pearl of Monjuic Hill and is an unmissable experience when in Barcelona. Depending on the time of the day it changes color from sunny beige to tender pink and is marvelous. A beautiful view of Barcelona opens from the steps of the museum and its top observation platform. Moreover, there are functioning escalators that can ease the rise to the top. Most of the year the territory is decorated by numerous fountains.

unexpected wonder. When we visited Barcelona we did not know about this museum. We visited it because our guide recommeded it, and it was a great surprise to discover this amazing collection in Barcelona, specially the Romanesque room.
An amazing and rich experience. A must see in Barcelona. The approach to the museum itself takes your breath away. So much to see inside as well. Take 3-4 hours.

Amazing view!. I didn't visit inside the museum but the view surrounding it is amazing! Got here using the hop on hop off bus and only decided to get off here on a whim.Great atmosphere, loads of people and musicians around. There are fountains all the way down the hill, great for taking loads of photos. There is also 2 cafes and a bar outside the museum.

Spend a lot of time here.. The museum is on the bus route and occupies an outstanding position overlooking the city.Visit here if only for the view, but if art is your thing there are many galleries which could take all day to absorb!

Amazing. I dragged my family to see art work from medieval to modern times. We all really enjoyed the collections they have there! It is not expensive to get in, but you see so much! Apart from actual museum, surroundings are beautiful, worth taking a picture or two. Don't forget to get on the roof top to see Barcelona's skyline.

A real 'must see' attraction in a city with loads to see!. My wife and I spent several hours touring the MNAC on a Saturday and were astonished at how quiet it was. However, we were both awestruck by the sheer beauty of the building and the thousands of artefacts on display .... and then, of course, there is the amazing view over the city from the terrace at the front of the building and the surrounding parkland to explore too.I'm not a religious person but I was left in awe by the sheer beauty and artistry of many of the items on display in the part of the museum dedicated to religious art. However, there are also areas dedicated to paintings, sculpture, furniture etc and all are quite amazing and beautifully displayed. Indeed, I've visited many museums over the years but have seldom been so impressed as I was with what was on display at the MNAC. I just loved it! Highly recommended.
A place to admire from the outside. To be honest I don't think the museum is worth going in but the building and the views of the city from it are stunning. Definitely worth walking around

Early Catalan Art Collection the Star. You need a minimum of a morning or afternoon to do justice to this great art collection. Why not concentrate your visit on what's unique to Catalonia--medieval frescos and wooden religious from Catalan rural churches gorgeously displayed. Use of red color makes them unique compared to their Italian era cousins. The park and view of Barcelona from the museum are also worth the trip.
