Great views. The views from this museum are amazing. I would have to say that I agree with other visitors who stated that it is best to concentrate on the newer or modern sections of the museum. One learns much of Barcelona by doing this.

Not worth it.. Want to visit museums? You chose the wrong city. Barcelona gets one thousand less funding than Madrid for them. Fair enough, they've done the best they could, and the collection of Romanesque frescoes are pretty good, but that's about it. The building itself is eclectic, built for the International Exhibition of 1928, and it stands to shame when compared to the Mies Van Der Rohe Barcelona Pavillion just 700m away. Unless you simply cannot live without seeing the frescoes I mentioned, go to CCCB instead, or to the Museu Miró. Or better still: when in Barcelona, just walk around, and never forget to look up. That's the city's charm.

First rate. This museum is in a fantastic building in Parc Montjuic. (Take metro to Espanya, leave the stn via Exposicio exit, and walk up/take escalators to Museum) It has a wonderful collection of Catalan religious art, as well as a smattering of works by Goya, Velasquez, and El Greco. The other highlight is work and furniture by Gaudi and other modernistas.

Interesting Museum. It is not the first place one would recommend from Barcelona, but it turns to be a very interesting museum where you can see pictures from the ladt 1000 years. I found particularly interesting the medieval part.
Impressive view . Every Saturday after 3pm entrance is free of charge. Unfortunately fountains didn't work so we couldn't fully enjoy the view. Place worth to visit even without entering.

Spectacular View!. Although I did not go in, the building itself & the grounds are beautiful & worth a look. The view, however, was spectacular & that alone makes it worth a visit. Multiple fountains, Sagrada Familia in the distance & of course Placa Espagna at the foot of the hill.As a bonus, the gift shop (if you're looking for more Gaudi souvenirs) is actually on the outside of the building.There are periods (Saturdays after 3pm) that admission is free.
Lovely way to spend a morning. This was surprisingly interesting and a lovely way to spend a morning. I would have spent a full day here if I had the time. The gift shop is phenomenal.
Birthday Surprise. One of the best cities I have been to in my life. This location is a must see when you find yourself in Barcelona.
National Art Museum. Even if you don't have time to go inside during the day, I highly suggest taking the walk the stairs at night and you will be amazed by the panoramic city views!

A grandiose perspective !. The area surrounding Plaça de Espanya are unlike any other in Barcelona. Mail it to the entrance of the Avinguda de la Reina Maria Cristina, stop between the two Venetian towers like two sentries, and you will see your next destination at the top of the hill: the National Art Museum of Catalunya (MNAC), housed in the National palace. It was built for the 1929 universal exhibition.After almost a century, it has retained all its grandeur. The MNAC contains an impressive collection of art spanning an entire millennium. It is essential to take the time to enjoy this world famous collection and the walls that shelter. The fresco "Christ in Majesty", which was transferred carefully to its place of origin in a church in the Pyrenees, is probably the work not to be missed if you are in a hurry.

An enjoyable art gallery. The permanent collection covers a long period of mostly Spanish art starting from ancient times and up until the Spanish Civil War. There are also good temporary exhibitions in a separate section. I found the older parts of the collection a bit boring, as it contains a lot of very repetitive religious art. The newer parts, however, contain quite a few jewels that make it worth a visit. As in many other of Barcelona's museums, they also have some Gaudi furniture on display.The ticket you buy is good for an additional visit within 30 days, which is very helpful since it's impossible to see the whole museum in one day (I needed 4).The building itself is the centerpiece of Plaza Espanya / Montjuic fountain composition and is also very impressive inside. At the end of each visit I love stopping just outside the entrance for an excellent panorama of Barcelona, thinking about how the art I saw inside relates to the city and its people.

Double Whammy - Magnificent Art and Magnificent Views!. This beautiful palace was built during the exposition held during the late 20's. At it's end, the structure became a star in the Barcelona evening sky. The use of it to house some of Spain's loveliest art treasures was inspired. The art inside matches the art outside. Additionally, this jewel is set high up in the magnificent Park Montjuic. When you pause to sip a coffee at the café at the front of the Museu, you have displayed in front of you, the beautiful panorama of Barcelona. It is breathtaking.Once inside, you are offered views of the best mural paintings of the Romanesque period, Gothic, Modern and 20th-century Art. Gaudí, Julio González, El Greco, Velázquez and Dali are all there. Magnificent sculptures share space also. One should plan on spending a few hours there.

Early March visit . This was superb. Spent most of our time in the modern art sections (not what I would have expected, as it started from 19th century). It warrants more time than we could give it. One if the best collections I have seen. Having been thoroughly disappointed by the Barcelona Museum of Modern Art, this was the complete opposite

Gallery. This was very long walk from my hotel, (needed the exercise,) took 45 minutes uphill, easy on the way home. The gallery has an impressionism exhibition on at the moment not totally convinced with this one, particularly having seen the Monet in Piccadilly some time ago. As you can imagine that was outstanding. Wouldn´t rush to this
Top of the world. Fantastic vantage point to get a bird's eye view of Barcelona, plus the exhibits are extensive and well-curated.
great location. the museum is on the way to Montjuc and is worth to visit it walking there from placa Spagna, there is great view on entire city

Wonderful! Free for 65+. MNAC is a fantastic museum. The architecture is amazing and the views are astonishing. The collection represents hundreds of years. The organization is original and works well. I could have spent several days here.
A must visit attraction.. This attraction has everything, wonderful views over Barcelona, great fountains and gardens and to cap it all the amazing artworks. You have to pay this museum a visit.

A great collection of art. This Art Museum has a broad and diverse collection with something for everyone. Excellent examples from antiquities to the moderns. Definitely well worth spending time here.

Marvellous . The Museu National d'Art de Catalunya (MNAC) is an outstanding hilltop palace, housing amazing art, with awesome views over Barcelona. You'll find older Catalan, Baroque and Romanesque church paintings plus Modern art here. My favourite section was the Modern which was superb. This is the largest museum in Barcelona and MNAC is worth visiting to see both the art (260,000+ works) and the building itself which is marvellous. MNAC and the Museu Picasso are the two places not to miss if you're an art lover holidaying in Barcelona. An absolute experience of a lifetime.

Beautiful building perched atop a hill with a commanding view.. The building is visually attractive and sits atop a hill looking down onto the Magic Fountain and Placa De Espanya. Commanding view ofer that part of the city. Nearby Olympic Statium is an attraction worth visiting as well.

great museum, great view of the fountains. A beautiful venue and well presented. A great explanation of Catalan history. The views and ambiance were magnificent.The building is beautiful.The rooftop terrace was very nice with good views of Barcelona.

A beautiful building housing a wonderful collection of art works. We took the bus up to Monjuic and walked down to the Museu. It is a huge building but the rooms are easy to access and well laid out. There are two floors housing historic and more modern works of art, including examples of Gaudi's furniture and Picasso's Woman in a Hat and Fur Collar. It is well worth a visit if you are interested in Art and have two hours to spare.

Very interesting!. For those who do not speak/read Catalan or Spanish, be prepared not to read much in English or other languages. We especially liked the Romanesque wing, filled with art from ancient churches.

So much to see we will have to go back. Excellent art gallery. It was great to see the breadth of Catalun art, well beyond Miro and Picasso. The building and location is also beautiful and well worth seeing in its own right.

Byzantine church frescos a must-see. The MNAC has wide-ranging collections, but it's worth making time to see the amazing collection of wall paintings rescued from north Spanish early romanesque churches, with the aim of preventing their vandalisation or stealing to order.The techniques used to first remove and then instal for display these works defy belief - and the images are beautiful. Don't miss!

Go there. We visited the museum after being to gaudi and a few other gallery's , however were very impressed with the layout . From impressionist trough to modern art , and sculptures galore, this will impress.Very easy to navigate and just the walk up the stairs will take your breath away.

Find the painting. Tickets valid for 2 days, children are free and parent got 30% discount when visiting as family with the children. Beautiful building with the water fountains. Stay a bit after it closed and enjoy the sunset or some local dance attraction.We spent most of our time in the renaissance part looking at the beautiful paintings. For 'Da Vinci Code' enthusiasts, find the paintings with a very pregnant looking Marie Magdalene and her statue holding the candle (which can be intrepreted in various way).

Coffee and beautiful views.. A lovely place to have coffee and enjoy the wonderful gardens, and views across the city. Also many other interesting little venues in the area so not a wasted trip. The building itself is stunning, and the art work as you would expect, classic.

Amazing views, impressive art but very cold. Went to the museum after spending a day walking around the mountains and had spotted this a couple of times and was curious what it was, we went just to tick off something extra on our list of places visited. Once in security was exceptionally high but was also busy, due to our cards we had we got past all the queues and security no problem at all. Once in, it was exceptionally cold as if in a freezer, while the art was impressive and vast, we did not spend as long as we could have due to how cold it was.,

Well worth the walk. The views from the terrace of this museum are spectacular. Easy access thanks to the escalators taking you all the way to the top, but keep looking back on the way up just to see the area

Wow very good museum will come back. The museum next to the olympic Stadium of Barcelona, is so great you need to spent a lot of time to see at least half of it. I myself will come back again. It snot only regarding painting , also the information on by is important. Price for the entrance is okay.

Beautiful view. Make sure to go around 4 o'clock when the fountains start working. It is magical... the park, the view, the museum itself. At the back of the museum there's a lady that comes every day to feed the street cat and it is the cutest thing you'll see that day.

Spectacular fountains. Been here a few times over the years. Lovely to take a slow walk up to the top - great views and surrounding gardens. On our last visit we saw the fountain show...simply stunning.

Great collection. We visited this art museum and were very happy to see such a large collection so beautifully displayed. It may not rank more highly that the Prado or other grander venues but it is a good overview of Catalan art.

Awesome atmosphere!. One of my top attractions in Barca (and free!!) - very beautiful building, nice area around this museum, cheerful atmosphere and amazing fountain! Gets really crowded on the evenings before the fountain shows - however it has its unique atmosphere, people are sitting around, chatting and enjoying it.
many of the same. It's nice to visit if you are a fan of the gothic style. They have lots of gothic art in the museum. They also have a department with more modern art, but it is secondary.
Expensive. You should onl spend that much amount on the entry ticket only if you love art . The place is nice for a one time visit but it is not for everyone.

Admire the frail beauty of Romanesque church art. I warmly recommend the Medieval Romanesque collections in this museum. Admire the frail beauty of Romanesque church murals and their surprisingly vivid colours -- neatly brought back to life by restorers. Interestingly, a number of the murals displayed were carved out from churches scheduled for demolition and painstakingly re-assembled here. When I write re-assembled I mean it in the literal sense -- it's almost as if these churches have been brought back into the flesh. I saw something similar in the Prado in Madrid. This approach probably wouldn't have been pursued today -- the modern conservationist ethic would probaly be not to remove the artworks from their original context. Nevertheless, this is a marvellous collection.I also found the collection of posters from the Spanish Civil War very interesting -- I wish there were more of them exhibited.There's a 180-degree view of the city from the outside, where there's also a small outdoors museum café. I wouldn't recommend anything other than take-away coffee from this place, though. I had an overpriced ham and cheese sandwich that wasn't properly toasted and cold on the inside -- it looked as if it had been pre-toasted. Tables were dirty and had old stains from coffee and milk on them.Free entry on Fridays. The museum website is very informative and has a lot of information available in English.
One of the best things you can do. This building is so impressing. It is one of the things I highly recommend you should do in Barcelona.

great museum, perfect view of the fountains. We visited first thing in the morning, got there before it opened and before the big buses arrive, so we could take pictures of the city panorama below without intrusions. The museum has a magnificent collection of art, very ingeniously presented. You'd better have comfortable shoes for this one because there is a lot of walking ahead, and all worth doing. We took a cab to Montjuic, where the museum is located, and spent the whole day in that park, since the Miro Foundation is within a 10min walk, the Poble Espanol and the Mies Van Der Rohe Pavilion were close by.

Great collection of the Romanesque art. If you like Romanesque art, never miss this museum. It has a splendid collection of Romanesque art from valleys of Pyrenees. The condition of conservation is incredibly good, and the frescoes give the splendor of 11th to 13th century. Simple but strong works. There are lots of other important works, but it's worthwhile to visit this museum only for the part of Romanesque.
Very impressive and enjoyable. Wish we had more time to explore. A beautiful venue and well presented. The views and ambiance were magnificent
A wonderful museum. Enjoy a variety of museum spaces. The recreation of a medieval church is outstanding. The grand hall has such interesting architecture.

Worth visiting. Although we didn't visit the actual museum, I would still recommend to visit this place. It has a good metro connection and you can get some great photo opportunities.You can combine it with Montijuc castle and park.It is good to see this place during the day and during the night (to see fountain show).

An absolute MUST SEE,. The approach from the Placa Espanya is a spectacular walk. There are open air escalators nearer to the top and just before the very top turn right for the final escator.Now turn round and look at the view! If you are a pensioner the entrance is free. I cannot say too much - it is just jaw dropping. Just wander round and enjoy. Eventually you will find an enclosed amphitheater.When you have finished walk around the back and you will come to the Estadi Olimpic. That is free to visit by everyone.

Don't miss it. I first visited this museum more then 20 years ago and was one of my most vivid memories in Barcelona. It covers basically Romanic and medieval art in the first floor and the late XIX and early XX century art in the second floor. The collection of medieval art is amazing. There are also a lot of furniture, paintings and photographs of the "Gaudi" period. However the most impressive e part is the Romanic art. They basically took all the frescoe paintings from endangered Romanic churches and broth them, reproducing the original church settings inside the museum. Absolutely unforgettable. In my opinion it is, along with the Sagrada Familia, one of the two unmissable attractions of the city. If you have the money, I t probably has the restaurant with the best views of Barcelona

Awesome Place. Nice place. unfortunately the fountain outside are not working which is one of the attractions people loves to see when they visit the place. The hop-on hop-off bus stops here (green line). a must see.
Worth a visit . It's free to visit. Nice chilled walked. Museum is free to visit. It's close to the Spanish village. Get the metro there. Fun activity

Must see and enjoy top view of Barcelona. First of all we did not know too much about this museum and we are not interested in the Catalunya art or some kind of their history but anyway we are appreciated this very huge building and great top view, like panorama view and we enjoyed some sandwiches at the front of this building with this great Barcelona top view and lucky us that the period that we were there, there was a musician who played Spanish songs with his guitar.So we love this place
Amazing views form the rooftop. Amazing views . Rooftop entry is €2 well worth it - spectacular photo opportunitys. Lovely little cafe and not far from the Olympic stadium

Art vs Landscape. We thoroughly enjoyed the grounds around the MNAC almost as much as the art inside! Great photo ops, be sure to walk the gardens, lots of walking outside, so a nice day is important.

Excellent Museum. We had a very enjoyable visit to the museum. It has a very good collection of major artists. The building is beautiful. The rooftop terrace was very nice with good views of Barcelona and overlooking the 1929 Olympic stadium.

Remarkable Collection of Christian Religious Art. Set high on a hill, with majestic views, this museum houses what might be the best collection of Christian art anywhere, with frescos and other items dating from the 1300's - 1500's. Even if you're not Christian or religious in any way, it's impossible not to be impressed by the craftsmanship & materials in these gorgeous ancient works. There are sets of escalators that run essentially from the street level to the entrance of the museum. Or you can climb the steps up and/or down for a good workout!The gift shop is just so so. Mostly generic items, nothing special.

Perfect for art lovers. If you really love art and understand at least the basic, do not hesitate to visit it! It has a little bit of every art age so everyone can find something they like. A beautiful explanation of Catalan history. Wouldn't recommend it to people who can't appreciate art, it could be boring for them.
Beautiful. We visited here while waiting on the magic fountain and it was truly a site to see at night!! This wasn't originally on our itinerary but so glad I was able to capture this pic!!
Take your time and appreciate its beauty. Not to be missed. A beautiful building with a fascinating collection.I would really recommend the Modern Collection. And a good shop and restaurant.

Huge museum but some of the expositions appear to be a bit dated. Huge collection with some really nice pieces but wandering through the museum I got the impression that it could use some uplift in appearance. Worth a visit though.

magnificient building. magnificient building, especially when the sun is setting itself below the horizon. There are no barriers as moving stairs are also on the street, which is great. view fromt he building terraces is spectacular.

Excellent views and nice collection!. We spent couple of hours and were just barely able to cover romensque frescoes and gothic art - very well preserved from medieval periods. The collection is really worth the visit! Fortunately, we had a guide who was able to provide more insights and context. The building itself is impressive. We took the elevator to go to the top of the building to get a birds-eye view of the city! The walk down (using escalators) to Placa d'Espanya gave us views at different levels. Highly recommend this museum and if you have the time take the walk up (or down).

Evening visit. We went for a walk in the evening. I thought it was magical. And the architecture is quite impressive. I was very impressed with the green areas in front of the museum. And i really enjoyed the view of Barcelona from up there :)

Beautiful building and stunning Romanic frescoes. The museum hosts an astonishing collection of Romanic frescoes brought from old catalonian medieval churches and restored here. Probably one of the best collections of medieval art in Spain. The building in itself is an architectural masterpiece. A pity that we went in a rainy day. Cheap entrance ticket as far as prices go in Barcelona.

Beautiful museum great panorama, fountains and park. When you park downhill halfway to museum, you can find a nice view on the city. The walk is pleasant and picturesque... In the museum itself there are lots of nice exhibitions and a terrace with panoramic view. I bought a common ticket for 18 euro.It included: General admission: €12 (valid for two days during a month from the purchasing date), Temporary exhibition: Xavier Gosé, 1876-1915. Illustrator of modernity: €6; To the Rooftop Viewpoint: €2; Spanish Village which is just downhill, another great place to visit.

Well worth the visit. Just approaching this place via the staircases leading up to it is very beautiful, especially at night when the fountain show is underway. Definitely check it out! A ton of people gather here. A must see!

Nice view from the hill. The Museum's architecture is amaizing. Also the location is perfect for pictures and panoramics. There are moving staircases available so there is no effort necessary to get there. Not to forget: the view is free of charge.

A Palace turned into a museum and art gallery. Beautiful on the outside , cold and museum like on the inside . Notice on the walls says free entry but to to see the good bits you have to pay. This visit was not on my orginal plans but I was tired off the pull and push of the metro so decided to stay close to my hotel and this hotel along with the magic fountains was just around the corner.outside the main door of the palace is a large paved area you can sit here and enjoy a coffe whilst you look out over the roof tops of the city . This is a high vantage point and the down side is there are lots of steps and escalators to contend before you get to the door. On the day I visited an older guy was playing his guitar and singing Spanish love songs for tips , very pleasent couple of hours .

Excellent experience!. Two suggestions: (1) Go inside and be impressed by the paintings and building structure itself, and (2) Hop off the HOHO bus, walk in front of the National Art Museum, and take panoramic pictures of the city.

Brilliant gothic artwork. The MNAC is as surprising inside as it is outside - a long ascent made worthwhile by the views it offers. Brilliant collection of Gothic (Religious) artwork well worth seeing.

Great views . The views from here are great. The museum itself is huge. Lots of interesting things. It's split into four very large sections. You are going to spend at least 3 hours in there. Art overload. Was included for free with the Barcelona card.

1000 years of Catalan Art. This musuem is on the top of Mont Juic. There is an excellent view from the top and outdoor musicians playing every day. THe museum itself is very large with a huge collection of religious art from the MIddle ages until modern days. The buidling itself is fascinating.

Free on Sat and Sun. I am not a big fan of museum.
But it is worth to see for free if you visit Barcelona durring the weekend. If I remember correctly, it will be free on Saturday after 3pm and all day for the Sunday. However, it is better to check the website again

One of the best museum in Bcn. To be honest, this is my favourite museum in Bcn! You can experience there mainly the romanesque art, which is really worth to see it! Plus, the museum is located on the Montjuic hill, nearby Plaza de Espana, which provide a great location! :) The fact, that sometimes you can go there for free makes it even more interesting ;)
Very nice. I was impressed by their Medieval Era collections. Beautiful facility inside and out. Great view from the outdoor area looking North.

Wonderful building - a must see in the city!. We were at Plaça d’ Espanya, which is really close, but decided to take bus 150 instead of going all the way up using the stairs and escalators, due to the horrible heat in the summer. It was a good option in the end, since the bus was air-conditioned and it took a route around/behind the museum, going past many other sites, like Poble Espanyol, the Olympic museum, Fundacio Joan Miro and going all the way up to Castell de Montjuic, which we went later on. We had a Barcelona card, so we went in for free and had access to the roof, with a breathtaking view of the city. It was summer, so there was electronic music playing and a bar, from which we got some nice cold beers and took our time admiring the view in the shade of some huge umbrellas. That was really special! As for the works of art, well, I’m no art connoisseur, and having been to the most famous museums in Europe before, it was mildly interesting. I really liked the Modern Art section, though, with the Civil War part. It was really worth going there, though, I loved the building, really, really gorgeous, a gem! I’m the kind of person who usually enjoys the buildings more than the art collections, and that wasn’t a let-down. There are some eating/ drinking options at the museum, but I thought it was really expensive for what it was; the food at the café was sad-looking. We ended up eating at Fundacio Joan Miro, which is within walking distance.

Fantastic !. Fantastic place that you can find a particular renascence works ! the walking path to the museum is a very nice experience! Spend more than 3 hours inside, includind the terrace lounge. Walk on the seeling and enjoy the view ! Amazing !!

Amazing art collection in a grandiose palace. The national museum of Catalan art holds an impressive collection of Catalan art (and some fine works of prominent European artists) through its historic periods (Romanesque and Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque, Modern art). I cannot decide what is more impressive, the collection itself or the building in which it is housed.

What a view!. Want the perfect view of the city from Montjuic? Then this is the place for you. The museum itself is well organized, split into different centuries with the earliest on the first floor and later works on the second, even featuring a Picasso painting and Miro mural. You get a little of everything here, well worth a visit. Not to mention, it's free with the Barc Card and on Sundays after 3pm!

Apart from the climb, lovely!. The old palace is beautiful from afar, although it isn't quite so lovely after the amount of steps you have to take to get there, even with the escalators in place it's quite a tiring walk to the top, by which you are very much out of breath.The museum itself is lovely-relaxing and quiet, with a beautiful view of the Placa de Espana below. There is a also a shopping centre situated on the top right corner of the Placa de Espana from the museum which has quite a few restaurants with a lovely view as well.It's also very close to the Olympic grounds-if you go past the castle and keep walking, you should reach it. Good if you're staying for a couple of days (although I wouldn't recommend this for a one-day trip to Barcelona simply due to the amount of time it takes to view an art gallery.)

Great educational timing. I liked the Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque art collection in this museum. It was truly magnificent and the educational aspects were outstanding. The display of the items is magnificent
Great. Even if you don't have time to visit inside make sure to take a walk around and see it...you will have a great view of Plaza de Espana and pretty area near by.

Beautiful Museum, Must See!. Though the collections inside are ok the facility, architecture and the views are outstanding. We were lucky and went on the first Sunday of the month when the entrance fees are waived and had a wonderful afternoon roaming the grounds. Must see!

Stunning. Walk through the parks and the sculptured surroundings for a wonderful experience. Well laid out and very attractive. Outdoor Escalators make moving up and down the several levels easy and convenient for all ages. Experience the splendour of the past and enjoy the wonderful views. Must visit.
Beautiful Barcelona!. This is another of the many spots you must get to on visiting Barcelona! You can go up and down with the help of escalators. The tourist bus took us there which was great too.

Nearly Excellent. I absolutely loved the Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque art collection in this museum. It was truly magnificent and the educational aspects were outstanding. Tip: Get the audioguide. It is excellent and very affordable at 3.50 Euro. In contrast, the modern art collection felt a little more like an afterthought (even with the audioguide which only offered a few commentaries on this collection that spanned the upper floor). Still some excellent work, but it could not compare to the earlier work in the museum. I recommend going when the museum opens and walking the gorgeous stairs to enjoy the majesty of this grand space. Gorgeous views and a wonderful place to take pictures. I understand you can pay a bit more for rooftop access, but I didn't find it necessary as the weather was perfect and the view for pictures spectacular.

Well done, but not the Prado. . I enjoyed my visit, but compared to the Prado the MNAC is a bit "slim". The Medieval, Cambio and Thyssen-Borizima collections were good, and there are two Goya paintings that's should not be missed if you are a fan.

Beautiful museum and nice view of Barcelona from up there. 2nd time I visit this museum. There are some paintings there that I like and wanted to return to it to take photos of. Also nice views of Barcelona when you are up there. You can go up using stairs or a taxi will take you all the way up, as I've done this time.

Fantastic setting on Montjuic. Great variety of art work from one of the most intriguing regions in the world. From the medieval period through more modern works by Picasso and Gaudi - it's all here. Some of the best lighting I've ever seen in a museum setting. Made each piece look spectacular.

Serene visit to see a lovely collection. Had a lovely time visiting the various galleries of MNAC especially the Medieval Romanesque & the Modern Art collections. Audio-guides are available upfront and commentaries are interesting. The crowd was thin during our visit so we could savor the art on display. For photography enthusiasts note that you CAN take photos in the MNAC, just switch of your camera's flash function.A trip to the roof deck (Patio) to view Barcelona was also worth the short stair climb. The only down-side would be the dining options... Or the lack thereof... but who comes to museums for food anyway?

Wow. No really, wow.. I've lost count how many museums we have been so fortunate to walk into around the world. Its like I have this wish list I've been working on and I have to say, this one was not on it. But we decided to at least get up on top of Montjuic and take a look at the views....once there the delightful gathering of local musicians and artists entertained us (as well as the lovely weather) and after devouring some delicious ice cream decided, "aw what the heck lets go inside even though the Med Sea below, sunshine and aromatic air begs us to stay outside!!". Because we went in late in the day we only spent about 3 hours there...and WOW, one of the most interesting visits I've ever had. I won't go into further detail but let me state this: whoever curates, collects and then sets up the exhibits, are all to be applauded. We learned so much about Catalonia, about Spain, that made me thankful we went. We were able to see unique pieces of periods of art history that we already enjoy at other museums, that can only be seen here, that we were thankful we went in. And I promise you, we will go back. Sorry for the late review...we were actually there in 2013 in August but I just HAD to submit a review.

A day at the museum . I visited this lovely museum while in Barcelona. It was a good day to visit. There were lots of exhibition inside. I was excited and stay the entire day. The museum was filled with tourists, and everyone was friendly. This is a wonderful place to visit while in Barcelona.

Amazing collections. An impressive building with an amazing collections. we only We only managed two of the collections but they were very impressive. The building inside is remarkable with a huge arena rather spoiled by two lifts recently installed. Has a restaurant overlooking the Magic Fountain which must be spectacular in the summer. Decent coffee shop as well.

The best thing about the Magic Mountain is this. I can't comment on the museum other than the fact that I wish I could've seen it.
But while seeing the Magic Fountain, this building, adjacent on it, illuminates beautifully.

Magnificent location and displays. Enjoyed the exhibits and amazed at care and reconstruction in medieval in particular. Staff helpful . Recommend bus but taxi from City centre cheap. Beautiful views of the city lovely gardens.

Museu Nacional.. Built for the 1929 International Exhibition, but since 1934 it has housed the city's most important art collection. The artworks span a thousand years, from paintings and sculpture to furniture and photos, prints and coins.On the ground floor there is Medieval and Gothic Art, Renaissance and Baroque, on the first floor there is Modern and Contemporary Art.We enjoyed our vist , the views are amazing.I think you have free entry on a Sunday, but the museum is closed on Monday's.
One of the must visits. We had not gone inside the museums, but even on the outside and the landscapes and the structures were so beautiful to enjoy
great place. If you came in Barcelona and are some free hours make it visit the museum. free entrance with Barcelona card
Too much religious art. Visited the Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya (MNAC) for another dose of culture. It had a great selection of religious paintings through the ages, but not really our style.

Must visit!. We sort of accidentally ended up here and loved it. We walked up from Plaza Espanya and marveled at everything we saw. The fountains, the museum etc. The escalators are very convenient and save walking quite a lot of stairs. We did not intend to go into the museum as not interested in art but we noticed entrance was free (after 3pm on Saturdays) and went it to admire the building. It is gorgeous! There is a roof top and you can walk almost all the way around and see great views. There is even a place to sit down and enjoy the views. Just beautiful.
Must see building, could skip the art. Okay I admit to suffering museum fatigue before arriving but not sure what the fuss is about for the place. The building itself was awesome though

WOW!!. I did not expect to be blown away by the beauty of this location and museum. It is magical! Breath Taking and certainly worth spending the entire day there to than see the wondrous lights of La Fountain Majica. Be sure to take a camera. Inside and out this is one incredible visit.

Worth it for the view. Well worth a visit, -walk up from the Playa D'espanya,using the outdoor escalators for wonderful views. The art is spectacular and the gallery an impressive building in its own right. free on first Sunday of each month
Art musrum. Good representation of development of Catalonian art. Learned a lot and enjoyed what I saw. Very impressively curated.

Perfect!. Even if you have no particular interest in art, this is a must! The location, Montjuic, is on a hill with breathtaking views over Barcelona. The building itself of the art museum is quite awesome. One of the most comprehensive Romanesque church paintings and Catalan art. Beautiful restaurant on the top floor and another cafe on the main floor.
Very interesting. I loved the Romanesque collection and the modern paintings. Great view from the terrace on the second floor - if you find it-. The cafeteria on the ground floor very expensive.

Brilliant. Go after 3pm on a Saturday when it is free and surprisingly quiet. For me the real star of the show was upstairs in the modern art section, which I not really a modern art person but really enjoyed it more than the religious art downstairs.

Go the Viewing Area. Didn't go into the Museum as such, but did pay 2 euro to go up the lift to the viewing terrace. Excellent view of all of Barcelona. Make sure you walk all the way around, its a bit hidden, to enjoy the 360 degree views.

ibtm-world '15. The 'bus city-tour' tourism offering is perfect when you only have a day in Barcelona. Both the red and blue routes do a magnificent job of highlighting the destinations attractions: of which this is one.

Unique Musuem.. Imagine collecting what remained of the Covenants of all of Catalonia, after the" Burning of the Covenants" and cramming that into a big Museum, great Modernista(Art Nouveau) furniture and design, art paintings and much more!Get in for FREE by visiting the site on a Sunday after 3:30 p.m. or the first Sunday of the Month.Save on the entry price( currently 14 euro) by 2 means:Buy and Art Ticket Pass 30 euro and get other 5 Art Museums for FreeBuy the Barcelona Card.

Amaizing Building. We were just walking and looking for Magic Fountain. Suddenly just in front of us we had this amazing, astonishing building. The view in overall was so wonderful but when you stepped up to the building you could have a beautiful view of Barcelona city. The view in front of us was so fantastic. We were there by night, no spectacle of the Magic fountain but still worth it. It was an artistic building with an amazing architecture. The museum and the sorrounding place worth visiting it. If you are in Barcelona this is one of the "must" to see.
Gorgeous building. Beautiful building. A trip highlight for Barcelona. Incredible integration of glass, tile, metal, wood, etc into one building. Did not attend a performance but wish we could have.

OMG...... This is one of the most impressive building and museums I've ever visited.The fountains, grounds and the view are spectacular - and they're free.Inside is a fascinating collection of art from the medieval times onward.there are a lot of stairs, and I probably would not recommend this for younger children but for art lovers this is a must visit.

Lots of stairs. The place was amazing although it was closing by the time I got there... I would visit again and spend hours walking around the different galeries and expositions. There were a lot of stairs though, but I guess that's what makes it beautiful although my knees didn't agree :P

Beautiful and amazing Frescos. One of the spots we wanted to see. The Frescos were amazingly beautiful and were set into the museum, like they would have been inside the churches. Interesting video on how they were removed from their original churches and moved tot he museum. Watch out for the little kids trying to pick pocket you outside on the way in.

Exquisite setting, inside and out. I had only one day to spend in Barcelona on this trip, and I made the most of it, in and around this museum, known as MNAC for Museo Nacional d'Art de Catalunya, in the Parc de Montjuic. Outside, it commands an impressive view of the city and surroundings from its perch part way up its high hill. If you don't mind a bit of an uphill walk, approaching on foot from the Placa Espanya is definitely the way to take in the magnificent fountains, the architecture, and the people of Barcelona out for a stroll.  Inside the best part of the museum is the collection of Romanesque frescoes and murals, preserved from isolated Pyreenean churches. The exhibits and explanations of the preservation of these amazing works of art are very well-curated, with photos of how they were removed and restored.  The museum is free for those under 16 and over 65. Plan to spend at least half a day here. Then take the rest of the day to explore the Parc de Montjuic, where there are gardens, other museums, an outdoor theatre, a fortress, and, more recently built, the Olympic Stadium.

Outstanding overview of Catalan art from all periods. Allow at least a day for this wonderful collection in a gorgeous building (actually 2). The frescoes removed from small churches around Catalonia and reconstructed in the museum are unique. The arrangement of the modern collection (late 19th and 20th century) is very interesting and a bit unusual but with informative labels in Catalan, Spanish and English.Extensive medieval and romanesque collection is beautifully lit and displayed.The upscale restaurant was nice for lunch with a beautiful view of the city- wish it had been open earlier for dinner.

Some gems in the collections and long views of the city. Impressive building, free entry after 3 on Saturday. Expecting local art but delighted to find Veronese, Titian, Tintoretto, Raphael, Perugino, Rubens as well as Zuberan, Velasquez and El Greco. Quite a long walk from th Miro foundation and a lot of steps and long walk to the metro. If you walk down, stay to the middle as there are a couple of escalators to save some steps.

Beautiful Building and setting looking over Barcelona. We took the hop on hop off bus to the Museum. We did not go inside but did sit outside enjoying the views across Barcelona from up top the hill. Give yourself a hour minimum here even If you are just sitting outside. There was a musician playing beautiful Spanish guitar while we were there which helped set the mood. Well worth the stop

Give yourself plenty of time. We unfortunately showed up thinking to spend 4 hours here only to find out it was a regional holiday and they were closing early. So you can do about half the museum in an hour and a half if you rush. But I'd recommend 4 hours to do it justice. There is some fantastic art and artsy furniture. The art has a Catalonian flavor that you won't find in other parts of Europe, the world or even Spain. I think the museum is an essential stop to get a rounded exposure to the Catalonian culture. It's also a must for Gaudi enthusiast with a fine collections of Gaudi designed doors and furniture

Location and views amazing. Exhibitions excellent.. Internally we only had time to visit the art rescued from churches in the Pyrenees but these were mind-blowing both in respect to their age and the technical difficulty of rescuing and displaying them. The roof terrace also has the most beautiful views of the city.

Largest collection of Roman Frescoes. - The Museu Nacional d’Art de Catalunya is located in the Palau Nacional (National Palace) of Montjuïc ,,, It is near to Plaza Espanya, Metro: L1, L3, L8, S33, S4, S8, R5, R6. From Pl. Espanya 10 minutes wonderful walk to the avenue of Reina Maria Cristina .... Or Barcelona Bus Turistic (Red Line).- Admission: €12 (valid for two days).- Opening times: 10 am to 6 pm (8 pm in summer). Sundays and public holidays, 10 am to 3 pm. Mondays closed, except public holidays. - The Palace is located on the hill of Montjuïc, a privileged setting from which you can enjoy magnificent and unique views of Barcelona. The front access to the Palace is reached by a major stone staircase from the avenue of Reina Maria Cristina, flanked half way up by the major luminous and monumental fountains.- Visiting the museum you can see the collection of Romanesque mural painting and most representative artists of Catalan Modernism, such as Gaudí or Casas. Gothic art, great European Renaissance and Baroque painters and the collection of photography, complete the collection. - You may be lucky to attend an exhibition there ...!!!!

Interesting museum. The museum contains some wonderful Modernisme pieces but I believe is most famous for the church murals that it houses. The building itself is so quite interesting.
Depending on how interested you are in the contents, you could easily spend the best part of a day here.
Entry is free if you have the Barcelona Card.

very complex and well maintained museum. I visited it recently, just a few months ago, during another amazing holiday in Barcelona. I had only seen the exterior an wanted to see also the museum. We liked it a lot and we managed to see almost everything. There are very many items, starting with pieces of stone and wood from Medieval times and finishing with modern art. We spent there about 2h but still there were a few things that needed to be seen. The view from the bistro is also great! More than that we were so lucky as we arrived on a Sunday when we didn't pay the entrance :) Gracias Barca!
We only visited the outside. We never went inside. But must admist this is an amazing building on an amazing place. nice park and ofcourse very busy visited seen the magic fountains are there too.

The biggest of them all. It took me almost 4 hours to visit all this magnificent piece of art, called MNAC. I found it really interesting as you actually walk through, from hall to hall, you can travel to time and see the progress of art through the centuries.I find the staff on reception a bit unprofessional, as they didn't give me any instructions or guidance, except of the map.

wonderful, interesting and surprising exhibits. The museum is on a hillside and quite a climb. We walked to it from Placa d'Espanya. It is a steady climb to start with which gets steeper. You walk passed the Venetian towers, the 4 columns which symbolise Catalunyan freedom and the Magic Fountain. There are some escalators and quite a lot of steps. There is a lovely cascade of water. There is a cafe on the terrace where you can stop and have a drink and take in the marvellous view before entering the museum. It is free entry for the over 65s like us with proof of age. It is an enormous building, There are lockers where you can leave your bags to the right of the entrance. We went to see the mediaeval and Gothic art with beautiful altar pieces and statues and some church plate. All very colourful. Then onwards to Renaissance and baroque art. Next more modern paintings. We then arrived in a huge space under the central dome which we understand used to be an ice skating rink. There is a cafeteria and and restaurant here. We stopped for a coffee and bought a sandwich and a small bottle of water. If you need water - do NOT buy it here they charged €2.50 for 33 ml - outrageous!! The sandwich was awful too - a soft sweetish bread roll with really tough ham!! Coffee was good though. After our break we went to the coin exhibit which was very interesting with some very ancient Greek, Roman and Visigoth coins. After this we were at the stage that we had seen so much it was impossible to take in any more. A couple of days later we went back to see the Romanesque department. It was stunning. There are Catalunyan church frescos from the 12th and 13th century. There was a danger that these frescoes would be sold abroad. They found a way of removing them without damage. They built replicas of the churches and put them on the walls. Amazing to think that these frescos are so old. They have been cleaned - and the colours are as they would have been the day they were painted. It feels as though you are walking into an ancient church. It is well worth visiting this museum.

Sophisticated display of art. This a remarkable collection of Catalonia art showcased in a modern setting in an older palatial building, an unusual juxtaposition. The park that surrounds it is a pretty place to spend an afternoon.

Visit when it's free. We climbed up all the stairs on a Saturday afternoon to arrive to the museum and find out it was free to enter. We noticed that many museums are free at the end of the day in Spain. So we went to visit. You have to see the church inside, it's amazing and so big. It's a very beautiful place, with many things to see and visit inside. I can say that I really enjoyed this place.

Didn't go inside. We didn't go inside but the views from the top make climbing the stairs absolutely worth the journey. If you are there to see the Magic Fountain, then take the time to go to the top to the museum.

Walk through the ages. Wonderfull building, great scenery outside on the terraces. Inside one can spend a day easily. It's a walk through the ages.Very, very beautiful art. The murals are unique in the world, but don't forget the halls full of stunning paintings.The famous names are all there, but everything, also the lesser known, is very high quality stuff.

Wonderful Museum with an Impressive Amount of Art!. My friends and I spent the afternoon at the museum. We took a taxi from our hotel, as we knew we would be doing a great deal of walking at the museum. When we showed our i.d. to get a reduced price we were informed it was free. What a deal! We started on the ground floor and worked our way around using a map we were given. We were treated to an enormous exhibition of Romanesque and Medieval art. Upstairs we were treated to works by Picasso, Gaudi, El Greco and many other well know artists. This museum is a must visit if you are in Barcelona. We did not get to all the exhibitions. It would have take us many more hours than had. Views from the museum are spectacular!
BEAUTIFUL by day or by night!. I visited this place at night and tought it was really nice but then I went in the afternoon and tought exactly the same!!

Impressive. Positioned in such way that you feel it's guarding over the city, the national museum of art is an amazing building, with waterfalls and fountains, lots of stairs and gorgeous views over the city. It's architecture is woth seeing

A huge exhibition of local art. This is an enormous exhibition of paintings and sculpture by artists largely unknown outside Spain (that said there are also the more familiar names: Picasso, Gaudi, El Greco). It follows many of the artistic trends taking place elsewhere and some of the work is very good indeed. The building is impressive with a massive auditorium and exhibitions in the basement that we didn't have the time (or the energy) to get to.The walk there looked a bit daunting from the Placa D'Espanya but there are escalators to help the less mobile up the various levels to reach the museum at the top of the hill and the views from the front of it are spectacular.
great part of Barcelona. This building is a great part of Barcelona and it is located on the hill..Near it there is a magic fountains and from that place you can take a great picture of Barcelona

Magic Fountain. We only had time to view the "magic fountain" in front of the MNAC however, the dancing waters coupled with the lights and music were fantastic. It is a must see while in Barcelona. The fountain is only active on the weekends starting at 7PM at this time of year.
amazing palatial building abovee the fountains. Very interesting venue we were actually there for a gala dinner with Miro tiled walls and beautiful domed cuppola

Great Palace. On our last day at Barcelona we went there. After you get out from the Metro at Spanish Plaza you can see the magnificent old palace at the top of a hill. The gorgeous building stands at the top of flock of stairs..The bad thing was we went there in the morning when the sun was against and the photos were not so clear. The good thing is the escalators. It was very good of Barcelona Municipality. They take you all the steep places easily. The museum and surrounding are really wonderful.

The best view of Barcelona - inside and outside. Really not expensive and wonderful museum. It has a most impressive collection of church paintings that have been collected and put on the wall - so you are looking at hundreds of year old church paintings. It is superb. If you love modern art you will find your happiness there also. But once you are done go up to the second floor, have a drink and a bite at the absolutely overpriced restaurant because once you are done you go towards the small exit on the right side of the window, climb up two sets of stairs and find yourself on the roof - from which you can walk around the museum and have the most beautiful view on the city and all angles, all to yourself (as really no many people know about this access). Enjoy!!! Worth every penny!

A stunning museum in an impressive palace.. The wonderful Palau Nacional houses the museum and they are a perfect match to each other.The museum has several collections from the early 11th century until the present.The most famous, the most notable and the must-see of the outstanding collection is the Romanesque church paintings. There are also panel paintings, wood and stone carvings and precious metalwork.My favourites were the panels came from the grave of Sancho Sánchez Carrillo and his wife Juana,representing the very rarely found Castilian Gothic style art. They look very old (around 1295) and very modern at the same time. If somebody would tell me to choose something from this museum, that would be my definite choice.In the Gothic art collection I found a few other paintings from which I could hardly break away, but it eventually covers the entire Museum.People who have time and energy to wonder around can find paintings from Goya, Tiepolo, El Greco, Ribera, Tiziano etc. Don’t miss the amazing sculpture of Josep Llimona, the Desolation, and look up the stunning Principal Dome.When you leave, enjoy a bit the waterfalls, and the Magic Fountain-show, or no show. Looking up from Placa de Carles Buigas to the Museum is a very impressive sight.
Excellent attraction on Montjiuc. Well worth a visit if you like museums. Great views of Barcelona and Placa D'espanya and the Magic Fountain. Also not far from Fundacio de Miro

Nice Museum, and free on Saturday after 3pm. It is not a huge museum like many others I visited, therefore I only needed to spend a few hours here to actually see everything that had to offer. It has modern art, Renaissance, gothic art. The venue is extremely beautiful.

It just keeps giving.. There are two great views to be had with the MNAC. The one of the City from the top and the one of the MNAC from the bottom. Take the hop on hop off, ( hoho ), tourist bus to the MNAC. Visit the Museum and then walk down the steps, past the 'Magic Fountain' to the Placa d'Espanya. Here you get the view of the MNAC in all its glory and here you can re-join the hoho bus.The MNAC has a whole smorgasbord of art with something for everyone. You can feast on it all day or nibble a bit here and there for a few hours.The 'Magic Fountain' provides illuminated displays at dusk on the weekends.Top Tip. Check out the MNAC website for the Magic Fountain display times.

A collection of treasures beautifully presented. If you are an art lover and you have even a morning to spare whilst you are in Barcelona then you should visit this museum. It houses a truly wonderful collection of art, from early Mediaeval period right through to, virtually, the present day. It would be impossible to see it all in one visit, a dozen visits wouldn't do it justice. Select the period that most interests you and head for it. You won't be disappointed. The early Gothic and Mediaeval galleries are magnificent. Everything is beautifully displayed and well spaced. You will want to return.

A Terrific Museum!. I spent over four hours here the museum is so packed with fascinating exhibits!Firstly, the Romanesque frescoes - these have been rescued from remote churches all over Catalonia to prevent them from deterioration, pillaging & vandalisation. Apses & arches have been especially built to reconstruct how these frescoes would have looked in situe. Wonderful & amazing. Then there is an extraordinary & extensive collection of Gothic altarpieces. The modern collection is good too introducing me to a number of Catalan artists with whom I was unfamiliar, along with works by Gris, Dali (including some interesting early realist works), Picasso & Utrillo. One of my favourite works is a pun on a Gothic altarpiece by Julio Romarez de Torres entitled "Tableau of Love". This altarpiece only has figures of women including two large (in your face) female nudes! The artist has a wonderful sense of humour! ( I wonder how the Church received this work?)The main restaurant was closed for a private function the day I visited but the cafe off the main hall was quite good. The museum is free for those aged over 65 years (proof required). Highly reccommended!

Outstanding view building and art. Spent most of a day here. Definitely a must do in Barcelona. Great art superbly curated. Building is also work of art. Auditorium at rear of building would be great for many things including Basketball. Beautiful construction.

Amazing . I live in NY and know great museums and this one is amazing It requires time but its definitely worth it. There is so much to see 4 different sections that overflow with art. The only thing for me was that the signs weren't in English I highly recommend the audio guideAnd give yourself a lot of time if you want to see it all and that's just the inside. The grounds are also very lovely so allow time to walk around

The views are amazing!. We were lucky enough to visit MNAC for a fashion show but the views of the city at night were hard to top! It's a stunning building of grand architecture and a must visit during your stay.

Absolutely a 'must visit'. . A great way to delve into the culture of a country is to visit a gallery or museum dedicated to the art of that country. This particular museum was absolutely wonderful to visit. We visited late on a Saturday afternoon. It was pretty busy but the building is so vast that you don't feel too hemmed in by your fellow tourists. Another plus - visiting later on Saturday meant FREE admission!!! Another must-visit. Do not miss!

Awesome Collection of Romanesque Cathedral Art. The Romanesque exhibit was phenomenal. They recreated the frescoes on the walls replicating domes and curves as in the original site! A great museum. Bought tickets at the entrance. Great view of Barcelona from entrance steps.

Beautiful. The view from the top is outstanding!!!! Looking down on the city of Bacelona. The journey up is also fascinating if you do not wish to take the stairs then they have escalators to take. the waterfalls are breath taking and they change colour at night.

Best thing to see in barca . This is one of the most impressive building I have ever seen. The view from the top are unberliveable, the fountains on the way up are lovely. The hight light of my hoilday visiting this place was lovely.

The view. A cool spot to chill at and relax. At the top of the stairs there is a nice view of the Catalunya city sprawl, grab a ice cold beer off a vendor find a seat, relax and take it all in. Hopefully the fountains will be putting on a display :)
Wow! . We attended a private gala dinner here the last night of our stay. The museum is breathtaking but a lot of steps. The architecture and frescos are spectacular and not to be missed
Very interesting museum with a view. This museum is worth a visit! It has a variety of exhibitions like modern and European paintings, Art Noveau ect. Nice views over the city from Parc Montjuik!

A great view of the city and an excellent meal. I ate at the restaurant in the evening and the views were fantastic, the food and service was equally as good. The location is spectacular well worth a visit

An amazing collection, beautifully displayed. The grand structure of the Museum is enough to invite you in for a look, and those who love art will not be disappointed. The displays are carefully arranged into the Romanesque, the Gothic, the Renaissance and the Modern periods. The Romanesque section displays a large number of decorations reclaimed from the naves of some of the more ancient churches in the region that had been abandoned and were in danger of destruction. Many of these pieces are exceptionally lovely, and you'll find yourself congratulating the technicians who reclaimed them. The Gothic period includes many excellent representations of religious art of the period, most by local artisans who employed similar methods of depiction of religious figures and selections of subject matter. It was most interesting to compare the depiction of the same events by different artists. The section representing the Renaissance period goes further afield, including non-Catalan artists such as Tintoretto, Lucas Kranach, and many others. I was particularly taken with the one Canaletto view of Venice, one of his best. Didn't get to the Modern section due to time limitations. For anyone who enjoys art, this is the number one museum in Barcelona.
nice museum. really liked the museum, very well organized - great views from the top of the stairs, good value for the price

4 Stars for Location and Outside of Museum 5 Stars for the th Big Picture. Let me preface this with the fact that this rating is for the exterior and location only. We did not have time to enter but if you like museums, we are told this is a good one. We loved climbing to the steps in front of it. You get to experience the amazing plaza below, the magic fountain, the huge columns, and an amazing view. By the way its free to experience this and just sit and take in the view. Nice place to pack a lunch.

Don't miss it.. As,soon as you get off at Placa Espanya. In front of you will be this magnificent building. Take in the sights that were built for the 1929 exposition and walk towards the museum. Don't fret about the stairs , there are escalators all the way up. Once inside. You will meet with Roman esquire and Gothic art. On the 2nd floor you will find modern pieces. We wish we could have stayed longer but we visited on Sunday it closes at 3 on this day. Remember, museum is closed on Mondays

Impressive Museum. We weren't originally planning on visiting the museum, but am glad we did. I was quite impressed not only with the art, but also the building. The restaurant on top was very expensive, but good.When we arrived I asked if there was a "senior" discount. We were told if we get senior rates in our home country (US), then we would also get it here - FREE!

Interesting. I am not an art connoisseur by any stretch, but I was impressed by this museum. It was not crowded and offered a variety of regional art. Lots of religious artwork.
This is a great stop on a walking tour of all the area gardens and Olympic area.

Gorgeous Building and area. I was with an art group to look at the Romanesque work only, so didn't view the rest of the collection. The Romanesque work including the frescoes, statuary, altar pieces etc. are astonishing. I didn't think I would care for the work since I prefer contemporary art, but with a good tour guide who explained the history and meaning of the work, it was fascinating. The building is also beautiful, and the terrace out front, views of the city, and magic fountain are lovely. The only negative was that it was very crowded, and the museum allows cheapskate souvenir vendors to hawk their wares on the steps. Finally, we also had lunch at the Oleum restaurant which is upstairs with an even better view of the city, and it was very nice. I have reviewed that in "restaurants".

Amazing frescos, avoid the saints. This is a must on your BCN itinerary, it's in the Articket passport. It's absolutely worth it, so I will just point out our problems on the day.1. If you go up on the bus Route 150, you will get off on C l'Estadi, and there will not be adequate signage to the MNAC: you can't get in from the back, you must go all the way round to the entrance looking over the fountains all the way down to Av. Reina Maria Cristina to Pl. Espanya.2. Food choices are tough: the terrace for coffee and pastry, the very expensive restaurant upstairs, or the cafe/resto in the giant exhibition hall. The cafe has prewashed shrink-wrapped disgusting food, the resto has overpriced not wonderful food. Maybe bring a picnic?3. The frescos rescued from the old churches are amazing, you will feel like you are in the church sometimes. After a while you travel back and get a feel for walking through an almost thousand year old church, very moving. BUT, then comes the overwhelming and confronting repetition of saints being tortured, in the painted alterpieces. Interesting to identify each saint's story by the repeated scenes and type of grisly death depicted, but we become sickened by it and moved on. Presumably, Christians in their local church would get used to only one or two saint-mutilation/death scenes, but in a museum, there are too many to cope with. Ah, religion.5. On the plus side: you get another ticket for a return visit, so you split up the ancient/mediaeval art on one day and come back for the Modern another.
worth the climb. beautiful architecture, stunning views and chance to just sit and look at the city. Mind the hawkers and the more nasty scammers that frequent the top of the escalators.

MUST. You MUST go there during your visit in Barcelona. From Placa Espanya to the museum, the path is really really beautiful and great if you love photos (great view included). Yet if you are not an art lover, you might find the museum kinda boring; don't miss the view though.

Free for Retirees. Viva Las Julbialdos! We got in free because we are retirees. Worth a visit, especially for the murals that were removed from Romanesque churches in Catalonia. Beautiful building with stunning views.
Highly recommended!. A beautifully laid out gallery with a fantastic collection & the views from the roof terrace were amazing. Would defiantly recommend it!
Beautiful sight. Well worth just even walking around the grounds. We didn't even go inside but loved taking the time to just sit and relax.

sure it's good if open. Went on a Monday in October and it was closed. A shame cos its a magnificent building and nice grounds. From the outside we had great views of the city, and the converted bull ring.
Museum visit. We thought we would spend an hour at this museum, but instead spent the entire afternoon. Amazing collection of Romanesque art plus art for all periods after through the 20th century.

A must-see in Barcelona. Amazing collection of local art. I particularly enjoyed seeing the way they have saved many of the frescoes from otherwise crumbling churches- they found a way to lift off the frescoes and have built curved frameworks into which to re-create exactly how these were found. It is like walking into the churches, but inside the museum, and that was just one wing of this museum.

Well worth the visit. Building is spectacular both outside and in. Lots of different exhibits and surprised by extensive Medieval Gothic Art collection. Need two to three hours to view the museum. Well located of Metro station and will be impressed by the walk to the museum as pass the magic fountains.

Just a short train ride and well worth the time and effort. As i was going up on a glass outdoor lift i could see this stunning building with waterfalls in the distance and thought i must see that, there were escalators to take one up and down also the veiw was spectactular.I did not get in to see the Museu as it was closed for the night.

Find yourself here on a free day. An excellent collection of art that comes from the hundreds of hard-to-reach chapels in the Pyranees. There are free days, so be on the look out for when. Walking here from Plaza Espana, then heading up the backside to Castell Montjuic is a wonderful day.

Great Museum. This is a great museum to give you a feel of Barcelona and the Catalan area, the museum is divided up into various sections covering Medieval Romanesque art through Gothic, Baroque and modern art, with great views over looking down over the magic fountains. A great place for an afternoon.

Free pass at sunday afternoon. The view is just so good. this is how we plan, we go to there at about 4pm in sunday, see around the museum, there are lots of artworks, include Picasso, Dali, Gaudi and Miro..etc., and there is a cafe just in front of the gate of museum, you can take a rest, drink some beer, and see the amazing view at the same time, until night, it will be more beatiful!! it just so chill.

AMAZING DAY AND NIGHT. It was amazing experience to see the Museum and panoramic view of Barcelona city .weekly some days infront of the Museum have beutifull water fountain show.If u are not visiting this show it will be valuable loss for u

Take your time!. I spent a total of four hours at the MNAC. Armed with the audioguide you should be ready to go. When you are done with one section, you come back yo the central lobby where there are plush couches to rest your weary legs before you continue to the other sections.
If you have time . If you have time check it. Like other museum, you have to spend time in there which is worth it. But if you are going for short trip, not recommended.

Great place to visit. Can highly recommend a visit, so much to see & learn, Would recommend a good 3 hours to view everythingAlso the buildings surroundings have great views & the fountains/waterfalls are amazing

Amazing views on a sunny day. I came across this area on the bus tour. Didn't actually go inside the museum because spent quite a long time just appreciating the view. I went on a sunny day and everything looked brilliant you could see the building and city of Barcelona and some far away mountains in the background. This is a go-to place if you want to take good pictures and just appreciate the beauty of the city. Not far from here is a cable cart ride which I would highly recommend.

A Distinctive Cultural and Distinctive World. Visiting the museum, we understood why Picasso, Miro, Dali emerged from the XXth century european artists. Since a 1000 years, the catalan art has taken differents paths to bloom.

You can walk around the main floor and view the bldg for free.. We found the building to be more interesting than much of the artwork. You only need tickets to get into the galleries, so I would suggest walking around the building and going to the rooftop for the view.
Great view of the city from the entrance. I've always enjoyed the museum, its building and the collections. Though I found the content to be a bit limited but it's a must visit to Barcelona.

AMAZING!!!. This place it's a must see...everything about it it's amazing especially the views you get! I highly recommend if you have kids they can explore everything around while you enjoy the nice views

Wonderful Museum. My wife and I spent several hours at this museum and this time we spent it looking at modernist Catalan art. There is plenty of beautiful art in this section, including paintings, furniture and stained glass. The people working in the museum are very helpful too, and very friendly. The bookstore is terrific.

Two for One > delightful area & sights !1. See the Museum - the Magic Foundation & Miro museum !! An amazing afternoon - something you can do on your own time. A relaxing day and then eat & shop the night away :))

A palace masqueradng as an art museum. On my map of the Magic Fountain area are marked nine palaces but from a distance like the cable car from the Parallel metro station to Parc de Montjuic, it looks like a castle or a tenth palace. But of course it is an art museum (one covered by the Barcelona Art Passport) and a serious one. We didn't do it justice because we had a pretty packed itinerary for the day but we did spend an hour here admiring the various paintings. Obviously a serious art lover can spend many hours here.I recommend you take the funicular to Parc de Montjuic, then the cable car to the real castle (fortress) then return by the cable car to the Miro Museum which is a short walk from this museum, then walk down the cascading levels by the Magic Fountain to the Espanya metro station. That should occupy much of your day.

Great views and art. First of all, the view of Barcelona from this museum is AMAZING. My friend and I ate at the cafe right at the front of the museum and gazed out over the entire city. Even if you don't go into the museum, just make the trek up for this.The museum itself is also really nice. It's more traditional art is geared more towards religious art, but the recreation of the feel of old churches was very unique. We didn't really hit up the modern art sections, but the museum is worth going into.
Catalan surprise. Well worth a visit. Has some truly fine pieces. Good to see Spanish early modernists as French artists seem to hog all the glory these days.

Great option on a rainy day. Beautiful approach to the building from the Plaza de Espana with water cascades and fountains.The building itself is grandiose and offers beautiful views from the front porch. The Catalonian gothic art collection was particularly interesting although other collections were very good as well. Try to avoid eating at the restaurants in MNAC: they're both overpriced. You can go eat somewhere else before or even during your visit.
awesome view of barcelona. the building alone is great architecture. it offers the best view of barcelona from the outside. rate for the museum is pricey though.
Very impressive. Not all pictures have interpretation in English. When going again, I will take the audio guide option.

Fabulous museum and palau in probably the most beautiful part of Barcelona. We visited Parc de Montjuic which in itself is a truly wonderful outing, and topped it off with a prowl through this beautiful museum. We approached it from the top of the hill after visiting the castle, and had a beautiful walk down through lovely parks and lush greenery. We came upon escalators which we rode to the museum. It was a Saturday so entrance was free from 3p.m. and boy did we avail ourselves of that! No hassle, no queueing to get any sort of ticket. Come 3 p.m., just breeze in. I think you can hire audio phones which I would strongly recommend. We did not have much time so we just rushed through modern art and the renaissance sections, and took tiny peeks at others. The museum is huge and the building itself is so beautiful on the exterior as well as the interior.There is a huge pavilion in it's center which I thought to had been a ballroom seeing as the building is called a "palau". It was really splendid with beautiful ceilings and carvings, and I couldn't stop trying to capture every crevice on camera. Later I found out that it isn't a palace at all but an exposition pavilion. Grand!!! Another truly lovely aspect was that there was music and dance teachers willing to teach any one to dance (which further strengthened my conviction of it having been a ballroom).The facade of the building is absolutely lovely. There are huge cascades and fountains in front which lead down to the magic fountain, and to other sections of the Montjuic Parc, and then on to Placa Espanya.Do not miss this lovely musuem!

Please note Sunday Closing Times. Went to the Museu for lunch on Sunday afternoon. Paid admission for the museum, our reservations were at 1:00pm. Did not realize the museum closed at 3:00PM. Our mistake for not checking. The baggage check and museum close promptly at 3, we were only permitted to leave through a side door. All the fountains are turned off at 3 also. The restaurant is average with high prices, but great views. Sad to have missed the museum plus paying an entrance fee to gain admission to the restaurant was extra sad. Of course this was my mistake - the museum looked lovely and we enjoyed wandering through the park. The fountains were on when we arrived so that was very nice. Another reason to go back to Barcelona. Took a cab there as the neighborhood is a bit far from where we were staying.

We were late getting there and it was just closing. The walk up to it and the views are excellent. There are escalators through the gardens which is very good.It looks a wonderful building from the outside.
Good museum. Its a lovely huge art museum with stunning panaromic views. It was a rainy day but when it got dry it was still beautiful view.

Amazing. This place is amazing! So worth the visit and the money! You absolutely need o take the audio guide it makes all the difference. The ticket gives you access to the museum for two consequent days. This place is packed with art and information and requires many hours of visit. I strongly suggest to plan a two day trip where you visit part of the museum and enjoy the Montjuic scenery. Make sure you have space in your camera you ill take a ton of pictures.

Extraordinary !!. Incredible collection of medieval Art, fascinating rescue of murals from all over catalunya. Take the time to really view all exhibitions it's worth the time. Take also a tour to the top of the building the views of Barcelona are incredible.

Absolutely Beautiful!!. This museum could not be in a more beautiful spot. It is on top of a hill with fountains and waterfalls gracing the approach. The collection is lovely and well worth seeing. The interior of the building is also striking. The staff was friendly and all in all, it was a wonderful want to spend several hours.

Terrific regional art museum. This museum is definitely worth a visit if you have more than a day or two in Barcelona (just behind Sagrada Familia, Parque Guell, Casa Batllo and the Picasso Museum). The setting in front of the "Magic Fountain" is stunning and the museum lives up to the setting. We spent most of our time in the modernism section with Gaudí, Picasso Fortuny, and others. Beautiful art, lots of it, and nicely displayed. The hand crafted wood furniture alone is worth the trip. As we are here for a while, we are planning another visit to see the other parts.

Worth it just for the view. We just walked around the exterior and enjoyed great views of the city and the street musicians. Beautiful location and facilities. Probably even better if you go inside to see the art.

Large gallery set on top of avenue and steps.. Huge galleries of art divided into different decades. At top of many steps ( escalators not working when we were there) magnificent fountain and views over Barcelona fro terrace outside gallery. Some Gaudi furniture .there, and a couple of Picasso,s work. Restaurant there, looked expensive. Most people snacking on steps outside enjoying entertainers.
