Dont neglect to see the more modern paintings, the Impressionist and Naturalist art, the gifts shop, and sculpture are also very good, Youll enjoy this place!

Very interesting. As my husband is a guide in a local gallery this place was a must. Seniors (over 65) were allowed free entry. It was some amazing art and even the modern art was from the 1800's not like Australia. The coffee shop was very nice and so reasonably priced

An unexpected gem!. We didn't expect this 'regional' museum to be breathtaking, but it was. The collections of medieval and gothic religious works - from alter triptychs to recovered frescos and paintings by classical artists - was remarkable, and unique in our experience. The modern art section is also impressive. As a whole, they underscore just how the Catalonian region was in generating and promoting European art.The collection is spread out throughout a large (neo-classical) building, so there is adequate space to take hoards of tourists without claustrophobia. There is good description adjacent top many of the works, so novices like us were able to get good information and insights into the artists/craftsmen and their works. We expected to spend two hours there and ended up there the whole day.Thoroughly recommended.The building sits on a hilltop with great city views. There are a couple of good eateries in the building.

Fantastic views of the palace and centuries of exceptional art. My jaw dropped when our cab dropped us off in front of the great fountain of this imposing palace of art. The series of fountains leading up to the palatial museum at the top of the hill was stunning. I would have been contented to just walk up the hill and see each segment of these beautiful fountains but my wife was hoping to see the actual museum and artwork too. I am glad she talked me into it because the collection of art here (like so many other museums in Barcelona) was fantastic. As I've said in some other reviews I was blown away by how well preserved/restored even the ancient Gothic art was. The layout of the museum is such that you can see the progression of artistic ability and expression in a seamless sequence. They also had some great examples of Renaissance and even contemporary art, what stands out in my memory was the collection of Civil War art and propaganda.Worth a several hour visit!

Exquisite!. The museu is really exquisite from the outside, with the dancing fountain and the greenery and the view from above. From the inside, I was not really impressed. I went there 2 times, once in the morning, and then I was advised to go one more time in the evening to watch the dancing fountain show, and I never regretted it! It was really really really impressive! If the time is tight and you need to go once, then shoot for the evening.
Luv Art. The artwork is setup according to either the period or style. The building itself is beautiful. You are able to have panoramic views of Barcelona.

Well worth a visit and stunning location. The location makes it worth a visit alone but the collections are fantastic, I only had time to see the Modern Art but if you are an art lover allow plenty of time to see them all. Many major masterpieces included and all items have an English description.
Awesome. The art collections and the building and grounds themselves are world-class. If you are in Barcelona make this a stop.

AMAZING COLLECTION - Medieval to modern. This collection spans the time from Medieval days to modern days. The art collection is truly inspiring. The Romanesque collection is amazing with frescoes from monasteries and churches throughout Spain and France. We then went up to the second floor where they house the Modern Collection.

Must stop museum. This was hands down my favorite museum in Barcelona. I mean the fact that it is located in the former royal palace is amazing. There are just so many great photo opportunities before you even see your first piece of art. The art inside is pretty amazing. There is just so much Christian and historic art with many interesting stories behind them. The museum is expansive and well organized. The end of the museum also has more modern, think WWII, art and really cool war propaganda photos.There is also a restaurant with a stunning view on the 2nd floor. You can also access the roof of the palace. This is placed off to the side and can be easily missed, you definitely need to spend a few minutes standing up there.

Really beautiful building. We enjoyed this area very well, and the buildings are very impressive. Lots of photo opps and places to sit and rest in the sun or shade. Didn't go into the museum itself, but just took in the views and area. Visit, well worth it.

Art and chill gardens. If you are an art freak, probably you wanna visit MNAC. It's the National Art Museum of Catalonia and there are lots of collections from different periods as well as activities. Although if you don't like art or u don't wanna visit the museum, you will see one of the best sights of Barcelona 'cause this museum is in a mountain. Also there are other museums around and a beautiful park to take a walk.
Free after 3, on Sat. It is a great museum to see the vast history of Catalan art, from the middle ages on. Very historic view of churches frescos and decoration.
rainy day. not so good for getting rainy that day. the outside view not so good but inside was enjoyable. not so crowded & good for spending 1-2hrs

A gorgeous place for Catalonian art,many reasons to love this place . Any reason to return to wonderful Barcelona will do, but a big one for us was for more time to visit MNAC after our first visit in 2012. What is there to love?1. MNAC spared no expense to modernize the National Palace. Airy, comfortable, perfectly lit2.Works of art shown at a rewarding and accessible viewing distance, as near or as far as it was intended to be seen.3. Great food from high-end eclectic Catalan restaurant, to low-cost small tapas cafe. Restaurant open late with its own entrance,for lunch and dinner, café in the center very comfortable, open all day 4.Outside, breathtaking view above the city. 5.Easy to get to by shallow (many) steps and landings or escalators up from street level or winding and strolling indirectly through Parc Montjuic. Or a quick cab ride up from Plaça Catalunya or Plaça Espana. **One reminder: be sure to take a flashlight/make sure your phone is charged, for lighting your way down if you intend to leave after dark.The only flaw we encountered: Not as brightly illuminated outside as it could be on the way down to the street..And the main attraction:I myself was used to Renaissance art, and not expecting to love this relatively "primitive" looking Romanesque work. But I was surprised at how quickly I fell for it-- such mysterious, austere, graceful, and even sophisticated work.Seems like an inspiration for many aspects of 20th century art and design-- use of pattern, illusion, line, shape.  Romanesque art should be looked at slowly and carefully, there is a mysterious order to the placement of color and line. In situ: museum faithfully recreated alcoves, pillars and archways simulating basilica and vaults of churches where these works were originally discovered in the early 20th century in rural Catalonia. Authentic viewing experience of the scale, shape, and position of the art and sculptures as they were meant to be seen.. . The museum also has some odder looking cast-off works from early and middle Spanish Renaissance--the direct opposite of the Romanesque-- ornate, dramatic, somewhst overwrought, heavily decorated with gold, strong colors, and multiple patterns, figures, and layers of angels.. an entertaining counterpoint to the austere earlier Romanesque works.

Go on a Saturday after 3pm - it's free! . I really enjoy walking around this museum. It's in a beautiful spot with amazing views. The museum is nice and cool and very clean, with plenty to see. I would recommend going on a Saturday after 3pm as it's free (I wouldn't have paid much for it). Plus there's the 150 bus which takes you from there all the way up to the castle and back to Espanya

Here you will find the finest pieces. Including some of the famous paintings of Dali and Picasso (which you will not find at the Picasso museum). A very modern and up to date museum. Remember the audio guide

A TREASURE!. This museum has it all.....beautiful outside.....beautiful inside! The architecture of the entire building, inside and out is gorgeous, rooms are bright, roomy in most cases with delightful high ceilings allowing light in. The art collections are varied offering Medieval-Gothic, Renaissance & Baroque, Cambo-Bequest, and a Thyssen-Bornemisza collection. Religious art is dominant in many rooms but to my thoughts, exquisite. There is a wonderful roof top viewpoint, a stunning auditorium and an art-education section and an 'interactive' informational area. The grounds are spectacular! The gardens, the amazing waterfall & fountains.....pure delight. A must if in Barcelona, and the nice thing, although it is very crowed outside, it is not inside, this place is often only taken seriously for it's outside beauty. venture in, you won't be disappointed......and it's free....and you can take photos.

Great art in a great location. A beautiful building in a beautiful location with a wonderful view. We took an unplanned stop off the tour bus to see the view, and decided to see the museum as well. Great collection of Romanesque frescoes and medieval religious art. We didn't have time to check out the modern art.

If you don't have time, skip it! The Picasso is way better. If you're in to religious art, then this museum is for you. The contemporary art section was interesting, but by the time I got there, I just zoomed by it because I had had enough of the art. The audio-guide was very basic at best, so I stopped listening when I got to the contemporary art collection.
National museum. This beautiful museum with its excellant architecture was once a palace with its beautiful landscaped gardens and breathe taking fountains a must see on a tour to barcelona

A stunning museum. I had always skipped the museum, just taking in the exterior views, but the collection is stunning. Plus, you can access the roof, which affords an even more wonderful view of Barcelona than you get from the front steps. Not to be missed is the rotunda and the amazing paintings, along with a show ring transported from a world expo. It's an amazing space, with an impressive pipe organ.

NIce museum to walk through. The only museum of the 6 free ones of the Artticket that I found really pleasant to visit. Large, great diversity, nice rooms, and not so crowded, and taking pictures is allowed.
Don't Miss this Museum. Spectacular Museum. The Modern section is arranged by photo themes across the ages-- amazing way of looking at the evolution of art.
GO check it out. From the top you can see the part of the city. Its a long walk but worth it. This museum is closed on monday so does all of the museum in barcelona.

The most amazing collections. Huge and well signposted, the collections here cover all Catalonia's art history from the earliest times. There also several private collections donated or visiting. Plenty of space around for strolling and other museums within easy walking. One of the prime stops o the Tourist Bus circuits.

Lovelly building. Stumble on here by chance after seeing it from fountains below. Wish we had booked a meal in the restaurant. Once again watch out for the thieves, they walk about with aplomb and can only be fined e400 so its worth their while we had a number of attempts by blocking us in just shout and draw attention to them

Our regular place of pilgrimage.. Every time we visit Barcelona we go to MNAC to see the Romanesque Frescoes from Taull and the surrounding area - we would not miss the experience for anything. This year we discovered a rooftop walk-way that offers a 360 degree view of Barcelona and can thoroughly recommend it.
brilliant. Close to our hotel. Amazing views and the Magic Fountain (Thursdays to Sundays) was great to watch. Didn't go into the museum but soaked up the views instead.

A marvellous collection and beautiful building. A taxi ride took us to the bottom of the elevators and the slow ascent increased our expectation of what we had been told was a marvellous building and wonderful view. We were not disappointed. The 3 distinct collections were excellent and very easy to walk around. The inside of the building was beautiful and full of surprises like the indoor decorated arena. Our only disappointment was not being able to have lunch in the lovely restaurant as it looked over the terrace and the magnificent view of Barcelona. We walked back to The Ramblas downhill through a beautifully shaded park and then tree lined streets stopping off for a drink at one of the many outdoor cafes. It is definitely worth a visit.

NIce museum with a great veiw of the magic fountain and a nice location down from the fortress.. A very interesting exhibit was there during my visit- and there is a lot to see in the whole of the museum. There are nice tables and chairs outside to stop, have a snack and glass of calvo that I recommend. The restaurant is not open all day and the café inside is clearly a...café.

Excellent museum in a beautiful location. Great museum with an impressive collection of art (from medieval to modern). The building itself, the park with fountains - everything is beautiful. A wonderful place.

View from the top steps of Barcelona. a ways out of downtown but a cab or bus gets you back. We walked to the hotel and it was about 45 minutes.Outstanding displays, beautiful location. There are often events held on the grounds oin fron the the museum

worth seeing for fountains. The outside is impressive! It's nice that the altar pieces and frescoes from a lot of old churches were saved but there are so many, it becomes repetitive. Liked the modern collection but wish they had more Gaudi pieces. It's better arranged, basically 3 sections, than the art galleries where you feel lost and trapped but there was also a massive unused area. It has 2 restaurants & the area around looks more like a business district without places to eat; however, the metro at the bottom of the fountain area offers the possibility of other options.
Beautiful Barcelona. Stunning! Must see when in Barcelona. Barcelona is a beautiful city in Spain. Very clean and the people are very friendly. Don't miss Gaudi buildings.

Great museum in a great location. We decided to go up to Mont Juic on our last day in Barcelona. If you get the Barcelona Card, the Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya - MNAC is one of the free museums. It would be worth the price, regardless.The art collection runs from the 13th Century to the mid-20th Century. A huge collection of Gothic paintings, sculptures and altarpieces are what drew me in, but the Modernism collection was wonderful. Of course I've seen many of the styles and themes of Gothic and Renaissance art, but I didn't really have a sense of Modernism.The Museum is really well set up, directing your path from one room to the next. Also, there are explanations at the beginning of the new sections, giving you a sense of what your going to see. In the Modernism area, you'll see not only paintings and sculptures, but quite a bit of furniture. This being Barcelona, they had a lot of pieces from their favorite son, Antoni Gaudi.Besides the collection, the building and it's location are one of a kind. Once you get to the top, you'll have spectacular views of Barcelona below. And on your trip up from Placa Espana, you'll pass the Magic Fountain. We missed it, but the fountain dances to music on some nights. Like many other areas we've visited, there are some talented buskers setting up some nice soundtracks. As we were walking out, a keyboardist was playing "Eres Tu" a 1973 hit from the Spanish band Mocedades. The younger crowds, like my kids, remember it from the movie Tommy Boy,All in all, a great experience.

Art housed in more art!. I visited on a Saturday when there is no entrance fee. The building itself is beautiful. I found the exhibits to be interesting even though am not an arts person, plus you can get wonderful views from the top. Close to the magic fountain so you can end your day with a good show.

Well worth the visit. Allow at least two hours, fantastic collection, well presented in a beautiful space. Wonderful position on Montjuic, go up to roof terrace for good views over all over Barcelona.

interesting museum. some stuff inside are pretty weird and disturbing!! i would recommend to anyone exploring around. this museum is part of the 5 museums to get to visit when purchasing the art ticket

Amazing and beautiful place. For my first trip in Barcelona, visited Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya - MNAC... I had heard many stories about, before visited. Was a wonderful experience! Beautiful places as position, atmosphere and full of art and culture.If you go to Barcelona, you have to see. I recommend

Must visit for art lovers, or just come up for the magnificetn view of Barcelona.. Great setting, great huge museum, with marvelous art from Catalunya. Lunch outside overlooking the city, then stroll the trails nearby, often shaded, to other museums and sites.
Art-Wonderful. A brilliant space to marvel at art and let the imagination wonder with you around the museum. Calming, relaxing, better than an hour of yoga ;) One of my favorite places in Barcelona.

Sadly didn't have time for inside tour but worth going for the views.. We took a glorious walk up through the well-maintained park to this impressive building but didn't have the time to view the art collection, Did have an expensive freshly squeezed orange juice on the terrace with its marvelous views over the city - only slightly marred by the number of tourists who kept standing in front of our table to take their selfies - don't they realise how ridiculous the selfie stick makes them look? Nice walk down past the water features and fountains to the nearby Plaza Espanya.

split our visit over two days. its was raining so obvious choice was to go to the museum, once we arrived and scanned our bag, we were handed stickers and tickets for a second day! didnt know that was an option, so a nice bonus to break up the meseum into two days, once youre in grab a free locker and put your stuff away and start exploring. we did the ground floor the first visit, and came back a couple days later and did the second floor, each time we spent about 2 hrs which was good and prevented us from getting MLS museum leg syndrome

Excellent Romanesque Frescoes, Beautiful Views. Many of the guide books give this museum relatively short shrift. After La Sagrada Familia, I'd put this number 2 on my siteseeing list. The collection of frescoes is very well done. They've reconstructed the inside of many churches to display them. The view from all around the roof is incredible. Everywhere else we went was mobbed with tourists, and perhaps the best part was how quiet this museum is and a wonderful escape from the selfie-stick hordes!

Worth a full day of your visit to Barcelona. This is a national treasure. The walk up to the palace is spectacular affording beautiful views of the city. The interior is divided into areas by era. Wonderful works from the renaissance to contemporary artists are well displayed. There is a lovely restaurant on the premises as well.
If you like art, you have to go. Go to their website, I went on a Sunday and it was free ( I think they do it once a month). It is in Montjuïc and it's just beautiful.
No English. All of the art in this museum were in different languages and you would be charged more for audio tours not overalls worth it
Great place. This is a very large place with lots of things to see. Give yourself at least 1/2 a day to explore it.
Ancient Spain. So fascinating to see glimpses of the city beneath the city of Barcelona. Always amazed at what they can tell us about the way outer ancestors lived a thousand years ago.

Worth it for the views and the grounds. As art exhibits go, it was so-so. But an amazing building, beautiful views and grounds. It was worth it, but be prepared for the hike up the hill. And here's a tip. Tickets are good for two days. So if you're traveling with a group or meet up with friends, you can split the cost and use the tickets over two days. We handed ours to a family at our hotel. Hope they used them. At least we tried to play it forward.

Great museum. It's a great museum, I'd highly recommend. I'm not an arty person but it was still worth the visit. My travel partner and I spent an hour or so, so take that into account when you're planning your trip.

A chance to see world's finest collection of Romanesque Frescoes. This is Catalonia's grand central museum with a wealth of artistic treasures. It sits high up on one of the hills overlooking the city. There was so much to see that we had to make the difficult choice to see only the collection of Romanesque frescoes, alterpieces and wood carvings. Mose of them had been rescued from chapels in the Pyrenees during the 1920s. There was a good display explaining how the process had been carried out. We had a lovely lunch in their restaurant with wide views of Barcelona in the valley below.

art museum. The grounds are beautiful. I enjoyed seeing the art work but I only had two hours and I apparently missed the famous murals? So I will have to go back someday. I like to look slowly and carefully at paintings.

Time for some historical artifacts!. I was pretty exhausted when we visited, the weather was hot and the climb up the steps was a challenge but we made it into the cool of the museum. The museum houses some very, very beautiful religious iconography amongst its collection.We were able to take the lift to the roof and enjoy some fabulous views of Barcelona and towards the rear, Montjuic.
Wonderful Museum. This is a great museum showing Catalan pride. Gorgeous building with great arts inside, very works spending a little bit of Euros and some precious time.
Wow factor . This was a hit during the day there, the view was stunning, the people in Spain are simply beautiful, friendly and helpful. I want to move there.
AWESOME!. you need to check this one out! me and my girlfriend went to barcelona last year on 2014 and this museum is just beautiful!

Wonderful Art and Views. We walked from the train station up the beautiful, park-like plaza to the museum. Thankfully they have installed escalators outdoors to assist with the climb up the hill. The water fountain and view from the front of the museum are beautiful. The collection of medieval frescoes is overwhelming. There was a dance contest taking place in the center of the museum providing us entertainment while we dined at the cafeteria. Be sure to visit the fine dining restaurant on the upper level that appears to be open for catered events.
Saturday afternoon free entry. Great way to look at Catalan art. Beautiful modernist section. Excellent views over Plaza Espana towards Tibidao. Free entry Saturday afternoon.

Impressive. Majestic views over the city from this magnificent building. When I first saw it I thought it must be the parliament building orn something but it's an art gallery. And of course there are the famous fountains.

Beautiful site all around. This huge museum is located high on a hill beyond Placa d 'Espanya. When approaching the site, your eyes are greeted by massive fountains and waterfalls along the kilometer it takes to reach the building. My first reaction was joy just to walk along the avenue... Once past the array of fountains, the approach to the museum is still magnificent to experience. There are many, many stairs, or outdoor escalators if preferred, moving up the hill past an enormous waterfall and garden area. From the front of the museum, you can see many miles of Barcelona! The museum itself is grand, a very large, stately building meant to impress when it was built in 1929. We visited the more modern arts second floor, and were very impressed by the pieces created during the Spanish Civil War, which conveyed the solemn spirit of the terrible circumstances of the time. Note: the museum is free for seniors 65 years or older.

Very nice and a lot to see. The walk way up to the museum was spectacular. Inside, there was a lot to see, and afterwards, you can go to the roof to get more views of Barcelona. We really enjoyed this museum. Save ~2-3 hours for this one!

Decent not Great. Great exhibits of Romanesque and Gothic altar fronts. If you're looking for other types of art, they're lacking. Despite playing host to numerous artists, Catalunya's art museum is lacking their best works.

Amazing building and location. Wonderful views overlooking Barcelona from the rooftop terraceTapas menu lunch in the upper restaurant was delicious English audio guide would be worth it because there are no English descriptions
Comprehensive Museum. Medieval to Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque, Cambo Bequest, Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection. Great rooftop viewing area. Pricey restaurant. A great find.

good at day, better at night. The fountain show with the music was incredible. The lighting and the rise and fall of the water syncronized with the music was one of the nicest memories we will remember

Handbag stolen. Daughters handbag was stolen at the open restaurant in front of the Museu. Suspect catering staff. Moved chairs into shade to be told not allowed and member of staff came up and shuffled chairs back into sunlight. Bag was on a chair. Very clever, from right under our noses. Bus Turistic tickets were in the handbag. When we tried to explain to the next bus, they were not interested and would not allow us onto bus, even though we had proof of purchase on smartphone. Had to walk to TMB central office where we received replacement tickets after a long delay and without much sympathy. Really spoilt the day in one of the worlds most fantastic cities.

Thanks for help. I was at the museum on wednesday. A little seagull screaming for help from the the teras garden. The garden locked and i applied the management centre of the museum. So There are excellent staff and they help the seagull after the museum closed. İ have a return flight and i was concerned about him's health . Yesterday they sent me via e mail a the video that was seagull carrying outside . İam so happy to see his flying to the freedom Thanks to the special people from Mnac ..

The exterior and area around the museum are great!. We didn't go inside, but spent a lot of time taking pictures around this area. The steps leading up the MNAC offer some very dramatic spots for photos.

Definitely should visit at least once in a life time. Great building, great collections. Should really prepared whole two days for this museum. Do not miss the restaurant inside the museum, excellent overlooking view to Barcelona.

Remarkable preservation vision. The collection of artworks recovered from endangered religious buildings is remarkable. While my preference is for such art to remain in the buildings in which it was created, it is far better to have it preserved in such institutions than have it destroyed aka ISIL.

Nice and quiet, worht a visit. if you like art MNAC is a nice place to visit. Granted, Barcelona is filled with various museums, but MNAC doesn't get get easily crowded because of its size and it's a bit away from the main attractions in the core of the city. The tickets for it can be expensive if bought individually and they will depend on the shows and exhibits at the time of the visit. But if one buys a tourist pass for several museums at once, MNAC is often included and definitely worth a visit. The museum is also located on hill overlooking parts of the city so it's a nice place to walk to and just sit and enjoy the vies of the city or enjoy the various arts performed by local street artist.
Closed on mondays. We told tour bus staff we were going to visit mnac and even they didn't tell us it was closed so just beware. The mountain is beautiful anyway and the views are breathtaking
Big and impressive!. All the art we wanted to see in Spain was in one place here! From old old times to modern art. And it was free on the weekend we went there!

fabulous art, spectacular location. wander around the various galleries and gardens for a full day's worth of cultural sighs. I was' trapped' inside during fashion week, with the enviable view of a parade from the window of a gallery!

A must see. Fantastic building with great views over the city. They have an extensive collection from medieval to modern. They have recently reorganised their modern collection so it gives a more socio-political story of the art and place. There are two very good restaurants, the posh one with a great setting and view and the other one which has changed to a buffet service from it's previously excellent table service menu de dia. Worth going for the views from the verandas outside even if you don't like art. They also have special exhibitions sometimes of photographers connected to the city or locality.

Well planned to walk you through various eras of art. I mostly enjoyed the more modern era sections that walked you through the last 100 years of art trends and artists. It was smartly arranged with informative plaques about the period even without audio.

Great collection. Well placed museum at the top of the stairs looking over the magic water fountain and Placa Espanya good view from entrance but even better from the roof of museum. Inside this wonderful building is an extensive collection of Catalan historic and modern art. If you enjoy art don't miss this museum. Price is good value.

Just the exterior is worth your time. Easily the most majestic and royal building of Barcelona. built in a grand palaciql style with fountains at different steps, large columns bell towers and some shaped central hall, the exterior itself makes for great views and photo sessions. We heard great reviews of the museum but did not have enough time - u need two hours plus, so had to regrettably skip it (12 euros pp). You can walk to it from Placa Espanya. Montjuic also has some lovely gardens and hills. The colourful magic fountain starts at 9pm from Thursdays to Weekends and an ideal itinerary would be to reach Montjuic in the afternoon/evening take aome snaps of the exterior and start seeing the museum from 5/6 pm followed by relaxing near the fountain when you come out. We were there during the weekdays and had to miss both.

A top flight museum. This year we focused on the modern wing as it was closed last year. Wonderful. Thoughtfully organized and a delightful visit. The entire museum is worth the time, don't miss anything even if it means multiple trips.

Breathtaking . Stunning building, fabulous views and really powerful art. I was expecting to be so moved by the Middle Ages art but it was mind-boggling what they have done to preserve it. The museum itself has build all these arches to recreate a church environment, it's so cool. Wasn't that impressed by the modern rooms, Paris and London has far better collections. Great use of 3D and digital at various points around the museum.

Great building housing some interesting displays. We only had a whistle stop tour of the museum - and visited the renaissance and modern art halls. The modern art was - as you might image - more or less turned over to the Modernistas - principally Antoni Gaudi, and there is a great variety of his work inside, from gates and doors to chairs. There was also a photographic exhibition of Gabrielle Casas work on when we visited which gave a glimpse into early 20th century Barcelona. Lots more to see in this vast museum if hyou have the time.

Best museum in barcelona. Not only is this an amazing piece of architecure, but the collections are definitely worth a visit. The views from the rooftop are breathtaking, with the plaza d'espana and its gorgeous fountains laid out before you. The inside of the museum is a marvel of old blended with the modern and the medieval art is spectacular. Just a short walk from there, you can also visit the Miro museum, which in itself is worth a trip. buy a Barcelona museum pass to get the best deal.

Amazing reservoir of beauty and sensuality, let alone spirituality.. On a hot day, and its Barcelona after all, its great to be drawn back into paintings created centuries ago. There was a moment in the baroque when the spiritual gave way to the secular and the artists painted what was around them. Besides the landscapes, people, furniture there is my favourite artist, Juan de Zurbaran's whose works are so filled with latent sexuality that they border on the erotic. Barcelona landscapes look familier because we walk past the same spots depicted on the canvesses . El Greco masterpieces are worth slowing your gait for to check out their serene intricasies, as well as those of Ramon Casas. Its easy to see the progress of the city through those painting, a city that;s always charming. When we have finished craning our necks, we sit on the steps and watch the last light of the day play on the hills beyond and the city of Barcelona below.

easily the best musueum in Barcelona. If you like medieval art then this is a spot to spend many hours in. There are two sections that speak widely to Romanesque art and gothic art. Catalunyan artists were at their best in these two periods.The gothic collection ranges all over Spain -ARagon, VAlencia, CAtalunya is well represented. There are some outstanding altar pieces..The ROmanesque section is even better. 11-12thc frescoes . Amazing!!!
Gorgeous!. Amazing building and all the fountains in front!! Situated on Montjuic near to Placa d'Espanya with anazing views! Definitely worth a visit even if you don't want to go inside!

I don't understand art and it was great. And I'll probably never understand art. But its a great visit. The view from the top is amazing. The building is simply a beauty. The numerous artworks the museum houses is immense. More than I could handle in any given day. But the sheer amount of quality art in a beautiful museum is worth the visit.Just be careful about wandering around the neighboring gardens. They're labeled as 'Jardins' but they're really just run down parks.

A nice museum by itself, amazing building. The building its area are very, very impressive, and you can wander around the roof and get a good look at the surrounding area and the city. We visited in June and assumed they were ready for the season, but many displays and areas were yet closed, getting ready for July and August. Even the dining area was closed.From what we did see then, most of the art was pretty modern (19th century and after). We didn't notice too many world-known art pieces, but it was still enjoyable. We really liked what we saw, and if you're about to visit 1 museum in Barcelona, it should be the MNAC. The second one should be Picasso's.

Monumental. This is a museum little far away from the cit, but you can get there by bus. It depends what kind of temporary exhibiton they have, it is always high quality. The permanent collection is very good.

World class romanesque frescos + free for seniors. This is a beautiful museum and gives free entry for seniors! Their collection of romanesque frescos kept me fascinated for hours. Didn't even have time to visit the Gothic collection, which my husband said was equally wonderful. Don't miss the roof top terrace with its spectacular views of Barcelona.

Disappointed, only got to see the outside.. What I did get to see is a grand building, In-fact, I use the picture I took of it for my Facebook cover photo. We had planned to tour this museum on International Museum Day, when their website said it was free access. However, when we arrived, after making our way down from Montjuic Castle, it was closed. At least we were able to sit out on the front terrace for the beautiful view of Placa Espanya.

so much to experience, so little time. This museum is in a beautiful location, with a view to behold. The staff are very helpful, the rooms of art are very large, well lite and very clean. The staff is very helpful, and interested that you have a great experience.The hours are great, but there is never enough time to see all there is to experience.The moving sidewalk is an energy saver, very glad for the assistance with the distance from the street.An awesome view, great for pictures,and lots of places to sit and just enjoy the experience.The BCN card is a great value to experience this museum for free.Do not miss this one!!!

Very Good Museum. Well located overlooking Plaza Espana....a number of rooms devoted to Gaudi - worth going to. Also showcases a number of rooms which contain Pre-Renaissnace murals salvaged from mountain villages...
Go for the fountains. I didn't go inside the museum, the museum is known for its fountains and if you go you should go at twlight and wait till dark when all get's lit up...it's quite the view.
Magnificent place. Beautiful outside and in, a wonderful collection and seniors get in free. The grounds are amazing and the area is worth a walk. Escalators for the elderly or infirm.

Amazing - what a view. Get out of the bus / taxi whatever at Plaça d'Espanya - then look up from this circle to the top of the hill. A nice gentle walk through the twin Venetian Towers and up to the fountains and then finally all the way up to the museum. We never went in built the view of and from the museum are well worth the visit.

View of the City. If you don't have the time to visit the displays, take the time to move up the multiple landing areas and see how the view changes. I did this on a bright sunny day and it was well work the effort.No fee to enjoy the views. Museum has a fee to enter.

Pride of Catalonia. Many museums and galleries induce sensory overload by saturating the display space. Not here. This is a stunning collection but each piece has its own space and dignity. And its location overlooking Barcelona is imposing. A definite must see on a visit to this great city.

Elegant and Interesting. We have been to this museum a number of times as there is always something new to see. The location, high on the hill overlooking the city is worth the trip alone. There are always musicians playing on the steps and even before you enter the museum, the atmosphere of Spanish elegance has been set. The exhibits are well set out, taking you through the ages of Spanish art right to the present. Well worth a visit!

A Very Special Museum. The setting of MNAC is magnificent, high above the city looking down the grand avenue towards the Placa Espana. In the Romanti galleries are unique murals taken with impressive technology from ancient churches near the Pyranees.

Very well organised museum. In case you are confused by terms like Impressionism, symbolism, etc, here is a museum that will take you step by step through the various phases of art, beautifully displayed.

A very good museum to know the Spanish art.. It is a museum situated in a such a setting that it it self is an attraction.The art pieces are tastefully arranged.There are a lot of the .you have to walk a lot to see that are outstanding.If you are in for some days it is worth a visit.

'A Museum like you've never seen before'. Situated on Montjuic, overlooking Barcelona, located in the 1929 World's Fair pavilion, this is indeed, as the publicity says, 'a Museum like you've never seen before'. Including splendid reconstructions of Romanesc churches with carefully preserved frescoes, moving through the Gothic period and giving a whole floor to 'The Birth of the Modern Artist'--from the mid-19th to late-20th century. The signage, in Catalan, Spanish and English, is thoughtful and informative. We kept returning to it (three times in all during our 10-day trip)--this is helped by the fact that it is free to 65+, and even if you are under 65, your ticket is good for two days. The bookstore is a treasure trove; and there are usually several temporary exhibitions as well as the permanent displays. There are two cafes (one inside, one outside) and an upmarket restaurant. It's a lovely place to pause from art to sit on the steps overlooking Barcelona and just enjoy the view.
Lovely art collection. A fine art museum in a beautiful building, in a lovely setting. If you enjoy art it is worth a couple of hours of your time

It is huge. I could have used two days.. If you have a backpack, check it at the lockers. Keep your ticket with you at all times. You may be asked for it as you move through different parts of museum. We only worked through the older exhibits on the main floor. The place is huge. Wear good shoes. I enjoyed the exhibits on the bottom floor. They even have a video to explain how they safely transfer the paintings from the walls of churches to the walls in the exhibit. The explanations are in multiple languages..we did not take the audiovuide but felt like we had what we needed to enjoy the paintings and sculptures. If you like modern art go upstairs first. Since we enjoy older works we started at bottom floor and glad we did.

See BCN from the roof!. Actually we didn't look at the exhibition in the museum. We heared that you can go on the roof and walk around there and have stunning views of Barcelona. And it si true! We went up there with our baby in a stroller and it was fascinating. A must see! I would highly recommend the BCN artticket. You can buy it online and pick it up for 28 Euros. It includes 6 museums and you can skip the waiting line which is awesome! We bought it to see Miro and Picasso, and used it for the roof of Museu Nacional where you have a great view of the city!

Classic building with a great collection in a stunning location. Just outside of Placa De Espanya metro, up the hill (elevators for lots of it) with great views of the arena area, is this delightful gallery with some really great pieces.Its the right size for an afternoon visit with many important Catalan artists works on display. I'd have to say it was the best gallery we visited in Barcelona. Used our Arte Ticket and saved money on the entrance.

Great outside scenery limited collection. Great to look around this museum from outside but for 12€ plus €3.5 audio renting and €2.5 one small bottle of water I really don't think it is worth a visit. I am not an artist but so far the museum I visited this one has least collection of arts. I only saw one painting from Picasso and one from Dali etc.
Views over Barcelona!. The view across the city from here are absolutely wonderful. Go on a clear day and you can see for miles.
Lovely place. Had to go see the magic fountain, and then we found the museum. Beautiful area, with many view points, got some awesome pics there. Walk around and enjoy the art and scenery.

An amazing museum.. The location of the museum is quite stunning. Seniors enter free of charge. The rooftop views were amazing. We visited the Modern Art Gallery and were astonished. Picasso's exemplary draftsmanship was clearly grounded in whatever art school was in Barcelona at the time, as were countless other examples of wonderful draftsmanship shown in this gallery, none of whom we had even heard of. It was an amazing find. So enjoyable. If you like art, don't miss this.
Free admission for seniors. A wonderful museum for frescos and varied art.They also have a display for the evolution of money, very interesting.

Fantastic museum of Catalan art. We took the funicular from the Paral-lel station so we could walk down to the museum from the top of MontJuic, but you can also get there using the Espanya stop. This wonderful museum has excellent views from the roof-top terrace, don't miss it. A beautiful building with surrounding grounds, fountains and landscaping, excellent photo opportunities abound. A fantastic collection of classical and modern art mainly from artists that are mostly unfamiliar but excellent. The collection covers a wide range of historical eras. Well maintained and beautiful exhibits, although not everything is translated into English. I would allow 4 hours if you really want to delve into the collection. Highly recommended!

Amaizing collection. I visited the museum in the Special Night of Museums in Barcelona. The place in the top of a hill, the view, the collection ... Love it. I recommend it for those who love religious art.

Beautiful museum with a great views of Barcelona. The collection is good and beautifully exhibited. The view is nice because the 360 degree views that give one a good idea of the size and expanse of the city. Nice to know: Free admission for disabled persons with ID, persons under 16, seniors (+65). Check this important page on their website: http://www.museunacional.cat/en/opening-times-and-pricesI took the red tour bus up, stayed a little over two hours and hopped on the red tour bus again, which continues on down to the harbor and then back up to Casa Batlo and Casa Mila.

magnificent museum. The museum can be accessed by subway (exit Espanya on lines L1 and L3). Then you walk to wards Montjuic and climb the stairs to the museum. About 15 minutes walk.Buses, including the city tour buses all stop close to the museum.The location on top of Montjuic is lovely, offering both a beautiful view of Barcelona, ads well as a long walk in the hill to see several other museums and attractions.The museum buy itself is a massive and elegant building, with a large terrasse to access it and facing Barcelona.The collections of paintings and sculptures are not only interesting but also extremely well presented. Even though I rarely like the art style on display, I spent 2 hours visiting every room and enjoying the visit very much.There is a pathway going around the roof, accessible for valid and not valid people, from where you can enjoy a great panoramic view of Barcelona. If you are not valid, the staff at the ticket counter will guide you to a special access to the roof.

Fascinating. The approach to this building is worth the visit at least 400 metres of huge water features with this very imposing building on top of the hill. Free to visit with the Barcelona ticket and the ticket you receive on entry is valid for 2 days. Lots to see, footsore by the end.

Do not miss it!. We liked everything, including the lack of the long queues that afflict most of the Barcelona "casas" and other attractions. The Gothic art chapels are breathtaking and moving.... In addition, the restaurant on the top floor is a must for food and views. Do not miss it!

Worth visiting. The museum is up on a hill and you over look Barcelona..that in it self is enough to visit, but the museum had interesting art and history to view. I am not a big museum person but this was worth an hour in the museum and then walking around and enjoying the views after the visit. enjoyed the Flamenco guitar player outside the museum.

MNAC in May. Some interesting and beautiful works of art in different mediums. Remember your visitors free the first Sunday of the month. Super view over the city and the Magic Fountains from the terrace.

Beautiful Building. I love the outside of this building! So pretty and very impressive fountain show at night. It was pretty cheap to get in compared to some other attractions in Barcelona (12 euros). There weren't too many pieces that I recognized, but I would not call myself an expert, and I only got to see the modern art section. There were several other sections, but I just didn't have the time. I probably would have enjoyed it more if I had seen more art that I recognized, so a little research beforehand would have been a good idea.

Wonderful. We spent a great deal of time here and could have spent more. On our visit it was not overly crowded as were must attractions and we did not feel rushed. The exhibits are spaced nicely and easy to maneuver around. The views are amazing. The only drawback was the restaurant. We wanted to have lunch with that great view but the prices for simple fare were outrageous, I think you were paying for the view and it was pricey. I suggest going after lunch

One of the Top Attractions in Barcelona. Museums always feature in any trip we make to a city and this one in Barcelona is an exceptionally good art gallery. Easy to get to and well designed inside so that it makes it simple to navigate through the numerous exhibits.Fabulous restaurant inside the museum too, but cannot remember it's name.

MNAC. Beautiful fountains and landscaping in front of the museum. Took the metro to the Espanya stop. It is a walk to the museum with lots of steps to climb so not good for handicap people. The museum was very interesting with a lot to see. The first Sunday of every month a lot of the museums were free. Had a great singer by the steps in front.

Amazing. Usually I am sceptical about museums. Some are good. Some aren't. However, Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya was very impressive. They have an open area at the rooftop. You can sit there, take photos and see Barcelona from the top. Beautiful. Museum has many artefacts with incredible amount of detail in them. The artwork is impressive. I was blown away.

A museum with history of Jesus. This museum is near line 3 Espanya station. About 15 minutes walk from the metro station.You will need a audio guide if you don't understand Spanish. The rental is €3.50 per set. Divide into two section with one section more about ancient drawing on Jesus and another section is private collection of various artists. There is a roof top section where you can take a nice view of Spain.You can buy a from online a passport where you can visit all six museum (museu picasso, cccb, mac a, fundacio antoni tapies, Fundacio Joan micro and Museum national D'art De Catalunya) where you can have it chop and have it as a souvenir.
If for no other reason, go.... Go for the views. Simply spectacular to look out beyond the fountain and onto the city. The museum will let you in and direct you to the rooftop.

Absolutely unbelievable . Visited the museum when I was very young but I can still remember to this day how beautiful it was! Visited it during the day and the night and both were equally as mesmerising. In probably one of the most beautiful cities in the world, this has to be one of the main attractions that one needs to be seen in my opinion! At night the fountain is just something else. Highly recommend going for a look!

Wonderful place to visit. Beautiful building left over from the 1929 World Expo housed this great museum that featured a lot of salvaged art from churches and cathedrals that were no longer functioning but had a lot of great art that needed to be saved. Very impressive presentation and wonderful building to experience in and of itself.

Nice place to spend evening..... If you are looking to do some shopping and spend an evening then this is one of the best places to do so. There is a music fountain show takes place daily in the evening, but pls. check for timings before you plan. Grab some chilled beers and enjoy the show.

Gorgeous building, not overly stuffed inside. The building is beautiful and the view from the grounds is great. What's nice about the museum is that its collections are broken up into distinct sections and each wing is easy to follow and not chock-full. It's tasteful, but you can feel like you've seen mostly everything in under two hours.

Beautiful architecture from outside and still beautiful from inside.. Abbreviated as MNAC, is the national museum of Catalan visual art located in Barcelona. This is located near Placa Espana and is accessible via metro. The building is really beautiful from outside and during the evening the special lights make it come alive giving it a totally different feel. When there are fountain shows in the evening then this building has a halo around its central tomb. This building houses frescoes removed from roman churches in Catalonia; they are now protected in a proper ambient and in replicas of original churches. If you are an art lover then devote a full day atleast for this site.

Beautiful Museum. This museum is stunning with pillars and waterfalls. The atmosphere was so serene. We did not go inside the museum unfortunately but would definitely recommend going to see the waterfall/fountain.

This museum is not to be missed.. It is an absolutely beautiful building and the artwork on display is absolutely first class. The museum shop had plenty of prints and gifts to buy. Many different areas within the museum that you could chose to visit if that particular type of art was your interest.

Marvellous museum. MNAC contains frescoes detached from romanesque churches in Catalonia; they are now protected in optimum ambient and in replicas of original churches. Besides these there are important masterpieces of western painting including Tiziano, El Greco and Zurbaran. If you visit Barcelona but fail to visit MNAC it will be a real loss. Reserve at least half a day for it. If you have limited time don't worry; because the ticket is valid for two days.

Amazing museum in a great area. Getting off at the place Espanya metro station and making your way up to this museum is an amazing experience in itself and things get even better once you enter this spacious museum. The building housing this museum is very impressive but the artwork and the organization is simply amazing. From the early stone paintings of the churches in Catalunya to the paintings of modern artists, this museum is a wonderful experience. Plan to spend at least 5-6 hours at this place with a stop for lunch. The audio guide was helpful though some of the descriptions are too embellished for my taste. One of the highlights of Barcelona for me.

Lots of Great Art. This museum has a lot of really good quality old art / paintings. The modern art did not impress me at all and I was disappointed that there was only 1 Picasso in the entire collection. However, worth the money and time to view.

Great Art Gallery. This is a major art gallery, too big to go through in one day. There is free admission every Sat. after 3 pm and also the first Sun. of the month (whole day). Be prepared for a long queue.
Wonderful. We were there with my who loves art and he enjoy the visit very much, it's so big you need a least two days to see all the galleries.

Awesome . Absolutely do not skip this place when in BCN. It was a highlight of my trip there. I would recommend a solid 2 hours. However, IF YOU ARE SHORT ON TIME ONLY, do the following:1. Visit their Romanticism art as it has the best Christianity Medieval Art in Europe and arguably, the planet! Get the audio tour for 3,50 Euros. 2. Walk up to the rooftop terrace and take in the view, it is WITHOUT A DOUBT, the best in the city.3. Go to the "modern art" wing and pass all the artwork and go to the Gaudi furniture. You will see many items that were once part of Gaudi's buildings and definitely worth the look. Also, there's a fantastic Picasso and a couple Miro's that you will happily see on the way out. 4. When done, walk down the steps and walk back to Plaza Espana as it will offer many views of the ornate building and offers different vantage points and waterfalls and fountains you can only see when walking down. There are escalators if you can't handle all the stairs!So, that's my "highlights" review if you are crammed on time. If you have more time allotted, the rest is all gravy!Hope you enjoyed! You can't go wrong with what I wrote IF you only have a limited time (approximately 1 hour).

Great museum with superb location. This museum overlooks Barcelona. It is quite large and has some superb collections. I was particularly impressed by the romanesque art and by the "modern" art (which in this case spanned from the 19th century to our days). This was, in my opinion, the most interesting museum in Barcelona.

Lots to see. I love museums, but since I was visiting with family I knew my time would be limited. I only got to see the Medieval and Modern sections with a lunch break. The reconstructed fresco paintings were impressive, and the furniture in the modern section was a nice surprise. I would recommend looking at the website to make a list of galleries in order of preference if you have limited time as there is probably too much for most people to see in one visit. The cafe was ok for lunch. The view from the front of the museum is worthy of a ten minute sit to take in the elevated views of the city and cascading water feature. If you like art and museums its a must visit. If your not so keen on museums its still an interesting place to escape the rain/heat. I hope to return some day to see the rest of the collection.

Amazing, both inside and out. The outside is fabulous, with brilliant sculptures, excellent scenery and grand designs.The art inside is evocative of Catalonia and Spanish heritage; and is not to be missed.Combine with the location (next to the Magic Fountain) makes for a brilliant half-day out.

Beautiful building,Fountains,splendid views on Plaza d'Espanya. The most important part of the museum is on the first floor, the church-paintings of the 12-14th century. Removed fresco's from Catalan churches in the Pyrenees. On the rooftop you can walk around with splendid views.

Very good option to visit on Montjuic Park. Very complete (and good collection) to see of several art periods (mainly Spanish artists). Wonderful views as you arrived trough Spain Square and see the staircase, the Magic Fountain and the cascades leading up to it. Free with the Barcelona Card. Recommended.

Still great after all these years. Suggestion: let them know if you are a senior citizen and they waive the entry fee. The view from this museum is nothing less than spectacular of the city of Barcelona. By itself, it is worth the walk or the cab ride.For the mobility impaired, the museum is well set up with manned lifts at all stair areas. The staff seems to want to help.The museum portions that we were most interested in are on the first floor, primarily religious-related materials. The highlight by far is the 12-14th century church paintings which were obtained from Romanesque churches in the 1920s. The Catalans saw that their old church material was being purchased by dealers and taken from the area and country. The government purchased the frescos, had them carefully removed and transferred to similar walls in the museum, and the rest is a very impressive exhibition. It is as though you are walking into numerous small chapels to see the art. They also have some pieces from the 12th century on the crucifixion which are especially of note. The Madrid Thyssen (sic) museum has a large display of art there as well including works by Cranach the elder, Fra Angelico, Rubens, and, interestingly, Gainsborough.The second floor exhibit area contains more modern pieces.There is a good gift shop and an interior restaurant and cafeteria as well as one that has a the view.
Need to allow time to enjoy this as it costs 12 euros. Allo a good amount if time. Enjoy the gardens, fountains and Olyic area before finishing off in the gallery

If you go to one place in Barcelona.... Oh. Em. Gee. This just blew my mind. Walking up from the fountain below (which is impressive as is), this is one of the most beautiful buildings I have seen anywhere in the world. We had perfect weather, which added to the whole experience, and Mont Juïc generally is just beautiful, but this took the cake for me as the best place in all of Barcelona. Definitely take yourself here!

A good 3 hours of varied art.. Although we aren't really into art we both found the varied exhibitions here to be really interesting and were happy to spend 3 hours enjoying the art and furniture displays. A nice little snack bar and restaurant just off the main hall so you can have a break from the walking around without having to leave the museum. Looked to be very 'disabled friendly' with chair lifts to any displays not on the level. Reasonable value at around 12 Euros ea. Lovely views from the front steps across the city.

On top of the hill.. My wife and I walked the short distance from the Placa d'Espanya Metro Station in Barcelona passing through the two tall 'Venetian Tower' pillars along Av.Reina Maria Cristina up to the 'Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya' one sunny Saturday afternoon in April. Whilst you need to climb quite a few steps (there is an escalator for part of the way) to access the 'Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya' you will find that extremely pleasant views of this grand building together with the delightful 'Magic Fountain of Montjuic' which is located in front of this hilltop structure can be seen on your way up, and once you've reached the top of 'Montjuic Hill' you will be rewarded with fine views of the city.As the weather was so nice, we didn't go inside the museum as we wished to remain outdoors so as to enjoy the warm and sunny day - however it was nonetheless a great experience just to have viewed the exterior of this charming building together with its beautiful surroundings, and we were pleased to find that no admission charges were made for entering these lovely grounds. Well worth a visit if you are in this vicinity on a nice day.

Best art in Barcelona. We only visited the Romanesque section of the museum (the most famous). We spent three hours because the museum closed and they kicked us out.The collection is unique. It consists mostly of frescos salvaged from small churches in the Pyrenees and replaced on substitute arches and apses. The artistic quality is as high as any Christian art anywhere in the world, and while Gothic art is all over the place (in Europe) Romanesque art like this is rare. There are also wooden sculptures and carved stone capitals that will take your breath away.The museum is in a beautiful site (on Montjuich), is modern and well set up. My wife was in a wheelchair and the staff could not have been more gracious and helpful. Spanish/Catalonian charm at its best. The descriptions are mostly in Spanish and Catalan, so if you can't fake romance languages, you should probably get the English audio-guide.

Great, pity it's so hard to get to. The museum itself is fantastic, with a great collection of Modernisme furniture, some spectacular transplanted Romanesque chapels, and no crowds. The view outside is also very nice.However, it's really hard to get to - there are heaps of stairs between the metro station and the museum (only a small portion of the journey is covered by escalators), in addition to lots of stairs inside the metro station, so you'll probably need a taxi if you struggle with stairs.

Worthwhile. This museum has a phenomenal collection of pieces from 11th thru 15th centuries. The restorers of the many frescos are to be applauded. Not a modern art fan, I skipped that section. Loved seeing the 2 Goyas in person.

enjoyed it. I enjoyed this museum very much. We are english speaking and you do not have to rent audio - the explanations are written very well when you enter into each room. The museum sits up high on the hill, but there are outside escalators to get there - no fear!
It's OK. We went to this museum because it is part of a six museum package for €30. Not as good as other museums.

Worth the visit if you have spare time. Otherwise, enjoy it from the outside. They key to understanding this museum is that it highlights the art of Catalonia and remember the province was suppressed under Franco for decades. The restoration of the Romanesque frescoes should be appreciated. The collection of Gothic antiquities is impressive. I enjoyed the more contemporary and modern collection on the upper floors.Very few of the descriptions surrounding the antiquities are in English so get the headset if you're interested in learning. On a nice day, you have a beautiful view of the city from Montjuic. Closes early on Sundays and is closed entirely on Monday.Plan accordingly.

Astonishing and unique collection of Romanesque frescoes. Whole church interiors with 12th century frescoes are displayed in this museum, it's like nowhere else. They were peeled off the walls of their original locations intact, and are displayed as if still in situ. The rest of the museum is good but the frescoes are exceptional.
Very nice Museum. Liked the Clear thematic structure. Exceptional exhibits, especially on romanesque fresco paintings. No lines, no crowds

Building more impressive than exhibit.. This was built in 1929 but you would think more like the early 1800's. Beautiful building. But I have to say the exhibit was average at best compared to the world class art galleries I have visited.Watched the "magic fountain" later that evening which was delightful.

A must for Art lovers. Take the audio guide to listen to the stories of ancient Medieval art in Spain. The entire visit is worthwhile. The views form the top are breathtaking as is the walk around the outside of this fabulous art gallery.

Wonderful building and Vista - dont go on a Monday. Wonderful building. Dominates the entire local area. Parks are landscaped and escalators on each level as its so high. So easy for the physically impaired. We went on the Monday and the museum was shut, But enjoyed the views. Water falls were also not functioning so will visit again once the park is fully functioning and the museum is open.
Lovely space.. The modern art section is great. There is a nice, slightly snobby restaurant, on second floor with superb views over Placa Espanya. The walk up and down is easy.

Went for the View. We did not go into the Museum....after Madrid museums we wanted to be outdoors....perhaps on a second visit to Barcelona.The view from the Museum front terrace to the Plaza d'Espanya and the Barcelona views are worth the trip up Montjuic. The fountains and steps cascading down to the 1929 Fairgrounds and the Magic Fountain are beautiful.

Interesting exhibitions. One of the best locations just to walk to especially at night during the week-end, offers a varied selection of permanent and temporary collections. And the views to Plaza Espanya is stunning.

A must in Barcelona. A must when you're in Barcelona, lots of really nice and interesting works. Although I would recommend to take an audio guide/guided tour since a lot of info given on spot is only in Spanish.

Incredible, don't miss this. It was worth the entire trip just to see this magnificent collection. It is absolutely astounding how they've preserved so many pieces of the Catalune churches. If you see nothing else in the museum, go see the medieval churches exhibit (on the left side of the entrance). Wow and wow.

Not really that good. Actually I do not like arts and museum. Because of this I did not like this place.
The view from out side it is really nice and magic.

Brilliant place to visit.. Brilliant place to visit. A wide variety of art and history to see.
The views from the roof are stupendous. The history of the museum itself is interesting, it was built in keeping with the period of buildings around in classic style but actually only constructed in the early 1900s, near to the magic fountain. Well worth a look.

An interesting place, with an extraordinary view. As said in the subject, not only a museum, it is also a place with an extraordinary view. As museum, it is interesting because there are different galleries wich helps to select what you may enjoy most.
I fall in love with this place!. View of the Plaza de España incredible! Delightful sight. Beautiful waterfalls. It is a miracle among a large bustling city.

indescribable beauty. This museum-one of the main attractions of Barcelona. It is located in the center of Barcelona, ​​near the magic fountains. This building can be seen from far away, as it impresses with its size and beauty.Beautiful architecture, statues, fountains, huge columns, all this gives the building a museum indescribable beauty.You can climb to the museum on the stairs or an escalator, which we did :)Inside the museum did not come. Because there are arranged paintings, murals, books, numismatics, so we are not very fond of, so spend time on it does not like.In addition, it is the building itself is a landmark, not artifacts in it.Since the museum building offers beautiful views of Barcelona. And on the steps of his people sit when the show the show magical fountains.
Outstandin. Wonderful exhibits. The building alone is worth the trip. Make sure you eat at Portonovo Silvestre after. Soooooo good!
Terrific Art Museum. There is so much to see. Give yourself at least 4 hours and enjoy the different areas of the museum.The red bus route takes you to this museum.
Fine examples of Catalan Art.. A good museum where masterpieces from different ages. The museum is huge. To bypass all take a long time.
Great Building. Great building, just in the centre of the city. in front of the most memorizeable place Plaza Catalunya. Best view in the night with light but still amazing in the daytime.
wonderful mosaics. These are some of the best 900 year old mosaics you can see. Also a nicely interpreted modern art exhibit. Like a little history lesson. And what a cool palace.

Grand building and grounds, Very interesting Gothic art presentation, Good Art up to current day. The walk up to the museum is very impressive and done on a grand scale. The technical presentation of the Gothic Church paintings is excellent. Taking/peeling the paintings from old churches (ruins) and putting it onto surfaces to simulate the actual interior of the churches is really interesting and well done. The Spanish impressionist art on display is enjoyable. Some of Gaudi's designs are also on display. Notable that there is only one Picasso in this museum. The view from the roof of the museum is very nice too.
centre of art. Tickets give you two days and you will need both. Well laid out and very informative. The fountains outside are beautiful and the park setting lovely to walk around.

Stunning, One of a kind. prepare enough time!. I been to many museum around the world, but this museum still keep me thrill. Many many unique and most stunning piece. from gothic to contemporary. If you love art, idea, design, beauty, may be u need 2 days to visit. Good news: the normal ticket is 2 days covered. and on Sat after 3pm its free. Apart from being inside the musuem, the palace itself is beautiful. up on a hill with escalator bring you up. you will enjoy the palace and barcelona city from top view. And the buffet restuarant inside the museum is very nice around 14 Euro. But if you want to enjoy superb dinner view the restuarant on second floor the price is a bit higher but you definitly got superb whole city view.Definitely come back if I visit barcelona.
Perfect. Museum and the around is perfect. Try to finish the visit at closing hours so you can watch the magic fontain afterward if its friday or saturday.

Even the staircase up to the museum is an event. Amazing structure, not too expensive. I was intrigued by the history of coins. Terrific architecture and views. A variety of art works, and an inexpensive cafe under the dome. Take a walk around the inside and outside of the roof. Great views.
Great view. Never went inside but the outside is really worth a visit. Beautiful building and the area around is well worth a visit to walk around.

Superb place for art lovers. Beautiful place. Museum is devided according to different art trends, although they run some temporary expositions. Check their site, they have differens days and events when you can enter for free.Even if you are not into art, just go for a walk around on the heel.

Holidays. Magnificent and impressive building topped by the cascading waterfalls and views to die for. Could this be Heaven on earth? If so I would gladly have my last service at The Sagrada Basilica and interned at the Hills of Museu National.
Great works of art. Art at its best.A must for art lovers. The masters are exhibited well and the displaying of them is superb.Easy to follow in different galleries

A must see day out. A beautiful building encompassing a wide range of art exhibits. The modern and contemporary art exhibits were especially fascinating. The building itself is worth looking at. It has a light and airy auditorium where the café is conveniently situated. Remember to look up at the ceilings; they are spectacular. We went on Sunday when the museum closes at three, so did not get round to see all exhibits. You could easily spend a whole day there. We finished with a visit to the roof viewing point where you can see a panoramic view of Barcelona. Highly recommended.

Beautiful setting, come for the art, stay for the view!. My partner and I came here to see the Magic Fountain and were blown away by the Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya looming over from above, looking down toward Placa de Catalunya. Such a beautiful building and the collection inside is marvellous.
Budget Barcelona. It was well worth the visit. Gorgeous setting and some great free exhibits. We didn't go to the chargeable ones but still had a great time.

World class museum. Set high on a windy hill this is a world class museum. The high ceilings, open & spacious rooms, excellent lighting mostly natural. The building is a work of art in itself, one room flows into the next as thought you are being subtly guided, everything is well place for viewing from different angles. It is a walk thru Catalonia's art history with at least one work from Catalonia's major artists. Lovely café . Only negative is the gift shop closes 15 minutes before the museum. Allow extra time to walk the grounds, statues, fountains, long lane of tall trees. From this hilltop are incredible postcard like views of the city & distant mountains. Excellent place for an unhurried afternoon.
Interesting. Very interesting museum ! Great and huge building in the "Raval" ! Very nice but a little bit expensive

the views are worth the walk. we did not go in, but the views of the city from the top and near the entrance are fantastic. Take the walk up to see the entire city. Sorry cannot tell you what it is like inside, we arrived too late.

Very relaxed museum. Very relaxed museum - open spaces to enjoy the artNot much translation texts of the works in English though.You may visit the roof, but only on dry days.Great walk to the museum via the main entrance - fountains - lots of fountains.

An amazing setting for wonderful works of art. The impressive water cascades and steps lead you up to a wonderful view of the city. Inside artworks range from beautifully presented church interiors to contemporary artworks including furniture.
Stay outside. Outside this museum is a lively parc with escalators and stairs. Lovely fountains, great view to the city. Perfect place to be to enjoy the view.

Worth every second. We didnt have much time to Visit the Museum, but we did go there and took pictures. and trust me, every photo we clicked is WOW...!! You can see partial city from the top. Must Visit.

Magnificent Art Museum. This is a sensational museum. It has such a fabulous collection of all types of art, from Gothic to modern, including some wonderful Picassos. We were so entranced by it that we went for a second visit. You could sit on the terrace for hours, just looking out over Barcelona to the Mediterranean. As Seniors (even though we aren't Spanish), we did not pay entry fees. It was so good, I would have been happy to pay!
The view!. Great museum. Even if art museums are not your thing, you cannot miss seeing the view from the top. Amazing!

Gorgeous Building and Grounds. The walking/arriving at this museum is not for the faint of walking...it is quite a trip just getting to the museum itself (even using the many escalators they provide). However, if you just take your time and enjoy the views along the way, that is all part of the enjoyment. The building and grounds are exquisite. While the exhibits inside were tastefully done and interesting, the real enjoyment for us was the exterior of the building, the waterfalls, and the extraordinary views of Barcelona once you're up there.There were a few "scammers" that approached us for "donations" when we were sitting outside, but if you just tell them to go away, they do. We didn't feel they were dangerous, just annoying. This is common in any big city, just something to be aware of.

Lovely!. Lovely museum full of works of art, sculptures & paintings. Proudly set atop the Montjuic hill. Providing spectacular views of Barcelona (Placa d'Espanya). In the same vicinity as the Fundacio Joan Miro, the Olympic Museum, etc...definitely a classic must see when you visit Barcelona.

I hope i could understand better. I always love arts, although I'm not -the-artist-type-That's why I was exciting to visit this museum. I did enjoy walking around the museum as there are many beautiful paintings, sculptures, and many others. But I hope I could understand their meanings or history better if only there were explanations in English. Luckily we got free entry on Feb 12th 2015! Because the entry is little bit expensive (about €12)

I didn't go inside but.... I didn't go inside but the view from the terrace is a must see as is the fountain show at night. The only reason I didn't go inside was because the people I was with didn't want to.

Uneven but worthwhile, especially for the Romanesque. The Museu National d'Art de Cataluna is the main art museum in Barcelona, located near the bottom of the Montjuic hill on the Placa Espana side. You can walk easily enough from the Espana metro but it is uphill (you're basically starting your way up Montjuic hill) and there are a lot of stairs and (fortunately) escalators. The area around the gallery is very attractive and has good views of parts of the city. The museum's collection focuses on Spanish and Catalan Art, with the greatest strength arguably being in the mainly fresco-style art brought to the museum from churches of the Catalan Romanesque in the countryside north of Barcelona. They have built wooden mock-ups of the structures that were the frescos' original home so you can see, to the extent possible, how the art would have looked in its original space. (I have no idea how they got this art off the walls off their original homes and into the museum, which is a pretty impressive feat even from the technical point of view.) There is a lot of this stuff, and after a while everything starts to blend into everything else, but there is nevertheless a certain intensity which is impressive in its own right. There is also some non-fresco art, including a memorable (if gruesome) painting depicting the deaths of the saints, which is featured as an influence in Hiroshi Teshigahara's excellent film about Antonio Gaudi.The gothic medieval art doesn't quite make the same impression, but there are some good later pieces and then a very fast transition into the museum's collections of renaissance art, which is made up mainly of non-Catalan art, donations from thee Cambo bequest and the Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection (the latter's main collection is based in Madrid). These are a mixed bag but include a few characteristic Titians and Tintorettos as well as an equally characteristic El Greco.The museum's second floor is devoted entirely to Catalan art from about 1850 to 1950. I can't say I was blown away by anything in here but there are some pieces that are at least interesting.
