The annotations on these materials are quite bizarre, written throughout from some kind of Marxist-influenced perspective that tells you somewhat more about the author's politics than the art. This is unfortunate as this isn't really art that speaks for itself, yet it has interest and a good commentary would have been a significant addition to museum experience.The labelling and annotations are bilingual Catalan and Castillian throughout with English translations for some but not all of the annotations. Food options at the museum (including the outdoor terrace near the front entrance) are mediocre though sitting on the terrace with a coffee or a beer or a glass of wine is certainly a pleasant way to while away half an hour or so.

Great views over the city.. Worth visiting for location and stunning views. Modern art section was very well presented although few artists of world class merit. However, enjoyed the whole building. Ran out of steam so did not have the stamina to go around the medieval art which did look wonderful. The ticket allows 2 days entry so could go back.

Amazing art piece, visit the modern art section. Do not hesitate to hop off the tour bus to visit the incredible collection of modern art, they have wonderful pieces of miro, picasso, etcInnan hour, you could see a lotBesides the museum, you have a wonderful view of the place de l'espagne if you font have much time. Dont miss it.
blown away. this museum is well worth a visit. its only 12 euros to get in but is valid for 2 visits and includes the viewing platform at the very top which gives a breathtaking view of Barcelona.

Excellent!. Great museum of antiquities and other things! Amazing view of Barcelona from up there, I recommend to see the Mies Van der Rohe Barcelona Pavillion first and the Magic fountain, then take the outside escalators to this museum(fantastic for pictures from up there) after walk to the right and a few blocks away is the Miro museum and a few more blocks the teleferico is terrific!
Picturesque. Did not go inside..but the area around it was amazing with city view. best place to spend couple of hours around this place....
Walking around outside worth it. On a short day in Barcelona, I stopped by the museum to only sit around and enjoy the view. This is a beautiful building. It is also the top of a great view.
Get off the bus here. This museum has a 'Romantic' section fall of reconstructed parts of old churches. It is huge, so you may need to decided which areas you want to visit. We loved what we saw

Good museum glazers with an interesting history. Brilliant place to visit. A wide variety of art and history to see. The views from the roof are also spectacular. The history of the museum itself is vey interesting, it being built in a classic style but actually only constructed in the early 1900s.

Impressive approach to the palace!. The Palau Nacional on Montjuic was the focus of Barcelona's international fair in 1929 and now houses the national museum of catalonian art. The museum boasts a stunning collection of gothic, Romanesque and medical treasures and religions artifacts.Admission costs 12€!

For aficionados of Medieval-Renaissance Art. Not for everybody, but a must if your taste in art runs to 13th century frescoes. The excursion to Monjuic offers more to see than one to Park Guell and equally great views.

art..art..art..!!!. if you be in barcelona for any reason,you shouldn't leave the city before visit this museum! there are 4 sections (gothic,art medieval, renascence, modern) full of authentic creations!

Very grand. We went in here on a very cold day, to get warm and left 2 hours later! An amazingly grand building from the outside, beautiful on the inside. We ate in the coffee shop too - lovely toastie!

Offers Great Views. We visited here while in Barcelona. We came across it while on a double decker tour bus and hopped off when we got there. The building itself is gorgeous and offers some of the best views of the entire city. We didn't do the interior tour but were on and around the grounds and the architecture is just beautiful!

the place to visit. A very good museum to visit to get t an idea of the catalan arts and a wonderfull collection of roman, gothic as well as modern arts. We also had a very good impression of the main hall
Important to mention the entrance is free for people over 65
Nice visit. If you are interested in medieval art and modern art, this is a great visit and it is free ! Don't miss the gothic art gallery, there are treasures over there.

Visited 1st feb a Sunday and was free. Good museum to visit if you like modern art. We visited the whole museum in less than 1.5 hours.
Good overall visit especially if you are visiting 1st Sunday of the month or Saturdays after 3pm as its free..😜

An Impressive Place. Firstly the approach to the building on the hill is quite impressive. The modern art is very good and if you like to learn more about the Catalan culture in art this is a good place to learn. Large gallery spaces with plenty of delicious art to view. Lastly the view from the front door balcony of Barcelona is definitely picture worthy.

Worth a visit. Works by many artists laid out deliberately almost hap-hazard from centuries ago to modern in one room.Two floors only. Two hours would be idealA bit out of the centre but a taxi ride or 30min walk

Not To Be Missed. Talk about a room with view - this has one of the best views in Barcelona. The beautiful old building houses some wonderful art. Make sure you spend time viewing the Catalan art and design from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Amazing.
Best Barcelona view point. Must go place, even if only for the fantastic view over Barcelona.Really beautiful surroundings and you can walk from MNAC to various other attraction points.

Wonderful landscape, nice place to visit!. Located in a wonderful palace with old architecture on a high hill from where you can have beautiful overview of Barcelona. Variety of wonderful art works of Spain from thousands years ago in this museum. Will take you whole day to view art and take photos around...

A Museum with a View!. This museum houses its art in a 1929 palace on a hill overlooking Barcelona. And what art! The collections are impressive and displayed to show to the best advantage each piece. If you need a break, try the restaurant or the café. By the way, visitors over 60 (I think the age is correct) are admitted free.

Do Your Homework in Advance !. Without English leaflet there was some aimless wandering on this visit. More extensive pre-planning homework may have eased some distress. What a delicious spot to wander about in distress!
The rooftop view is not to be missed.
(this venue is included in the six museum bargain ticket package)

Museum with a huge amount of art. A lot of art for the entrance fee! Although I think one must be very into art and history to appriciate the museum fully.
A note: be careful with people asking you to sign a petition and give money on behalf of handicaped children. They hustled us.
Really beautiful. We were swept away by the art and restoration presented so sensitively here. It is a deeply absorbing and interesting place.
Fantastic. Beautiful, welll exhibited, fantastic builduing with lits of light and open space. Even the temporary exhibition was very interesting

Wow!. I always thought that it's more beautiful from outside, but was definetely mistaken.
The museum is so amazing inside. I'm not only talking about the art, but about the building. looks like a beautiful old palace, I was actually surprised that it was not that old.
Definetely - yes , visit it.

A Dose of Cultural Knowledge. Situated at the top of a hill overlooking the fountain, MNAC is certainly a sight to behold. We went at opening and the place was empty which gave us the opportunity to see this museum bare without anyone else to obstruct our view or interrupt our curious minds. If you love museums, you'll love this. If you're not into museums, skip it.

A unique experience. If you like art museums this is worth visiting, especially for the Romanesque section, which is quite unique. The rest of the artwork probably doesn't reach the heights of the prado or louvre but it is still good to see artists that I wasn't familia with.Great building and easy to get to.We had lunch at the resaraunt. There is a great view from the right tables and the food and service were very good. Lunch cost around 30 eu per person.If you are thinking of going then good to take advantage of the other attractions in the area or just walk through the loverly park and gardens.We also took the funicular up to the fort which was a great view but relatively expensive at 12 eu return.

treasures of the Romanesque. Fortunately, the ticket lets you in on two days within the space of a month; take advantage of the opportunity to repeat your visit, because the first exposure will overwhelm, overpower, overstimulate you. The collection of Romanesque wall paintings and panel paintings is unrivaled, well worth spending both visits admiring them. The grand building in its even grander setting atop the Montjuic is worth a visit on its own, especially at dusk, when the city lights up below you.

One of Europe's great museums. On a hill overlooking the city in a beautiful building you will discover a fantastic museum and art gallery. The layout is perfect - very spacious and light. Start with the Romanesque section, which is one of the greatest collections in the world. The Catalans were concerned about the degradation of the frescoes in churches in villages and with great care they removed them and re-installed them here in the form they had in the original church. This remarkable technical feat comes off so that you feel as if you are indeed in an old church when you walk around. Room after room reveals priceless treasures on the walls. As well as frescoes there are perfectly preserved paintings on wooden panels that glow with colour and are full of meaning. You will also find wooden scuptures from the 12th and 13th centuries that are so moving - perhaps the finest is on the descent of Christ from the cross. There are some fine pieces in the Gothic and Renaissance sections of the museum but they mostly do not compete with the incredible riches in the Romanesque part. Upstairs you will find two very large areas devoted to more modern art and to Modernisme, the Catalan equivalent of Art Nouveau. The latter sections are among the finest anywhere: the designs by Gaudi and his contemporaries are so strikingly beautiuful. Again, the displays are top class. What a superbly laid out museum this is! There is a bookshop, a cafe/restaurant and on the upper floor a restaurant with a great view over the city; the latter usually needs to be booked. There is so much to see that one visit is hardly enough, so it is an excellent idea that the ticket you buy allows you to come back free another day within one month.

Catalan history,art and pride. This is a very well laid out Museum. The Gothic and Romanesque collection is startlingly bright and colourful. The journey through time is wonderfully curated and allows you to connect the rooms and movements in art.If you purchase one of those Articket BCN, the lovely staff here informed us that you can visit this museum twice with the ticket. And we did.Don't be intimidated by all the steps up to the museum. There are escalators. Or you can jog up if that's your thing!
BEAUTIFUL!. well worth a visit! classic building and artwork with amazing views! lockers are available if you have bigger bags, which was handy.
Don't miss this.. Set high up overlooking the city this place is great. Learn about Calalunya, it's artists it's struggles. Relax at the café and enjoy the beautiful building. The views are fabulous.

A great view over the city. My favorite part of this otherwise impressive building is the view. After being amazed by the small waterfalls, the great arhitecture you finally arrive at the top, turn around and see the entire Barcelona.And you get to sip a coffee at the same time from the local terrace.We did that on our last day just before going to the airport. A perfect moment to end a perfect trip in my dream city.
A bit of Catalan History. Very interesting Museum and well worth a visit. Lots to see and learn about Catalonia. Great views from the roof terrace over Barcelona and the Olympic stadium.

Was not impressed initially, but was pleasantly surprised..!. This is truely on of the Best Museums for Catalan History, and Religious Art that I have seen. This for it is a tasteful selection of what represents True Catalan, and its struggle with Identity and Surviving its Battered Heritage. You really can't appreciate the Catalan struggle, but this helps a bit in displaying certain differences here that provide a glimpse of how and why Catalan wants it's Sovereignty. Also a glimpse in Very Early Catholic Iconography, which for the most part has been forgotten, just remnants here, but primitive in its beginning are displayed here. Also a Modern Art wing that provides so very refreshing before and after Franco, Modernists Movement, not too much, just enough to tell the story. At the end, WWI & WWII essentials, how they suffered is captured on canvas and film. Worth the time & $...!
Good paintings. The museum has a lot of paintings mostly. It is nice to see but it does not give you the WOW factor. Seeing many museums in my life and this will not be one of the top 5

If you like Medieval art this is probably the best place in Europe. This museum has probably the best collection I have ever seen anywhere (and I've seen many) of early and late medieval art. It's also not nearly as crowded as many museums in Barcelona (especially if you go early) and I spent a very happy and very informative 5 hours with their fine collections of early medieval and gothic art (never made it to the modern section at all). My one warning would be that dining facilities are limited: the cafe has very limited seating and the day I was there and prepared to spend big to eat in their restaurant the restaurant was entirely booked for some affair or other.

Beautiful day. We took a cab up to the museum which was great for a very cold day. But if weather permits, stroll through the surrounding parks - beautiful! (You can also walk to the nearby Miro museum.) Skip the snack bar out front and go inside where there are both a cafeteria in the back and a fine restaurant upstairs. Overall, MNAC is a spacious museum with an extensive collection of beautiful works by Spanish painters who did not get their due internationally - because of politics? history? Hard to say, but well worth your time now. Also, the building itself is magnificent. Go inside!

Hmm. Needs updating. The thing is this. We live in a new fast paced technology driven world and the challenge is old artefacts need to be 'brought to life' somehow so that the experience is not just walking from floor to floor seeing static exhibitions. More is needed

Excellent location. The entrance to the museum is as great as the museum itself. We didn't have time to visit the museum from inside but just the view from outside was good enough to satisfy us. the view of the city from the top is beyond describable. You've got to see it to appreciate it.

The Light Show. Make sure you stop her this museum is worth the trip grab food and beer from the mall before you go. The walk up the steps will give you a workout. At the top before entering the museum there was a live music. Great place to stop and take pictures in front of. The fountain show at night is something magical.

Great collection of Catalan art. Recommend getting an articket for visiting these musuems.. or one could even get access to all this art on Saturdays between 3-6 pm for free!! Its a very good museum packed with catalan art. Worth a trip

How DID they do it?? WOW. How on earth did they take 1000 year old frescos from the interiors of Romanesque Churches in the Vall de Boi and reassemble them here??!!AmazingWords can't describeWorth the trip to Montjuic but I suggest you do Miro Foundation in the morning and this in the afternoon......do it on a friday and stay for the free Font Magica just down the steps!!

One of the best attraction in Barcelona. We visited here with our best friends in july 2010. If you are interested in culture and art of Catalonia region then it is totaly one of the best attraction point in Barcelona. It is located on montjuic hill and in a walking distance from piazza espana. The terrace infront of the museum has also one of the best city view. You can spend hours here by watching city with a coffe which is sold at the cafe located there. Museum building is very big so it will take around a half day to visit. All exhibited items are stacked neatly in a row which is not tiring you while visiting. You will learn many things about Catalonia if you visit here. It is highly recommended.

You will need to use your map!. Enjoyable art museum, a very impressive building. We purchased a Barcelona art for card 30 euros per person and this gave you access to 6 different museums and no need to wait in line to purchase tickets, if you plan on visiting 3 or more museums you will save money.The museum is split into various art movements which sounds good as you could select what you wanted to look at but the layout is a little bit confusing and you will definatley need to keep refering your map.Food and drink outlets available outside to sit and watch the world go by and take in a fab view over the whole of Barcelona.

Great, but would recommend a two day visit. Having been to some art museums in Europe, I must say this one has one of the most diverse collection of art pieces. From Romantic to modern, it would take you hours to finish seeing the whole museum. Thats why if you are in Barcelona for long, I would recommend making a two day visit to this museums. I helps that the admission ticket is valid for two days. I got a little bit bored after the 3rd hour mark. Overall, a great place to spend time but a hell if paintings make you sleep.

Free entry for 65+. The museum is housed in the huge and magnificent Palau Nacional and located on Montjuic hill. Entry is free for 65+ of all nationalities. Tickets for paying guests are good for two days during the same month. You will need more than two days to see all what the museum offers. It is wise to visit the excellent web site (http://museunacional.cat/en) to check the hours of winter and summer operation (Mondays closed). Make sure to bring your camera, tablet or phone to take thousands of pictures of an incredible variety of art. Particularly the Medieval Romanesque wing is unique in the world, housing the preserved wall paintings from many churches of the Pyrenees. Then there is the Gothic art wing, which I unfortunately had to rush through, so I missed the Renaissance and Baroque wing all together. And that is only the ground floor! There is also the first floor with modern, contemporary art. Clearly, this museum requires multiple visits to do it justice.

Viewed from the ouside only.. We started by viewing the building, venetian towers, placa espanyol and the fountains from the roof of the Arena shopping mall located at the north end of Placa Espanyol. The roof terrace is free to access by going up the numerous interior escalators. There is a supermarket in the basement of the shopping mall, so you can stock up on picnic things prior to going up to the gallery and surrounding attractions.We then took a slow walk up the path between the towers to admire the fountains and Art museum behind.It is a magnificent building amd we whiled away a good couple of hours in the gardens.We didn't pay to go inside as it was too expensive for us on our budget (i was travelling with my 12yr old daughter) and had already stumped up a lot for the Sagrada Familia and other sights. We then had a wander around the Olympic park and stopped for some lunch in the grounds.A pleasant morning spent away from the hustle and bustle of Barce city centre. Definitely worth a visit.

Ten centuries in one day. A beautiful place with views across Barcelona, and that was before we went inside.Take your time - we are glad we did, since we got a history of Catalunya through its art. Geography, religion, politics, social history via some stunning artists and their works. Captivating and rich.

The view alone is worth the price of admission!. I visited this museum in December with my girlfriend. Neither of us are art or history buffs but I wanted to check the place out as I'd heard the area surrounding it was beautiful.We weren't disappointed. As soon as you step off the Metro and look up at the Gallery on the hill you realise it's a beautiful building, and the fountains and area surrounding it do it justice.Even the view from outside the museum, without paying to go inside is excellent, so if you're really doing your holiday on the cheap you could climb the stairs to the museum and check out the view without ever going inside.When you are inside, there are several galleries with seemingly endless rooms of art to check out. I'm sure art buffs would appreciate it more than we did, but even so there were some incredible pieces in there.It might be worth paying for an audio tour though. We didn't, and as a result didn't know much about any of the pieces, as the majority of the signs are in Catalan.Still an enjoyable couple of hours though.Finally, we made our way to the rooftop terrace, where you get some astonishing views of the city. You can pay a few Euro to see the view from the terrace without going into the gallery so again, if you're looking for a cheaper activity, you could just do that.The view is amazing a real photo spot for tourists. Worth the price of admission alone.A great way to spend a morning, and only a short hop on the metro from la Rambla so no problem getting there at all. You could even walk it if you fancy a long stroll.

excellent. I suggest to admire this magnificent monument through the roof garden of the arena exactly face to face. Just on the top of piazza Espanya`s metro station. And from there I suggest to start the visit to Montjuic parc,something you wont regret for sure.

Wonderful Museum in a beautiful area of Barcelona. I am not an art or museum lover but it was a very rainy day and the MNAC was within walking distance from our hotel. And when we arrived, we also discovered that Saturdays equal free admission! I ended up loving the museum so much that we stayed until it closed and they made us leave. Best of all, my 8 year old, who I thought would be bored, totally loved the paintings and sculptures as well. She was truly taking time to study each painting and talk about it with us. The MNAC should definitely be on your list of places to visit in Barcelona.

spectaclular. Another "must visit" if you're in Barcelona. A beautiful building, easy to find your way around, and with all the facilities you'd expect from a world-class museum. And it's free for oldies!

Come and see art treasures...... Plan to spend the day at this amazing museum. The site it's great eat at the nice cafe inside and then wait for the sunset and stay for the Magic Fountain show......!!!

This is a piece of art. This museum is built on the hill, so you can see it from far away.You can take the escalator up to the 1992 Olympic site or take the escalator down to the magic Fountain and Placa Espanya. No matter which way the view is breathtaking. The museum itself is a piece of art, I love this magnificent building. They also have a good collection of paintings and sculptures. It’s worth it to spend time there. A few years ago we went there on Wednesday, it was free. This time we went on November 22, Sat. it was free after 3pm. Happy Travelling!

Very worthwhile. While you're visiting Barcelona, it's worth the trip to Montjuic to see this beautiful museum. It has a wonderful collection of the old as well modern works organized in a very interesting manner. The hop on buses stop at the museum making it very convenient. And there is a breathtaking view of Barcelona from the front entry.

Simply Wow. We never actually made it inside of the museo as we got sidetracked by all there was to see outside. We started at the top of the stairs as if to enter the museo, but opted to go down to take pictures of the fountains. Each level down provided a more amazing shot than the previous. Each level has a different fountain and provides a wonderful view back to the top. Once you make it back down to street level there are yet more fountains. In the evening, the main fountain is lit up and dances to an array of music. The perfect atmosphere for a calming night, or even a romantic set up with a loved one. Either way, the sight is a must see for everyone. I can only imagine the inside, and anticipate my return to see the rest.

One of its kind. This place is an art refferal for all the new trends in europe, if you like modern art, this is the place! I disliked all the skaters rappers and graffities around the meuseum dangerously doing all kind of acts.

A must for art lovers!. Wow! You will certainly get your art fill here. Visit on a Saturday after 3 pm and entry is free until 6 pm.The museum holds a fantastic collection of art and is set in a beautifully designed majestic building.My only complaint is that there was only one Picasso and two Dali's, which was disappointing considering their associations with Spain.

My First Spain Visit. This place is absolutely beautiful. From here you can take several beautiful pictures and if you were on the bus tour and get off they have bathrooms inside (very important for me). There is a small fee to go to the top of the building and take photos or you can just take them from outside in the front. Very nice architecture inside and out!

World class art museum. This museum is large and I would say specializes in Medieval and Gothic Art, although there is a fine representation of art throughout the ages. This building is from a World's Fair in the 1800's so getting around can be a bit of a challenge especially for people who need handicapped access. We encountered many stair and narrow passages. There are elevators throughout, but just be aware it takes a bit of planning.We encountered many school groups, obviously having a grand time doing activities making those areas a bit noisy. The displays of art and artifacts are expertly arranged and are stunning to see. The views outside the museum are breathtaking. There is some food available. Photos are allowed.

Wonderful Romanesque art. Took the hop-on hop-off bus to the parc de montjuic, dismounted here and visited this museum and the Joan miro fundacion before getting back on the bus. The interiors of the Romanesque churches dating from the 11th, 12th, and 13th centuries were the highlight for me. Also enjoyed the way they had organized the modern art section by theme. Had a pleasant lunch in the cafe here.

So much to see. We only had a few hours for this one, so we concentrated on the modern art sections, which were our main area of interest. These were very well laid out, if somewhat labyrinthine. Look out for the excellent oils technique of Mariano Fortuny on display.
Best museum in Brc. Romanesque, the Thyssen-Bornemisza collection and Modern part 1-2 was all excellent exhibitions. Staff was friendly. Floor plan was well planned. Exhibition was excellent curated.

Spectacular ceiling and stained glass; wonderful music hall. This is a special treat, especially if you get to see it on a sunny (or partly sunny) day. The facility is absolutely amazing, from the way it handles light, to the space you will experience, to hearing the music.Not a shabby small concert hall (it seats over 2,000 people), it is in use most of the year. We had gone on a guided tour, so I didn't get to hear a live concert there, but they did play an organ sampling, which was great -- a lot of reverberation throughout the hall.The advantage of the guided tour (get one in your language, and be sure to reserve tix in advance as they will sell out) is that you not only learn about the hall, but you'll see it in the daytime when the light is best. If you go to the concert, on the other hand, you'll visit it as it was intended. Now if you can go to a daytime concert.... :-) !!

Some truly beautiful art. This is one art museum that the building is just as cool as the collection it houses. The art inside is well curated, and dates back to the 1100's. Mainly Spanish artists, the collection is vast. Spend some extra time admiring the building, as it is simply stunning.

Give it as many hours as you can afford.. A stunning view of the city from the entrance steps is just the first delight in this Art Museum which contains treasures of art and furnishing from Roman times onwards. I have never spent so long in a single museum, and I still didn't feel as if I had exhausted it; by the time I reached then end I was ready to start at the beginning in place eveything in even clearer context. Unmissable.
Beautiful Architecture. I came out here on my own to update my visual library. The architecture speaks volumes and the landscapes beautiful. I will definately recommend a visit

Go for the city view. Ironically, it is the city view of Barcelona that is more attractive than the contents of the museum. The museum is located on top of the hill and the view is breathtaking. Note that it does takes some time to go up to the top so reach there early. I personally do not think that the collection is world-class and honestly, I'm not even sure if any of the pieces is even worth remembering. Luckily, the entrance fee comes with the Barcelona Card (not recommended!) else the it will be a one star rating from me. The only saving grace is the view and the nice party atmosphere OUTSIDE the museum. 2.5 stars and hence worth a look (outside).

Good visit. I was not in any other museum in Barcelona. I stayed there for arround 2 hours but it is not enough to see all. I went with no expectatives and for me was surprising and enjoyed it. Then I stayed in the steps for a while and enjoyed the fantastic views.

Interesting and expansive look at Catalan art across the centuries. This museum was a part of my Art ticket so I decided to check it out. It is on the hill overlooking the city, which is a lovely and peaceful part of town. (Even if you don't go to the museums on the hill, visit it for some relaxation!) I first visited the Miro museum so approached this on the way down the hill to town. One can, in fact, take escalators up past very cool cascading fountains to get there, as well. Back to the museum. It is a grand old building, and represents a very, very long timeline. There was a special contemporary exhibit of a Catalan artist with which I began my visit and enjoyed very much. The rest of the collection was a bit of a rush for me, since it was the end of the day and there was so much to see. It is, quite frankly, a bit overwhelming, so one might be advised to do a bit of research before going. The collection was eclectic and mixed and varied. I needed a few days to process whether I liked it or not and in the end, I think it is worth visiting, especially if you've got the Artticket, which gives one entrance to six museums for one price. Take the time to relax in front of the museum, at least on weekends, when there are musicians playing on the steps in front of the museum. I would have liked to have begun my day earlier there. I think I would have better appreciated the depth and breadth of its holdings. In any case, go there if you've got the Art ticket. It is only a 5-10 minute walk from the Miro exhibit (a must see!) and a nice way to work your way down the hill back to town. Recommended.

Huge! - worth a visit (even if you only enjoy the outside). We got off our sightseeing bus in front of the MNAC and walked up the many stairs and around for a bit. Good photo ops and nice fountain in front of the museum.After our visit we walked down again and all the way to the bus stop. If we had been just a bit awake we could have stayed on the bus and been driven all the way to the top and gotten off (and on) at the top :oD. Oops.

Wonderful Museum. Good audio guide. Wonderful views. Beautiful building. Lots to see. Look for the glass elevator if you would like to see more modern works. I stumbled around for awhile and finally found the elevators, but I was too tired to continue my visit.
worth visiting. many fantastic collections, it´s in the Montjuic hill, a classic building like a palace. from here you can have a perfect view of Barcelona.

Disapointed. I have visited many art museums, but this one did not appeal to me. It was interesting to see the mural paintings which had been saved from the painted walls of ruined churches and cathedrals and somehow transported to Barcelona. but the rest of the collection was somehow bland. No doubt many will disagree with me, but it is my opinion. I did not feel it was worth the 12 euro entry fee.

Bliss. I visited the Museum twice.The first time for 3 hours was not long enough so the next time I stayed for 4 hours knowing what I wanted to view and enjoy.Only about 30 minutes away from U232 using Metro and then a slow walk.A good few steps to climb but their is an escalator available if required.The view from the top is fantastic.
One of the best museums in Catalonia. Surprising and unique collection of Romanesque frescoes. Has a slightly different schedule than most museums, closing on Sundays afternoons.

Free on a Saturday after 3pm. I came by myself on a Saturday for the free entry.Extremely worth it, there were four exhibitions, all in different periods and were quite long too. I thoroughly enjoyed the band in the main hall with many people dancing it was a lovely atmosphere!Incredible architecture you cannot come to Barcelona and not visit this beautiful attraction!

Wonderful building, huge, well organized fine art. Huge beautiful palace filled with three big floors of Catalonian art. Went to the third floor, modern art, which had dozens of rooms and hundreds of paintings and sculptures from 1850-1950. Only a few from the local masters (Picasso, Miro, Dali) but extensive notes in 3 languages incl.English, detailing the development and divergence of the way modern art evolved locally. Also a very fine restaurant halfway thru the modern art floor.

Big Museum!. This museum is a nice museum that's very big and it has one of the best waterfalls out front that I think I've ever seen! Many people stop by this museum just to take pictures of the building alone. The museum is located in a great part of Barcelona as you're next to the old olympic stadium, magic fountain and Montjuic Castle. Even if you don't make it inside the museum, just stop by the area and enjoy all the amazing sites!

Wonderful Modernista Art!. For an easy education in Modernista, you can't go wrong here - the building is beautiful, one is encouraged to go to the rooftop (!) for a view and there are plenty of bathrooms. Rooms of furniture, modern art and ancient art, breathtaking and not so overwhelmingly vast that one is exhausted. Intelligently curated. One of our Top 5 favorite visits in Barcelona.

Some great pieces. We were there on a Saturday and it was Free from 3pm. I also believe that admission is Free every 1st Sunday of the month. General admission is usually 12 Euros each. So, this was great. We did not have many hours to spare so we got a brochure which showed us the many highlights of the museum and where they were located in the building. Museum is located by PL. Espanya Green Line L3 or Red Line L1. In front of the museum is the Magic Fountain where you can see a beautiful water show at nights complete with music and lights. I believe there are no water shows on Mondays, Tuesdays or Wednesdays. At the back of the Museum you can walk to the Olympic Stadium. When you get to PL. Espanya Metro station, look for the 2 tall towers and walk in that direction. You will pass the magic fountain and the Museum is behind. A fair bit of walking, but everything around this area is worth seeing. If you care to you can pay 1E and go up to the top of the Barcelona Arena for a view of the area. The Arena is the huge circular orange building. You cannot miss it as you exist the Metro.

Art Treasures of Catalunya. The building itself is spectacular, fronted by an artificial waterfall and "dancing water" fountain. MNAC forms a significant landmark in Plaza Espana. Give yourself a couple of hours minimum to see the collection. The exhibits are logically organized by chronology, and contain many national treasures that are clearly identified in the visitor guide.Note that seniors (65+) are admitted free. There is a cafeteria/restaurant in the exhibition hall. It makes a nice stop to refresh, but beware, the prices are steep. The gift shop has a very nice selection of gifts. We were pleased to find items we could not find elsewhere.MNAC is well worth the investment in time. Give yourself time.

Impressive. Very impressive museum. We visited only the ground floor, which includes Romanesque, Gothic and Renaissance art. We spent about 3 hours there. We did not see the Modern art, or drawings, prints, posters or numismatics (coins). Lots of 13th to 15th century paintings of Christ and variously graphic paintings of martyrdom scenes. Equally impressive is the walk from the top of the museum down past the Font Magica to the Plaza de Espana. This is a must-see area.

Don't miss the Modernisme area. If you like Gaudí and the rest of Modernist architects do not miss the painters, graphic designers and furniture creations. If the whole MNAC museum is too much for you, I would go for this section.

Amazing views . This is a truly impressive part of the city. Well worth spending a little time taking pictures and wailing round exploring the building. Be warned many steps to walk up but once at the top you get some amazing photos

My favorite museum. The view of the city from here is great. The actual building is wonderful...open...light. Loved the exhibits as well. Sit out front and have a drink. Then wander up to the Miro Museum. Take the double decker bus back down the mtn. Now that's a good day.
Good spot for pictures. Beautiful Monumental area for taking pictures.Again an over crowded area.Take care of Pickpockets.Touching the 24 Hours overcrowded Las Ramblas area

Don't miss it!. The care and scholarship, curatorship, that has gone into this collection is unmatched. The strength of the collection is first of all the Romanesque frescoes but there are many more treasures from the Gothic to the Art Nouveau. The best museum experience I have had in a long time!

Nice building!. Impressive art gallery. Which used to be a palace? Didn't go in, just admired from outside, walked up all of the steps leading right up to it but didn't fancy mooching round an art gallery when it was such lovely weather outside so we skipped this. Nice and clean, lovely fountains. Very busy. Worth visiting. Great views from up here too.

Fantastic!!. Wow this was an amazing art experience!! I have never seen so much Gothic art ever and so beautifully exhibited. You could take pictures of the art which was new to me and the setting could not have been better. The museum entrance was free the day I went which was a bonus. This is a "not to be missed" experience and a true splendor of Barcelona.

What Art What a View!. OK we never actually got inside because it was such a nice day but the building is magnificent and the views are breathtaking.Well worth the climb.Next time I'll go in _ _ _ promise!

Traces of Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya. It is Friday morning in Barcelona and Seamus has awaken me like he believes he is the bloody town crier. “It is 11:00 AM and you have slept 14 hours!!” Sweet! Because I had been awake since 6:00 AM Wednesday morning Texas time. After spending some time making notes, writing and researching an adventure on Paco, the notepad, we dress and head to the Lobby to hail a cab. Many blocks later and after some hair raising traffic we are deposited on the east side of the Museu Nacional. I will admit that the scene that unfolded before me was a wee bit surreal. There were people lingering about, some walking, and some photographing the view. In the middle of this scene was a man on a chair playing a guitar. It looked like a scene from a 1962 postcard. I was enchanted. As we approached the front entrance there was another guitar player and people seated at tables and chairs drinking coffee. The whole place had the appearance of a sidewalk café not a museum. Inside we bought a pass for all museums and made our way to the inside café for a pastry and coffee. The sight that awaited us was beautiful, an arena with peach painted ceiling and friezes with targes adorned with heraldic symbols of every district of Spain in gorgeous color. An enormous pipe organ protected by two angles was the highlight of the room. We grabbed pastries, coffee and seats in the arena and enjoyed a leisurely snack before our excursion into the depths of the museum.We started with Renaissance art and traveled as if by magic into Baroque art which opened into a maze of Gothic art and statuary. Hours flew by in what felt like moments. Through vaguely remembered tales and stories we were introduced again to St.John the Baptist, St. Catherine and her wheel, St. Steven who it seems is always painted with rocks on his bloodied head, St. Lucy with her tray of eyes, and St. Barbara.We have just entered the medieval room when they announce that museum will be closing in 15 minutes. Seamus then recalls that he had been busted and his backpack was confiscated as though he was a common rapscallion (terrorist). They are probably tracking our every move now. We snag back the pack and make our escape to the lemonade stand for a refreshing drink and rest on a park bench as we watch the sun set.

Stunning art. Must see if you are an art lover. We spent an afternoon here with the kids and I admit it's a lot to take in but the work of the artists is breath taking. You need time to wander, stare, absorb and let it all seep in but well worth the time and visit.

A lot of art from Roman till today. Go up from Placa d'Espana. It is possible to use a moving staircase so it is not a difficult journey. Look at Barcelona - wonderful view. Then go into the Museum. I would start with Modern Art part - with excellent Spanish art from the turn of XIX and XX century - so go up first. Then go to the Gothic and Roman art - especially whole parts of churches. Worthy to try!

Magnificent both in terms of content and location. this is an outstanding reflection of the Catalan culture which obviously include and pre dates the great Gaudi.lunch in the restaurant is both reasonable, high quality with breath taking views of Barcelona.

Astounding. The art collection here in the Palau Nacional is astounding. You really need to plan at least half a day for this. The building is huge and a work of art in itself. One of the many highlights are the rescued murals from about to be destroyed XI-XIII century churches. They are wonderfully displayed in recreated interiors of the churches they are from. The collection of moderniste furniture is great too. Cafe on the terrace has a great view down to the Plaza Espanya. Only thing we didn't care for was the roof. Views are ok.

Took my breath away. Start with a fantastic view from the plaza at street level and look up. Decide to climb or ride the escalators. Much more difficult if you need your chair pushed, but possible. Fred 1st Sunday of e very month. No lines when we went about 9:30. The beauty of the building itself is far surpassed by the magnificence of the art. I was blown away! Photography is allowed, but NO flash. Check your backpacks and any large bags as they will be in your way. (Besides, you don't have a choice.) We stayed just wandering with one stop for a snack, until 3 pm closing. No way to see it all. We decided to return to Barcelona as we still have not seen other museums or any art galleries.People are polite and helpful. There were 20-some things as well as older folks everywhere. Just appreciating the Catelonian art. I just never knew.

Spectacular in every way. Although I only scheduled a couple of hours for this museum, I quickly realized I had vastly underestimated the time I needed to appreciate this treasure. The view of the city from the front steps, the amazing building itself, the collections of paintings on wood, which is the Catalan style of religious paintings....simply staggering in beauty & immensity. It took well over 3 hours to work our way through the beautiful & moving religious paintings alone & one of my biggest regrets is that I waited until the last day for this - I simply did not have enough time here. One could easily spend days here. I ran out of time before seeing the roof terrace...and my next visit to Barcelona will include a lengthy amount of time here.

The best views in Barceona!. I love this place! There are stunning views of Barcelona and great works of art. This is a very relaxing place to visit and is a good contrast from the hustle and bustle of the busy Barcelona streets. There is a wide range of Art on show including Medieval Art, Gothic Art and Modern Art. There is also a great little cafe in the centre of hall which serves tea, coffee and cake!
Loved It. A very beautiful museum. I could have easily spent half a day here. The ceiling in the Gothic area is a definite must see.
Culture. Spent 5-6 hours here its was so interesting. Cafe poor value for money and don't know how to make tea.

Worth a visit. Really great views of the city from the steps outside and interesting displays inside. Good cafe inside and a trip up to the roof terrace is also worthwhile when you tire of looking at all the paintings.

The fountain staircase is a terrific sight.. Escalators are available. The views are terrific, well worth the effort. The museum is cool, very hot outside. Some stunning works of art, some really interesting galleries. The displays of coins was really interesting, i was waiting to discover pieces of eight.

Glad It Was Free. On Sundays this museum is free, which I was very happy was the case after I got inside. The building that houses the museum is incredibly impressive, but the art left a lot to be desired. The staff was a bit surly when I asked for a map, but I stood firm and got one.

Absolutely amazing Romanesque and gothic art collections.. This place is a must for anyone interested in early Christian art. Even if art isn't your thing the rooftop terraces provide some of the best vistas of Barcelona. And best of all, if you are over 65 it's free!

Great Monument in Placa Espanya !. We didn't have time to visit the inside but looking at it from outside , it seems like a diamond on Top of the magnificent Placa Espanya !!! The building itself together with the statues and waterfalls, the stairs and the view of the Placa, is a unique structure !! Great photos day and night !!

The best place in Barcelona. We took the metro here which is a little way out of town, but in a good way as it was relatively quiet. We walked up following the cascades of the magic fountain and it was a great walk. It is quite tiring for the kids, some of it is escalated.At the front of the building you can sit and look over the whole of Barcelona whilst enjoying a beer from the outside bar, the sun went down whilst we were here and it was a great place to be. Even our tired out kids enjoyed the view and the break from the hustle and bustle. As we made our way down, it was getting busier so I think late afternoon a couple of hours before sunset is a good time to go.

Go for the frescos. We heard that this museum had priceless frescos which the Catalan government rescued from small unused village churches. They bought the churches and brought in the Italians to peel the frescos from the walls and reinstall them in the museum in a setting designed to recreate the shape of the church. The exhibit had several videos showing the churches and how the process was done. The frescos were fascinating and the videos very interesting. This was the exhibit we came to see so we cannot comment on the other exhibits. This exhibit was brilliantly done. Get the audio guide.

Delightful. We visited via the metro and walked up past the Magic Fountain via the steps and escalators leading to this beautiful,imposing building. Many of the exhibits here are frescoes which have been lifted from Medieval churches in the Pyrenees to prevent complete loss from deterioration. The processes involved are detailed via a video screen and that was very informative. The content was largely religious in nature, but quite diverse and the colour retention was amazing considering the age of this art. There were plenty of other things to see here too including some lovely sculptures and we spent most of the day exploring in a leisurely way. The building houses a restaurant and cafeteria plus a lovely bookshop/giftshop area. A great way to experience Catalan Art.Highly recommended.
Amazing building. While focused on Catalanyan artists, the building is a work of art and the display of modern art is well done.

Nice but!. The collection here is fairly average, but still worth visiting if you like religious art. They also have a large number of exhibits by Spanish artists (unknown). the entrance fee is reasonable, and you could spend half a day here. The walk up the steps looks a little daunting but there are escalators up to the right.

Don't miss this museum!. The walk to the museum from the metro was enjoyable by itself, with the Magic Fountain, the towers, and the fountains.This museum has an excellent collection of medieval and renaissance art. Get there by opening time, 10:00 am to avoid the tourist busses.

Broken escalator. This magnificent museum, located high on a hill, is easily reached by escalator. They were not running the day we visited, but it was SO worth the climb. The building itself is a work of art, the collection is magnificent, and the view breathtaking.

The view!. The museum by itself is worth climbing that killer hill- its has a really nice collection of the gothic altars, everything presented in very specious way, although the descriptions are mostly in Spanish. Very good collection of contemporary art. It's not a museum that will worn you down- you can see it all easily in 2 hours. Don't; forget to walk around the museum to enjoy a breathtaking view of Barcelona.

Incredible frescos. Romanesque art at MNAC is glorious.The fresh colors and preservation of the frescos and altar panels is unbelievable.You do not have to be "arty" to find the exhibits jaw dropping and well worth the trip.Great views over the city from Montjuic are a bonus.

Nice museum. The museum is located on top of a hill overlooking the city. Access to the museum is up several flights of stairs, but fortunately there are escalators as well.We visited the Mordern Art section and there were a large range of paintings and sculptures. A room is dedicated to Gaudi with pieces from the Gaudi Park, sample doors and chairs. There were only 2 Salvador Dali paintings and one Picasso. There were, many other Spanish painters. Also included were early century posters and some photographic art.We were allowed in free and it would appear that this is the case on some days and times.

Unique art. If you like art the "Medieval/Romanesque part of this museum is not to be missed. The way this art is displayed is amazing. The Gothic art section is extensive and beautiful. The art provides a view of the development of art and a view into Catholic history in Catalonia and other parts of Spain. I went to the Modern and Contemporary Art section my last visit to Barcelona, and enjoyed it but found it less unique.

Excellent collection. Spent an afternoon here but could have spent the whole day. Excellent collection in an amazing building on montjuic overlooking barcelona. Be sure to also visit museau jean miro which is only a 15 min walk away.

We spent the better part of two days here and loved every minute of it.. Great museum. We loved this place and spent the better part of two days enjoying it to the fullest. It is wonderful and has so much art that we in the USA have no knowledge. It was a good eye opener for us. We highly recommend spending some time here.
beautiful. Highly recommend this, the work is stunning. The history even better. Prebook and buy tickets online.

Great building, great views. The building is classical in style and very well suited to housing works of art, The current exhibitions of Romantic and Gothic frescoes, murals and wall art are awe inspiring, even for the non-religiously inclined. The views over the city, from both museum roof and terrace, and around the magic fountain are magnificent.

Inspiring and amazing collections!. Fantastic collections here. I especially loved the ancient murals collected from various chapels and churches that have been set up here, in recreations of church naves, etc. Incredible, I have never seen anything like it. There was also a beautiful furniture exhibit when we visited. Not to mention that all the usual exhibits here are wonderful. You will need to set aside several hours to really dig in and enjoy the MNAC!Beautiful building in a great location on a hill. Be sure to go up to the deck and have a good look out at the city. A great location for selfies, with Barcelona at your back!

Art all around!!!. If you like as I do you can`t miss this place. I was really very impressedd with the collection as I was not expecting to see. The building is amazing. Ypu can not miss if you like art.

Vale pelo exterior. O edifício e o local em redor são do mais bonito que existe. Mas o museu em si tem peças demasiado parecidas (repetitivas), o que o torna pouco deslumbrante. A visitar o museu que seja no primeiro domingo de cada mês, uma vez que aí as entradas são gratuitas. The building and the scenary are very beautiful. But the museum itself has too many repeated pieces, which makes the museum not that great, I would say. If you want to visit it, make sure it is on the first sunday of the month, as the entrance is free.
Stunning location great art gallery. The collection is one of the best and certainly most varied in Barcelona. We particularly liked the modern art section. Must return to do it justice
Inspiring. By visiting this museum i was so inspired by amazing peaces of art. So interesting to see all exhibitions, dont lose opportunity to visit on of the best museum.

A wonderful view. I can't really review the museum as to be honest we didn't have time to go inside. The museum is beautiful on the outside though with it's statues, fountains and architecture. The view over Barcelona is incredible and worth the trip in itself.
Art. We enjoyed the art work shown at this museum. We only wish that we could see the contemporary wing which was under construction and closed.

Alot to see!. Had some free time in between two tours we booked and we went to this museum as recommended by our guide. it was amazing! Many wings with a lot of art! Everything from the midevil periods to the present! Highly recommended!

Fabulous frescos!. We very much enjoyed our free visit on a Sunday afternoon/evening, although there is normally an admission fee. Allow about 2 hours just to absorb the galleries. Something for all tastes. The climb or elevator trip to the roof terraces are well worth it, with stunning 360 views over the city. There is a cafe in a beautiful musical concert hall and good toilet facilities. Don't forget to visit the vaulted underground exhibitions. The most stunning waterfalls, fountains of light and music and the sparkling view at night, is also well worth waiting for at sundown. You can access in wheelchairs but a taxi or bus is recommended to the Gallery otherwise three elevators or steep steps are the other option. There are also some steps in-side the museum to negotiate.

Informative and well presented displays. Located at Barceloneta. Two floors of displays with one pre 1714 and one post. Very interesting and modern easy to follow displays. Enough English to follow history easily. Enjoyed visit. Probably allow 2 hours for visit.

Take the road less travelled. The easiest way to reach MNAC might be taking the red line of the subway and hopping off at Plaça Espanya. Yet, I'd recommend another path to you that I myself prefer: Take the green-line subway from Las Ramblas (from Liceu or Paral-lel) or simply reach the funicular station to the Parc de Montjuic. When you get off the funicular, turn left (the opposite direction of the cable car station for the castle up ahead). You are on the Miramar Avenue. Walk until you pass the Fundacio Mirò and arrive at the intersection. Turn right or simply follow the signs for "MNAC". There, you will be walking downwards on the Passeig de Santa Madrona. The path is so nice and quiet. When you finish this Passeig, you'll see MNAC on your lefthand side. The city lies ahead and you'll have one of the most beautiful panoramas with a sight reaching Tibidabo!

Loved the Modern Art not into Gothic. This is a good size museum with great views of the city. They have chairs and tables to sit and relax and enjoy the views. The restaurant in the museum has stunning views but is not cheap. I very much enjoyed the modern art section with some great works. I was not into the gothic art so I basically skipped it.

Very beautiful building with impressive surrounding.. I wasn't inside. But you definitely need to walk around. there is great view from the main entrance and a lot of many other interesting things around. Building is very interesting outside.

Almost Missed This. Thanks to one of the front desk clerks at our hotel, we made our way to the Plaza de Espana to see the fountain then climbed (and it is a climb coming from that direction, even with the escalators) to the Museu. The building and its location alone are worth a visit, but its Medieval art was eye-popping. The area with the more modern paintings was closed for reno, so I can't comment on that, but according to the sign, it should be open by October 1.We treated ourselves to lunch in the restaurant at the top of the building--incredible view and the food was good.
Stunning Building. Lovely collection of art in a fabulous setting. We just visited the 'modern' art (1888 and onwards) which included painting, sculpture and furniture. well worth a visit.

Surprise! This place is packed with stars!. We thought this was a palace, so were pleasantly surprised by the news that it was an art museum, and then again when the staff told us that the gallery had free entry from 3pm! Hurrah! (I think it was originally a palace which might explain our naivety!)Lots of art work and plenty of names you will know. Take the time to head upstairs (lift or stairs) to check out the brilliant Joan Miro installation that was created for IBM in the 70's. There was also an allegedly great view from the top, but there was a bit of a queue and looked like you might need to pay for this luxury, so we didn't check it out.

Spectacular Views. The hidden gem to this palatial museum set high on the hill is enjoying the roof top views although the museum was nice and the frescos are impressive nothing beats the roof! Once you enter at the front there is a small sign on the far right that leads you to the elevator which stops at the restaurant once you get off the elevator you must go about 2 more flights of stairs to gain access to the top. Breathtaking views don't miss the opportunity to travel 360 degrees around the top I happened to stumble upon the "hidden" arrows as I was taking amazing pictures of Barcelona and the beautiful architecture of the museum. I recommend planning an journey to the museum by way of Parc de Montjic by traveling up the Funicular located at Metro Par-lel then walking down the through the botanical gardens to the museum.

What a view of Barcelona from here!. Well the view over Barcelona from here is breathtaking. You can see the bull ring, cathedral, and lots of other points of interest. And all that before turning around to take in the beauty of MNAC. The towers and turrets are beautiful in design and the Barcelona Touristica bus take you right to the door step. Make sure you get off and spend time here. We didn't go inside so can't comment on that but still scores top marks for the exterior alone!
Fantastic venue. Really enjoyed our visit to MNAC, Lovely location with a nice cafe. Free entry on a Saturday afternoon after 3pm!

Great visit, depending on your likes for art. When I visited only the medieval and renaissance galleries were open. The renaissance gallery seems to go on forever with endless Madonna and child versions... by the time I was through there I felt as if I'd been walking the Louvre without as many staircases to climb. The medieval section on the other hand was fascinating with recreations taken from 12 century Catalan churches... of course, you might not be equally fascinated.I spent near 3 hours overall here. Tickets are good for 2 days if you have time to come back. You have a fine view over the city from the steps in front of the museum. And a chance to grab a snack (soft drinks, coffee, sandwiches) from a stand at the entrance... you might even be able to snare a chair at a table to eat if you wish. Prices are what you'd expect... beyond normal but its about a monopoly situation.From here you can walk to numerous other visit spots. Took me a bit to find the pathway signs but once in sight you're set.

impressive. the whole area is amazing...big. worth visiting. all the waterfalls on the different levels, on top you can have a bite and drink before going in to the Museu. If you are lucky there might be a free exposition.

A fabulous museum and a great view to boot!. At the top of the hill behind the Plaza Espanya, this museum houses an excellent collection. Be sure to go to the top/roof garden for the views whcih are stellar... Has a great gift shop as well.

Even if you don't go inside, the view from here is awesome.... Catch a glimpse of the amazing views and tranquil, lush surroundings overlooking the city centre from this wonderful location. Take a bus trip to the top to enjoy the steep climb with panoramic views.

Wow.Great job has been done there!. The biulding itsself is promising already at the first sight!Easy access as well to the top of it,with a respectful number of exhibitions from all the eras of catalunyan art!On the cons, I 'd say that the coffee one can enjoy right outside of the museum is extrreemely expensive,as well as that it's pretty easy for someone to enter for free and enjoy the non-free exhibitions inside,as the security..well,they won't check you that much (that could be a positive thing too,of course!)!!!
Beautiful Building and Surroundings. Take stairs when you get out from the museum and enjoy the views of the fountains. Absolutely magnificent

Favorite exhibit was closed, otherwise...yay?. This museum is understocked in varieties of art. It's predominantly a place for Gothic, Romanesque and other related Medieval genres with a heavy emphasis on Catholicism and the themes of the Crusades. While the work is amazing to see up close - especially if you love death and gore on gold leaf - much of the collection goes on forever with no deviation. I was sorely disappointed in the measly Baroque and Romanticism collections. Baroque is my favorite of the old styles and it just isn't abundant here. The entire modern art collection was CLOSED FOR THE DAY so I tragically cannot comment on anything there.The greatest feature of this museum is sadly not its art collection, but its location and tranquil grounds. Out front a sweeping view of the city can be reached by climbing some epic hill-sloping staircases, or using some escalators and a few ramps. Once at the top there is a huge fountain and lovely terrace serving a modest range of wine, spirits and casual eats. A Flamenco guitarist was there playing for tips, excellently I might ad. It was an unexpected treat for the day to sit with Mojitos and enjoy a sun soaked panorama of Barcelona all the way to the hills.

Beautiful works lie within. Walking up to the Art museum is wonderful in itself...waterfalls, lots and lots of stairs...or, an escalator if you're tired...but, once you go in, the exterior, which I believe was completed in 1929, transforms into a modern space that houses some of the best Gothic artwork I have ever seen. Worth a visit

For Gothic Art Enthusiasts. What made this art museum interesting are the fountains and grounds outside, the views of Barcelona and the gothic art housed within the splendid architecture of this building. While this type of art is not my favorite for those who appreciate it this museum will fill your interest. The special exhibits are very good but some where closed during our visit.

interesting buiding and unique collection. apart from the obvious Spainish painters represented the section on Catalan Romanesque Churches was stunning both in an informative and presentational sense and in content. up there with best exhibitions I have visited. The aurak guide also v good. Cafe/Bistro on top pricey but pretty good food with amazing views.

Very enjoyable. I don't consider myself a fan of Romanesque and Gothic art but this museum has a fascinating collection that is artfully displayed. Well worth the visit, both inside and out as the setting is beautiful as well. There are lots of escalators to help navigate the hill.

Marvelous. We visited the museum in July and it was packed!!! A lot of waiting outside and inside to see most significant art pieces. I haven't visited many art museum to make a comparison but it gives a great feeling, even goose pumps. The collections was rich and the presentation is great.We visited the museum on the way to the Olympic Montjuic complex and the Magic Fountain and there was no fee. As i understood later, after 3 pm is free in Saturdays.

A Wonderful Museum. The Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya is a wonderful museum that has plenty of art. My wife and I spent 1.5 hours there. I especially enjoyed the Carmen Thyssen Collection. The Romanesque and Gothic collections are also great to see. The modern collection was closed to visitors when we went, which was a disappointment.

Beautiful Building and Contents - Beware Pickpockets. The beauty of the building and fountains is amazing! So amazing, the pickpockets count on the fact that you will be mesmerized and not notice someone bumping into you. Not much in the way of Police presence. Do not let this deter you! Just keep your valuables secure.

Shuttle through time and space. I visited the museum mainly because of its collection of catalan romanesque art. And this collection is the most disturbing, beautiful, yes: exotic art collection I have seen in a long time. Although not unfamiliar with the art of those times, I never experienced such awe and sheer perplexion, not only of the incredible high quality of the pieces shown but of how strongly they present a mental and pictorial world that is so so different from ours. It is a common thing to compare contemporary graphic art to the way of representation in medieval art. It helps just a little. I still felt like visiting another planet.The presentation in the museum is superb: the collection is superrich but it is placed so spacy and so well curated that you never get exhausted by the length of the exhibition path. And how they dealt with the apses in fresco, extending into the exhibition-space, that is so original and refreshing. And after the collection you will be spit out in that hysterical architecture of the Palau Nacional. I can take only so much....

Enjoyable visit!. This is a huge museum - it's best to allow a minimum of three hours. Although it's not customary to find museums on my itinerary, this is one that's not to be missed. It's a total package and the setting overlooking the fountains is priceless.

Beautiful art museum. This is an extremely beautiful art museum and both the permanent and temporary exhibits are worthwhile. I am giving it only 4 stars because the modern art galleries were closed during my visit. While it would have been nice to see these, there are nevertheless some interesting collections here. I found the Medieval collection extremely interesting, especially the way the frescos were presented in situ. The Plaza de Espanja leading up to the museum is of interest as well, if for no other reason that the huge fountains and panoramic views that it provides of this beautiful city.

only 3 dots because half closed. I wanted to see the modern art, but half the museum was closed for work!! They did have a pretty good sampling in the temporary exhibit space. so I went to see the gothic and Romanesque sectioned\ and was pleasantly surprised, not gloomy at all.

Great Medieval Romanesque Art - Modern Art Closed Until October. This is a great museum with a great collection of Medieval Romanesque art. We like how the rooms were laid out, with the frescoes in recreated structures where they were found. The view from the roof was also amazing. We visited in September and all of the 19th and 20th Century art is not on exhibit while they renovate. We were disappointed that even the main pieces were no longer on temporary exhibit or moved to a different location in the museum. We were still very happy we visited and now look forward to another trip.

Impressive building, Collection so-so. The MNAC is supposed to house 7,000 artworks but the top floor was undergoing renovation when we were there and we kinda felt cheated. Still, the building itself is impressive and the ticket actually allows you to visit it again on another day. It has an amazing collection of restored church murals though under its Gothic Art section. Still worth a visit but probably more worth it when the upper floor completes its renovation.

The National Palace of Art. Catalan art, that is. It looks down at the Placa Espana, looks down as the Catalans look down on Espana both then & now. All museums in Barcelona are free on Sundays & it would take several days to do this museum justice. We arrived a tad into the Sunday free hours & ran through it. After it closed we enjoyed refreshments outside on the terrace looking down at Placa Espana, the bull fighting ring converted into a mall & out at the entire city beyond. We want to return to Barcelona & to this museum when we have the time to do it justice. The historic religious art collection is accompanied with more modern art right up to & including the 20th century. The building itself is also the art worth seeing, so look around & up at the ceilings. The grand space where the magnificent organ is will dwarf you & awe you as well.

The Water Show at night is a must see. We're not museum people so we never actually went in. However during the day the view from the steps is amazing, there's a little bar there you can grab a glass of wine and just enjoy the view. Live music was playing there when we went. At the entrance from the parking lot you should see two Trikes renting them for rides....it's a must! Probably one of the most memorable moments from my trip. I've never been on a motorcycle before maybe that's why I enjoyed it so much. Don't let the confederate flag deter you, they're from Norway and to them the flag just represents American Rebel.At night at the bottom of the steps at the fountain they put on a light/water show. It's amazing and definitely something to see.

A Must-See. It's worth heading up here even if just for the view and for a walk round the nearby parks on the hill. The museum itself is huge and really interesting to wander round, plus there's free entry after 3pm on a Saturday. We got the bus up the hill and explored the nearby Olympic Park area too, then walked down to the Magic Fountain before jumping on the metro back to our hotel.

Wow…fabulous art!. Great medieval art in an amazing location. I could have spent hours walking around. The colours of the religious art work is so intense and mesmerising. One of the best art museums I have ever visited. Wear walking shoes and be prepared to spend some time here…you will want to.

lovely setting - don't eat here. the museum was undergoing some renovations while we were there so we couldn't gain full access. The highlight was actually the terrace walk along the roof, the views were spectacular. We made the mistake of fasting too long, and ended up having to eat in the museum cafe on the ground floor because we were so hungry. (there is another restaurant on an upper floor) By far, the worst experience of our week-long holiday. A choice of three "mains" from a bain-marie buffet. Actually couldn't identify which one was which from the menu, because they were all slop. The waitress was horrifically unhelpful, and we actually got more information from fellow patrons. Beautiful museum, just eat before you get there.

Nice to visit again. I had already visited it in a previous visit, but I was happy to go in again. Unfortunatly, the modern art section was temporary closed, but at any rate the museum worth a visit, as the building itself.

This view is NOT to be missed!. I didn't go into the actual museum however I did enjoy a drink from the cafe whilst marvelling over the spectacular views of Barcelona. Only one way to describe it - WOW.We happen to be there on a scorching hot day and could see for miles and miles.Luckily for the less active type, there are escalators taking you up and down which for me was a great addition with two small children.An absolute must see.

Boring without modern art. Better to stay outside and enjoy the beautiful view, then spending time inside. With more or less only paintings and sculptures of Jesus and decorations in churches, it gets a bit boring and single minded when the first floor with modern art isn't there.

An amazing experience. It was a real experience to visit the MNAC this year. They've managed to recreate chapels and churches of Romanesque, Gothic ad Byzantine eras and bring the original frescoes onto the walls in an amazing way. Worth a long visit indeed - make sure you allow plenty of time for this excellent collection of paintings and artifacts. We were sorry the modern collection was closed for renovation but we'll definitely go back next year to the that as well.
Wau!. Massive museum and probably the most photogenic place in Barcelona, go , this is a must see, behind the museum is more attractions so chech them out as well.

A lot to see.. Visited with a German friend and we paid for the audio guides. The English audio guide was fairly comprehensive, but the German guide was not.
Overall, the museum was good. Most of the signage was in Catalan, so it was hard to understand.

Must Come Here If You're in Barcelona.. Beautiful both inside and out. Beautiful art. The architecture of the Museum itself is beautiful and has amazing views of the city. There's a show with music and lights with the fountains in front of the museum. It's a great place to go with friends or family. Me encanto!

Beautiful medieval painting. Greta place to see some of the finest fresco paintings in Catalan Romanesque Art. Lovely ambient of Montjuic and most probably the best spot to observe panorama of Barcelona having coffee, sangria or cava sparkling wine in museum coffee bar.

Fantastic views of the city. Although it gets crowded outside, there are never many people inside, so do have a look around, it's free!The fountains are light at night and give an amazing show. Better to get the City tour bus and get off at the top and walk down (you can always get back on the bus at the bottom and go around again!)
Very rich collections. Amazing collections of art and architecture very well presented. A beautiful edifice with stunning view over the city
Breathtaking. Beautiful views, amazing pictures, a must see especially at night. I didn't pay to go inside but had fun taking pictures and walking all the way up to the entrance. A beautiful view

Great place to visit and the view of the city. It was a nice place with great art. I appreciate the temporary art which was great portraits done with water-colour.A lovely view of the city which is a great photo opportunity.

Amazing views.... We visited the Museum twice; the views made it worth coming back for more. Head up to the top of the steps and then turn around and try now and be wow-ed; we enjoyed a very cold beer at the top and would do it again and again and again.

Great way to spend an afternoon.. The museum is spectacular there is so much to see once you get inside and even from the outside what a view. There are multiple galleries you can view all with amazing collections of work.I would definitely recommend and revisit.

Gorgeous!. Thie museum was under construction when we visited, so we only saw two sections. The art was really secondary to the building and grounds, though. The approach was stunningly beautiful, and you can go up to a rooftop viewing area that has incredible views of the city. Just that was worth the price of admission.

Best museum experience in Barcelona. This multi level building is gorgeous inside and out. Many one of a kind exhibitions, don't miss any of them. Take the elevator to the roof and walk completely around 360 degree views.

Worth the trip, if only for the views. The Museum is at the top of a hill that steep that there are escalators up, we used the hop on hop off bus which stops outside.There are magnificent view from the steps of the Museum.The museum leaflet has some key items shown by their location on the room plan.We used our Museum pass which included a ticket to the roof from where the entire city can be surveyed.Shorter queues here but again the pass bypassed them completely.

Great, both inside and outside. Free after 3 pm Saturday. Don't get there too late as the museum starts to ask guests to get out at 7.45pm. I prefer this museum and the neighborhood area more than all the Gaudi's places. As you get out from the station Pl. Espanya, you see the Arena of Barcelona (the inside is now a commercial center), which is also very nice. Then you have to walk about 600-700m to get to the museum which is on the top of the hill, looking down on n the city. The walk to the museum itself is also enjoyable.Inside, they have rather nice collections. The biggest one of them is the antique mural painting collection. After the visit, if it's on the weekend, you can wait till the water show at the Magic Fountain downhill. All these things worth a whole weekend afternoon.

great art gallery. First buy your BCN hola ticket which gives you free entry to the whole gallery. Some parts are free anyway. Fantastic exhibition going from medieval to modern with some interesting Guadi furniture as well.

Very nice museum. I would definitely recommend visiting this museum if you're in Barcelona. They have a broad art collection featuring works from Miró, Picasso and Casas as well as medieval works. It's not crowded, so you'll have the time and room to comfortably take a look here. Students have free entrance to a part of the museum.

Free at Sundays, nice art and great view. This was end of our walk in Montjuic. And timing was nice for us. It was sunday and after 3pm it was free entre. Great art there at museum . And great view to Placa Espanya from roof. Also Terrace there. Definitely worth of visit.
