Stunning. Both by day and by night, this museum is worth a visit. By day, in order to see the museum building and displays, but night to see the impressive fountains, with the spectacular colours and music!

Stunning museum :-). Easy to reach by metro ( Lines 1 or 3- Pl. Espanya) from far you will be amazed by this stunning building and the Montjuïc fountain next to it! We bought a combine tickets online (18€ Museum+ Poble Espanyol). This museum presents original Catalan art but is also known for its extensive collection of Romanesque paintings. I do recommend to rent an audio guide, otherwise you might not enjoy much since the paintings and sculptures have only catalá-spanish-french descriptions. On the top of the museum there is a nice terrace with spectacular views of the city. For me it's was a formidable and very cultural experience!!

Great museum, great view, mind that modern works not on exhibit till end of Sep. Probably the best museum in Barcelona - a fantastic, spacious building with various wings dedicated to medieval, renaissance and modern art (though if you're a fan of the latter, you should be aware that they're re-doing the entire wing and as a result, only a few of the works are on exhibit until end of September). A must-visit attraction with a fantastic view of the fountains and the city itself.

Spectacular. This is the best place in Barcelona for me, right besides the Montjuic park, this is a real architectural gem. It is beautiful both in daytime and at night, when the magic fountain fill the place with music, color and breeze wet air. This is a scene worth the whole visit to Barcelona.

Well worth a visit. Paid entry but worth it if you have a morning to spare. If on a flying visit be aware that you can see some exhibits for free. When we were there the modern section was being refurbished and a temporary exhibition of highlights of modern art was free to view. We paid our money and were not disappointed. The church murals are amazing. Go, spend some time, relax, enjoy. Food, here as in many museums, is expensive however.

Spent a whole day here, feeding the pigeons some popcorn and watching cute little sparrows sneak in and stealing some.. Sat in front of the fountain for a while, it was relaxing watching the people get lost in the atmosphere, finally headed inside the museum, which has incredible art work! A must see for sure. There was a park to the side which is also worth a visit.

Interesting building and artifacts. Spent a good 3 hours in this place - there is a lot to see especially if you want to see the history of Christianity and it's impact on Bacelona, plenty of frescoes to see, past coinage etc.

GORGEOUS!. we had an All White party here and my husband and i said it reminded us for the movie Hunger Games and being in the Capital! It was out of the world! The museum has one of the most breathtaking views of Barcelona! Make the walk up to it and just take in the city!

Highly recommended for the fabulous views of Barcelona!. Located on a hill, this is one of the most impressive museums in Spain , if not Europe. Even if you are not interested or short of time for viewing the collections, I would still recommend going here for the amazing views of the city. For a small fee, they let you climb up the roof of MNAC and the views are unmatched and definitely worth the visit..There is a small cafe at the entrance which is great for a relaxing break from the sightseeing...lets you linger and soak in Barcelona in all its true beauty....fabulous indeed:)

Outstanding well organized museum - especially the Romanesque exhibits. MNAC is a fabulous museum especially to see Catalonian art. It is located on Montjuic. The building itself is beautiful to see. Once inside the museum is well organized and as you enter each section you are guided through the exhibit in a logical manner. Its most famous exhibits are the romanesque collection in which many frescos have been removed from their churches and preserved to avoid them being stolen. The museum has done a fabulous job of recreating the architectural structure of the churches from which the art was taken so that they can be displayed as originally intended. The explanations on the wall do a good job describing the art. There are also a few interactive displays to add more to the visitors experience. We also viewed the modern area of the museum, which is currently a temporary exhibit while the permanent facility undergoes renovation. Though this was a limited display the museum has included some significant pieces from modern artists such as Gaudi (furniture), Dali and Picasso. Overall this museum is well worth a visit. There is a restaurant inside and a little cafe outside selling sandwiches, quiches, ice cream etc...

Music Lover. If you are a music enthusiast, this is a place for you to visit. A fascinating experience for me. I am sure i am not the only one who thinks so... but the place is very crowded, it was during the season i guess.
a must!. wonderful religious frescoes from 1100 -1500 AD….the general artworks and sculptures are the finest in Spain and some of the best in Europe ….the building itself is a masterpiece.

Get Lost in days gone ........ Religious, contemporary, romance - you want it they have it all on display. They also have on display the biggest organ ever constructed. Located near the Olympic stadium and arch museum so it is a full day of wonder. Stop at the Arenas and get an excellent pitcher of sangria.

Got Lost. One of the funniest experiences of our travels! If you are not an expert on medieval altars the awesome collection of such can be bewildering; we got utterly turned around in the galleries and were reduced to hysterical giggles as we tried to escape the maze. Honest we knew this was important art but... for us the disappointment was that the modern galleries are closed for renovation. Whatever .You are art blind and dumb if you can not find things to enjoy here!

Well Worth the Visit - the Location, the View, the Collection. Walking up the steps to this museum provides inspiring views of the city and the collection is wonderful. Stop in the park and have a coffee or sandwich. Sit on the steps and admire the view.

fantastic. Half of the ground floor modern art section was closed but they had put a ' greatest hits ' selection in the temporary exhibition space in the basement which was wonderfully cool. I had studies art history but had no idea there were so many great Catalan artists. The roof terrace is well worth a visit too.

Worth visiting museum both for collection and view. It's a very nice museum. it was a pity that the part that housed the paintings were under renovation but still they display a good part of the collection in another area. It also has a very nice terrace and provides a good view of the city in a nice sunny day.
Great City Art Museum. Great temporary exhibition of an artist who spent 15 years in Tangiers. Beautiful building. Hard to find a taxi when leaving the museum.
did not go in but the building is amazing. Did not go inside but the outside of the building is an amazing sight. Well worth seeing, incorporate this into a trip up mont juic.

Beautiful building but modern art expo missing!. The MNAC is a stunning building. Entrance was free after 3 on Saturday. Unfortunately the modern art section was mostly closed which was very disappointing. The other displays were very large but layed out in a slightly labyrinthine fashion which was slightly overwhelming. Notwithstanding this it is worth the visit but wait until the new modern art expo is ready.
great architecture. took a lot of photos of the place. Great exterior design. Not a fan of museums and art though.so it gets boring for me.also it was a bit expensive for the ticket entrance.
Amazing View. The art selection was OK. However, the view and architecture was amazing. Make sure your ticket covers the terrace view so you can see all of Barcelona. Free wifi in central locations.
Not so good. Not what I expected, and not in a good way. Two of the expositions were closed, the collection was very small and there was no information that you can visit only part of the museum.
Worth a look. The building from outside and the surrounding area is spectacular and not to be missed. The museum equally impressive and given the free admission it is not to be overlooked.

Beautiful location, nice collection. The museum's location and its building are artwork in itself. The collection is good, and the way the interior of some of the old cathedrals was removed and reinstalled is amazing. It is challenging to a non-Catalan or non-Spanish speaker to follow the significance of each piece, as they are only labeled in these languages. I believe there is an audio guide available in other languages, but we did not take advantage of it.

Well worth the stop. I was on a hop&go bus tour because I wanted to go to Mount Juic. I didn't know about the MNAC and it was a nice discovery.What I found different from other museum expositions is that there's a lot of gothic art. Also early christian art is gory and not censored.The museum itself is spacious, easily accessible and the price entree is reasonable, compared to others.

Beautiful building, great collection and student discount!. Incredible museum with some great pieces that should not be missed! Renaissance, gothic, medieval and modern art, all housed in stunning surroundings. Well worth the visit. The coffee at the top of the steps outside was cheap, yummy and you have a great view too (: Also if you have a student card you get 30% off entry, always a winner.

Great museum for art. This is a beautiful museum even from the outside. It's magnificent to see and at the start of Montjuic Park. There are many things to see in the park, but this museum is great. It's a very large museum and things are spread out nicely. You can go for free on Saturday's after 3:00 which we did not realize as we had purchased an Articket that got us in to 6 different art museums. If you like art, this is a great place to go. Very beautiful.

Romanesque church art. ...from little churches scattered throughout the Pyranees. Good gothic collection too. If you like that kinda stuff, you're going to like this museum. Also the fountains are pretty cool and the building is interesting. The Miro ceramic tile mural and the painting (frescos?) inside the dome are pretty good too.

Far better from the outside.. This is written by a 20 year old guy who is not hugely interested in older art so it is going to be obviously biased and not the museums target audience. The only time I have been more bored in my entire life is when I was forced to count bricks at school ( 2344 ), while I appreciate the time and passion that goes into the painting I failed to appreciate the skill or the feelings the artist was trying to convey. I found most of the patrons observing the art to have a mean age of 406 and the attitude towards the interest of a younger audience is the same as one might expect of a person who has awoken to discover his legs have been eaten off by platypus'. The staff are kind and courteous as one would be to someone who you believe has a mental disability but lacks the curtesy to treat them like a human being. You can't take a backpack into the museum and not can you take a bottle of water as it may be seen as something more interesting than the art. The work by Gaudi is brilliant and the Mural on the ceiling is breathtaking. Go an a Saturday afternoon or on the first Sunday of the month, it's free!

A great place to view the spectular light show they have on Thursday nights.. A must see. They have a wonderful collection of frescos, learn the process of how they prepared this exhibit. Check into catching the spectular water show in the main fountain area on Thursday and Friday nights. Starts at 9pm.
Wow what a theatre. Yes Yes go and see a show and sit and marvel at the fantastic surroundings. Enjoyed every minute of it and took lots of photos before at interval and afterwards.
Lovely to look at from the outside. We didn't actually go in but we walked around this beautiful building! Definitely worth a visit.There are escalators going up to the building.

Worth a visit for sure. If nothing else, walk up to MNAC just to get a look at the view and a closer look at the fountains but once you're up there you really ought to visit MNAC - pleased we did. Some parts of the museum were closed when we were there but thoroughly enjoyed the Roman and Gothic exhibits. Well laid out so we were able to wander through without doubling back etc - just had a natural flow.It was possible to get really close to the works for a close up view most of the time which I appreciated. Sometimes it's nice to see the brushstrokes or the canvas underneath. The wall-mounted info labels for the various art pieces weren't written in English so we were sometimes at a loss as to what we were looking at but it was often self explanatory or we could guess with our knowledge of Spanish (not sure how accurate our guessing was!). Many of the paintings depicted terrible and pretty graphic suffering which was interesting and engrossing in an odd way. There were also some nice painted wooden alters, decorated with metal - not something I've seen much of before.There's a café inside the middle of the museum but we chose to have a coffee outside with the view. The shop sold postcards (and a huge range of other items) - 10 for €2 which was a bit of a bargain!It would be an uphill walk, but not far to the Joan Miró Foundation from here but wouldn't suggest the two in one day necessarily - both quite engaging and deserve full attention! (except if some of the exhibits are still closed when you visit).

Must see and see again!. Museum of National Art of Catalunya. Gorgeous building and gorgeous collections. Inside of a beautiful parkland with gardens. Don't forget to visit the Olimpic park as well - the impressive reminder of Barcelona's Olympic Games.

Great Collection of Medieval and Renaissance Art. Worth a stop you you enjoy Medieval or Renaissance art. Beautiful location and free admission with the Articket pass. As always be careful with your belonging. We saw the happy conclusion of a purse snatching. Several bystanders chased and returned with a woman's purse which I believe was taken after she left it hanging from her chair while seated at the outdoor cafe near where the buses drop you off at the museum.

Highly recommended - you will enjoy it!. There are many good reasons to visit MNAC, put simply it is a spectacular national gallery that opened my knowledge of the art and culture of the region. Some of the good reasons to visit are:1. The stunning view of the MNAC as you arrive from the vantage point of the musical fountain.2. The bird's eye vista of the city when you reach the MNAC.3. The intimate internal architecture as you walk in and throughout the gallery.4. €12 for an adult was valid for two days and other galleries. 5 There was no long queue to get in compared to other sites.6. The exhibitions were splendid and I learned so much about art of the region.7. There were accessible toilets for people who use wheelchairs. And toilets in each wing.8. The cafeteria was excellent and affordable, or a gorgeous restaurant upstairs.9. The dome was beautiful. 10. The gallery shop was one of the best shops.11. Public transport close by.12. A shopping centre nearby.
Nice. Nice and impressive from the outside and offers very nice view of the city! Also, there is decent sangria up there :)

Museu Nacional d'Art de Cataluna. Nothing like taking time to see a museum, it would have been helpful in being able to read more of the language in Spanish, but you can get by. Again a lot of great art of see.
Really amazing :). In evening it's really nice and romantic, with music and lights..Also if you go on top of big shopping center on the other side it's nice view..
No need to pay. You can get into the museum and the temporary exhibition at the hall (or the auditorium) for free. That's good enough to see if you don't bother about paintings so much.

Well worth the visit for lovers of Romanesque Art. The guide book we used gave this museum only mild endorsement. We found the exhibition of Romanesque are to be beautiful and superbly displayed. It is a real gem for those who have a love of art from this period. We also delighted in walk through the fair grounds with it fountains, stair ways and and shady paths.
Wow!. It sits atop a hillside overlooking the city. You will be amazed by the diverse collection and the city views.

Beautiful Trip up to the MNAC. The museum is ok; however, all the sightseeing on your way to the MNAC is well worth it. The view is spectacular and you could sit right outside with a glass of wine and enjoy the people and view.

Palace and National Art Museum. My wife and I walked to the Palace from the Rambla - about 30 minutes on a pleasant, sunny day. The Palace was worth the effort. Wonderful vista of the city skyline, beautiful fountains, a welcome police presence, and available WCs and refreshment stands. An added plus is the ready access to the Olympic Park just behind the palace. It's a freebie too. We decided to pass up the museum.

Some Amazing collection and some ehh.... The building itself is worth seeing and it's a easy walk from the subway. Once you get up there is also a great view of the city. I didn't like all the collections especially the Roman art and there wasn't English descriptions on all the work so that was really disappointing.

A gem of a museum!. No trip to Barcelona is complete without a visit to MNAC. The Romanesque art collection is world-class. We set aside an hour to walk the beautifully manicured grounds and enjoyed the fountains.

Astonishing!!. In my opinion, after Sagrada familia is the second best building in Barcelona. Sadly, I was there on a Monday, so it was close and no water show either. But still I enjoy it. Just disconnect for 10 minutes from everything and enjoy the sunset!

Not into religious art. Much of the work was Christian historical which my husband and & have no appreciation for, especially many paintings showing vulgar torture scenes. The building inside is modern & spacious.
Beautiful start to a great trip. Great collection of art and the building itself is incredibly impressive. The walk up to it in itself is excellent. Must see attraction for anyone visiting Barcelona.

MNAC interesting in many ways. The MNAC can be visited for various reasons, we were charmed by the small modern art collection in the cellar, the scenery from the roof is also very beautiful and we had lunch in the oleo restaurant; it was a pity that the MNAC closed so early in the sunday afternoon (15h).
excellent medieval art. The layout of the museum is fantastic. The display of arts are excellent and intuitive. The renaiscence period is also very good.

For art lovers!. Housed in Palau Nacional building, is one of the foremost museums in Barcelona. Great building in a great zone and full of art which comes from almost one thousand years of beautiful art from various periods... Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance and nouveau Catalan. Ideal place for the art lovers!
Walk to the top for best view. We did not go in however you can admire the famous square of placa espanya from MNAC. Fountains, architect and amazing views..definitely come and see this area!

Stunning view. We got lost in the beggining thinking this building was Montjuic Castle - and ended wasting 15 euros paying for the awfully expensive entrance of the former. This building - the right one!! - is free to look at and the fountain gives a completely stunning view. Also very refreshing to be around the water in the hot weather of Barcelona!

We will tour inside the Next Time. We took the on/ off tour bus throughout the city and this is one of the stops. We were awestruck when we saw the building and fountains from the sidewalk. We returned in the evening for the light show. The music and colored fountain was nice but you don't need to stay that long. The best was the picture we took on our way home. We would definitely return and tour the museum.

Fantastic views. Impressive and imposing building which is one of the stop off points on the red route of the Barcelona Bus Turistic, my daughter wanted to get off and take some pictures, but sadly, did not have time to visit inside the museum.

cpalomar. Wow. Do take a taxi ride. The location offers beautiful views of Barcelona but more importantly, an excellent collection of works by Catalan and Spanish artists of the 13 to 16 centuries.we did not have time to see the modern collection!
beautiful. A super unexpected pleasure, This is a beautiful building, very helpful staff and so informative on Catalunian art. Set in beautiful surroundings.
AMAZING!. Awesome museum, fantastic views, great fountains - well worth the visit! Quick cab ride from downtown, about 15 minutes max!

Gorgeous Building, Great Views but Limited Free Hours. I arrived here at 2pm on a Saturday, right before the free hours start at 3pm on Saturdays only. So I decided to relax, order a coffee and take in the amazing views of the city from the small square in front of the museum. The free hours started promptly at 3pm and while I was impressed by the excellent collection of Romanesque, Renaissance and Baroque art, I was incredibly disappointed that the sections featuring the modern masters like Picasso and Miró were closed during the free hours. I would have paid for the full ticket if I had known in advance or did some research instead of becoming entranced by the magnificent view. In any case, seeing the El Greco they had was worth the arduous trek up the steep Montjuïc via the tastefully concealed escalators leading up the hill from Plaça de Espanya to the museum. Nicely done, Barcelona.
Unreal!. We climbed to the top and then to the bottom. You simply must take a picture at every level. The fountains and architecture alone make this a must do on your trip.

Astonishing View at day and night. Came here twice just to sit outside, ear gelato and enjoy the scenic view. I didn't go to into the museum. But why a great place to have this structure. I enter eyed the mountain from the opposite side (beach side) and walked towards this end by getting a chance to see everything on the mountain. WIFI is everywhere so I took the time to FaceTime my family and share the view. So many people, beautiful grounds and structure. Take the time to sit on the steps and enjoy the Magic Fountain show

No English.... The building and exhibits are beautiful, definitely worth the visit, and is quite affordable. The view from the terrace is also amazing, and it is only 3 EUR to go up to the terrace (It is included in the ticket price if you visit the museum as well). However...most of the exhibit is only in Spanish or Catalonian. This really put a damper on things for we didn't understand 70% of the exhibits...This was really bothersome, and I understand that this is not an English speaking country, but in a city with so many visitors, we expected that a well known tourist attraction would have English.

Good display of Medieval art work. Though repetitive the collection of Catalunyan Medieval artwork especially the old church apses dating 1000 years old are beautiful and immaculate. Good collection of other artwork till the modern nouvea art of Barca and Catalunya. Great spot on Mont Juic

What a place to have a Museum. This is a really imponent building! Junt above the Montjuic Magic Fountains with a splendid view of the city and Plaza de España. The building itself is really awesome and the itens it has really important and historic!

Iconic art, beautiful building and free entrance on Saturday!. We loved our visit to the Museu Nacional. The building is impressive and beautiful (in a city with memorable architecture). We loved sitting on the front steps to the museum, watching the fountain and views of the city. Some of the galleries are closed for renovation, but there is still a small gallery with art that you likely studied in an art history class as well as newer, less renowned pieces. An added bonus -- entrance that Saturday was free!

Stunning inside and out.. My husband is not a museum buff but he really loved this place. There is so much history in this place I could have spent hours in there. Pretty much everybody have covered the best parts. So I'll just say go and drink it all in.
We really liked this. It was a well presented museum, and lovely restaurant, a haven when the rest of Barcelona was overrun with too many tourists.
Hidden gem of Romanesque art. If you appreciate early (Romanesque) art, then you MUST visit MNAC. The setting is spectacular, and there is a fine restaurant on site.

A wonderful national museum. Another world class museum in a world class building overlooking a set of world class fountains that are wonderful to see at night. A place to visit and make sure that you have enough time to see more than a few exhibits.

Great views of Barcelona and exellent old arts. Take Your time to go there and if don´t want to go museum just climb up or use steirs to go hill and take marvellous pictures of sights, but museum is really worth of seeing!
This is a favorite, if only for the water features.. What a beautiful place. Go for the view of the city of Barcelona from the steps. Look at the fountains and marvel.Breathtaking!

Great Views. This is a great building and it holds lots of cool art. I do like the fact that there will escalators leading up to building. How very modern. Hee hee. It's easy to get too. Definitely well worth a look.

The setting and view are the best features --- and some practical advice. This would rank about 10th on my list of places to visit in Barcelona. To be honest, I'm not a fan of 900-1800 century art. The temporary small exhibition of their contemporary collection (due to remodeling) is very well done and instructive -- mostly less famous artists (less self-promoting?) than the single works of Dali, Picasso and Miro on display. This collection takes about an hour or less. The other collections will take much longer. (For more Miro, visit the excellent Miro Museum in the park.)As other reviews note, admission is free after 3 pm Saturdays and senior admission is free all the time. I was there on a Saturday afternoon (lunch time) and there was no crowd, although it likely gets busier later.The setting is spectacular with views of the park on the backside and an almost panoramic view of Barcelona on the front. The "roof" restaurant is actually only part way to the roof and there are two routes the very top. One is an elevator in the front left side (when you enter) which goes partway up and then two or three stories of stairs. The other elevator, for reasons unknown, is not marked with signs but goes all the way to the top. But to get to it, go through the main hall to the concert hall (with the organ) and head slightly to the right across to the other side where there is a small information table and ask to use the elevator. (The two obvious elevators when you enter the concert hall only go to the restaurant level.) This hidden elevator takes you to the backside of the palace with views of the park. There is new, excellent flooring to stroll around the east end of the roof and eventually to the very front (with a few short stairs involved). If you have limited mobilty, it is a toss-up whether the front or rear elevator is better, since the latter has fewer stairs but more distance to cover.Getting to the Palace can be confusing. Their website only gives general information, such as bus numbers, without any specific map of the route needed to reach the entrance and how much walking is involved. I sent an email asking about the route with least walking and stairs but never got an answer. It turns out there is a parking lot on the right side (facing) where a taxi can drop you off and where the hop on-off Touristic bus stops (but the tickets for that bus are expensive). The route I took involved several escalators starting from the Plaza Espanya -- up escalators on the extreme right of the Magic Fountain and down escalators on the left. First, walk from Plaza toward the palace about 2 city blocks then an escalator to the bridge over a street and a few steps down to a large plaza with trees and small cafes next to the fountain, a pleasant shady place to people watch. Then take another escalator up to the waterfall. At that point, both up and down escalators are now a short block down the sandy road to the right and those take you up to the right side of the palace. You'll see the parking lot and another snack bar. Then walk to the left on the ramp back to the center entrance. If you arrive from the park (back) side by bus or taxi then there appears to be a bit of a walk mostly downhill but no clue on the museum's website about the exact route. The Magic Fountain and other water features really make the whole atmosphere of the Palace special. I highly recommend seeing the Fountian light show (see my review).

Versatile art museum with clear and loud message. What I liked about this museum the most is the strict structure and the clear sequence of the time frames. Having 4 separate exhibitions dedicated to the different ages of the catalan art made it really easy to get it, understand it and feel it! An audio guide of the museum is very professional as well, it adds a lot of sense to all you see and multiplies the use of the visiting museum! My personal favorite is the room full of art-nouveau stuff and, of course, the view from the terrace in front of the palace! I can not say in is top-five of the city's attraction, but for those tourists who visit Barcelona not for the first time, I would recommend to walk by and spend an hour learning something about catalan art. The

Loved it!. So much Romanic and Gothic art! We loved it. Wonderful rooftop views, and the restaurant is absolutely marvelous. Clean and well-placed bathrooms, and a lovely, well-stocked, and reasonably-priced gift shop. The staff are wonderfully friendly and very knowledgeable about the art pieces. We loved our day at the museum.

Wonderful collection of Romanesque and gothic art. Had only a limited time but filled 2 hours with the superb collection of catalayan Romanesque and gothic art. Not sure about the other collections but these were extensive and of high quality
great afternoon. purchased a discount ticket with my hop on hop off discount book. the musuem is huge allow at least 3 hours. ticket allows two days of entry. free locke use.
A Feast for the eyes. Large museum in a beautiful setting at the bottom of Montjuic.Amazing art collection in a beautiful building with waterfalls cascading down the front.

Get some culture. The museum is a very good price with a nice bar/restaurant on the roof. If you have enough of the sun have a wander round the museum which is huge a with so much information you can easily spend a good 3-4 hours in there! Plenty of interactive things to do as well.

Visited when Multiple Main Exhibits were Closed. We visited during a time when almost all of the modern exhibits were closed. The have a beautiful collection of Gothic and Medieval art, but to the untrained eye it all begins to look the same after a few rooms. Travelling exhibits were unspectacular. The view from the rooftop (included free because of the exhibit closures) was the highlight of our visit. Spectacular views of Barcelona!
Amazing preservation. The best part of the display are the preserved sections of artwork taken from the walls of ancient churches and brought to the museum.

Beautiful Building with Good Views. We enjoyed the building and the views more than the art. The frescos were quite nice and we enjoyed all of the religious art. The modern section was not open the day we visited. The cafeteria was substandard in both the selection and quality of the food.

If nothing else, go for the view. We were there on a Saturday, as entrance is free after 3 PM. We chose to walk from the Placa d'Espanya metro station, and it was a very nice experience, climbing the hill little by little, and seeing the views slowly appearing around us.We were in somewhat of a hurry and only had time to see the Baroque and Renaissance exhibit, which was very nice. The entrance to the roof was also free, and we enjoyed sitting there in a light breeze seeing all the way to Tibidabo.

Modern Wing closed. I was very disappointed that the famous modern wing was closed for renovation and they had not set up the temporary modern exhibit yet. So I was stuck with all the medieval stuff. On a positive note, and why this review is getting a "very good" review, the restored Romanesque frescoes were amazing and a one of kind sort of thing. So if you only go for the frescoes, it would be worth it.

Views inside and out. Before you even step inside the MNAC offers some beautiful views of Barcelona. The building itself is gorgeous both inside and out, blending history with modern design. If you are not too interested in looking at ancient artefacts or religious symbols there is still a lot to see in this building. The staff are welcoming, the layout is simple to navigate and they don’t even make you exit through the gift shop, an unusual treat. I still did visit the gift shop! The Oval Hall at the back of the building is huge theatre which hides a little café where you microwave your own food if you want it heated. My favourite exhibition was a temporary one called Joan Colom Photographs 1957-2010. This collection spans decades of photos taken by Colom and his colleagues chronicling the journey from gritty street photography into photojournalism. It ran until May 25, 2014 and if extended is a must for anyone interested in photography. Even if you are not interested in the exhibitions the site of the MNAC is well worth a visit for its architecture and views alone.

Worth a visit. We did not go in the centre but it is well worth a visit . Get a bus or a taxi to Placa espanya . Cannot miss it , an large area with 2 large towers and walk towards MNAC past fountains and up to MNAC . There are some escalators so that it is not all steps . Once at the top there are stone seats for a rest and a little refreshment area . If you then walk behind and up some more escalators you will be on top road and just a short distance from the 1992 Olympic stadium .I don't know if it is worth making a trip to see stadium otherwise but if you are at MNAC you might as well and then if you go past the stadium ie left from MNAC you will soon get to the cable car up to Montjuic castle , then later down funicular to Parallel subway ..... 2 stops and back in Ramblas ...All done in about 2 1/2 hours .

My Favorite Barcelona Museum. Romanesque art, I thought to myself. Do I even care about Romanesque art? After a visit here, the answer is most definitely yes. This museum is so well-curated and brings together so many interesting pieces that I'd highly recommend it even for someone who has no special interest in art. Many of galleries are built to resemble the original churches from which the art on display was brought in. The staff is happy to answer questions (in Spanish or English). The size of the collection is rich but manageable. And the art itself is absolutely gorgeous. The modern collection is currently closed, BUT they just started displaying highlights from that collection in a temporary exhibition, so you won't miss out.

Fascinating Collection-- I want to see the rest (renovations). Yes, half of the museum is under going renovations. The Medieval Collection is fascinating and very extensive-- well worth the time and expensive. Do not let this scare you away. If you do not read/speak Spanish, be sure to get the Audio Tour. Bathrooms were clean and well maintained.

Gem of a Museum--Especially for Gothic Art. After a long gorgeous walk from Placa Espanya, you will reach this fantastic museum which is well worth two hours minimum! Unfortunately, much of the museum was closed for renovations during my visit, but I was more than satisfied by the Gothic and Romanesque collections. They were the best collection of those time periods that I have ever seen. The state of paint preservation on many of the wooden medieval sculpture was absolutely unequaled. The altarpieces were also HUGE and not split into sections by collectors over the years—as you find in other museums. Like I previously stated, much of the museum was closed but I still managed to become tired, so I took a little rest on the numerous and amazingly cushy chairs that line the central area which links the museum wings. Overall, the atmosphere in this museum is wonderful—welcoming, comfortable, and the art is perfectly curated in spacious gallery rooms, allowing the pieces to connect with guests. I highly recommend! Just one caution: the self-serve cafeteria is downright awful! Unless you want a coffee, I would skip it and its food.

Under Renovation. Because this museum is undergoing renovation, only the medieval collection was available for viewing. I must say, however, that what I saw was a first rate and extensive collection. In the center of the building, under the dome, you will find a huge performance area and circular seating on the upper level. This place is worth a visit if only to enjoy the gardens and fountains that lead up to the museum itself. Also, about a 15 minute walk from here, you can visit the Miro Museum.
Great way to spend some time. A very well maintained museum. They layout was clean and easy to navigate. The building and location offer some great views of Barcelona

Warning: part of the gallery is closed. A huge section of the gallery was closed on my visit, and I was annoyed that the person who sold me the ticket didn't tell me this until after I had already paid. (Warning: The same thing occurred at the Museu d'Art Contemporani - their whole permanent collection was closed but they didn't tell me until after I bought a ticket. I had purchased an art pass for 30 euros, which ended up being a waste of money.) I couldn't even see the Miro mural because they had closed that part of the building for a private function. The building itself is lovely but I wouldn't go out of my way to visit the gallery until they re-open all of the collections.

Do not miss this one, it's great!. If you are even in the slightest interested in history and art, go and visit this museum. My biggest regret is not having had the time to visit all the collections, because we went there at 3PM on a Saturday to benefit from free entry (also available on the first Sunday of each month). 3 hours just flew by, and before we knew it we were practically kicked out by a quite rude warden (apparently the key word in Barcelona is "Cerrado").Apart from the fact that the building is gorgeous, the objects displayed were extremely varied and interesting, reflecting a very eclectic cultural mix, with influences from all over the world. Especially in the Antiquity part, i was expecting to see the usual Roman remnants, but instead, everything here has a strong oriental twist.If I ever get a chance, I will go back and finish my visit.
Worth visiting for views. We didn't go inside, but it's well worth getting off the open top tour bus to see the views and take some fab photos.

Check what is open. The fountains outside are very nice. We were very disappointed that the contemporary sections were closed as that had been the main reason for our going. They are due to reopen in October 2014. Admission was free for seniors.
Great view. Even if you don't go inside there is a great view from outside. Good for photos and spectacular outlook over the city.

A palace and a museum. During our visit the second floor was closed . In spite of this fact we enjoyed very much our visit. We dedicated almost two hours to the first floor .There, we admired the Gothic and Medieval as well as the Roman departments with astonishing murals and wood carvings and statues .The buiding itself has a lot of charm .On the second floor it has a restaurant with a splendid view of Barcelona.The bookstore has a very good selection of art books.The cafeteria allows time to view the building on a cup of coffee or some other drink.Do not miss the terrace in spite of the need to climb some stairs after the use of a special lift.The view is rewarding and the pictures of Barcelona will always remind you of this wonderful museum/palace .

A fantastic tourist location in Barcelona. It is a great Museum in every sense. It,s location on Montjuic just uphill, it,s Majestic building are all great. Viewing it both from Montjuic hill top park and from the statue of Columbus were great. It has spectacular collection of art and one can spend whole day exploring them. But we had to hurry because of limited time .Never the less it crated a lasting impression on our mind . Visit to this Museum is a must for any one visiting Barcelona.

Hands down, one of the best spots in Barcelona. I might be biased since this was the first spot I saw in Barcelona, but this museum and the placa that leads to it are truly a magical place. The placa is majestic and looks like a mix of all sorts of various architectural types. It is bustling with people during the day, but at night, at 3 am, that is when it is is beyond words. Everything is lit up, it is quiet and you can breathe Barcelona air with a smile on your face. Make sure to walk to the museum, walk up the steps to the very top and sit up there, enjoying the breathtaking views, listening to an old man play spanish guitar, see the pigeons surround every sculpture in the vicinity. It's beautiful, and so worth a few hours of your time.

Best gothic art I've seen. The museum views are to die for ;). Buy pass to city tour bus and hop on and off for an easy trip! The location of the museum is stunning and reveals all of the city below it.

If you love Anunciations!. We never left the 9th-11th centuries area. A spectacular presentation of ancient art. When you see the Archangel Gabriel with Mary and there is a dove or breath of God, you know you are looking at very early depictions of the Anunciation - and there were several! We were transfixed. In addition, upon leaving the museum, you have a spectacular view of Barcelona. To the right of the entry is a refreshment stand with the best ice cream - Swiss Movenpick - not to be missed!

2 for 1. Due to limited time we couldn’t visited the museum but we went on top gallery paying £1.50 each (usually £3) kids under 16 free. The view from top is excellent all four side (best from front and back).

Wonderful art. It is a very nice museum with very interesting pieces of art and also a lot of temporary exhibitions. Not only the collections but also the building and the surroundings itself are worth to visit.

Lovely museum of Catalunya art history. It's quiet a big museum to visit. Many historical journey of art to be presented but with very limited time it;s hard to finished all in details. One of the best display was The Romanesque art display. Very nice and unique. All the items was stunning. Because the museum almost closing when we reach there so we can't explore that much but it was worth it to visit the museum.

Don't Miss this Museum!. This Museu Nacional de l'Arte de Catalunya, is located on Montjuic just uphill from the Fira de Barcelona. It can be reached conveniently by several modes of public transportation, including the Bus Turistic. The museum could take days to see properly, since it encompasses most of the art history of Catalunya. If you have time to visit only one section, the Romanesque art display is spectacular. It contains many of the actual mosaics removed from remote Romanesque churches in more rural parts of Catalunya, including S. Climent de Taull. The colorful art gives the lie to the phrase, Dark Ages! Barcelona is full of things to love. Besides, there is the spectacular Museu Maritim in the old Drassanes where ships were built for the navy of the kings of Aragon. There is the art and architecture of the Modernists, Domenech i Montaner, Gaudi, and others. There are the wonderful Gothic buildings of the Barri Gotic. And there are the people. The staff at the Hotel Colors in the Horta district were especially kind and helpful to me. I recommend them for a pleasant stay in a modern hotel away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Great Romanesque Display. As another review mentioned, the contemporary exhibits were closed when we went, but I don't think we would have had time for them anyway. The display of Romanesque art is amazing. We had been to the Vale de Boi and seen all the signs that we were looking at replicas of paintings and statuary and that the originals had been moved to the MNAC in Barcelona, so it was great to catch up with the originals. But it was just as amazing to learn of the process by which they literally strip the paintings off the walls and move them. The paintings from the churches were displayed as much as possible similarly to the way in which they were originally mounted. The paintings from the churches were wonderful, and of course, some were better preserved than others. I was pretty surprised by some of the altars and paintings on wood. They were so brilliant and the colors so vibrant that I thought they had been restored only to find that they had not. If you are into Romanesque history and art, this museum could easily take more than a day. We went through the Romanesque with such interest that we were pretty worn down for the Gothic and Renaissance. We hope to do the later years more justice on another visit. The only complaint is that much of the signage was only in Catalan and Spanish, I wish more had been translated to English.This is a 3 hour visit per day attraction-not because you can see it all, but because there is just so much you can absorb at once. But it would take several days to see at my pace. Somebody who was not as enthralled as I could probably do a quick once over in a day. The 12 euro fee was not insubstantial, but the visit was worth it.

Bonus time.. The night we were in town found out that the museum was hosting a free night, with no charge for attendance. The artwork was varied from oils, pen and ink, to marble statutes. A large collection that one can find very rewarding in that you have such fine exhibits all located in one place. It is amazing to see the talent of different artists and the creations that they have produced, some of them taking years to accomplish. The no fee and the size of the collection was thrilling and the night showing worth staying up for. A real bonus!

Must see in Barcelona. This is an affordable site to visit. The renaissance and medieval art is just incredible. You can spend hours here and not rush. The views of Barcelona from the front steps are great.

Free Saturdays from 3-6. Well worth seeking out. Take the metro to Plaza Espanya and take the escalators and stairs to the massive palace built as part of the 1929 or 1888 exposition. This place is the pre-eminent place for Romanesque and Medieval art taken in situ from Catalonian churches. There is also a fantastic roof terrace to wander and take in the spectacular views.

Go to the roof!. All the current reviews are correct -- the museum is good but it was disappointing that the "contemporary" galleries were closed for renovation. However, I followed signs to the building roof. The view of Barcelona was unbelieveable. I could see the Gaudi park and church from up there. Also walked to the back rooftop for garden views. Don't miss it.

Gorgeous building and the Barcelona Olympic Statium is behind it.. This was worthy he long walk and the stairs (although there are escalators). The building is gorgeous, the view amazing, plus the Barcelona Olympic Stadium is behind it.
Amazing views from the roof terrace. My partner, Sally, loved the art, whilst I loved the views from the roof. Overall, a brilliant place to visit.

Loved it and learned a lot!. I should have visited this museum at the start of my trip as opposed to mid-trip. It was a great introduction to the Catalonia and its rich history. The layout takes you through the original tribes/settlements to today and allows you to fully understand this beautiful region of Spain.
Excellent museum of Catalunya. We enjoyed our visit to the museum to learn more about the Catalunya culture. The building itself is majestic.

Stick to the Picasso and Miro. Love the location of this museum high on Montjuic, but half the museum was closed for renovation when we were there, including 19th and early 20th century collection of works from Catalan artists. It was a disappointment. But if you are a fan of Romanesque and Baroque art, you'll be satisfied. Be sure to ask before you buy your ticket if the entire museum is open.

A huge, wonderful collection. I especially liked the medieval and gothic collections. There are walls from old (1000 CE or so) churches that are magnificent and very thoughtfully displayed. I only had two hours there but wish I had spent more time there.

Amazing day/night views. This place was absolutely beautiful. The art work on the ceilings was beautiful. Breathtaking views of Barcelona and at night the fountain lights up the sky with the beautiful colors. A must see!
Not much available. Most of the main exhibits were closed but the building is very interesting. Free if you are a senior citizen, not terribly pricey if you aren't.

Magnificent Building, Inspirational Artworks. Approach the MNAC from the plaza below, and prepare to be enraptured by what you will find. Beautiful scenic vistas of the city of Barcelona. A magnificent structure, and thousands of works of art preserved from Romanesque churches in the North of Spain.

Worth coming up for the views. We didn't go in the gallery so can't comment on that, but it's definate;y worth walking up to the entrance so you can see the fabulous fountains and get views back down over the city.Beware - we saw scammers running away into the bushes after trying it on with a tourist and being told to go away.
Impressive Art and spectacular viees of Barcelona. Free entry for seniors well designed exhibitions huge collection of Gothic art. The ancient coin collection was very informative.

Worth a visit. Interesting art gallery but whole of modern (19th and 20th century) section is closed until September. Entry Tickets not discounted to reflect that (a bit of a shame) although you can see the temporary exhibitions as well. One of the latter was my favourite - the painter of Tangiers (Tapiro). The other exhibits are impressive but bit too religious focused for my taste. Good views from terraces as others have also said.

Staff rude and awful. Be prepared .You may come across some rudeness when you approach some of the staff .Do not expect 'excuse me' or sorry,words disappeared from staff dictionary.Some they lack of good manners and dealing with visitors can tiring ,even they don't don't love the job.No room for rudeness and no excuse.The museum is great and on Saturdays is free entrance from 3pm till 8pm.

The perfect photo opportunity in Barcelona. I have never been inside the museum but man oh man it has one hell of a view. Opposite the museum is a downwards stair case that leads to the famous fountain. But that view from the top of the stair case is spectacular! You can basically see all of Barcelona. It is the perfect place to take an iconic photo of this great city

Really cool spot - Amazing Views. This was probably one of my favourite places in Barcelona. The fountains are pretty impressive and the steps at the top make for a great little place to hang out with an ice cream or beer or whatever. But the best part is the views across the city - spectacular. Can see all over Barcelona!

Amazing inside & outside. What an imposing building and surround walking from the Metro, even on a cloudy cool day, fountains blooming, gardens glorious, take the sturdy stairs or escalators, the view out over the City to the hills is priceless.Speaking of priceless, we had discount vouchers from the Barcelona Tourist Bus at the ready, but our entry was free as Seniors, unsure if this is the case everyday, anyway it was a bonus. Even though two galleries are being renovated there was sufficient to see and enjoy, we spent 3-4 hours of enthralled enjoyment
Beautiful!. What a spectacular building. And free. Unfortunately, the modern wing was closed for renovation. And did I mention the view? You can see the whole city from up there.
Not a great cafe. We arrived at the café towards the end of the lunchtime but the food on display looked tired and unappetising. It was also quite expensive for what was on offer.

Beautiful. A place to see, we loved the ceilings paints, the construction in general is impressive. Be ready to climb around 200 stairs, but the view is really nice from there to take pictures. If you can visit went the water fountain is on, even more impressive.

lovely views. The outside of the museum is stunning. Its lovely to walk up to the museum from Espanya metro station as you get the full view of the whole building and the magic fountain. There are escalators so you dont have to walk up all of the many steps and once you get to the top the view over Barcelona is gorgeous. The entrance to the museum itself is €12 which i think would be worth the price normally but when i visited i was disappointed to find that a large portion of it was closed to the public. So i would recommend checking online before you visit to avoid disappointment.

Could not visit the whole museum. It is an amazing Museum, besides you can have a great sight from the top of Plaza España.We could not have Access to the 19th and 20th century expositions. It was closed for the public. It is recommended to check on line or give them a call prior to your visit, to be sure if all the expositions are available to visit.

Fantastic, outside & inside. The museum exhibits a wonderful collection of works, sculptures, bronzes and paintings of many famous artists who have left their artistic expressions in Barcelona during their stay in Cataluna. Many artists are represented in this museum: my favourite: Tintoretto. The museum is worth a visit also for its beautiful architecture. It has a large indoor arena. The arena is dominated by a historic organ that is still working perfectly. The view from the terrace is amazing. Entrance 12 €. Free with the Barcelona Card.

Worth the Admission Price. While it may not be The Louvre or the Sistine Chapel, the MNAC still holds some incredible artwork. Especially if you're at Montjuic anyway, it is definitely worth checking out (it's housed in the Palacio Nacional)

Wow, Wow, Wow!!!. My girlfriend and I took the cable car upto Montjuic and walked around and it was the most amazing way to get there. Staggering views, lovely walks and when you reach the museum it just blew us away!! The best way to describe its unveiling to the eye is if you start at the top and work your way down is like opening a present.... the more you peel the different perspectives you get then when at the the bottom the present is completely unwrapped! Just breathtaking!!

Beautiful outside but disappointed inside. This stunning building is worth a visit to admire the fountains surrounding it and to discover the montjuic park. We were able to go inside free as part of our barcelona card but we were disappointed that a huge part of it is shut , and will remain so for the whole of the summer. The highlight for us was going up to the roof and walking around and admiring the views from all sides.

Not an art fan. This review is based solely on the building as I'm not an art fan and didn't go inside. The building is very impressive both in size and architecture. The fountains on the way up the main are very good and vary in size any layout. The views at the top are stunning and have great panoramic views of the city. TheViews up the top are definitely worth the climb

A comprehensive collection, and a cool building to boot.. I went a little while back, but it remains one of the best experiences I've had in Barcelona. Very unique perspective on Catalan art, with lots of explanations. Plus the history of the building is really interesting (a converted exhibition space). Definitely worth a visit for the layman (like me) who wants to see what Catalan art's about, and for the more intellectual or seasoned art aficionado who wants the best collection of Catalan pieces in the world!
Beautiful. We only managed to fit in one gallery but the collection was amazing and the gallery itself is beautifully laid out, staff are friendly and helpful and it was a joy to wander round.

Loved it!. Just the exterior of this museum is worth the visit. Sitting up on a hill, it is an impressive sight as you walk up to it. Once you are there, it offers a beautiful view of Plaza Espanya and Barcelona.However, don't pass up the interior. The artwork preserved from Medieval churches is amazing. To see how they preserved the artwork, and then see it displayed as it looked in its original location was very impressive. When you consider how old the artwork is, it is that much more amazing.

Excellent collection of medieval murals. I was very impressed with the medieval collection at this beautiful museum. I was pressed for time, but I could have stayed much longer viewing the murals. If you enjoy medieval or Renaissance art, this place is for you! Truly enjoyable.Also, the terrace and rooftop provide excellent views of the city.

Interesting collection. The best part of this museum is the section devoted to Romanesque art. Taken off the walls of Mideval Romanesque churches and preserved in displays shaped like the apses and niches from which they were taken, these works of art are fascinating and quite different. By the way, the view from the terrace of the museum is beautiful and the Miro museum is also near by. The Mies van der Rohe Pavillion is just down the hill a short distance.

Location is more impressive than the exhibits.... Amazing location and the museum itself is very impressive old palace. The exhibits are not that impressive, still a nice place to spend a few hours visiting

Gorgeous views of it from Placa Espanya. Great views from Placa Espanya looking up at this huge, gorgeous museum building. Several fountains immediately in front of the way up. Fortunately, there are escalators most of the way. The last rise has an escalator but you need to go to the far left side of the building to access it. It's not readily apparent/obvious there is this escalator. Art was beautiful as well but the building/fountains for me was the show stopper.
Very interesting. You just can't skip it if you are in Barcelona. Its huge and interesting museum and its free if you have a Barcelona card.

Unique exhibit. In addition to the grand setting and spendid views, this museum contains a unique exhibition of Romanesque art. This is not your usual looking at pictures hanging on walls or objects in glass cases. Inside a grand space they have reconstructed several chapel interiors from the twelvth century exactly as they found them in the Pyrnees mountains. Their isolated location saved them from destruction and walking thru them is like a trip back 800 years. We live a few blocks from the Metropolitan Museum of Art in NYC and almost chose not to enter the museum, feeling we have much of this at home. We entered because it was included on our Articket bought to avoid the lines at Picasso and found it to be an excellent museum, and were blown away by this unique exhibit of Romanesque church frescos. If you are on Montjuic don't miss it!
Great photo ops. Beautiful to look at, and a beautiful view of the city from it. Didn't have time to go inside, as we didn't have the time. It was not cheap though.

Brilliant place to visit!. I haven't previously visited art museums abroad but this one pulled me in due to how spectacular it looked from the outside - and I definitely was just impressed inside!Definitely worth a visit and good value for money, it's huge! Also lovely view from the top :)
Nice view. Again it gives the wonderful panormic view of the barcelona city, be there and enjoy the view with fountains just below and city in front of you.

IMPRESSIVE AND GREAT WALK ON A COOL DAY. Great place to spend half a day with the surroundings, Magic Fountain, Villa Olímpica. Excellent sample of Catalunyan art. Monumental and ample public spaces, structures, fountains, and plenty of things to do. If you are interested in avant garde architecture you can visit the Ludwig Mies van der Rohe museum which is the Germany Pavillion to the 1929 International Exposition in Barcelona which is quite astounding concept for the time.
Magnificent Views of Barcelona. Get to the top of the hill and work your way down. An absolute must see. You don't have to go inside of the museum to enjoy this.
Underwelmed. Vast palace but the photographs in basement were of more interest that the artwork. Impressive location & can be mixed with visits to Miro & Olympic sights.

Excellent!. I just stopped by this attraction in the afteronoon and stayed on the outside. The architecture is amazing with an impressive view from the top. Unfortunately I did not have time to visit inside.

Who knew Romanesque art could be so transfixing?!. The museum's collection is comprehensive but the real star is the Romanesque art from Catalan. Just amazing in color and emotion. I was transported to another world. Great views from the hill. The admission was expensive but worth it.

Spectacular. It is, in many cases, cheaper to buy a concert seat than to play the entrance fee. This musical academy is outstanding. The highlight for me was the outstanding stained glass ceiling above the concert hall. The ceiling alone makes the visit worthwhile
Interesting museum in Montjuic. very interesting museum especially the renaissance and gothic era. it is not good that nothing is written in english and you have to pay for an audioguide.

Wonderful time spent!!. A section of the museum was closed for repair, but we entered the older area with paintings and murals and sculptures. There was Medieval art with works from 11th-13th centuries.Wood carvings and metalwork was also presented. The Gothic art from the end of the 13th through the 15th centuries presented pieces from Catalonia. It also had artists such as Jaume Cascalls, Pere Sanglada, and Jaume Huguet. The last area we visited was the Renaissance and Baroque art, produced in the 16-18th centuries. See famous artists as Titian, Tintoretto and El Greco and Diego Velazquez. Beautiful religious art filled our afternoon. We were there 4 hours. There was also a special photographic presentation of Joan Colom with pictures from 1957-2010. This was riveting!!

Worth a visit. If you've climbed up Montjuic Hill, do visit MNAC. Their gothic frescoes are second to none. Sadly the Modern Galleries were closed when we visited - but then that means we have to return to see them.

Moment of peace. The modern part ofthe museum was closed and we were a bit desappointed but if you go really all over the monument(on the roof...), it's a very special and nice moment of peace with a beautifull view...Not really for kids in my oppinion...Pour les français, ce musée est idéal pour un peu de culture et de calme, la vue du toit est magnifique, le bâtiment vaut à lui seul le coup d'oeil! La partie moderne était fermée et nous a manqué un peu.. mais pas de regrets!

wonderful place on a rainy day. The building was amazing but so many of the areas were closed. The entire art collection was closed off a bit dispointing. The special photo exhibit was great. The Barcelona Pavillion at the base of the building was the a true experience. Being able to finally see where mid century modern was born was amazing.

Excellent views. The walk up was fantastic, pass the fountains and waterfalls - was free to go in when we visited, have to be honest did not view the art but went up to roof terrace for some more fantastic views.

Views from the roof are stunning. Picturesque views. Climb to the roof and walk round the rooftops, seeing views from different angles. Modern section was closed when we visited and we still had to pay to see the classic religious art and a photography exhibition. Worth it for views, alone

As a location Great, as a museum Average. The building and grounds and fountains are an amazing expression of the desires of a Catalan nation. The building is large and impressive and fountains are amazing. The art and the presentation seems to be a distraction from the main event which is the building itself. If you want to see great art, take this escalators in back of the museum and go to the Miro Foundation.

Amazing. Such great art and culture. Would definately recommend this if going to Barcelona. It has 3 different parts. Photos of Barcelona over the years, medieval and 1 other which I can't remember the name of but such a vast range of things to look at and the cost is minimal.

Not much good art here!. It was really disappointing! Just a bunch of junk thrown together-not really art-the building is cool and it was free on our BCN card so that was worth something to us. We were there in the first Sat of the month and they had a party outside going on which was fun-a dj and dance music but be careful not to get hit by a skateboarder! While geared for young people-many locals of all ages were outside enjoying the evening-a fun free night-with a great light show too! Gave you some atmosphere of the city which is so full of life!

Fascinating arts, do not miss it.. Spare a lot of time for it. Too many fascinating artworks especially paintings. Some of Dali's masterpieces are also displayed here (unfortunately no photo allowed). I'm not christian but there are a lot of stunning artworks of Christianity. They attracted so much of my attention. I enjoyed my time here very much. Worth every euro spent.

Awesome views. We went there with the metro and the mechaninc stairs in a sunny day!Do not miss it! The views are great and the catalan art inside it is amazing! The Pantorcratar paint is really nice.

Impressive inside and out. The MNAC building is one that commands attention. From the first time you lay eyes on it you know something wonderful awaits you inside. Very impressive collection within it and outside there's a lot of room to just sit and watch barcelona pass you by underneath. The views from the entrance are pretty good and if you go in the evening might as well stay and witness the magic fountain!! That will be a perfect end to your day for sure!

Beautiful architecture. This building has some brilliant views of the city and its just next to the Olympic stadium, so you can do both in one afternoon. I would also recommend you to visit it at night when the fountains are on, its heavenly.

Impressive building and breathtaking view. The building and its surroundings are impressive with their magnificence and grandeur. When we visited the museum, only the Medieval and Renaissance sections were open. The rest was closed for renovation and I was a bit disappointed because I wanted to see the Modernism collection. The view from the museum is spectacular. It's undoubtedly a must-see on your Barcelona list!

Even for non-art fans. I'm not into art very much. Unless it is the Impressionist era, everything else is just blah to me. This place though, is pretty impressive and was worth the time to wander around and look through. Even if you don't like art, this is a nice place to spend some time. I'd go early in the morning too, when there are less people.
Great permanent collection. Pressed for time, so didn't see it all, but the museum had a great permanent modern art exhibit. I would suggest visiting for about 3 hours, if you like to take to stroll.

MNAC. It is a great museum where you can see practically all the Art History from the medieval days until nowadays. It is located in Montjuic Hill and from here you can see Plaza España build for the World Exhibit that took place in 1929.

Brilliant Catalan collections. Whilst the downstairs galleries are devoted to mainly religious and historical frescoes, sculptures and icons, the first floor is more varied with mainly modern art. The gallery hosts events and dinners, so the main central auditorium may not be accessible. Poor cafe / restaurant facilities and much wasted space spoil what is a fantastic building and experience.

Great views from the terrace!. We didn't have lots of time to browse the whole collection and so just paid €3 for the two of us to go up to the terrace area for the views - well worth it for the views over the city were superb. the interior of the building was also impressive. cannot comment further but don't be put off by the large collection if you don't have the time - just enjoy the views!

Great musuem with incredible views of city. I spent an afternoon here after exploring Montjuic, and loved wandering through the art galleries, as well as the gorgeous view of Barcelona from the top terrace. It´s better to go in the late afternoon to catch the sunset, and Magic Fountain show at the bottom. I went on a Saturday afternoon, when it´s free after 3 PM.

Great Afternoon Hangout. The walk up to the museum itself was enjoyable. The fountain display and statues were quite a sight. Many good angles for picture taking. A great way to spend a leisure afternoon.

Come here on a rainy day. Unlike the Prado museum in Madrid, this one is not a must... Come here if you're on a long enough vacation in Barcelona that this visit wouldn't make you miss out on anything else. Interesting collection of art from medieval times that would make you appreciate the fact that you weren't alive then :) Don't forget to visit the rooftop terrace which is included in the entrance ticket, there's a beautiful panoramic view of Barcelona from above...

Try and fit this in. The displays are in Spanish, Catalan and English. Some you can touch, pick up etc. We had a discount from the Bus Touristic of buy one ticket get one free so cost us 2.25 euros each! Gives in depth history of how Catalan came into being and the relationship with the rest of Spain

Cultural and Visual Gem. Beautiful view from the Plaza de España. Like nothing else in Barcelona, at the bottom of Montjuic is the stunning MNAC. There is currently a great Photography exhibition on by Catalan Joan Colom. Not only is the MNAC great to look at but when up there you also geat great views from when you're up there over Barcelona. A trip to Barcelona isn't complete without getting a panoramic view of the city from either Montjuic or Mount Tibidabo. If heading to Montjuic, do not miss the MNAC

Supreme Spot to Get a Great View of the City, Magic Fountain, & Placa d'Espanya. Simply put, the MNAC is a great place to a view of the city. The photos I posted along with this review show that you can see much of Barcelona sprawled out before you, including Magic Fountain, Placa d'Espanya, La Sagrada Familia, and more. You don't even have to take the stairs to get there, there are escalators! The view alone keeps even locals coming. Around sunset there were people crammed onto the stairs in anticipation of Magic Fountain, lending itself to creating an energetic atmosphere. What more could you want?With that being said, let's get to the museum itself. The grounds are well-manicured and pleasant to stroll through. There are a couple cafes on the way up and one at the entrance of the museum, but I'd say steer clear; they're pretty pricy! We aren't art buffs by any stretch of the imagination, but can still appreciate good art. MNAC certainly has this. We caught it on an evening when entrance was free (a quick Google search shows: "Free entrance:Saturdays from 3 pm; 1st Sunday of each month,May 18th, International Museum Day") and did a quick 1-1.5 hours walkthrough of the museum. While I wouldn't say I loved every piece, there were a few that were interesting enough to be worth seeing.________________Bottom Line:Great view of the city, which alone makes the trek worthwhile, plus it's FREE! If the museum is free, I'd say it's certainly worth a quick runthrough if you can spare the time. If it isn't free, it's still only 12 Euro for two-day entrance at most (families, students, seniors, adult groups all get discounts); you art fans will likely appreciate the two days. Whether or not the visit is worth it is up to your taste and time you have at your disposal.

Great Architecture. The rating of the attraction is more because of the impressive building and fountain 'courtyard'. Even if you are not big on spending time in museums, make the time to see the building and ascend to the entrance to see the view of the city from the hill and to enjoy the Magic Fountain. If if you are short on time BCN, you may consider skipping the entry into the museum itself (unless there is something specific that you would like to see), although I found their collection of Romanesque churches of the Pyrenees quite impressive. Although I did not do it, reading the reviews makes me wish that I would have spent some time outdoors to enjoy the view, then scheduled to dine at the restaurant and see the performance of the Magic Fountain from there... oh well, there will be a next time for sure!

Breath-taking beauty. We didn't actually go into the museum, but enjoyed the terrific views from outside. There are cascading fountains surrounded with beautiful shrubbery in front of the majestic museum. My husband was especially impressed - and really enjoyed the escalators!

Transported by escalators. Situated on a hill overlooking the city, worth visiting the area just for the views alone. What's more you do not have to walk up endless flights of steps, there are escalators so you have no excuse not to visit.The museum has an interesting collection, spanning 1000 years maybe more. Exhibits are well displayed with plenty of space to stand back and enjoy. I had not planned to visit here but local friend said it was a must and it is.

A fine collection. This is well worth visiting, if nothing else for the Romanesque frescoes. These are amazing, and mounted as if in situ in the places from which they came.The inside of the building is not what you might have expected from the outside.Disappointed that you have to pay extra to access the roof terrace.

A wonderful surprise. We bought the six-museum pass and went here just because we were seeing Montjuic. I was delighted by the museum, which is a beautiful building. It has a wide variety of art through the centuries.
Dinner at Museum. What a stunning visit. we were bussed in and had Tapas and Wine at the museum. We had special access to the exhibits and it was just awesome.
we only ate here!. The restaurant is fabulous - good food and STUNNING views - you have to book to get window tables.The building is fab

Go for free in the evening!. A big museum. So you probably should go. It is the biggest sight in the city, but how much time you need is going to completely depend on how much you like museums. We went on a Sunday night which had free admission and was a perfect fit

Well worth a visit. We visited more because of the building itself, and its location, than because of the art. However, I found I really enjoyed both the early (Byzantine) collection and the modern works (about 1900 - 1940s). We were on the HOHO bus, so there was no special journey to get there, and the gallery is free for over-65s.

Lots To See. Give yourself 3-4 minimum just inside the building. Plenty to see, some amazing talent to be witnessed. Day I went was fortunately free in, a great bonus, don't know if its the same every Sunday.
Great Museum. Great Museum and fantastic views. Their collection was incredible and we didn't find a lot of people. At the top of the mountain, we went by food and it was a sweety experience.

Interesting. Not sure i comprehend modern art, but it was worth a couple hours just to walk through, slow down from the Barcelona hustle and bustle, and get a different perspective on things. There is an exhibit currently about media and there were some interesting displays related to the 60's, 70's and 80's in terms of images and news writing that were worth the visit. The building itself...absolutely stunning especially when you consider how different it is from the neighborhood. Worth a few hours.

Huge landmark, don't miss it. When you spot the museum after getting off of the Plaza Espanya metro station you get a chilling feeling of intrigue to know what`s that huge building on the hill, so architecturally beautiful and the exhibition inside it's out of this world.

Lost Amidst Art, Frescoes & Fountains. Great Museum located on the Placa d’Espanya featuring artists such as Dali, Picasso, Velazguez, Mir, Gainsborough, etc. Wonderful collections of Romanesque, Gothic, Baroque, Renaissance and Modern art, sculpture and photography. The building itself is spectacular with a huge dome (amazing frescoes!) and Ballroom which once served as a ceremony room for Spanish Royalty. Tickets are good for 2 days, cost 10 Euro, Audio Guide was 3.5 Euro and well worth it. From the Fountains, look for the escalators both left and right if you don’t want to climb all the steps up to the Museum. Nice benches around to watch the Magic Fountains below you and take in the views. Easy to lose track of time with so much to see!

Everything I wanted. This is a huge museum and I could have spent hours and hours here. I love art and I loved this museum. Many different wings and time periods represented. I would suggest having many hours free to really enjoy it. It also wasn´t very crowded which made it a nice experience as well!

Great if you have extra time. This is a nice stop if you have extra time on your trip. The paintings are gorgeous and it is very interesting. There are audio tours available that explain everything as you tour the facility.

Looks great from the outside. My wife and I didn't get a chance to go inside, but I'd still recommend visiting. Not only is the building one of the most beautiful buildings in the city, but the views from there are even more stunning. We had a great day thanks to this wonderful building.

we only had time for the Byzantine art. We must go back, because we only had time for the Byzantine art wing. It was fabulous. It was different. I like most art museums but I am happy to be able to see something new. New for me, that is--The Byzantine pieces are of course all old and religious; many are altarpieces or church friezes, but the style was unlike the Italian things seen in Art History class in college. It was refreshing and enlightening.

Not the Metropolitan but a good start.. Really some amazing pieces from the early Byzantine to the latest impressionist art of Barcelona. For those fascinated by coins, you have to see the Numismatic rooms of this lovely palace. Don't miss the central concert hall and the very huge pipe organ as well.

Excellent Collection. The museum is very easy to find but a bit of a walk from the bottom up the stairs. The view from the top is great showing the city below. The museum itself is very large with so many styles of art. The museum is separated into about 5 different areas so you'll need lots of time here to see everything. The museum is very clean and organized. The building itself is very impressive as well.
catalan and european art collection. good collection of paintings, sculpture, and some furniture. not a massive collection but well chosen.
