Really amazing. This is a not to be missed location. Building and location are extraordinary. Art collection very impressive. Very few cities in the world have a place of this qualtity.

Good value. We visited this museum last week. There was no queue to get in at approx 11.15 the staff on the desk were very helpful and spoke some English. Suggest you get the audio guides to help you around this vast museum. So much to see, we spent 2 hours here and I didn't see everything. There are plenty of restrooms and a cafe if you need them. The view from the outside is amazing you can see the Barcelona panorama. We used the Bus Turistic to get to this museum as it is up the Montjuic hill. You can walk from placa d'espanya there are escalators and steps.We paid about 15 euros for 2 of us as we had a coupon from the bus company. Don't be embarrassed to use the coupons they expect you to do so. Make sure you visit the main auditorium and admire the organ and the decor. They were busy setting up staging and lighting for a concert in the auditorium but we were still able to view it.Definitely a must see in Barcelona

Great Place ... Great Views. This is a wonderful building with great views. It cost around 10 euros and the ticket last 1 month. The collections are great ranging from renaissance to modern art. The ceiling on the modern art floor was amazing and there is a enormous organ that is worth a look at. The water fountain wasnt on when i went to the Museu nacional but there is nice waterfalls and parks near by although i would advise getting the metro or bus up there as the walk is quite tiring to then spend some time walking around the galleries.

Must see in Barcelone. A very interesting museum. You must take care to manage your effort, because there are very very much things to see.The visit take you 3-4 hours (and it is better you don't hurry ). You will be amazed. You must know the museum entrance is free in the first sunday of the month and also in other days-see on the Internet.
musical fountain. the view of plaza espana from MNAC with musical fountain was mind blowing. one should visit it in the evening to see the lighted musical fountain.

Absolutely superb!. Wonderful, huge museum with some truly great pieces of Catalan art by artists who seem to be largely unknown outside Spain / Catalunya. Other pieces of artwork from international artists wereTicket was part of the Barcelona ARTICKET and the actual museum ticket is valid for 2 days. I could have spent days there, fabulous place and if you arrive around 10am it is almost deserted. Easy access vis external escalators and a great view of the city from the museum. You can use your camera (without flash) inside and the coffee shop on the ground floor near the huge auditorium is great value for a coffee with milk at around €1.80

Museum. It was such a lovely walk up to the museum - great views of the whole city . Wonderful waterfall - and absolutely amazing views ..Did go inside the museum - as outside it was so beautiful . Enjoyed a good cup of coffee at the cafe out side. If you ask for hot chocolate you will literally get a half cup of melted chocolate!
Wonderful views from the top of the hill.. We just walked around at this location and it is a superb photo spot and such a pleasant place to take a break from touring.

The art and culture of Catalunya. This remarcable museum shows the art of Catalunya along the last thousand years. You cannot forget the romanesque frescoes, the "modernisme" (catalan branch of Art Nouveau) based on the arts and crafts movement, the paintings by Marià Fortuny, Ramon Casas, and other remarcable artists from Catalunya. Another must in Barcelona!!!

One of the best museuns. The museun houses many afrescos from rural churches of Catalunia. They are shown in an impressive way and are housed in a museun in a fantastic location. You should not miss it. You will be impressed.

From Romanesque altars to Gaudi, this place has everything.. The architecture of the place is beautiful; the setting overlooking the city is beautiful; the art collections are superb. The facilities are great too, the attractive café, the gift shop, the washrooms, the escalators to get there, the elevators in the building.

Huge white spaces. This enormous museum, recently undergoing repainting into all white, contains interesting art, as well as art that I don't have patience for.
But worth the visit for sure.
loved it, favorite museum in Barcelona. definitely see it, I had the museum card which was worth buying if you see at least 4 of the museums on their list.

Excellent museum. I liked that it is very well organized, with clearly marked areas for the different artistic styles; the quality of the exhibitions, the scenic views outside the museum, specially at night when the fountain show is being displayed. We happened to go on a Saturday and there was live music in an open space of the museum, and people were dancing swing; it completed our visit with a different kind of art...
What a find!. My husband and I wanted to know more about the Catalans and decided to go to MNAC. Leave time in your schedule to explore this very unique museum.

Incredible. Great museum, with amazing art, very big, so you might need some time to see it all but it is worth it. Close to Miro museum, not very far from metro, but the walk to the museum is also worth while. It is monumental, the building itself is incredible. It is possible to see it all in a couple of hours, and you have very comfy chairs to rest, and you are going to need to take a little break at some point. It is a must see when in Barcelona.

history of barca. well this is a stunning building worth seeing. there are a lot of steps so people with disabilities would be better off travelling on the tour bus to get to it. id like to score higher but we didnt make it inside as with everything else in barcelona it costs to get indoors so you cant do everything. the olympic stadium is also close by if interested in seeing that!!

Great building, great view, houses the spectrum of Catalan art treasure. A note on getting there - if you want to take the Funicular from Para-LLel Metro station and you arrive on the Metro do not exit the station gates - look for signs for the F or ask someone. The MNAC is a pleasant stroll from the Miro Museum. The building is immense with a beautifully position restaurant that has a Kaleidoscopic view over Plaza d'Espana and the city. The art collections reflect in many ways the artist development of Barcelona with some collections extending well beyond that with striking pieces. Walk the steps down to the Espana metro station.

Worth it fir the view and building. If you like your art like me it is worth paying to see the exhibitions. Some bits are free though. On a nice day I recommend coming here anyway just to enjoy the view. You can walk to the park, then the Olympic stadium and then up to the castle from here.
My Favorite part of Barcelona. this is a beautiful place, walk up to the museum and take pictures from the front, view from the roof is not worth it.

A beautiful place, easy to get to via public bus. We only had an hour or two, but the building was beautiful and there was plenty of space for the art. We concentrated on the modern art section. I particularly liked the small room containing the "likable drunks" which had once been in a bar.The view from the roof is highly recommended - NOT! The elevator does not go to the top. There are at least 3-4 extra floors to climb. Once there it is empty, kind of deserted. The view is fine, but my friends who did not make the climb enjoyed the view from the front of the building just fine.
Must see for art fans. This is a great place to go to see classics as well as traditional Spanish artists. If there were only a few places to go in Barcelona this would be one.

Very interesting if you are interested :). From the placa espanola you can walk up to the museum and take some nice pictures in front and behind the magic fountains. This museum has a nice collection of different eras starting with the some ancient pieces over roman, gothic, etc. up to the modern times. I thought this museum would have a bit bigger collections, but it's still very interesting

Grand building and spectacular collection. Wow, we were surprised when we arrived at the MNAC. This building had Capitol proportions with endless steps, waterfalls, fountains, the best views over Barcelona and a fantastic art collection. The Medieval collection is stunning but they also have Picasso, Dali, El Greco etc.I'm amazed that you dont hear a lot about this museum and it also pretty quiet. Too bad Gaudi is dominating the tourbus crowds agendas.

beautifully built national museum. even if you are not a big fan of the arts, the MNAC is an architectural masterpiece you have to see when you visit Barcelona!Tip: free entry every Saturday starting 3pm! don't miss seeing the magic fountain afterwards!

FANTASTIC. This gallery has some fantastic artwork within and is a super building to be in.The views from outside are to die for. Sit on the steps, sit at the cafe and take in the view.Entry costs are good and free after 3pm on Saturday.Been there in 2012 and December 2013, paid entry both times and love the MNAC the surrounding area and the views

Best Romanesque works in any museum. The largest compendium of Romanesque pictorial work in any museum. Though it was strange to see so many murals removed from their original settings, it was unique to have them all in one place. Highly recommend this place if you like Christian painting from the 11-12th centuries. There is hardly anyone in the galleries.
Huge!. MNaC is a huge museum. Plan at least a big half day if you can, and even that will be rushing some of the exhibits.

One of the best museum in the world!. Great collections to see! Great location and great sofas to rest in between sightseeings of the collections! Great shop as well though most of the books are in Catalan!

I was surprised. We went here on our last day in Barcelona and it was very, very nice. The exhibits are well organized and the museum staff is very friendly and will point out many of the fine points of the exhibits. There's probably a little too much religious art work for my liking but the Modern exhibits are fantastic. This museum is definitely one I'll visit again.

Forget the art - go for the roof top architecture. Pay for the entrance, but you can skip the art and head straight for the roof! The art is almost entirely Christian sculptures and art from cathedrals. While beautiful, it all begins to look alike. If you love architecture, be sure to visit the roof! You can get up close to the incredible domes and arched windows. Walk the cat-walk high above the courtyard and enjoy the view of Barcelona. If you go near sunset, snap breathtaking photos of the Olympic spire with the sunset behind it. Also, the moon rising over the domed roofs and the fading sun reflecting on the carved spires make fabulous photos.

Nice. Gorgeous building, especially when you view it from the bottom of the multitude of stairs leading from Plaza de Espana. Inside was about what we expected. TIP: Entrance fee was kind of pricey, but when my husband asked about a senor's rate, we were told seniors are free! Alternatively, if you enter after 2pm, there is no fee.

Magic Place. The exhibitions are very well done - whether you want to spend your time there will depend on your taste in art, though.But what you definitely must not miss is the beautiful building and the spectacular setting. The fountain with colours dancing to the music, the stairways leading to the museum, the view over the city from the terrace at the front entrance.
Impressive!. We didn't go in as the walk from the cable car had been exhausting. However, it's a stunning venue and well worth the trip to see it.q

Barcelona is at Your Feet. We came up from the subway to see a beautiful long boulevard. A little further and we see a tiered fountain climbing the hill to the museum. After a long flight, I was pleased to see the long climb to the museum has been replace by escalators on both sides of the fountain. We liked what we saw in the museum, but were most impressed by the views from the front steps. Enhancing the experience was a mini concert on the steps where visitors could sit and enjoy the overall atmosphere.

Have lunch here. As noted everywhere this is an excellent gallery in a beautiful palace. I would just add that the dining room with its panoramic view is a wonderful place to eat (with excellent food)

Catalan artwork at its best. MNAC has beautiful collections of Catalan paintings,sculptures and art. It also has a little souvenir shop, from where to can pick up few gift items.The entire building is located in such a prime area from where you can take beautiful pictures and make it your Kodak moment.

Catalan art and Roman frescoes. This museum is closed on Mondays. There is a reduced rate for students and professors but a person needs proof. The building is massive and beautifully situated overlooking the city of Barcelona. Rick Steve's stated that "this museum has world class and rare collections of Romanesque art mostly from Catalan villages in the Pyrenees. There was a coin collection that was impressive due to the fact that over 300 of these 16th century coins were found in a jar in an abbey. They truly were in mint condition. There were quite a few paintings by artists I was not familiar with. There were several El Grecos, two Ruebens, a Sisley. Another section had some furniture that was originally in the Casa Battlo. I usually enjoy museums but for me this was not a museum of interest. Research the collection online before you go so you can decide for yourself.

Amazing-Inside and Outside. For me this is the perfect museum experience! Its a grandiose building, royal, scrumptious, overwhelming with rushing water fountains, high above the city. It was built for the 1929 International Exhibition and then became the most important museum in the city. Walking there from the subway entrance is a wonderful trip in itself! But once inside; again amazing! It houses the greatest display of Romanesque items in the world, with the 12th century frescoes saved from many churches being the highlight. They have done an amazing job of recreating the vaulted ceiling and apses and decorated them with the lovely frescoes. There is also Gothic from Catalonia and all of Spain, modern art and great Spanish artistes, such as Velazquez and E Greco. I was there on the first Saturday of the month and admission was free. I paid for the audio guide (3.50 euro) and it was well worth it! Excellent descriptions and the correct length. There is some English information in each room, but nothing about the specific art so I would highly recommend the audio guide.I've been to Barcelona several times but never thought reaching the MNAC would be easy, but it was. Most cruise ship shuttles drop you off at either end of the Las Rambles; at the top is the direct metro Line L (red) and the ticket instructions and machines are all very easy to understand and use. Just make sure you start off on Line L going in the correct direction and its only about 5 stops. Subway cars clearly indicate upcoming stops, so its very easy. It takes about 15 minutes to get there and as you come out of the subway station, you will see the massive building. Expect to spend at least 2 hours there. Lovely gift shop, indoor and outdoor café, clean bathrooms. What else could you want? Highly recommended!

A great destination: art and architecture. A wonderful museum of strikingly contemporary design abutted to the classical Palau Nacional resulting in a kind of joyful harmony. Well organized, with bright, airy galleries, MNAC is an inviting environment. We enjoyed a Tapies Retrospective and discovered the work of Julio Gonzalez.
Give yourself lots of time here. Your admission ticket entitles you to two consecutive days - use it! The art is amazing and well curated. You will see incredible works by artists from Catalunya.

I could have spent all day here.... ..but alas, I was on a Regent Seven Seas shore excursion and our time was limited. The admission price was included in our package deal, so I don't actually know how much it cost to get in, but in my humble opinion, this place was worth it and then some. It's divided up into multiple sections, such as the Gothic and Medieval section and even includes Renaissance and Modern Art. We explored the Gothic and Medieval side during our brief tour and I was super impressed with the sculptures and frescoes that they had on display.Also - don't miss the views of Barcelona from the top of the hill near the museum. It's beyond breath-taking. In addition, the "grand room" is literally HUGE and the gift shop was pretty intricate and interesting...It's pretty amazing that they allowed non-flash photography, as well. I would have thought for sure it wouldn't be allowed, but I was wrong! If I'm ever back in Barcelona, this will be one of the first places that I'll have to re-visit.

beautiful collection of art and artefacts. it is free on saturday afternoon. a good visit to combine with enjoying the magic fountain at 7pm. As it was raining when we visited on november 16 evening, we did not stay for the magic fountain display.From the metro station, the MNAC is approximately 200 - 300 meters away.There is a cloakroom to store your bagpack. Photography is allowed.I was impressed with the artefacts that the museum had painstakingly assembled back onto the walls, pillars, and arches.A impressive collection for non-museum person like me.The cafe closes early ?6pm. Before taking the metro back, we visited the arena shopping centre where we viewed the magic fountain from afar. I realised that the lights coming behind MNAC were those use during the Barcelona olympics or world cup. Note that behind the MNAC is the Olympic stadium.

Amazing museum, plan sufficient time to visit. The MNAC is based in the Palau Nacional, which was surprisingly beautiful on the inside and an extra incentive for the visit. There are 2 floors, and 5 huges "rooms" (Roman // Gothic // Renaissance & Baroque // Modern & Contemporary + Drawings Prints & Posters // Numismatics). And also a temporary photography exposition on the second floor. You receive a handy folder with an overview of the Museum's masterpieces per collection. That would theoretically allow you to do a "quick visit" of all the highlights. I only got to see the first floor (Roman / Gothic / Renaissance & Baroque) as I like to take my time to enjoy art. From what I saw, my definite preference went out to the Gothic room. But then again, I did not get to see second floor, which probably housed many gems too.Two small disappointments : - the in-house cafeteria closed at 4:00 pm while the museum was open until 6:00 pm . There was another cafetaria outside, but it was quite cold and windy and not ideal to sit on the terrace.- I planned to combine the MNAC with the Font Magica (absolutely worth the wait!!!) A little inconvenient that the museum closed at 6:00 and the Font Magica only started at 7:00. All visitors from the MNAC waited outside the museum, because the Font Magica is located at the bottom of a set of stairs at the foot of the MNAC. As it wasn't the warmest November night however, the waiting was a bit chilly. Fortunately we were warmed up and entertained by a jazzy band of wonderful street musicians, who played while we waited for the fountain show to start. I would definitely recommend both the MNAC and the Font Magica. (even if I had other expectations from the music that accompanied the fountain show). The Font Magica is like fireworks, except that it's in water. It kept me glued to the spot for well over an hour.

Arts and landscape. From the nearest metro station, there was a very big park and the museum was on the hill. It was great view to see city. There was a cloak and I left my coat and luggage there. There were some separated sections per theme in the museum and I could start to see anywhere.There were cafes in the building and outside.

Surprisingly good collection of Catalan art. It is a large building with varied types of art, including frescoes rescued from old churches to modern sculptures by Gargallo to the Thyssen Bornemisza collections.

Excellent. This museum is set high above Barcelona. When you enter at the front there are several sections of steps which take an effort even if you are in good shape. There also are escalators on the side of the steps for those who want. The building is beautiful and the art plentiful. We sat outside and had an ice cream and enjoyed the spectacular view. I recommend you do the same.Jeremy T

Stunning. A beautiful modern building set in amongst the ancient buildings of the University. Several exhibitions all divided into seperate rooms and clearly laid out. Even if you are not an art lover you will appreciate the air conditioned building and the chill out area.

Time killer. Very interesting collection of artefacts and art, available on the art ticket pass. The galleries take a while to get around but the works are beautiful and well arranged through different periods.

Inspiring. The views when you reach here over the rat of the city are wonderful, but it is only when you enter the museum that the volume os art and historical objects come into being, from baroque to contemporary to romanesque, you could easily spend more than a day in this wonderful attraction

Good art, good views, beautiful building. I got here via metro stop espanya. This way is beautiful as you get to walk down the road infront of the gallery which is really nice taking in the fountains and water.
The gallery itself is nicely laid out and has a few good well know pieces of work.
Epic view from outside.
There's also a cafe and restaurant.

Museum of Art MNAC. Easily accessable from the rear, but more spectacular from the front by the fountains and not to worry about all those steps, there are electric staircases to each landing, both up and down.Inside well its an Art Gallery, and well worth a visit

Brilliant first sunday. I happened to be in town the day the museum was free. I didn't not that the museum closed at 3PM. I was a bit travel weary so I got off to a late start. I wisely headed for the romanesque fresos first. This museum is a must see.

Free after 3. Great museum - free after 3Pm on certain days. Great gathering place out front - set outside had sangria and listened to musicians and had a beautiful view of the city. Only issue was we wanted to eat in the restaurant - no warning we were directed up there by several of the aids and when we got there no sign - restaurant closed no sign - we found iut later it was closed for a wedding.

Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya - MNAC. This place is beautiful inside and out, plus evening has musical dancing water sources, on the outside the building is stunning, with escalators that make the climb very comfortable, a place worth visiting for day and night.
Just lovely!. I enjoy art museums & this one did not disappoint!The actual building & surrounding landscape is beautiful as well as the art pieces inside.There is something for everyone

Amazing view of city fropm the terrace and superb variety of art inside. On a beautiful day the views over the City were matched by some of the exquisite art within the exhibition. Baroque, Medieval and Modern all beautifully displayed. Highlight was the exhibition of ancient wall paintings rescued from small churches in Catalunya.

Visit Romanesque rooms. The collection of Romanesque frescos from Catalan churches is well worth a visit. We also visited the gothic collection, the Cambo bequest and Thyssen-Bornemisza collection, all of which were far too heavily centred on religious topics for my liking (the Thyssen-Bornemisza collection in Madrid is obviously much more impressive).

Beautiful, but avoid the concession!. A wonderful view, beautiful building, but the concession was a rip off. Our server was rude, the prices outrageous! My friend ordered a chai late - she got disgusting sugar water for 7 Euros! She is diabetic, took one taste and realized it would put her in a coma! She asked for a plain tea instead and the rude man said ok, and then demanded 3 Euros! 10 Euros for a cup of tea in a paper cup for take away? No thanks! The low point of a wonderful trip

Wonderful art museum. We weren't planning to visit this museum, but later decided to because it was free admission with our Barcelona pass. It was a pleasant surprise. The building itself is very grandiose and the exhibits were great. There was a lot of variety in the museum, including sculpture and painting. They even have a Picasso displayed there.
Boring Inside Beautiful Outside. I enjoyed the outside and the views of the city best. The inside did not have any wow factor and the exhibits were typical artworks.

Good experience. The building itself is a work of art and the view from the top is breath taking. We enjoyed going through this museum on our last day in Barcelona and were not disappointed. I particularly enjoyed some of the very old pieces of religious art (altars, doors, etc).

Great introduction to Catalan art at this museum. The walk up the hill to this museu was a little taxing, but the collection is outstanding and well curated. Little bit of everything. Not knowing much about the Catalan artists, I was impressed by what I saw. Their restaurant, which is pricey, has good food (which I found rather in the French style) and a nice view of the city,

A must for museum vistors. This spacious museum contains the frescos completed in the 11th and 12th centuries from small village which were at risk from being either destroyed or sold to private collectors. It is an incredibly moving experience as you go through (we used their audioguide) and see these works of art presented. The many unknown artists who did these works merit our thanks, as does the museum for saving them. The museum continues with a super collection of other religious art presented in a way which is very relaxing. Going for either by themselves is worth it. We spent perhaps two hours there and did not even see half the museum. We will return.As senior citizens, there was no fee to enter other than the purchase of the audioguides. Ask. It was not an expensive museum to visit.The building itself is located above the city and has a series of fountains that you pass by on the way up if you come by metro and wish to walk up. There are outside escalators available. You can take a cab which delivers you much closer. For the mobility impaired, there is a lot of waling with some stairs and they do have wheelchair lifts.The view from the museum of the city is about as good as it gets. You can see the Cathedral as well as the Sagrada Familia off in the distance. Even if you don't visit the museum, the view itself is worth it.Highly recommended.

Old and New. Not usually a fan of museums but this one was great and comfortably doable in under three hours. Beat the crowd and go early. Enjoy a pleasant walk afterward to the Fundacio Joan Miro. Consider the Museum Pass if you think you'll see four museums and want to skip the lines

Historic art in a stunning location. Housed in the Palau Nacional on the mountain of Montjuic , you can sit outside and admire the beautiful view . The museum itself houses some incredible peices of art including the best collection Romanesque murals in the world . Most were rescued from abandoned churches in the Pyrenees and the displays include fascinating film showing the lengths the curators had to go to in order to collect and preserve these murals. We really enjoyed the visit .

wonderful Catalan art exhibits. I really appreciated the Romanesque churches which they have brought into the museum by an amazing method and restored in the actual church structure. The building is located on a hill with views and the building itself is lovely

Not ready for this!. Standing at the opening steps of MNAC and you look down over the city and get a great panorama of Barcelona.Enter and you are assaulted by the grandure of the museum and the effort and attention given to presenting it's exhibits.I will admit that I was slightly overwhelmed by the number of frescos and underwhelmed by the slight shortage of seating when inside each viewing area. That being said, 5 hours and I think I only scratched the surface of the exhibits.If you are serious this museum will reward your time - it's worth planning a very full morning, afternoon or day and taking a good time-out on the front terrace for refreshment.Just two stops down on most tour buses is the Miro centre if you want to blow the whole day on art :)

Fabulous Museum. The MNAC is housed in the National Palace, a large, striking building on Montjuic. This museum is filled with treasures you will probably never see anywhere else but in Barcelona. For "mayores" (seniors) there is no charge! When entering we received a very helpful brochure that listed all of the museums masterpieces and was color-coded according to the section where they were located. My wife and I spent a few hours in two of the museums six sections – Romanesque Art and Modern and Contemporary Art. The collection of mural paintings taken from Roman churches in the Pyrenees is unique in the world. There are also many colorful altarpieces from the 11-13th centuries. In the modern section we came across Catalan artists that we were unfamiliar with, but whose artworks were interesting and beautiful. Maria Fortuny was a favorite. The art is housed in the National Palace, a large, striking building on Montjuic. As others have commented, the arrangement is intuitive; it is easy to find your way around. MNAC was definitely worth a visit for its unique focus on Catalonian art.

A beautiful structure with a eclectic collection. We loved the beautiful building with its electric collection of art ranging over many centuries. We particularly liked that for seniors, there is no entrance fee. You won't regret having stopped at this museum.

At least 3 hours. on my lkast visit, I've spent close to 5 hours to the museum so make sure that you've scheduled a half day of your program. ArtTicket helps you to skip the line (but generally not so crowded)

fascinating. Unfortunately we left this to our last day after a week of hectic sightseeing and therefore didn't feel that we did it justice. Some beautiful and fascinating works of art on display, something for everyone whatever your taste in art

Ambiance extraordinary. The museum itself is expensive unless you go Saturday from 3-6 pm when its free. It has some lovely art and worth a stroll around as any great art museum. Buit the setting and the whole feel of the place is beyond the ordinary. The fountains the people the hillside and views...wow!

Pop it on your list for a Barcelona trip. I had been to Barcelona several times and never visited this wonderful gallery. I now know I really was missing something. This has a great selection of the best of Catalunyan art and artifacts presented in a beautiful building. The 3D recreation of a Romanesque temple particularly appealed to the children. The views over Montjuic and the city are spectacular.

A World Class Art Museum. In Spain, the Museo Prado is considered to be the most important art museum in the country but no one should miss the MNAC in Barcelona. Located at the top of a hill, it is worth the climb up - about 150 steps to the entry after taking two escalators but the great art inside is worth every step. The exterior is also breath taking - looking very much like a castle and adorned with neo-classical statutes. In addition, there are three waterfalls running from the top down. There is also an unobstructed view of the Plaza de Espanya and the twin Venician Towers. While the outside is older, the inside is as modern as any museum in the world. The collection of Medieval-Gothic art is absolutely first class. Don't miss this if you visit Barcelona. Lastly,unlike the Prado in Madrid, this museum does allow photos and video - No Flash, please. There is a modest entry fee but worth every penny. Free on Sundays.

Simply amazing!. There are plenty of reviews here of the amazing religious frescos and how they have been painstakingly displayed as if they are in the actual church 'domes'. The hop on hop off bus drops off to the right side at the level of the museum, but should you find yourself at the bottom of the amazing 'hill' at the front entrance do not despair....there are escalators all the way up! Your hop on bus tickets will also you get you a discount admission.

I still don't get it. A great exhibition space, which really shows off the art therein. It's a shame that I'm not smart enough to get it though. A good way to spend a couple of hours, if the weather's not quite up to scratch. There's a bit of a lack of explanation and background regarding the works though.

Monumental Structure. We had a little trouble finding this museum but when you see where you are and how huge it is with a ceremonial entryway...you wonder how there could have been any difficulty. The interior space is vast with Romantic Medieval, Gothic, Baroque Modern and Contemporary art well represented. There is also a Coin collection. We went during the Festival of La Merce. The museum was free but hours were shortened. Spent time looking at the Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza collection and lots of the early religious art. Well worth the time.

A stunning venue. What I like about this venue is - well, it blows your mind when you first walk in. I was looking for a great venue for a gala dinner for 550 people. This is it!Staff are great, very flexible. Access is good for production equipment and crew.Food is normally created by the Hotel Arts - fantastic!Highly recommend
Awesome Art. Beautiful museum atop a mountain. Very nice works of art and nice architectural structure. Staff was helpful and friendly.
Art museum. If you are interested in the progression of church art in the middle ages this exhibit is second to none!

Brilliant collection in a beautiful building. This museum was a great surprise and, even better, we had free access as we were over 65. The early Romanesque pieces, rescued from old and abandoned churches, were magnificent and well displayed. The frescoes are special.
We ate lunch at the restaurant there, with superb views over the park and Barcelona. Food was great too.

Surprisingly amazing. This museum says it covers 1000 years of Catalonian art, but that did not prepare me for how amazing was its 1000 year-old material and its presentation.It has an amazing collection of Romanesque art saved from about 10 churches in nearby mountain valleys, removed from the walls and transferred to the museum where they are displayed as if in situ. It's like visiting all these churches in about 2 hours. Some of that work, is very beautiful. Some is in fantastic condition to, with really bright colours. And some is very modern in form.There are also numerous paintings by local artists from the 18th century onwards (which we barely had time for) and a whole section of Italian Renaissance works (Spain controlled the area around Naples then) which we did not see at all.Final word - if you're going and you like to learn about what you're seeing, this is a very well laid out gallery with good audioguide. At our pace, needs a whole day and is worth it.It is in a magnificent building with a wonderful restaurant with splendid views (you must book to get a look in there! though there is a modest cafe on another floor).Surprisingly, in this museum you could take photos and I happily took advantage of that.

Great art, well displayed. Even though the subject matter of most of the art was not our favorite type (medieval religious), the pieces they have, their vibrancy and the way they are displayed made this a special experience. Be sure not to miss the frescoes.

Quite Outstanding Collection & Building. The speciality is the various old frescoes removed from ancientchurches in Northern Catalonia which are remarkably vivid. Therest of the Museum has a varied quality collection of paintings, stained glass and furniture through the centuries up to more recent times. In addition to its contents, the late 1920's building is itself is most impressive not least the large central hall. Good quality refreshment facilities and giftshops befitting this Museum.

The Catalonia Museum. This historic building with great panoramic vies of Barcelona contains an extensive collection of all forms of Spanish--its galleries include romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance, Baroque, Modern and Contemporary Art. One can spend a full day here and appreciate the building as well.

The place for Catalan art. The hop on, hop off buses stop here, otherwise you will want to take a taxi or get off at the Espana Metro stop and walk, then take the escalators up. This is also where you will see the Magic Fountain Thursday - Sunday nights at dusk.We were lucky, being retired, our admission was free. The art is varied and is divided into categories, such as modern (which really wasn't modern, but was more mid-century), classic, etc. Some Guadi designed furniture is there and is quite interesting. A good percentage of the art is religiously based. There are works of famous artists like Picasso and Renoir. There is a cafe inside at the back of the building and a vendor run cafe outside in the front. There are lovely views from the terrace.

Fabulous museum in an incredible location.. Don't miss this place. Not as much on the radar as the Picasso museum, but it's a vast place with fascinating exhibits. You get a sense of the history of the place, and the pride of the people. And the high end restaurant on the top floor is worth the money, for both the food and the view.

Beautiful museum, in front of the magic fountain. If you are in Barcelona for a short trip, I would strongly advise you not to waste time here.It is a beautiful museum, definitely worth visiting, but as it is really big, you cannot enjoy it unless you spend at least a whole afternoon, and still it might not be enough time.I really like museums, so in 2 hours I was barely done seeing the medieval section. It closes early on Sundays (3 pm), but during the week it is open until 6 (between October and May). Admission prices (€12), opening times and all other relevant information can be found on their website under "visit us" (http://www.mnac.cat/index.jsp?lan=003).Even if you won't have time to see it from inside, it is worth visiting the outside and the garden on the back anyway. The building is magnificent and the view breathtaking (an almost panoramic view of Barcelona).Also, it is in front of the magic fountain, so if you come for an afternoon you already have a nice plan for the evening. There are some nice restaurants in the area and there's easy access to the metro.

Take your time. We spent two whole days here looking at the vast array of Gothic and Medieval art as well as the Modern wing - your ticket entitles you to two days in 1 month. Great building and the audio guide was fantastic.
Excellent display of ancient religious art. Beautifully situated, the former palace has many intersting exhibits. The most interesting for me was the excellently displayed religious art.

Stunning Building. The closest Metro is Placa Espanya, when you get up on street level just look for the 2 enormous columns which mark the start of the Avenue de la Reina that leads past the Magic Fountain ( so well worth a visit Thurs-Sunday 21.00 - 23.00 hrs!) up to the museum.This is a lovely museum with fabulous architecture and views from the roof terrace. There was a 10 euro entrance charge per person and its worth getting the audio guides as very little of the exhibit labels are translated into English.Be warned the food and drink at the front and in the museum is expensive for what you get. I personally would get off the metro, go to the Arena next door, go down to the basement and buy a fabulous baguette and pastry from one of the little units - there is a fabulous artisan bread café down there!The museum has Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque artwork and artefacts, it also has the largest collection of Catalán art in Spain.What is really impressive is the way the old frescos have literally been lifted off of the walls in older churches in the region and relocated here in purpose made arches and walls. Being used to the conservation ethos of the National Trust- this rather brutal process is a bit shocking but it does make for a very impressive exhibit!I was slightly disappointed that the museum is so heavily focused on religious works of art, I was expecting a wide range of artistic styles and subjects and there are a few - but by and large it’s a museum of religious art.We spent a good 3 hours wandering around and taking pics. When we had finished at the museum we walked around the right hand side of the building and wended our way through to the cable car station that took us up to Muntjuic Castle - lovely way to spent the day!!!

Great art from Medieval to Contemporary!. Who knew there was so much fabulous Catalonian art? Not only were the permanent collection and the exhibits terrific, but the building and restoration are a masterpiece.

A lot of beautiful frescos. This was one tourist spot in Barcelona where there were not a lot of tourists! On Mont Juic with great views of the city from its roof. There were many excellent frescos from ancient churches.

Sunday brunch at the restaurant. We went to see the museum but had not left sufficient time to view all the exhibitions and have brunch. We opted for the brunch and we were not disappointed the setting and views were amazing and the food complemented the setting perfectly. We hadn't booked a table but were accommodated as we arrived at the restaurant as they opened, I would recommend booking as people were turned away shortly after we arrived. A truly wonderful dining experience the food was exceptional and the wine recommended by the waiter was a bargain compared to some others we had tried elsewhere. Make the time to enjoy this wonderful dining experience.

Wonderful museum, greatest view of Barcelona. Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya (MNAC) is a great museum which so well organized. Pick the era that you are interested and everything is chronologically organized. It is great, you can see how art and artists evolved over time. The museum is so easy to visit! It is a short walk from the Espanya metro station. Just come out the station and look for the hillside covered by the Magic Fountain and the castle (aka the museum) on top. You get to see the Magic Fountain as you walk to the museum. This is an easy walk...there are escalators going all the way from the street to the museum. Actually the escalators continue onto the Fundacio Joan Miro. I would recommend planning your day to see the Fundacio Joan Miro first, and walk back toward the MNAC. Plan on having lunch in the MNAC. Restaurant which has the greatest view of the city of Barcelona. The MNAC provides free admission to seniors (65+). Trust two seniors: you can easily manage the Barcelona metro, the walk (with escalators to avoid climbing stairs or hillsides), free admission and a great view. My only regret is that we ate before the museum. It serves lunch 12 to 5-remember the late evening meals in Spain. Even the restaurant served just dog food, it would be worth a visit for just the view.

REALLY WORLD CLASS EXHIBITION. Try and spend at least 2 - 3 hours at this museum - the exhibits are really interesting. Murals, oil paintings, the architecture of the building itself .... well worth the entrance fee. If you are doing the HOHO bus, they have a coupon for a bit of a discount. While there, don't forget to visit the roof top look-out, the view is awesome.

A Museum any country would be proud of consider its own. Very, very well done. A true rendition of the marvelous wall paintings that were done in churches in Medieval days, lifted from the churches and repositioned in replica layouts. Truly impressive. There is also very good galleries of Spanish art, modern art, all very cleanly presented in the magnificent splendor of the Palace built for the World Exhibition in Barcelona. Truly a MUST visit

Much more interesting than I expected. Worth a trip to Montjuic for lunch and a visit to the art museum. It's large so give yourself some time to explore. You can take escalators down the mountain in front of the museum for fountains, cafés, plaza espagna. The miro museum is also on the same mountain.

Surprising. Great views from the terrace. Went to see the modern art: interesting but relatively average. Happily suprised by the medieval section: really amazing and well planned exhibit, not too overwhelming but interesting and informative

A wonderful museum!. What a surprise this museum was to us. We went primarily because it was included on our Articket which covers five museums in Barcelona. Otherwise, I'm not sure we would have gone here. What a mistake that would have been as this museum turned out to be one of our favorite attractions in Barcelona. First of all, the views of Barcelona from the terrace of the museum are stunning. Then, the museum itself is wonderful. The art is displayed in beautiful surroundings with enough space around each piece to fully appreciate it. The medieval art in particular is displayed in the way one would view it in the churches from which it came. It was beautiful. So wonderful that a group of people thought to start saving this art from local churches before it was taken and put on the market. Now it is available for all to enjoy. Also enjoyed the Renaissance art and Modernist art. Don't miss this museum on your visit to Barcelona.

Amazing exterior!. We didn't even go inside. We were up on Montjuic walking around and wanted to see this because I had seen pictures online. It's massive and beautiful. We returned the next night to see the "magic fountain" show. Not to sound like a "stupid American", but after seeing the fountain at the Bellagio in Vegas, this was a bit underwhelming (no music, for example). However, none of the fountains were on when we saw the MNAC the evening before so it was worth the trip to be able to see the fountains on. The show itself wasn't much to write home about but the fountains just add to the beauty of the building.

Lovely museum. I visited the museum because I had to do something while my husband was working in Barcelona. I thought I would find a quirky local museum with unimportant works, but boy was I wrong!The building itself is lovely, a gem of the early 20th century. I liked that they had a cloak room where I could put my bag since it was quite a big museum.The ticket allows you to come back for free up to a month after you buy the ticket. I found that very interesting specially because I went back a few days later to pick up a few prints of the paintings they have there.I was touched by the fact that the people of Catalunya fought to keep their mural paintings from the ancient churches in the country (after one was sold to a museum in Chicago). But I found it funny that while they state that catalunyan art must stay in Catalunya they had a few German sculptures on display there. Huh.I loved the modernist collection, too. There's a beautiful selection of art nouveau works (oh, the jewelry!), though I think the furniture would be best showcased in a room "like it was back then" rather than on white platforms against a white backdrop.There's free wi-fi, comfy couches here and there, many clean bathrooms scattered around, a few restaurants and a good gift shop (which you can access only with a ticket, however). The museum is on a hill but there's escalators almost all the way to the top.

Glorious. I would consider this as one of the top five attractions in Barcelona, easily. Dragging a two yeyar old through a museum isn't easy and there was so much to see, so I focused on two of the greatest treasures in the museum - the collection of Romanesque frescoes, murals, carvings and sculptures from Catalan churches and monasteries and the collection of Gothic panel paintings and altarpieces by the Catalan (and Aragonses and Castilian) masters from the mid fourteenth to the late fifteenth centuries.If you are an art buff (like me), you have to go and see and savour the collection, it is truly breathtaking.If you are not (like my better half), you would still be amazed by the monumental frescoes, the vividness of the colours, the exquisite details on the altarpieces, the intricate carvings etc etcAnd then there are the splendid views of the city from the top of the hill and the beautiful building in which the art is housed.And what you must also not miss is the restaurant - some of the best food and wine you will have in Barcelona, sitting under a frescoed ceiling in a beautiful room, withh maginificent view of the city beneath you. That is truy the icing on the cake!

A fitting place to house the history of Spanish art. A grand building converted into a sensational art museum this building towers over the plaza de Espanya. Take the walk up the boulevard all the way to the majestic building with the done. Entry is reasonable at€12 . Four separate galleries present all periods of art, marvel at the frescos recreated into church coves, fantastic religious sculptures, and great paintings. Photography also has a place. This building also offers panoramic views of Barcelona. A must see for the art livers and those that wish to know more about Spanish influences I the history of art. Fantastic experience.Suggestions: take good walking shoes, allow plenty of time, and purchase audio guides.

fabulous overview of the art of the centuries!. a beautiful welcoming building- all the art of the area from ancient times up to modernists-- and a gift store full of treats!an exhaustive review of art that will saturate your mind and eyes. Luckily some resting places, too!

Decent gallery, but the building itself is the highlight. Admission for this museum is somewhat pricey (16 Euros for students), and whilst there is admittedly a lot of art, large quantities of it are religious works from artists you're unlikely to have heard of. The photography section was more interesting, and there are works by Goya and Reubens on display. The view from the roof is quite spectacular, although its not significantly better than the view from the entrance. The building itself is quite spectacular, although its worth noting you can get in to that part for free if you're visiting one of the restaurants (of which there are three). The poshest of which was fully booked even on a wednesday lunchtime, so book in advance. Avoid the cheapest "microwave your own food" restaurant, which is overpriced, given that there's a medium $14 euro set menu next door.
Interesting. Some of the exhibits are interesting but I was not so impressed comparing to other art museums in Europe. My favorite part is the part of Gothic art - do not miss out
A Must. Beautiful building, fantastic art and exhibits. It's worth every step up the staircase. The view from the promenade is unbelievable.

Romantic, Gotic, Baroque or Modern; which one you like best?. Easy parking at the back of the museum. It is enjoyable to spend some time at the cafe in front of the museum. Plaça Espanyol is right in front of you and off course a beautiful view of the city. The museum holds hundreds of valuable and adorable paintings and sculptures. There are four main galleries. I enjoyed Baroque and Modern the most. While buying the tickets, we took a special deal and bought the tickets for Pablo Espanyol as well. It has given us some saving. They also charge you to enter the upper balcony of the museum. Basicaly the same view actually. No need to spend more I think. The shop inside the museum is large and has interesting stuff that you could pick up as souvenir.

real experience. great romanesque collection. early churches domes resonstructed and frescos moved in, very beautifull and impressive. The same could be said about Gothic collection. The building itself is very beautiful inside. You can also buy a combined tickets to the Poble Espanol nearby

Interesting architecture. I very much liked the architecture of the building. Unfortunately, I personally am not so big a fan of modern art (black square with red dot), but always find paintings or installations that surprise me.
It was a pleasure to have the opportunity to visit the museum. Beautiful art. Beautiful spot to visit. We were there with 1200 people for a conference and held our welcome reception there.

Great Museum. Well worth the walk. The building is amazing as is the contents. Wonderful exhibition of early frescoes from the region. The modern art collection of Catalan art from 19th and 20th century was an eye opener for someone from overseas.

Need to give it the time it deserves. A very well curated museum, but it does need the time to appreciate what you are looking at unless you are a student of Spanish, Oops!, Catalunyan history :) Make the effort it's a really wonderful place in an architecturally stunning building that I believe was constructed for the World Exposition of 1929. Also, try the restaurant there on the second level. The food is quite good and the view is breathtaking!
Marvelous site. This museum is on the Mont Juïc and looks out over a part of Barcelona. The fountains are wonderful: in the evening they are in full display on music with a lightshow. Must visit!
Beautiful walk!. The view from the top of the museum is breathtaking. You will see all of Barcelona from the top and the Olympic facilities are close by. Wear comfy shoes!

One of the greatest museums I've ever been. Museum of National Art of Catalonia is a must see in Barcelona. Here you will see many works of art you may have never seen before, real art pieces and why not, masterpieces. Besides, the building is beautiful both outside and inside. It's easy to find the halls you're most interested in, should it be modern or classic art. You can't use the flash, but you are allowed to use your camera and make a good video to keep it for a memory.

Beautiful building and good art displays. The approach to this beautiful palace and the views from the entrance are awe-inspiring. Once inside this is a lovely place to spend a couple of hours roaming through the art displays. We come each year and never tire of its beauty (and it is free for seniors).

A definite must-see in Barcelona.... Wow, from first looks, this museum definitely doesn't disappoint. It's beautiful! It's a bit of a trek up a lot of steps, but its totally worth it. Once you get to the top, the view of the city is perfection. We were lucky enough to be there on the first Sunday of the month so it was free entry! We were also VERY lucky that there was a special exhibit of Antoni Tàpies going on, and it was beyond words amazing. It was such a great experience and afternoon, I would recommend a trip to this museum to anyone!

totally worth it - go... big and amazing building , right next to the magic fountain , don't worry about the long stairs - there's an Escalator ...at the begining it was really boaring - it's all walls they replicated and glued everywhere , but the modernizem part was beautiful and amazing (it's the 2 last rooms) and it's free on the 1th in every month

Worth the stairs. With a beautiful view of the nice fountains and the city, I recommend to go here when the sun is setting. We had a conference dinner inside, so I only had the oppurtunity to se on of the exhibitions. Recommended.

Impressive. We went to MNAC for a dinner function, which also allowed some time to visit the older parts of the collection. I knew little about the museum prior to the visit, and was quite impressed by the frescoes, etc. that had been rescued from old churches; some dated to the 7th-8th centuries. Would recommend this for a specific visit. Plus the views of the city from Montjuic are spectacular.

Surprising. Just the place is worth a stop: the climb off Monjuic is worth the view and the Palace in which the Museum is, is very nice. The collection is huge so focus maybe on one or two of the four major aisle. We choose the most modern sculptures/paintings and even without a lot of world-renowned names (there was one Picasso and one Dali) the art in there is impressive. We also scanned rapidly the Roman-paintings that were taken out of little churches of the Pyrenees before Hitler could put his hands on them. Those too are impressive even though they're almost a thousand-years old.
Good but you need lots of time!. Amazing place but its HUGE - allow yourself a good few hours if you want to get round it all! and don't eat in the cafe, food is very overpriced.

Beautiful building and gardens. I did not visited the museum, as we have'nt enough time. But the building itself, and the beatiful gardens, stares, fountain and statues, made it, for me, one of the three best sites of the city.

Died and gone to Heaven. The blame for reason I couldn't walk the rest of my holidays is laid firmly at this doorstep. Loved it totally and utterly. I would happy spend my days here going from one display to another and never once see the same thing twice. There isn't a thing to fault.

Nice art collection. Enjoyable museum and view of Barcelona. Spend an hour or so here and then walk to the Miro museum. Buy the musuem pass...if you go to three museums you will save euros, and be able to skip the long line at the Picasso museum.

Outstanding, if overwhelming. The museum is enormous, but almost impossible to see in its entirety in just one visit. A handout visitors guide is very helpful, visually highlighting and locating what they consider the museum's masterpieces. We found the Romanesque Art collection, with its mural paintings, unique and worth following through the entire collection. We wish we had done the same for the Gothic collection, because the Renaissance, Baroque and modern collections did not represent the best of many artists shown. Unfortunately for English speakers, the exhibits are labeled only in Spanish and Catalan and the English audio guides were very confusing to follow.

Pretty big. In a nice location, a pretty big museum with lots of mediewal and catalan art pieces. You can spend 2 days in here. Its A nice decorated and air conditioned building and a Cafe in front entrance.
Reasonable price, so elegant museum. A plenty of artworks you will see. Also here you can look back to see the city from bird's eyes view.

Breathtaking. The interior displays contrast starkly with a fantastic collection of medieval and gothic art--truly a wonderful collection. Also family friendly as my three year old was able to sprint around the arena while my husband and I took turns in the galleries. The gift shop is full of eclectic treasures.

Great Building. ther are many lots of rooms from early middle age to modern art, something to every one, but you will need most of the day to get through. For your well-beeing you find a excellent restaurant there.
For Seniors 65+ the entrance is free.

Forget the Gaudi and Miro if you don't have time.. This is an extraordinary museum in a magnificent locale high over the city. It has an unparalleled collection of Romanesque frescoe and Renaissance art, among other standouts. Should not be missed.

A great alternative BCN day trip!. After struggling with the crowds of Las Ramblas and Placa Catalunya, visiting Montjuïc was such a welcome change. I left quite early, getting the Metro, and immediately spotted the two large columns that I'd been told to look out for. Walking between these columns you can see the Museu straight away, and you simply need to walk towards it! There are escalators to facilitate the hill up to the building, but you'll probably want to spend some time photographing the incredible building before going up them.Once you reach the building, you can see across the whole of Barcelona pretty much. When I visited it was quite busy here with tourists taking photos, but if you want a quieter spot for photos you can walk up a little higher/take the next escalator and enjoy the view from a number of beautiful free-entry gardens. At 10am on a Sunday morning I only came across one or two other people in these gardens!Also, as I visited on the first Sunday of the month I got into the Museu free of charge. I found this to be an added benefit on top of the great views, lovely surroundings, and of course great art inside. I particularly enjoyed the Civil War photography section in the Modern 2 exhibition, but the older sculptures and wall murals were really interesting too.

Amazing collection of early Romanesque art. This museum is a "must" for every visit I make to Barcelona. They have painstakingly salvaged many interior frescoes from the surrounding forgotten chapels of Catalonia--it's just unbelievable! I just wish the museum provided more opportunities for sitting so one could just rest and take in all the details--there's just too much to see on a whirlwind visit, so be prepared to take some time. The collection of Renaissance work is nice as is the early modern. Sadly, I'm not very familiar with the more modern Catalonian artists--although there's a very nice free exhibit of Antoni Tapias right now--which is very nice.

Amazing Frescoes in a Beautiful Museum. This museum on Montjuic, with its fantastic views of the city below, is one of Barcelona's most beautiful attractions. It is a large collection, so plan your time according to what interests you most. We were there for over two hours and did not see everything, but what we enjoyed the most by far were the fascinating 12th century frescoes from Catalan Pyrenean churches. The slide presentation on how the frescoes were stabilized, removed from the churches and relocated to the museum was extremely interesting and a great testimony to those who worked so painstakingly to ensure these national treasures can be enjoyed for years to come. There is also a very good Modern art collection as well. If the art collection isn't enough, the Palau Nacional where the museum is located is a wonderful structure. After your visit to the museum, stroll around the grounds and then walk down to the Placa d'Espana. The trip down is easy, and there are escalators if you want to go back up but don't want to challenge the stairs. The fountains and waterfalls on the way down, with the Palau as the backdrop, provide some of the best photo ops you'll experience in Barcelona, a city that's full of them. We combined this visit with a trip to the Joan Miro museum further up the mountain, as well as a visit to the 1992 Olympic site. It makes a great day. Take the metro to the funicular to get up the mountain and then and spend a leisurely day descending. There are plenty of other sights to see as well including beautiful parks. The metro lines at Placa d'Espana will get you back to your hotel in no time.

Best experience in 4 day Barca trip. 12eu entry. By Barcelona standards this is dirt cheap, but even in a more normally priced city it'd be worth it.Takes about 3-5 hours to visit without even renting (3.50eu) an audio guide! Which i kinda wish i had now, there were very few printed explanations in English next to the works.What you will enjoy in the museum is of course a matter of taste, there is huge variety and thus, something for everyone. I had never really seen gothic art before so spent a few hours seeing their very large (and disturbingly violent) collection.Many of the rooms have quite cool air conditioning and you might (like me) be in them for ages...so if you're prone to getting cold, bring a jumper even if it's a warm day.

Spectacular art and unmatched city views. This was our last stop before departing Barcelona, and we had only one hour to sample the exhibits. The museum gives you a brochure with the top 10 exhibits, and that is a good starting place for charting your path. We went first to see Gaudi's furniture, and then on to Picasso and Miro, spending most of our time in the Modern art sections. My husband wandered off to see Romanesque frescoes and he said that they were his favorite. Afterwards we had ice cream on the patio outside the entrance and enjoyed a Flamenco guitarist while taking in the views of the city.

A couple of days worth of viewing. I recommend allocating a couple of days/ afternoons to this huge museum full of Catalan delights. Tickets allow re entry and the location is amazing. Continue up Montjuic for wonderful views and more sights.

Fabulous. This was the only art gallery we visited. (Paris had done us in) We chose it as it represents the artists of the Catalan region. This is the region that Barcelona is in. I didn't realize that the culture of the region was so strong..its not like it's just another area of Spain..it has a completely different language. This is an enormous beautiful building high up on the hills above the city. You are not going to walk there. We took the hop on hop off bus and it drops you in the car park next to the building. Lovely views from up there. The gallery is huge and traces the history of Catalan art from early medieval times to the mid-20th century: European artists and Spanish artist are also represented. The Romanesque collection is one of the best in the world. From the Gothic to Modern the collections here are excellent. Plus, it's just a beautiful building!

A Good Diversion. Everything in the city is about Gaudi - so I found the museums a breath of fresh air. Picasso is as well a must see. Buy the 6 ticket museum pass on-line which allows you to by-pass all the museum wait lines. It is well worth the expense. Trust me.

Provides a cool and calm break from the tourist spots of Barcelona. We had a really enjoyable afternoon at MNAC. The collections are varied and there is something for everyone. I enjoyed the two Modern Art collections very much and the Gothic art panels were quite amazing. If I lived it Barcelona it's somewhere I'd like to spend Sunday afternoons as there's a really calm feel to the whole museum and the architecture inside is worth a visit in itself. I wish we'd gone to the restaurant as we had a coffee and a snack in the cafe and it was very expensive and the service was dreadful and all the tables were piled with dirty dishes.

You must see this Museum if you have 3-5 hours.. Amazing collection of art. I am not a huge art lover, nor do I support spending vacation time in museums, but MNAC was well worth the time we spent there.You should see how they have removed art from the walls of the medieval churches and put them up in the museum so that the art doesn't get lost or be sold to others. They actually show an elaborate video of how they do that.And seriously some things that you will see there are beyond description.The view of 'Fountain of Magic' and of the city from MNAC is fantastic.My Suggestions:1. Carry water, though you can buy it from the café inside, its difficult keep going to the café again and again.2. Please take the audio guide, you will be able to understand the art there a lot more. Though there are printed materials on the walls, which you could read, but audio guide is more elaborate.3. Wear you walking shoes, the gallery is HUGE, so you'll have to walk a lot.4. The restaurant inside is good and moderately priced. You could stop there after you are tired of walking for hours.5. It will easily take 3-5, so plan your itinerary accordingly, if you plan to visit.6. We did not buy tickets to the terrace (posters claim that the Terrace offer a great view), because it would have costed us 5 Euros extra. We didn't think it was needed.

Huge gallery; plan your visit!. Great museum of Spanish art; definitely worth planning your visit well, as trying to see everything would be a very tiring schlep. Really good audio guides are avaiable in several languages, and good floor plans and guides, so visit the front desks before you set out. Brilliant exhibition of mediaeval church altarpieces, and there is a single cubist Picasso (which I was able to view as the only visitor in the room, which was a lovely change from the crowds at the Picasso museum in town!). The building itself is amazing, and the inner hall is definitely worth a look. Cafe and shop are both good.

Worthwhile for the building itself. We loved MNAC. As soon as we got off the metro and saw the building we were impressed. It's absolutely stunning in real life and just walking up to it and sitting on the upper steps while buskers play in the sunshine is a treat in itself. The architecture inside and out is just stunning and it's brilliant that they keep it free admission. The only downside is that the collection is not as impressive as the building, don't get me wrong there's some great stuff in there and it's well curated but it's not up to the art museums of London or Paris which is what the granduer of the building gives you the impression of!
Great View!. Didn't go inside, but enjoyed the view on the way from Plasa Espaniol to Montjuic via Magic Fountains. Beautiful part of Barcelona

Breathtaking views.. Confession - we saw this building from miles away across Barcelona so when the Tourist Bus stopped there, we visited. We are not lovers of art as such, so did not look round the museum.However the road leading up to the museum gives such an impressive view of the building and grounds, that we were drawn to keep walking up the myriad of flights of steps and terraces. We took a huge amount of photographs as the view at every level was amazing, and increased until we got to the top (bought tickets to go up into the tower) where we were able to see the most fantastic views of the city. WOW!!!We wish we had time to have returned to see the evening music/fountain show, but hopefully we will do this on our next trip.

A nice view of Barcelona city from the top. This trip was awesome, experience of a lifetime; a place worth visiting. Went to the MNAC twice! Get your tickets for the Bus Turistic tour and you wont regret, at all!

What a view!. This review is slightly biased; the reason being that a guy handed us his tickets as he left (which allowed us free entry and access all areas). I'm not sure if I'd have felt differently had we paid. It's quite a trek up to the top via escalators and steps but the view is totally worth it. We peeked into the museum restaurant (Oleum) and the view was breathtaking. I looked up the restaurant on here when we got back to the hotel and I wish we'd coupled up a meal with the museum. If you're a couple I am struggling to think of anywhere more romantic than here; classy, beautiful and not stupidly expensive. Dining aside, the collection was "traditional". The frescos were mindblowing but for me monotonous. The building itself impressed me as much as the contents and I think they know this as many sofas are scattered for you to gaze at the magnificent ceiling. The "modern art" sections had mainly renaissance stuff; if you want to see a good dali you gotta go to Figueres...!

Huge!. The museum is very big, so you really need to plan your visit. It has a lot of art from all over the world and from a lot of eras.
It also has an amazing view of Barcelona city, and the magic fountain
A beautiful building with impressive collection. On the 1st Sunday of each monrh it is free. It is worthwhile visiting this museum. unfortunately didn't have enough time and I'm sure I;ll come back .

Why did it take me so many trips to discover this?. This makes my fifth visit to BCN and on each of my previous visits I've neglected to take a look inside this magnificent building. The inside is as beautiful and as well maintained as the exterior, and the collection of Gothic art is outstanding. It made for a great contrast to our visit to the Joan Miro Foundation just down the hill from the Museum. If you have time, the National Museum is definitely worth a visit...the walk up from Plaza Espana is special...would love to see it at night when the fountains are on full display.

Excellent sightseeing. Beautiful museum with a lot of history. We learn a lot in this visit.Place very clean and organize. Price is fair and worth it the visit. We love and expect to visit again next summer.

Really worth the visit! Great surroundings too!. I first took time to visit this place on my thirs visit to Barcelona, there are so many things to see and enjoy in Barcelona but I am very happy that we came here and spent the day and do highly reccomend it!Came here with my family, kids are 6 and 10. We were lucky enough to se the Antonin Tapies exhibition and really loved it, it was a great inspiration for the kids!The building is a beautiful palace, lockers available, both a cafeteria and restaurant in side (fantastic view!) also a nice gift store not to mention the free wi-fi. The building stands above several stairs leading down to the Magic fountains and Plaza Espanya, I reccomend taking a seat st the top of the stairs after 7 pm and wait for the light show in the Magic fountains. We brought something to eat the and bought cava and slush from the vendor just outside the museum.Also just behind the museum you will find the Olympic Stadium.

An interesting museum in a renovated warehouse. This is a wonderful museum for tourists and locals to learn about the history of the Catalunya people.There is 3 levels of displays and there are wonderful and interesting information on each part of the history.For English speaking visitors there is a lot of informationIt's well worth a visit

THE art museum to see in Barcelona. If you can only see one art museum in Barcelona, this is it. The building and the collections are much larger than any other with multiple styles of art on display that will appeal to many different tastes. In the interior, we enjoyed the "modern collections." On the outside, the beauty of Monjuric hill and the impressive façade of this facility are unforgettable.
Lovely views. Fantastic views. Got in for free on Saturday afternoon. Not sure I would have gone inside if I had to pay !

An amazing collection in a pompous building!!!. From the stunning building to the amazing collection, this museum is a must-seen place.Located in the palau nacional, the MNAC has a vast and well preserved collection organised in different sections: Romanesque art, Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque, Modern art and numismatics. As the collection is rich and large I will definitely recommend to spend more time in the Romanesque section which is amazingly beautiful and incredibly interesting. The frescoes removed from old churches in Catalonia are stunning!!! The colours are well preserved and all the works look so modern considering the time they have been made.I also recommend to see the Gothic and the modern art sections with beautiful paintings and furnitures from catalan artists.DON'T MISS IT!!!
Fabulous. Have been to Barcelona before but this trip made the effort to get to MNAC - definitely worth the effort!

Nice way to pass an afternoon. After spending my morning in the overcrowded Park Guell this was a nice change. Small amounts of people, quiet and great big air conditioned rooms. I didn't take an audio guide here, not sure if it cost extra. Instead I wandered around at my own pace. There is some beautiful work on display though not many famous works. A nice place to spend a few hours away from the crowds. Once I had made my way through the collection I had a sit down on one of the enormous armchairs in the middle of the upper floor where there was also free wifi. This was a nice touch as I was shattered at that stage. As you leave again you will be treated to a magnificent view of the city. Well worth a few peaceful hours.
Just magic. Did you ever wonder how was Barcelona on the Roman period? Then you have to visit this museum. Very cheap and just a fantastic experience

Old meets New. There are some great sections in here of old art work and artifacts but I was let down by some of the newer exhibits that were on display downstairs. Calling some of these works "art" was disrespectful to the great art upstairs. However, if you want to see this for free, just come on a Saturday afternoon.

Amazing building in an amazing location. Went there on a Saturdday, so the entrance was free. And it was great! I'm not sure I'd have paid for the exhibition itself, but in the end I appreciated the paintings of the catalan artists.If you get there (do it on a Saturday!), try to walk from Plaça España. If you do so, you'll get the perfect approach of the magnificent MNAC building. The perspective is great, there's a massive fountain/waterfall falling at the foot of the building. Once you walked till the façade, enjoy the view over Barcelona!After your visit, continue by walking through the Olympic park of Montjuic!
Good. Very nice place make sure you will visit restaurant on top of the building amazing views good food nice service
Contemporary at its best. Well curated show of international might , thought provoking in a great luminous space ... not crowded ...very very pleasant! Great bistro across the street!
Short trip to MNAC. Unfortunately I didn't have much time to explore this magnificent building but from the little I've seen, its a must for first time Barcelona-visitors.

Wonderful!. Loved this Museum especially the Baroque section. We bought the joint ticket with entry toPoble Espanyol and saved a few euros, this ticket also allowed entry the next day, good if you start to get tired and are no longer enjoying he visit.

Nice to visit!!. Visit the museum, enjoy the paintings and the expositions, and have a nice day....After you are done enjoy the wonderful view from the top and be thankful to visit a city like Barcelona!! Awesome experience!!!
Worth an afternoon or even all day. Amazing artwork covering many Spanish generations and artists but also world famous artists. Its a beautiful space and the lunch in the upstairs cafe is very nice!

Nice museum but not the Louvre. I was able to go in the museum. It is not huge and there are a lot of local painters from the 15th, 16th and 17th century. There is one or two picassos. It is well organised and the building is nice to see as well. It is not similar to the Louvre or Prado. I don´t know that it is worth the 18 Euros to go in.

Architecture and exhibits both worth viewing. The building is beautiful and worthy of walking around, inside and out, regardless of whether you want to see the art treasures inside. The range of exhibits did have something for everyone. I enjoyed the display of ancient coins as much as the other artwork. It's an easy walk to the Olympic Stadium and the Magic Fountain. Buy an ArtTicket to save money and avoid waiting in lines.
.nice!. as museums go, this one is a winner. very well laid out and since they always have events going on, a real treat. children might get a little bored though, so its best to go without them.

The view at the top is worth it. This is a very beautiful art museum, but the thrill for us was the view at the top. After taking a series of stairs and outdoor escalators to the museum, which is in itself a lovely journey, we came to the entrance and turned to face the city. Amazing. You can see forever. This is the place to take that treasured vacation photo!
