Absolutely amazing!. Absolutely amazing! Located on the hill, possibility to enjoy a breathtaking panoramic view of the city. Lovely park around the museum for nice walks. We spent there few hours, I wish I could spend the whole day there.
The Shop .... We went in for the AC and the bathrooms, but ended up viewing the free exhibits and spent more than half an hour in the shop. Great place for interesting souvenirs without the crowds.

Stunning. The location, building and overall collection are all impressive, but it is the Romanesque collection where the museum soars. Simply one of the best exhibitions of art (and history) I have seen anyplace.

FAVORITE MUSEUM. Allow yourself enough time to experience all the treasures this museum has to offer. We could easily have returned a second time. It is well laid out and full of lovely surprises, encompassing the history of Catalan Art. Great gift shop also.
Wonderful on first Sunday of the month. Beautiful building, seating on the hill, but do not worry. There are escalators up and down. You need around 3 hrs to visit museum.

A real treat.. This museum is very large and has well laid out galleries. Sadly there are no English subtitles and I would have liked to have had more information about the exhibits. The religious art, frescoes and carvings are very interesting and of excellent quality. Do not miss them!

magic fountain. We finish our day in the area of the Museu, we went to view the early evening of the fountain show it was wonderful. Lot of people so you should go early to a better vantage point, we wer on the bridge just west of the fountain

Interesting museum in the Parc Montjuif - combine with the Miro. The hop-on, hop-off bus will take you to both these museums - both worth visiting. The Catalan Museum also has a spectacular view of Barcelona. The Medieval and modern/contemporary sectons were very interesting.

Come here just for the great views of Barcelona!. We arrived in Barcelona on a Saturday and since the museum was near our hotel (Fira Palace), this was the first attraction we visited. Had read on TA that the views are amazing from here and it's definitely true! Just the walk up the steps to the museum was a treat as there are cascading fountains. Great photo ops. There's a small bar just in front of the museum where you can buy a Sangria, wine or coffee and a terrace with tables to sit and enjoy the amazing panorama of Barcelona. We lucked out as it was just after 3 pm when we arrived so the entry was free! It's only free on Saturdays. What a great start to our 5 day stay in Barcelona! We came back in the evening to take some night time pictures as well. It's just a short 5 minute walk from Espanya metro. If you have time, go for a nice quiet walk on the path behind the museum, it leads to the Olympic venues.

double-check closed days. We attempted to go on a Monday, and the museum was closed. Apparently, they were always closed on Mondays? Just double-check open dates/times before you go. It's a bit difficult to get to - we used the Bus Touristic to get up there.

A must. We actually took two days to go though so we could go at a leisurely pace. Spent about 2+ hours each day. Ticket is good for two days, so it worked well. Don't forget to get a map and definitely get the audio tour if you are truly interested in the art and history of this area. Great wifi too.
Well worth a visit. Like the museum very much. Well set up display and very interesting.Disliked the toilets as they were not very well cared for.
Excellent collections. Apart from a great collection of paintings and sculptures, the museum also exhibits interesting and fine furnitures of Catalunya. The building itself is also impresssive.
very simple. The place was very simple with no WOW feeling as compared to the bus tour information .. more of paintings very average ... can me ignored
Great museum and it is FREE!. Free admittance after 3 p.m. on Saturdays. Perfect place to end your Montjuïc tour. So plan your visit ahead if you plan on saving some cash.

Beautiful building, gorgeous views, poor exhibition. We were extremely disappointed here - the exhibitions were not my thing at all, and without paying extra money for an audio guide or a tour, knowing what you are looking at is extremely difficult! The most outstanding aspect for me was the view from the outside overlooking Barcelona - amazing. Definitely worth visiting just for this alone.
Beautiful building. We didn't go into the museum but walked up to it and sat on the steps outsdie looking over the city for an hour. Cafe out at the front is quite expensive. Fantastic views.

Stunning city views. This is worth a visit even if you do not go inside. Although, I found the exhibits worth the price.
The building is very nice and has spectacular views of the city, the fountain is also another great photo opportunity.

Impressive building, stunning collection. A stop on the Bus Turistic Red Route we had pencilled in on the itinerary back in May. The stroll from the bus stop to the entrance is a treat in itself with views of Barcelona and down the Av Reina to Pl Espanya. The entrance is free for "jubilats" (Pensioners) and the young lady didn't even ask for I.D., just gave us tickets to a myriad of wonderful exhibits. We spent a few hours wandering the galleries full of art from the first century to the present day. The presentation in all areas was just first class and compares with any major museum we have seen.We took time out at the cafe for coffee and cake, very reasonable prices and good quality.This is certainly worth a return visit, you cannot take it all in on one pass! Loved it all.

One of the great collections in Europe. This museum was so rich in Gothic, Romantic, Renaissance and Modern art that we returned for a second day. The huge old castle has been masterfully remodeled so that the galleries are well-lighted, spacious and calm. Good signage, though not all in English. The best food offerings are outside on the terrace in front overlooking Barcelona. The coffee bar inside is OK but windowless, and the fancy restaurant is preposterously pompous and overpriced, though in a lovely room. The large collection of precious and rare paintings and altarpieces from ruined medieval churches of the Pyrenees, preserved and mounted here, are breath-taking and unique.

The view is worth the walk. The view from the museum is worth the visit. You see all of Barcelona. Ask for a family price / children 16 ^ under are free and students 8.50. The museum has some very interesting paintings and church artifacts. There are multiple exhibits, in a large space, so you feel like you've actually received value. #Even if you are not into church history and paintings, take the walk, the view is amazing and there is a bar at the top.

Don't miss!. We visited on the first Saturday of the month, so no entrance fee (yay!). It’s quite a large museum, and the displays were beautifully lit and presented. Makes for great pictures (no flash!). My favorites were the fresco section and the gothic art collection. The museum is easily accessible from Placa Espanya. Lots of elevators, so it’s no big deal to make it to the hill where the museum is. Pretty views from the MNAC terrace.
Breathtaking location and structure. Located on crest of Montjuic this museum is a beautiful building with key art. Investigate the 7 museum pass for 30 euros which can be purchased at any museum.
The site which I miss most. Great art collection located in an impressive building, accessible and well maintained, overlooking the breathtaking scenery with friendly and pleasant atmosphere

good representation of art of the region. They close early on Sundays, so we did not enjoy it to the fullest. However, the museum was well organized and represented well Catalonian artists (we learned a lot about the region). The palace itself can be accessed without a ticket and the restaurant served expensive but tasty buffet meal.
Beautiful location, amazing collection. An amazing collection of Spanish artists from the 10th C. To present day. The view of the city from the front steps is breathtaking.

We weren't planning on this. We were tired and thought we'd just breeze through (for teachers/faculty, public museums are free and we travel with our faculty ID's) but we were surprised and delighted by the space and collection. We love art so this was areal treat. The entire site is spectacular with amazing views, fountains, etc. definitely worth it

Great Views of Barcelona and art for free. It was a lovely day and the ascent from Placa Espagna up the hill to the monumental museum was fun, exercise and great views (if you do not like the exercise there are elevator stairs to the top - you just have to look for them, since they are a bit out of sight). See where the Sagrada Familia is located, and other outstanding buildings - very informative.And then the entrance was free (on a Saturday after 3 p.m.!). The collections are varied and worth seeing. The restaurant has a great view! (I just had a glass of wine since it was after lunch but he food seemed appetizing). I liked the exhibition of the extremely large painting of the battle between the Spanish and Moroccans by Fortuny, with all the history of the painting explained (and Dali made his homage to the painting). Art can be fun.

Give yourself a couple days!. One of the great joys of visiting Barcelona is learning more about the Catalan culture and language. Cataluyna suffered under Franco, so it is no surprise the Catalans would retaliate by building this spired cathedral to its art. What a building! And then there is the art. Your ticket is good for two visits--but that is not readily apparent, or at least was not to me. I highly recommend you visit two times. On one of them, make sure you are at the terrace overlooking the magic fountains on Placa d' Espanya at sunset for a drink. If you stay long enough on thursdays-Saturdays (check that), you'll be treated to the magic fountain display. Situated on top of Montjuic, the museum gives you one of the best views over Barcelona. Take the funicular as part of your metro pass up and down the mountain. There's also a cable car that swings over the Med and lands you in Barcelonetta, but the price was too high, I thought, and time too precious to move at a snail's pace down the mountain. Back to the art: It is extensive and can leave you shell-shocked if you do too much. One thing we particularly loved is the museum's extensive collection of painting lifted off the walls of old churches in the region (churches with little life expectancy). We were also interested to learn about the relationship between the Catalan and French Impressionists and their style differences. I heartily recommend joining one of the tours or getting an audio guide, because the place will overwhelm you. We joined many others for a snooze under the central dome! pace yourself, get oriented, and learn. And...don't miss the cafe, situated inside of an arena within the museum. breathtaking view, great food.

Museum with a view. What strikes you first is the walk up to the museum, for those not slightly interested in the last 1000 years of art, just the garden and the view of Barcelona is worth the trip there. The museum is very well laid out and opting for the information phone, a cost of 3.50 euro is worth it, otherwise you could find yourself wandering aimlessly along, particularly if you can't read Spanish, as not all is in English. For those with a passion or even a passing curiosity in art it is a great experience. All museums are free to the public on a Sunday, but you need to start early as they close at 3.30, which came as a shock, given Spain doesn't seem to get going until 3pm most days, not so in this instance, so set your alarm!

A must see. The location -Montjuic, the building and the collection are worth the visit, with works by Catalan artists from Medieval times to Modern. The medieval collection of fresco's is a must see for every art lover. The very good restaurant Oleum in the Throne room is also worth a visit.
Make sure you have enough time!. Definitely one of the sites worth visiting in Barcelona! Make sure you have plenty of time, as there is plenty to experience!
incredible collection of art. one of the most important museums in Barcelona, with an incredible collection of art, and the building is very niice

Wonderful gallery in exquisite setting. We visited on a Sunday afternoon when there was free entry (check in advance for times when this is the case) and were really impressed by the beautiful building. A range of different art, our favourites were the more modern ones, such as Vayreda. We then enjoyed walking around the gardens outside. Well worth a visit.
Ok. It's museum was ok, but isn't compare to the others that we saw (Joan miro, Picasso, etc). It is in a beautiful building, but the exhibits in the museum were not as good as we were hoping.

Delightful!. Everything about this museo is special. A fantastic location on Montjuic with views across BCN to Tibidalbo. Simply getting there is a treat, climbing the stairs, or taking the outside escalators. Not for the out-of-shape, but of course you can take a taxi. Once inside, the building and the collection are worth the visit, with works by Catalan artists from Medieval times to Modern. A world treasure.
Stunning. The building is as incredible as the art. Dali.. Picasso... Miro....A must see. The views are also amazing. The best gallery to see if you have to choose on a time frame.

Enjoyable. museum for art lovers, especially fantastic catalan art collection! Also the great view to the city - nice to have a walk outside to enjoy the city and absolutely obligatory for Barcelona visitors. It's located at famous Montjüc mountain.

Closed on Mondays. Fantastic views from here right across the city. Don't worry, you do not have to climb all the steps by the waterfalls, there are escalators to get you to the top.
Sadly, we visited on a Monday when it was closed!

Free entrance after 3 on Saturday. I'm glad we got entrance free as we were not so impressed with the exhibits although it seems we mainly saw the Catalan art which was fantastic and well worth preservation but one you've seen one you've pretty much seen them all! Views from the top of the hill once again really good through the mist and rain.
Superb. We spent a couple of hours in the museum. The Roman collection was amazing. A must see for any culture vulture.

Great museum but not for everyone. This is a terrific museum, beautifully laid out with a large range of exhibits across 1000 years. The highlights are definitely the Romanesque and Gothic sections, particularly the displays from the old churches, which are laid out as they would have been originally. The audio guide certainly helped with understanding it all, but this museum is really for those with a keen interest in art.

Interesting. Take the visit on Saturday from 3pm. It is free! Also on the first Sunday of each month. Go there by bus from placa Espanya. I visited the pictures and drawings galleries of Catalan artists. It was great. As in every large museum, it is impossible to see it all. The building is beautyfull and the views are nice. You may stay there untile the magic fountain show stsrts.
Amazing building and views. Viewed the collection from churches around Catalunya. The way they built structures to present these old church decorations was amazing.

Exhibits were bah. This museum looks truly spectacular from outside (and in) especially as it is situated atop a hill. you can get good views of the city from there. The museum itself was so so as I felt it focused too heavily on Christianity based pieces but this is probably a personal preference.

So interesting. This was a fabulous way to spend a few hours. Very striking building and the park around it was good to walk around. Museum is very good value (remember to use your discount tickets if you did the bus tour). Excellent museum.

A visit to this museum gives you more than just interesting art.. This museum has something to please everyone. The building is set on a hill giving spectacular views of the city before you enter. Built as a National Palace in 1929 it contains both majestic centre rooms and smaller rooms for most of the collections. My favourite collection was that of the Romanesque murals and scultures. They are stunningly displayed and the audio guide is more than helpful and interesting. Several works have been saved from destruction by housing them in this collection. What I loved was the fact that none of the art was behind glass or roped off. One can go up to each piece and see clearly the artistry in each brushstroke. This visit was a highlight of my stay in Barcelona.

Good art gallery, excellent Catalonian frescos. Excellent museum. Good selection of artworks from 12th century to contemporary all Catolonian artworks. Set in a nice building.Quiet so you can take your time and savour the art

The best museum in Barcelona.. The museum building is beatiful - you can enjoy it just looking its architecture.And the inside is even better! I visited with Barcelona card so I got it for "free".It takes a lot of time and walking to see everything - but it is totally worth it.I have never seen so many beatufiul arts, painting in sculpture in one place.In my opinion it is must see in Barcelona (if you are into art of course)

A gem of a museum.. It was a lovely way to spend a wet day. The museum building itself is a magnificent work of art and well worth the visit.By the way, seniors go in for free.There is no way one can see every thing, so we zoomed into the areas that interest us, like modern art. Hopefully we can come again for more visits. One huge painting I can remember was a battle scene which was very detailed.The architecture of the museum left quite an impression on me. I loved the beautiful decorative ceilings and pillars. Within the museum is a concert hall, which reminded me of a round skating rink, with a giant organ located at one side. I can imagine beautiful music within this acoustic hall. (I hope it is acoustic.) Outside at the entrance, one gets a splendid view of the city. In short, I would say that the museum building is truly worthy of the art within it, or perhaps it is the other way around, the art collection is worthy of the museum building protecting it.

So much to see in one place. The building is in a stunning setting with views across the city. There is so much to see in the surrounding area make it a day trip and go to the olypic parc, the magic fountain, botanical garden, cable car, etc Within the Nacional d'Art there are some wonderful things to see including the building itself.

Amazing building, amazing Art.. The large building is set on an expansive hill overlooking the magic fountain and the city. There are many enjoyable steps to get to the top from all of which you can enjoy the view, but of course you can go by car, taxi or bus and still get a magnificent view and see the building.There is a small fee to get inside, unless it is after 3pm, when it is free. The number of galleries seems to go on and if you wish to see them all, allocate a lot of time. We did not have enough free time to see it all so we will just have to go back.
a Must visit!. We loved it! I enjoyed every singe bit of the MNAC. starting the way up and ending the beautiful fountains in the evening. this is a MUST destination for everyone visiting Barcelona!

fabulous conservation of Romanic art. The museum is large but divided in different sections of Romanic, Gothic and Modernist art. The Romanic frescoes that were removed from their original locations are beautiful and the ambience feels religious as well. The audio guides are excellent.

Art art and more Art. The building houses four different areas covering several periods. I'm not the greatest art appreciators so some of it was A little bit too much. But worth a visit, especially for the view out the front

Very interesting museum. The museum is situated on Montjuic in a beautiful palace on a place with breathless view. Situated on Red route of city Sightseeing, the museum is also at 10 min walkig distance from "Pueblo Espanol".Catalan art from different forms - sculpture and painting to posters and engraving are here from the Roman Empire period to the Art Nouveau time.

Fantastic Building. Wonderful Museum, there were lots of artists I had never heard of, but I have to say well worth the entrance fee.
The building itself is absolutley magnificent, it was just as enjoyable looking at the architecture as well as the exhibits inside.
Views from outside were also tremendous, well worth a visit.

Great experience. I spent three hours exploring this superb museum and I was thoroughly impressed. Take your time, there's lots to see. The location and the views of Barcelona are spectacular too. Well worth it.
What a view!. Never actually entered the Museum, but we spent a few nights taking in the view from the steps... absolutley breathtaking! evening of music and water dancing was a great memory

Great value and great art.. We really like the layout of the building, the art they had on display and the way the staff didn't hover too close when you got up close to the exhibits. The cafe was a little over priced and a little lacking in choice.

Magnificent building. A good choice to come even on Sunday (see the BCN scene). Very beautiful bldg. its a cluster with Magic Fountain, BCN Arena n the BCN Art Museum on the mountain top. Metro right below.Even on sunday, there's an opened cafe for drinks at the museum front door. There's also stone benches where u can just sit down n enjoy the bird eye view of BCN.Behind the museum is the Olympic Ring w/ venues.

Worth a visit even if you don't pay for the exhibits. My daughter is an art history student, so MNAC was a must-visit for us. But to me, the best part was the incredible architecture of the building. Even if you don't pay to see the exhibits, checking out the building is a worthwhile adventure. The escalators to get you up the mountain are a bonus. The fountains outside are beautiful, and put on a great show each evening - check the schedule posted on the stairwells. According to my daughter, the art is good, although my favorite exhibit was the collection of coins and medals.
Great building so cultural. The whole area from placa d'espanya up to montjuic and including MNAC is fantastic. a definate must see and a lovely area to sit and look around and enjoy a coffee
Stunning Building. I'm not into art at all but this is worth visiting. The stunning building is just as good on the inside as it is the outside.

Ring and check they're open. Save your feet!. Climbed all the way up the flinkin hill for this one. It was shut. Workers holiday in Spain so my friend said. Who we had to text to find this out. They could have put it up on the door. Right underneath where it says they are open reduced hours for public holidays. They weren't. The world and his dog were waiting at the top of this hill for it to open. It was never going to open. Missed out on Sagrada Familia to do this one. Still annoyed. Wouldn't have minded if they'd just said why. I'm sure they have a laminator. Who doesn't like making a laminated sign?! I'd even have forgiven comic sans. So one review splodge as i saw not one painting. NOT ONE. Meh.

A great starting point for visiting Montjuic district.. Placed in Montjuic, the MNAC is one of the best museums in a city like Barcelona which is full of all sorts of museums.But if you want to enjoy the very best of art (antique and modern), there you will find great collections of paintings and interesting temporary exhibitions.Furthermore, you will enjoy an amazing view of Barcelona, with its Plaça d'Espanya and its Venetian-style columns..MNAC is also a good point of departure for visiting the district of Montjuic. Near the Mnac, there is another impressiive museum, the CaixaForum, the Fira of Barcelona, and if you like walking you can also reach on foot the upper part of Montjuic, where there is the Fundaciò Joan Mirò, and the Estadi Olimpic (the OLympic stadium) and much more.

Free after 3pm on Saturday. Loved this place. Great place to sit outside with a view of the City from the terrace as well. Entry seeed to be free after 3pm on Saturday whereas there was a charge before that. So go later ;--)

Stupendous Architecture and Art Collection. This is a must see! From the fountains and the steps leading up to this impressive building to the sheer beauty of the entryway and main areas this is beautiful. Not to mention the wonderful art collections contained within. Plan to stay at least 2 hours. Three great places to eat within - cafe style, and then a less casual and a more forma restaurant (on the 2ND FLOOR W/GREAT VIEWS!)

Beautiful Building. I love the building and the site. The museum itself was well done but limited and you can see the building without paying the museum entrance tickets. We did not get the audio so maybe I would have appreciated the collection if I had more information. Nice but not a must see.

Easy On Off stop. We spent 2-3 hours walking in and around the MNAC. Its on the hights over Barcelona and LOTS of great views. Easy walk to Cable Car and other attractions. Good Cafe / Public Park nearby.

Art to assert Catalan Identity. Let's be clear from the start - this gallery (or rather collection of galleries in one space) is not in the same league as the great national galleries if what you're looking for is a general collection of European Art - it has some gems, but if that's what you want then best aim for the Prado, the Louvre or Britain's National Gallery. But if you have an interest in art and particularly how a national sensibility can shape it then do not miss this place. It's collection of Catalan art - the clue is in the place's title! - is magnificent, wide ranging over the centuries, and we found it fascinating enough to take a whole day to do the visit justice.Just looking at the outside is impressive enough - built as a pavilion for an international exhibition it forms part of the complex on the city's dominating hill, Montjuic. Best approach via Placa D'espanya, when escalators (or steps if you're feeling energetic) will whisk you up past the flights of fountains to the front of the gallery and a magnificent view.Inside the place is divided historically: a "modern" section - up to 1920? - is Catalan dominated, but hence has interesting artists you won't have seen before; the Baroque and Gothic sections are obviously dominated by religious works but include some little-known gems; but for me the absolute 'do not miss this place' factor was the Romanesque galleries. Here work from early medieval churches - largely murals, though with a good collection of panels and 3D work - had been laboriously saved and removed from their original, decaying, sites to be displayed here - and wonderfully displayed they are. Mock church interiors have been built which display the works as they were in relation to viewers and each other, so arched paintings are displayed on arches and so on. The Museum is able to, and has, spared a huge amount of exhibition space to show off these works, its speciality - in wonderful settings. Even if you're not religious yourself it will give you some idea of what it must have felt like to be a worshipper in a medieval Catalan church - magnificent!And before you leave, make sure you have a coffee - or a beer - in the cafe in the great arena hall - spectacular!

The building and the views make the visit worth it!. I wasn't sure what to expect from the MNAC, but I was pleasantly surprised. The trip up to the top is spectacular! You can climb stairs all the way, or escalators are also offered for much of the way as well. The lovely and cool fountains add to the serenity and peacefulness of the area. There is a lot of walking involved either way, but we enjoyed it. The views of the surrounding area is amazing! You can see La Sagrada Familia as well as Tibidabo on the top of the mountains in the distance. Sitting on the steps while resting and gazing at the city was enjoyable for our family.Both the outside and the inside of the museum building are impressive. There are 4 wings to this museum with different art periods from Gothic to Romanesque to Modern. The art inside is nice and extensive, but after a while it kind of all blended together. We only spent an hour and a half with children, but one could easily spend the entire day. Children 16 and under are free and the museum is closed on Mondays. Enjoy!

Great Museum, Beautiful Location. On foot through massive columns in the square below, past many sites and up many steps sits this great museum that the kids also enjoyed.Get the audio guide, and if you only have a few hours, hit the "highlights". Get religion and art in a great setting. Bring a bag lunch and sit outside or behind the museum for some peace and quiet.Would highly recommend.

The building and views are spectacular. I was less wowed by the art inside but the building and the views were worth the trip. Gorgeous fountains and views of the city with a nice art collection but not too many pieces that were notable. Sitting on the steps, overlooking the city was beautiful.

A nice museum in a fantastic building. The museum is really nice and with many beautiful works of art to see. However what I enjoyed the most was the building itself, both from the inside and the outside.

Nice if you like Gothic and Baroque art !. Honestly not my cup of tea, but I have enjoyed the visit in this huge old palace, huge enough to avoid the crowd "feeling".The collection is mostly Gothic and Baroque, not the most exciting for my kids.The modern art part is quite nice and refreshing.Price is really reasonable, a good place for a break.Restaurant is available at the first floor and seems very quiet and relaxing (but I have not tested it !)Access is easy from the Plaza Catalunya, so you can enjoy the climbing next to the fountains, by stairs or escalators.
AMAZING!!. What a wonderful place.. stunning inside and out! Wonderful location and really magnificent building. Accessible from the Barcelona Bus Tours and well worth a visit.

A Pleasant Visit. While not quite up there with the two "biggies" of Madrid, the MNAC is a museum well worth a visit. I was impressed by the art that the museum has, the way it is displayed, and most of all by the building which houses the museum, which is in and of itself a work of art that must be seen from the inside. I surpassed my personal 2 hour "museum limit" because I was enjoying the visit as much as I did. In addition to the snack bar on the first floor, there is a very good looking restaurant on the second floor which has a beautiful panorama of Barcelona. I cannot comment on the food as I did not partake.It might be noted that I introduced myself to the cashier as a senior (over 65 years of age. Some places request proof and passport or drivers license [with picture] are generally accepted), and so there was no entrance fee.If you have children under 11 years of age, please do not bring them to the museum

very interesting across a road range. we liked all the artwork here but you need the audio to fully explain the artwork..particularly the Romanesque and Gothic artwork. We also liked the more moden artwork by artists who may not be that well known outside Catalonia but whose work was very interesting particularly Joacquim Mir

An astounding collection. Such beautiful works that have been preserved with such care and respect. We spent most of our time viewing the religious frescoes, which just took our breath away. The building itself is incredible and it is well worth the trip.

SCAM!!!. After checking online that museum works until 6p.m. daily we took the trouble of going there on after-Easter Monday. We arrived at 2:30 and spent some 30-40 euros for 2 on museum tickets and metro. Half an hour after entering the first exhibition we were told that museum was closing and were kicked out! None of the 5 ticketing people and several controllers said a word about museum closing in 30 minutes when we were buying the tickets!!!When we complained and demanded our money back we've been told that the money from the ticket sales are already gone somewhere and so were the 5 cashiers.Outrageous!!! If you want to have tourists you've got to respect them.

World class collection in some areas. Wow - greatest museum I have ever been to for Romanesque Art (c 1050-1200). The frescoes moved from churches elsewhere in Catalonia (spurred because the Boston Museum of Fine Arts bought an apse fresco at the turn of the 20th century and took it out of Spain) are splendid, spledidly conserved, and OUTSTANDINGLY displayed.The later stuff is good, too - but I'm a medievalist and I have my priorities.The admissions fee (12 euros in April 2013) gets you a TWO DAY ticket. I did sometimes wish the labeling was more generous - I'd take French. Catalan and Spanish are not quite enough.
disappointed. The exterior attracts the attention, views are amazing all around, but the exhibitions were poor, i am sure there are better museums in Barcelona, was disappointed :(Visited April 2013

Stunning!. As you approach this amazing museum, you walk by fountains of water shooting water vertically in columns. The closer you get, giant cascades of water fall below the museum. The museum has the most amazing collection of Catalonian art throughout the centuries. Every section of this museum will intrigue you.

Íts worth it for the views alone!. If you like art--go. If you just want a great view of the city and Plaça Espana then it is so worth it. Just make sure you take the escalators. It may not seem important at the beginning but even good walkers should avoid the steps. You can get off at each level and you can always walk down the steps!

A must for art lovers. Make sure you give yourself plenty of time to see the exhibitions. It will take some hours and you can catch a bite to eat there. Beautiful setting and views outside are breathtaking.

Review from the outside. If the art inside in the museum is like the exterior, don't pass it up. We did not have the time to visit the museum but enjoyed a break at the steps outside the museum where coffee is served and live street music is played. The view down to Place Espanya is out-of-this-world.

The building is worth the visit. The building is beautiful. Even if one is not a lover of 'art', to stand in the center of the rotunda and look up, it's hard not to be in awe of the artisans who designed and built such a beautiful space.

A must see!. I would allow about a day for this visit. We spent nearly 3 hours just doing the modern art section. Lovely lunch in the restaurant (free wi-fi) overlooking the city and fountains. About 50e for 3 plates of tapas and two glasses of wine.
beautiful. amazing location, spectacular, and the building is incredible. very romantic. views from the gallery are amazing

Enormous Collection of Art in a stunning building. The Art Gallery is massive, dominating the local landscape. Although it costs 10 Euros to enter at most times, it offers such a large range of art from across Southern Europe. The museum starts with paintings sourced from the walls of Catalonian churches and moves through religious icons to fairly modern artwork. The museum can easily take a few hours out of your day for those who move around Galleries quickly and can take even more time for those who prefer to absorb the atmosphere (or stand there looking closely at the paint strokes to see if the artist has hidden a message in there). I would certainly recommend visiting this gallery as part of trip to Montjuic but do bear in mind that this gallery will take at least a few hours to move round.

Historical Treasures. This museum was one of the best I have been to. The art collection was fabulous. Plan on spending at least half a day or more here to do it justice. It is in the Montjuic area of Barcelona.

A wonderful building with interesting art. If you like early-medieval (Romanesque) frescos at all, this is the place to see them -- they are amazing, some with astonishingly bright colors -- room after room of frescos rescued from old churches in Spain. We also enjoyed the twentieth-century art. And the building itself, especially the huge hall, is an interesting piece of monumental architecture. Just FYI, once one is up there in Montjuic (take the Metro), it's fun to wander around the park grounds (hilly!) and even grab coffee or a light lunch at the outdoor bar/cafe run by the Miramar, overlooking the city and the port. We decided not to take the air-cars up to the castle because we ran out of time, but that would be an alternative way to get the marvelous view.

Enjoyed the art-Avoid the restaurant behind the entrance!. We spent most of our time looking at the modern art, which is my favorite. It wasn't as much as I had hoped, but it was still good. Some fantastic early 20th century sculptures that I just stared and exclaimed over for a while. We popped into the Gothic/Ren. section, and if this is your thing, you will love it. It's not mine, though I took some interesting pictures of saintly gore. We mistook the restaurant behind the cafe (not taking the elevators to the European 1st floor) for the main restaurant and ordered the 3 course meal. This was the worst meal we've had since landing in Barcelona almost a week ago. The basic street food we got while waiting to check in on day one was better! Avoid this food! It is poorly reheated glop. It's a shame, as I have had some lovely food in other art museums.
Beauty Abounds. One of the best museums we have ever visited anywhere. The preserved frescoes and the efforts taken to move and place them in the Museum are worth the trip alone.

you just dont have enough time. the setting is magnificent, the walk up to the mnac is breathless with the fountains and the views of the city from the steps amazing.once inside you just havent the time to see it all, if you are an art lover you could seriously do three days here. the ticket gives you free entry on day 2, i stayed about 2 hours and looked at the gothic and romanesque areas but the museum is vast and i had other things to do

Good museum, nice location for views!. The romanesque part of the collection is by far the true masterpiece of the museum! Nicely set up collection with also gothic, renaissance and modern parts also!

Check out the Frescoes. My view of Picasso has radically changed since visiting the outstanding Romanesque frescoes at MNAC. The galleries have recently undergone a multi-million pound renovation and if you know the Demoiselle D'Avignon as the launch of modern art then look at the staring eyes in these frescoes and you will realise where Picasso got some of his inspiration from.

So much more than I expected!. I really only went because the building is so impressive from the outside, so I was pleasantly surprised by how impressive and well done the museum was. The Romanesque section has almost rebuilt Romanesque churches in the walls of the museum, and the modernist section, especially with its art nouveau furniture and paintings, was beautiful.

A Worthy Gathering of Collections, and More. My treat here was the Romanesque collection, more extensive than any I have seen elsewhere. But you'll want to see the other collections as well. Save time for it. The museum is huge. You'll probably need an entire afternoon. Save time for the area around the museum too; there are fountains, unique towers, an escalator between two levels of the park in which the museum is located. It is close to the Olympic Park, the Miro museum, and the former bullring now a shopping center. The museum's building itself is worth studying.
This is a must see. Very good museum well organized in such a nice building, it is up the hill and once you are there you can overview the entire espanya area.

Get the audio tour for a more complete experience. Let me start with the trip up (escalators are a potential avenue to take). It is worth it if all you do is get up the hill. The views are better that Park Guëlle and the crowds are slightly more manageable for you to get that shot you're looking for. Going in I utilized a Barcelona Card so I didn't pay admission and I skipped on the audio tour. If you're not confident in your abilities in Spanish or Catalán, get the audio. It drove me crazy bit knowing exactly what I was looking at. I explored the Romanesque and Gothic sections and they are laid out well and appropriately.

Good layout and facilities.. Highly reccomended to those who like historic religious art. However, there is a good range of all types of art in a functional building with great views and a good cafe. (We didn't try the resturant).

A fine gallery in a beutiful building. A great introduction to Catalan art and design. On Saturday afternoon after 15:00 free entry with the locals, great atmosphere as was the music outside waiting until 15:00!

Stairs, stairs, stairs.. Your ticket is good for 2 days. They don't have to be consecutive days. I look forward to going back tomorrow to finish the museum. I live in Riverside California USA and we don't have access to this fine art unless I drive 50 miles to Los Angeles.

beautiful at night. people will wonder hows its beautiful at night.... i have not been inside the museu, the surrounding is pictureisque and you can easily spend around 1 hour or so... too good for photography :)

Go When It Is Free On Saturdays After 15:00 (3:00 PM). The museum does a good job at demonstrating how Catalonian's participated in each of the major art movements over the last 1000 years.The museum is (currently) free on Saturdays after 15:00 (3:00 PM). We felt that one hour was about enough time for our visit. The building itself is interesting to see too, but I am glad we did not pay for admission.Note that there are hardly any seats or benches throughout the exhibits, so be prepared for a lot of uninterrupted standing.
Nice museum. Nice museum but take the audio tour as nothing is written in English next to the pieces on display. For a general walk thru you will need about 1 hour.
how did they do it?. Complete interior sections of churches are installed with their beautiful murals. They varied collection includes furniture by Gaude. Its quite an uphill walk so get the bus.

Lovely art. MNAC is a bit difficult to get to but once you're inside you can spend hours looking at all the art. I really liked seeing the paintings and some sculptures were interesting to look at. Unfortunately I'm not an art snob so the most I can say is that I liked the art.

Enjoyed the external architecture. We had our share of art exploration in museums of Madrid, so we decided to enjoy MNAC's external architecture. MNAC building looks like an extravagant palace, with a dome structure at the center. From this vantage point, you can see the Placa Espanya and the Twin Venetian towers down below. There is also the magical light fountain below this museum, though we missed it because the fountain show is only during weekends.

Great if you love art; great if you don't. The Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya (MNAC) is located at the top of a hill. It does have escalators as well as stairs but make sure you are ready for the walk to and up to it. You can get to it from Port Vell by using the cable car - although we loved the walk. It is free after 3pm on a Sunday.MNAC is a great place to go if you love all types of art - especially modern art. Alternatively, if you do not, then the building is definitely worth seeing up close.Behind the building is a number of arenas and museums concerning the 1992 Olympics, as well as the Olympic stadium and the Montjuic Communications Tower. Also, for art lovers, there is the Joan Miro museum.
Amazing. The MNAC is fantastic starting with the great columns just in front of it. After that you can see a beautiful fountain and than you see the Museum itself with great things inside.
building beautiful. great building, wanted to photograph it from every angle - then eventually entered it and had a similar experience of enthusiastic hunger for more.... go see it, well worth it.
Plan to give this museum enough time. Extensive collection of Roman and medieval pieces. Stunning paintings from the XIXth century. A must. Plan to spend at the very least 2 hours, and more like 3.
Excellent visit. Really worth a visit if you're an art lover. Loads of amazing pieces to see, and it's free! Building itself is also incredible.
Good spot if you love comtemporary art. I am more of a Monet, Renoir, Velasquez, etc. in other words it was OK, will not come back, instead I will visit Museo del Prado as many times is needed

Superb Collection in a Great Location and Building. There's a huge amount of early Catalan art here - the modern stuff is elsewhere. The building itself is impressive and offers great views over the city. Don't be put off by all the steps - there are escalators most of the way up (possibly the whole way; the one at the top is off to the left and I missed it.)Entry is free after 3 p.m. on Saturday.

Art interest. For traveler who know and interest about Catalan's art, this place is worth visit because there are many exhibition. One who does not really into art, I suggest not to pay for the enter ticket. You can enjoy the exterior of the Museum, it is Huge, locate on the high hills so we can see Barcelona's beautiful view from the top, and the design of the exterior is amazing!

Many Religious Scenes. If you are in to the preservation of art from the churches of Spain and just religious are in general, you will like this museum. It's divided into sections that very clearly state what period you will see. I enjoyed the museum and the beautiful view of the city. Wear comfortable walking shoes as you can walk the museum and the surrounding park. You can go on line and buy one ticket that cover entry for several museums. This is well worth it as you do not have to go on a special day and you don't have to wait in any lines.
Wonderful museum!. Absolutely stunning presentation of Catalan church frescoes. This gorgeous museum really highlights the wonders of all kinds of Catalan art.

Fantastic view of city. Just a stunning location. Having a cup of coffee while enjoying the birds eye view of the city while my little boy happily chased pigeons was an unforgettable experience. And that's before entering the museum!

Stunning from the outside. This Museum was closed when we visited, but it was enough for us that we got to see it from the outside. It is truly breathtaking. We sat outside and listened to a busker whilst enjoying a beer on a sunny day in Feb. Don't miss this place, it was absolutely gorgeous.

Amazing. This is a beautiful building set at the top of Montjuïc overlooking the city. All art enthusiasts should come to this attraction as it houses a vast amount of collections ranging from Romantic, Gothic, Renaissance, Baroque, and Modern. Whilst we were there, there was also a temporary exhibit showcasing the findings of uncovering art layer by layer to find false/fake prints compared to the real deal. This was very interesting seeing how technology how evolved today. However as a temporary exhibition, there weren't always English translations to everything.A large building where you can easily spend half the day. It also houses a restaurant and two cafes (which houses good cake!).Unfortunately, I must also state that you must be very careful with your belongings. As we entered the building, a lady had been taking photos of the spectacular view. On returning to the bench where her partner was also taking photos, she discovered her handbag had been taken and was nowhere to be seen. On visiting Barcelona, we were strongly made aware about pickpocketing and petty theft in the city, but on witnessing a lady losing all her possessions made it so more real.

very organised. i didnt have enough time to see it all, the museum is huge. very organised, security everywhere, because a lot of sculptures are not tucked away.after 7pm the fountains outside provide music/light show. definitely go and try to see it, if you are anywhere around placa de espania
Don't Miss this one!!!. So much to see, give yourself a day and a half to see it all, largest collect of Frescos I have ever seen...

Overlooked attraction. This museum has so much to offer and such a broad range of art from the very unique and huge collection of Romanesque art to Salvador Dali! Fantastic way to spend half a day. Beware agressive pigeons if u choose to snack at the cafe outside the museum

Could spend days here !. Wonderful location for this magnificent museum. Escalators on the approach up the hill make this a very accessible place .Excellent value .The numbers on the guide refer to specific exhibits , not to a room number , as we realised when exiting ! A short walk from here through the park to the Olympic Stadium with more wonderful views !

Collections are simply beautiful. When we were there, the museum had free entry from 3pm-6pm on Saturdays, which was more than enough time to see the Romanesque art that is the heart of the collection. The exhibit show pieces of extraordinary beauty and interest. We've been to many museums throughout Europe, Asia and the USA and saw pieces here unlike any we've seen elsewhere. There is an enormous amount of other material from Catalan artists from various other movements too. The building itself if a showpiece! The only downside is that most of the printed explanations for works are only in Spanish/Catalan, but there are audioguides in English (and other languages) for a few Euros more. The gallery attendants were also happy to explain in English as much as they could (they were often able to explain fully, and even when they couldn't their English was certainly better than my Catalan or Spanish!).
Excellent Museum. I am not really a huge fan of musems but this was brilliant and very interesting!I especially enjoyed the the collection of paintings by the Catalan artist Francesc Cambo

Miss This Museum At Your Peril !. The Catalan National Palace is not just an art gallery, it is also a demonstration of fine architecture and art design. The palace was built in the twentieth century and the interior spaces have been carefully redesigned to hang a unique collection of art encompassing all periods in the evolution of Catalunya. There are some surprises such as Carmen Bestian by Maria Fortuny and Georgina, Duchess of Devonshire by Thomas Gainsborough. There are a selection of photographs of the Spanish Civil War, which are startling. I was most taken with the Modern Art 2 gallery, which has one of the most compelling collections that I have seen and there is not an unmade bed to be seen anywhere. I returned for a second day to revise and etch the collections into my memory and to enjoy the myriad of masterful interiors again.

Frescoes!. We saw only the fresco exhibit. It's amazing. The museum was the only place we went in Barcelona that did not provide English translations for all the information, making it hard to get the most out of the visit.

an interesting museum. Conveniently located not far from Las Ramblas, we enjoyed the artwork in this contemporary building. It does not have the best collection of art you'll ever see, but what it does have still is remarkable and very well displayed. Easy to get to and worth a couple of hours.

magnificant views around. it is on the hill, accessible byt the tour bus too, or the public transport. haven't been iside due to the lack of time but it had great panoramic views of nearly the fird of Barcelona.

What a gorgeous building.. This museum is located on a hill in a beautiful palace.Make sure to take the time to climb the many, many stairs leading to it (or take the escalators if you're feeling lazy).The palace itself is absolutely gorgeous with huge halls and a great view.As for the exhibitions, well, that's for some to love and others not, but we rather enjoyed them as well.Don't miss a walk around the museum to explore some magical corners tucked away from the crowds.Highly recommended.
nice view. didnt go into the museum but the view of the city from the steps is great...sat outside with a cuppa ,enjoyong the view while listening to gaby sellanes on his guitar

Absolute Gem !! (and I'd never heard of it). Ask the taxi driver for MNAC! First of all , there's the location: in the Palau Nacional on the hill at Montjuic. There are fine views over Barcelona and the Palace itself, built for the 1929 World Exhibition, is stunning. Inside you find many, many unexpected gems even from periods you may not be particularly interested in. The vibrant colours (made from precious stones) of the 800-900 year old Gothic art are amazing: the Romanesque friezes carefully peeled off church walls are a technical tour-de-force: there is major artwork by artists like Velazquez and Titian as well as a Picasso that is better than most of the stuff in the Picasso Museum elsewhere in the city (he was a worryingly average artist most of the time!!). For us, and it is a question of what grabs you, the highlight was the breathtaking collection of 'modernista' (Art Nouveau to us) art and furniture - we have never, ever seen the like. You must go - and it's on the ArticketBCN, a 30 euro ticket that gives you access (without queuing!!) at 6 other museums, including the Picasso and the Miro, for less than half price. You've got to go !!!

Something for everyone. This is a huge museum, and after reading that is has a large collection of Romanesque art, I wasn't too excited since religious art doesn't interest me. I headed here anyway on a rainy day and it was definitely worth the visit. While there are large sections of Romanesque, Gothic and Baroque art, there is also a large section of Modernist art where I spent all my time. There were so many gorgeous pieces, and even a couple funny ones that used to decorate a wine cellar. I would allow about 2-3 hours to tackle the modernist section at a casual pace. The audioguide wasn't too useful and is not really necessary here. There is definitely something for everyone, and it's a great place to head to on a rainy day. Also keep in mind that Saturdays are free from 3 to 6pm.

Worth a visit. Interesting place if your an art lover. Lovely views over Barcelona, especially at night with all the lights on. Pretty building and great surroundings. Unfortunately, we visited in January so we didn't get to see the Font Magic (Magic Fountains) played to music and lights just below he gallery.

big museum and lots of painting. I m not a big fan of museum and painting in general.. so my review don't have a lot of value i guess. I have spend about 2 hours in there with my wife, it was interesting as an architectural visit. I did not find amaising painting or nothing big and famous in there.. but i like the place, it is beautifull and peacefull. they have an amaising terasse with spectacular view and good ice cream... Also in the back there is some kind of a concert hall build like roman arena. quiet interesting.

Very impressive. When we walked here from the Olympic Stadium, we noticed the impressive building and sweeping views of Barcelona at its doorsteps. The Magic Fountain was right below it. It has the following collections: Romanesque Art, Gothic Art, Renaissance and Baroque Art, and Modern and Contemporary Art.It was mind boggling as how they moved the paintings from the Romanesque churches of the Pyrenees.If you are into the history of Catalonia's currency, check out the Numismatics section.On the way to and from, we were accosted by would be criminals, as a couple of women were either giving us a carnation or asking us to sign a petition. They were aggressive, pulling on our jackets. Be very aware, as these women work as a team in trying to distract you.

too much for little. it is worth visiting so that you get to know more than picasso and miro, but 11 euros?????? I find it too expensive for what it is. I have seen much greater museums in europ for less entrance.
good place. Whoever is visitng barcelone must visit this place. beautiful architecture, awesome place, must visit

Nice for local musem. This museum is focused on Catalan artists. The building itself is impressive and the location is beautiful. I found the Picasso museum much more interesting if you have limited time.

Totally Satisfying Experience. This art museum is housed in a massive turn of the century exhibition Palace on a hill overlooking the city. There is a huge staircase leading to the main portico with fountains and gardens surrounding. Inside, the museum is divided largely according to periods. The Romanesque section contains Europe's most important collection of church frescoes displayed in church like rooms. There is a magnificent collection of Gothic paintings and sculpture, Baroque and 18th century paintings and a large collection of 19th century Spanish art, furniture and other artifacts. This museum contains masterpieces by an number of painters including El Greco, Rubens, Goya, Fragonard, Tiepolo, Picasso and Dali just to name a few. Barcelona's finest Art Museum and not to be missed.

Can see similar artwork in churches. The museum in itself is beautiful, both inside and outside. It can be nice to go there, look at the surroundings, enjoy the view, have a coffee and relax. A lot of the artwork dates back to the 10th to the 13th century and therefore the figures are simple, in 2D and sometimes the proportions of the human body are off. I found that a recurrent theme was catholic religion and I feel that I saw similar, if not more interesting, artwork in the Cathedral of Barcelona (Bari Gothic) and the church of Santa Maria del Mar (south of the Cathedral). If your time is limited, I would skip this museum and go to those churches and neighbourhoods instead.

Such a nice museum. I visited the musuem in August 2012 with my 10 year old daughter. So many exhibitions to see and a great view from outside the museum. We stopped at the museum, during our sightseeing tour with the hop-on hop off bus (which I highly recommend to get to know Barcelona). The museum is a treat and give you a good inside in Barcelona's cultural heritage. So nice that you are allowed to take pictures inside the museum, which we did a lot.

Nonpareil Romanesque frescoes/statuary. Amazing, they saved frescoes from chapels in remote Pyrenees, both just after WW I and later. One of the world's best collections of Romanesque (1000-1300) work.

Amazing especially in the evening. We didn;t go inside the building, but the building is stunning even from the outisde. You should definately try and see it during the magic fountain display. Amazing place to spend an evening ;). Getting up the musuem was also very easy as there are escolators.

Something for everybody. A huge museum with highlights of almost every time period in catalan art.No line to get in, nice surroundings, you can get lost in it wandering for hours and hours.Close to Plaça d'Espanya and the Magic Fountain.Good place to buy an ArticketBCN (since there's hardly any queue), if you want to visit other musea in Barcelona (and don't want to wait in the line there).

Amazing. One of the highlights of our visit. It's enormous and you can't hope to explore it all but the absolute must-see are the church frescos that have been gathered from numerous neglected churches in the Pyrenees and are shown here in all their glory.
A palace. Located atop Montjuic Mountain, facing nice fountains, close to Pueblo Espanol ( a group of old Spanish houses )holds a nice collection of both Catalunyan, Spanish and nedieval arts.

History of Catalonia. MNAC is a very good museum, slightly out of the way but very easy to get to if you buy one of the round-city bus passes (well worth doing). There are some truly interesting pieces here, well worth a look, you probably want to allocate about 2 hours if you want to see everything.

Stunning views of the city. Stopped off here on a bus tour. Sat outside listening to a local musician serenade us with his guitar. Sip a delicious hot chocolate whilst admiring the view. Amazing building with various exhibitions and restaurant with a set menu.

Feast Your Eyes. Really enjoyed the 100 Masterpieces and was intrigued by the free exhibition explaining how the staff examine, date and restore paintings, murals and sculptures. The staff were friendly and helpful. The whole area around MNAC has stunning views and again there were more places to explore than we had time.

Nice museum. The MNAC has a stunning exhibition of arts, we espesically enjoyed the Romanesque Art Collection with mural paintings from Romanesque churches of the Pyrenees. When you are visiting, make sure to visit the Oleum restaurant with the superb view of the exhibition area and the city.

Very impressive!. With the largest of collection of Romanesque art in the world, we found it was awesome. We purchased the audio tour for an extra 3 Euros and had the little device to educate us throughout the whole museum. Definitely a great experience

Well worth it. I had planned a quick walk through but two hours later I was only half way through. The internal design of the museum was very effective and the romanesque frescoes were definitely worth seeing. I liked not being overwhelmed by the art which happens to me in many of the major museums/galleries and a good introduction to Spanish artists. I felt I learned more than I had in Prato or other galleries. But it also does have some internationally important art - Fra Angelico is always one of my favourites. Lovely views over the city as it is on the hill next to the Olympic site.

Well worth a visit. This museum is housed in a gorgous palace which makes it worth walking up there alone! Inside there's a comprehensive collection of artworks which give a true flavour of the region. This museum is part of the deal if you buy the Barcelona Art Ticket.

Magnificent Building. The MNAC was a magnificent building in a fantastic location. Everywhere was immaculate. There were several school trips inside but it did not spoil it as the area was generally quiet in November. This was a very enjoyable few hours and it took only an extra 10 minutes walk to take us to the olympic stadium.
views from the MNAC are breathtaking. views from the MNAC are breathtaking. it is nice to go there to see the sunset. there's people playing music, and it makes the afternoon really nice

the most outstanding collection of Romanesque art --nothing like it anywhere. This is a gorgeous museum, the National Palace, the most incredible site --you can see the whole city and the view is magical. The museum is beautiful, and comfortable to tour--the Romanesque art is unequaled in quality--we went back two days to study it--if you like color, and pattern and exquisitely rendered frescos- you will not believe the quality and technical skill and how well preserved this work is. Cafe is very nice,great coffee, and little bites, and open all day=== and there is an exceptional restaurant there ---with the best view you could possibly imagine..The Museu is worth a visit or two or three. Get a Barcelona Art ticket--you can make repeat visits!
The view is better than the museum. Do not get me wrong it is beautiful but after visiting some other museum this one comes short in expositions. The museum per se is a work of art.

check out the solo Picasso -so worth it. There's a lot of walking to get around this impressive building, but so worth it. I had seen a huge amount of European art by the time I visited here, including the Picasso museum, in the gothic quarter. Yet it was at the National museum that I saw one of the most impressive picasso paintings - woman in a red hat-and I was mesmerised by it. There are many fine art works in this place, and I recommend you have lunch in the huge auditorium in the centre of the building - such a sense of space!
Modern Building downtown. it an impressive building in the heart of the city, they have different exhibitions that can you can check and visit
A must-see in Barcelona. An excellent example of Romanesque and Gothic art, in a privileged environment. If you love art you can not miss visiting this museum.

Superb art museum. Set aside a day to go through. Unique museum with items not seen elsewhere. Large sofas half way round for a rest. Great catalonian art works and many sculptures. It looks busier than it is as many people sit on the steps outside for the view.
IAAF Centenary Gala Show. I was there as a member of IAAF staff so in a way it was a grandiose birthday party - no time to do any sight seeing.

Extraordinary. Located on the famous Park Montjuic, the museum is beautiful and the expositions presented very interesting, we could see expositions from the Romanesque time, Barroque, Gothic, Modern art and even photography. We got a coupon when we bought a bus trip, so we had 20% discount; the bus is stopping by every 20 minutes so is easy access. There is no food available just a couple of stands that really not provide to much variety but if you want to have a snack maybe. It is one of the most to visit in my opinion if you go to Barcelona.
You have to see there.. You have to see there.I really enjoyed the daily journey,I leave Barcelona with a very good feeling.
Clean Place with Nice Assortment. After a long day of touring, it felt good to sit down in a clean, relatively quiet place and enjoy a glass of Spanish wine with some simple but tasty food offerings.

Beautiful building & great views, layout of exhibitions a bit confusing. The building is situated at a beautiful hill with BREATHTAKING views from the bar outside. The whole area is berautiful; I think we found it from the back as we came from Montjuic and the Olympic Stadium and went down the stairs through Magic fountain as we were leaving.Great art inside too.However, I think I did not get to see half of everything because the exhibitions were in different rooms (granted) but somehow the building didn't flow well and you can easily find yourself going in circles. Also, I don't particularly like the way things have been displayed rather sparsely. Although you known there are a lot of things to see, the museum doesn't feel very full.The paintings are very beautiful, but to be honest I enjoyed the architecture of the building and the scenery of Barcelona from the museum much more

Definitely must be visited. During my trip to Barcelona, I aslo visited this museum, which Catalans are proud of. It has too many sections. If you are interested in history, art, anthropology etc., you will need minimum 3-4 hours. For the entrance you have to pay a fee. Especially (in my opinion of course!) art of Catalunya in early Christian Era was interesting. Its location is very near to the metro station. Finally, it should be seen!

early close. We went to this muesum on a Sunday afternoon and we were not aware of the early close so we didn't really get to see the displays because we took time to eat lunch first. There is a first class resturant which was expenise, Good food but more that we had wanted to spend but our fault for not reading the menu correctly when we ordered.

Great Option for a rainy Barcelona day. I had not planned on spending a couple of hours inside - but a steady all-day rain meant coming-up-with a 'Plan B'. I'm glad I did - very interesting exhibits (of course, my degree was in Art History - so you might not have as much interest). Only reason I didn't give 5-stars was because I did get a little tired of all of the exhibits from the 1200-1400 era... even for me they began to get a tad monotonous. But, even if you don't go inside - definitely walk all around the grounds: fabulous views, and just a quick walk down to the Magic Fountain.

Well worth the time.. This is a beautiful building with many works worth seeing. It is easy to reach from the Espanya Metro station. Check at an information booth for the bus route number that you need. They change the numbers regularly so your tourist guide might not have the correct number.

massive!. We we running late after spending a long time at the Joan Miro Foundation so we only saw about 20% of the collection here..But that 20% was amazing! Absolutely lovely collection of paintings, sculptures, furniture ...Will definitely return in the future but will probably need to set aside 4 hours! The cafe outside has very comfy seats and great views!
Imposing building.... ... beautiful paintings and sculptures... You won't find many masterpieces, but it's warm art, and it's so pleasant to walk through it's corridors...

Big Museum on Montjuic. MNAC is a very large museum on Montjuic, just a short 10-15 minute bus ride from the very center of Barcelona. You would not go to the museum without visiting other venues on Montjuic such as the Joan Miro museum. MNAC has a very large collection of Romanesque and Gothic art as well as good examples of Renaissance and Baroque works by great masters. The modern collection is, not surprisingly, dominated by Spanish/Catalan painting and sculpture: Picasso, Miro, Gaudi, Dali, etc.

The building, site & view are fabulous. Perhaps we weren't in the right mood, although it was the right day to go - a little rainy/overcast. I liked that everything was Catalunya specific - put a new twist on art and style of Gothic, Baroque, Impressionist, Modernist. But we didn't find most of it that exciting. Maybe it should have been pouring rain. We used our discount coupons from the hop on hop off bus, so that saved us 20%. All but the most recent descriptions were in Spanish/Catalunyan, so perhaps it might have been more meaningful to have a guide. Yes, the building, site and view are fabulous, but we did see most of that from the hop on hop off bus.

Outstanding Romanesque art!. This is definitely worth a visit. Fantastic view of the city! Inside is displayed this wonderful and unique collection of Romanesque art from churches in villages in the Basque country. The art is expertly displayed. The museum is free to seniors, but would be worth an admission price! Cannot recommend it enough, even for a trip filled with churches and art! Do not miss it! Easy to get to on the hop on hop off bus.

This museum is huge. This is such a large museum that you need to spend hours to see everything. The building is beautiful and the location is awesome with a great view of Barcelona. We are not art experts but found the art collection quite interesting.
The view is worth the trip. I didn't make it into the museum but the exterior of the building is phenomenal. As are the views from it of the city.

Tricky museum to follow and not miss the attractions but worthwhile. Wonderful museum, with an incredible view of Barcelona. Many many famous sections to visit, rather hard to follow the rooms and areas and not miss the El Greco´s for example, so be careful and ask question, so you visit all the room. Unfortunately, all descriptions by the art are in Catalan, so pay for the ear phone hand held guides.

Beautiful location.. We did not have a lot of time to spend and see the whole thing. But what we saw was excellent. The most beautiful was the location. I could sit on the steps overlooking the city listening to live music for hours. When I say live music it was a street performer but he was good.

The building and the view are more impressive. The MNAC is located on top of Mont Juic, the hill which was the site for the 1992 Olympics. The building is beautiful and the views from the area surrounding it are lovely. The artworks are a bit disappointing, especially when compared to the art in the Prado in Madrid.
Nice Gallery. Enjoyed a visit here on a rainy day,few famous works, some Picasso and Dali. The restaurant there looks quite posh and pricey but great views.
A first class museum. A great collection of art covering a millenium in Catalonia. I especially enjoyed seeing the middle ages come vividly alive in front of your eyes.

Fantastic location, views and a building. Reserve some time.... This a place to go when in Barcelona. You have everything under one roof to fit every taste of art. Also the museum is a fantastic buidling to look at and shoot some breathtaking photos to and from Plaza de Espanya. Please note that there a plenty of steps to climb up and down inspite of the escalators.
An excellent museum. A very large museum with works of art encompassing the range of all of the fine museums. See it with an audioguide and allow 2-3 hours at least to do it justice.

picassos palace. truly eclectic art museum,a beautful building in its own right,a good 1/2 day out,velazquez to sisley to picasso to modern spanish artists all in long cool,well lit galleries with plenty of seating
Wonderful.. Several periods of art are displayed here and are well marked so one can easily get around. Well done and in a beauitiful, gorgeous venue.

A truly magnificent experience. Building stands on a hill, but amazingly there are escalators to take you up most of it from Plaza Espana. Art display is one of the best I have seen especially the frescos in the Romanesque section. Needs many days to do the lot!
Evening event in the Oval Hall. It´s an amazing location and we saw a music band and great air artists that evening. The cartering was fantastic and delicious!

Immerse yourself in this wonderful museum. What a find! Your ticket is good for two days within one month, so be sure to return if you can't view everything on your first visit. Although I loved the early galleries, the Modern gallery was most informative. Be sure to see the furniture from the Moderniste houses.

Don't miss it!. Just Beautiful.evertthing!Highly recommend you see it! The setting is magnificent overlooking Barcelona and spectacular architecture. We just visited the Modern art section which was huge and beautifully curated!
You can see many art pieces and view of the city.. You can see many art pieces and view of the city. I went there especially to see Dali's pictures. I liked everything there.

My idea of a perfect cultural magnet. Beautifully situated with a panoramic view over the city, world-class exhibits clearly laid out and labelled, helpful staff, terrace bar and restaurant - what more can I say?
wow. It is very big the museum. Needed 3 hours to see everything in it.Fantastic art paintings and statues.It's right near the magic fountain.very nice

Loved this museum!. Beautiful place in Montjuic Park-- saw the Gothic wing with an audio tour-- and really would not have gotten nearly enough out of the visit without the audio guide. Incredible gothic church frescos that had been rescued from churches damaged in the Spanish civil war. Unique and special--
Great gallery with amazing views of the city. Had a great morning here at the gallery away fom the busy city and also enjoyed the views over the city!

Wonderful facilities views and piano. You must visit the MNAC. It's on a perfect place, with wonderful views, the building is very charming and perfectly organized. Explore the free area, because there were not free exhibitions.
Very good street musicians as well. One of my memories is a snack that we ate at the stairs overlooking Plaça d'Espanya and listening to a fantastic street Guitarist.

Great Art!. Well worth the trip to see this museum! We learned so much about Catalunya and it's artists. Beautiful museum and displayed well. Get the head phones, for sure, as much signage is not in English.

Interesting. The building (Palau de Barcelona) in which MNAC is located is very beautiful. You can admire a lot of masterpieces starting with roman art and finishing with modern art. I disliked the fact that the names and wording about the masterpieces were written olny in Spanish and Catalan so I was a little puzzled because I speak only English, French and Romanian.

High level provider of beauty. Beginig with arhitecture and finish with exponates, everything is admirated. The museum revelated us the big interest of catalans in arts in all of kind, and from all times, from their country and others. A tresure of World!

Blown away. Had no expectations except to see the building the museum is in and the views. But getting inside changed that immediately- never ending supply of delicious brain food. The collections are amazing. Breathtaking. Don't miss the medieval Catalonian church murals. Like nothing I've ever seen. 1000 years of Catalonian art. It was my favorite thing in Barcelona

Good place to spend a rainy day. • Romanesque frescos worth seeing
• Interesting displays in all sections
• Well laid out displays
• Good audio guide
• Would get excellent views across the city on a clear day
• Café was fair value

Absolutely stunning.. First of all, the building, the crown jewel of the 1929 World's Fair, must be seen. And the art is wonderful, especially the frescos transferred from the walls of very old churches. The modern art section is also worthwhile-- who knew there were Spanish impressionists!

Modern Art in the MNAC, Barcelona. In this art museum, I went to see the Modern Art section. Appreciating landscapes as well as people painted by artists of various talents, I enjoyed the interpretation of nature in the almost silvery-violet light before a storm, detailed countryside rêveries, hungry beggars contrasted before the Church of the Sacred Family's construction beginnings, rich nobles painted in detail by painters commissioned to please, and still life paintings of situations in people's encounters either on the roads or in town. Spanish religious belief lies deep in some paintings, whereas social responsibility is in others, the refinement of culture being present in most displays. Of course, if one wants to see gold spread out in large quantities, one must see Gothic Art where the priesthood set itself out in its most glorious attire to admiration of the humble peasants and nobles it looked to conquer and impress in its early stages of development. This did not appeal to me, quelling the artists' eyes to the feelings they could describe through their brushes' passing and colours much more deeply than this superficial coating.In the modern art section,one can also enjoy sculptures of the utmost detail, a man riding a horse leaving you breathless before this synergy of understanding between the two, a billowing bow-tie ribbon on the delicate neck of a child, its expression caught as if by a modern-day camera, just to mention the two that will remain in my memory life-long. This museum has no lifts so plan good walking shoes and one or two bottles of water, as well as a sandwich for lunch. A small shop enables one to buy a few painting postcards, still life magnets, just in case your grandmother likes both culture and has a bad memory she wants to arouse on her fridge door.

Must see the Romanesque and Gothic parts. Allow a couple of hours for each. This is the best collection of Romanesque church interiors in the world and it is beautifully presented with and excellent audio guide. Got a decent cafe and a fancy restaurant, too and the view from the front across the city is spectacular. Take a Montjuic bus and get off at the closest stop so you don't have to climb all the way up from the Placa de Espanya.

Great collection of Gothic art. MNAC which is located in Montjuic makes for a good outing. The collection of Gothic art is impressive and the building itself is beautiful, especially the area near the music organ.
