In general the museum was not very crowded when we went and therefore more enjoyable to see.

Pricey. Lovely building. The collection is large, and we started with the Romanesque - there are many frescoes which have been removed from mountain village churches to protect them, and rebuilt within the museum. The colours are fantastic and the paintings fascinating - some frescoes are quite amusing. A video shows how the frescoes were removed and conserved and this does show in English. However, I would have liked more explanations of the actual pictures in English. What there is is in Catalan and Spanish, so not much use to most foreigners. The rest of the collection was not particularly special. At 10 EU we thought the entrance fee was a bit high. By the way, the kiosk outside was charging EU2.50 for a small bottle of water, so bring your own.
Lovely Terrace. Lovely terrace, terrific views. Pleasant coffee and Sangria. Lovely terrace, terrific views. Pleasant coffee and Sangria.

Religious painting and more. We happened to take refuge in the museum in a cold and rainy day. And what a surprise we took, the building itself is absolutely breathtaking. Many religious paintings and frescos on display. Also a modern art area is on the 2nd floor. Get ready to walk and be on your feed the museum does not offer many sitting options.

Freebie Sunday!. The museum is open until 2.30 on Sundays, and this one, being the first of the month was free.The collections we saw (medieval & modern) were fascinating, the building - and the view - are absolutely beautiful.
Rain and Art. Spent a very rainy day in the comfort of this museum. Lots to see and admire. A wide variety of exhibits - enough to meet everyone in our party's tastes.
Great views. We didn't tour the museum because we were pressed for time. We did stop and take several pictures. The museum provides great views of most of the city.

Not the Prada!. If you have the energy, this is worth it to see the building and the views of Barcelona. Not easy to access, uphill. If you have visited the Prada, I wouldn't put this on the top of your Barcelona list for viewing art. It is well exhibited.

Definitely worth the metro ride for the view and the art.. This museum is situated on a hill about a 15-minute walk from the Espanya metro stop. Once you get to the entrance of the museum, you see a beautiful panorama of the city and you can enjoy a drink while sitting outside. Inside, there are many pieces of art, but I wish the Modern art was as extensive as the other sections. Altogether, I would recommend this for anyone interested in art--you will see many beautiful pieces here.
Barcelona overviewed. The museum is wonderful. The evening sun-set from the museum and walking around and seeing the place and the surrounding Olympic village was all part of the experience.

A lot to see!. A typical very big museum with a lot to see. It is airconditioned so you can do it too. There are a lot of churchart pieces, nice ones. They also have shop with beautiful postcards of all the nice paintings that I liked.

Breath taking!. MNAC. ....wow. This place is huge and amazing. A place to see during the day and at night. Its quieter in the day, which is perfect for the art museum side of things. There's stunning architecture here, and most of it is free to see. Main cafes and restaurants are posh, but pricey, with a full 3 course meal and glass of wine costing over 60 euros and more. Outside snack bars are cheaper but with limited choice. At night, the place is visually stunning and busy with tourists. Outside the MNAC there is water fountain show with light and music. Worth seeing!The whole olympic park takes from half to a whole day to see, depending on how much detail you want to see and how fast you can walk. TIP: for eating, go to the lower levels of the Arena shopping centre instead. Its 2 mins from the Espanya metro stop; about 10 to 15 min walk from MNAC. Large choice of food there. Looks great at night too.
The best in Montjuic. After wasting in Museo Joan Miro, we went on to MNAC and really enjoyed it. It's huge, with exhibits of all eras. It's not crowded, what makes it even nicer.

Panoramic. The view from the Espanya metro on climbing up the stairs is phenomenal. It was the Merce 2012 festival so the police presence was high as there were more than 10000 people there at night. Gorgeous by day & phenomenal by night
Very Interesting. I would recommend around 3-4 Hours to do this attraction properly . Good to take a Guide if there is one available . Nice restaurants within walking distance of the Museum .

Surprisingly good. One wouldn't think of a good restaurant at a museum but this one was a nice surprise. The view was outstanding. Be sure to make a reservation in order to get a table by the window.There is no museum admission charge if you are just going to the restaurant.
Bus Tourista Red Route of the city. The exhibits were well laid out and very informative. The views over the city from the steps were more amazing than I had anticipated.
art!! and view!!. Just a must see! Remember Sunday opened till 14.30 and Monday closed. Plan carefully the trip to Montjuic.

Jewel of Catalunya. We are seniors and visited on a Saturday which gave us free admission (there is usually a fee). The museum is located above the Magic Fountain which could be a difficult walk up. We had a Metro pass and rode bus 193 to the top and walked down the many stairs afterwards. Before entering the museum, we sat out front with a picnic lunch and drank in the vista spread below us. The museum is a treasure trove of church frescoes uniquely transferred from the upper reaches of Catalunyan and Basque regions. Don't miss the videos explaining the process! This exhibit area displays an expansive collection of work.We visited several more well done exhibit areas. We were allowed to take photos as long as we used no flash. I asked for permission from the staff before doing so. Don't miss the auditorium area, a lovely architectural delight!We did not see everything because we ran out of energy before the museum ran out of exhibits!

Amazed. OK I like art history and I love classical art and impressionism. They are good enough to allow you readmission the following day on your ticket and I needed this. I was absolutely blown away, did not expect to find are of this quality away from one of the main capitals. I mustr have spent nearly a complete day of my holiday there

Worth a visit. A beautiful building on Montjuic, close to Placa Espanya and Poble Espanol. The interior has been transformed and is very light and modern with works of art by the great Masters, Picasso & Dali. The greatest collection of Church frescos in the world. Free to seniors and students.
A wonderful museum. Although we only had time for the Romanesque section, just the setting of this museum is worth the trip.

Magnificent. The building alone is worth the visit, and the coffee in the huge hall good. Church murals are so well displayed and the medieval painting too, we exhausted ourselves before reaching the more modern stuff. Good views over the 1929 Expo site of which it was a part.
Great Location. The location is wonderful and it's near the Magic Fountain. Great views of the city. It's worth the trip, but I wasn't overly impressed with the collection.

Great Catalan Art. I love museums and I love this museum. It´s a great place to visit because of it´s beautiful building and of course because it´s at Montjuic but the art is fantastic. Catalan art and history is great. You should definitely take a few hours there and even have lunch here to truly enjoy all the exhibits.

Hours were a bit confusing. the books all said that it was closed on Monday but it was open the Monday we were there. Take a guide book for the museum with you as most painting descriptions were only in Spanish--and the English pamphlets were 'out'.

Incredible Setting. Housed in the Palau Nacional, the building itself is part of the gallery, very grand and beutiful. Lovely collection, my favourite was the modern and contemporary art, although I think the museum is famous for the roman works it houses which are unlike anything I've seen in any other museum.
Very interesting. For a fairly cheap price there is a lot of awesome displays and information presented. It took a couple hours to go through the whole thing, but well worth the time!

A Paradise for Art Lovers. Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya is a stunning building with great, impressive artwork. We spent 4 hours in the museum. If you are over 65 it's free if you show your passport. The museums art work is set out to make it easy for the visitor. Plenty of sofas to have a rest and a lovely cafe. The views of Barcelona from the Museum are amazing.

Collection of international importance in a fabulous setting. The Romanesque frescos alone are worth visiting this gallery. These are displayed in reconstructions of the original interiors from which they were removed, and are truly stunning. The rest of the collection is equally impressive, with each section thematically laid out. The setting is equally impressive with stunning views across the city from the terrace.

Great art and fantastic food!. Don't forget to pop into the restaurant upstairs to marble over the views of the city. We ate the pumpkin gnocchi with fig sauce and they were so good, I can still taste it!
Pitty it was closed. Most of the museums are closed on mondays take note of this! The view from there is realy worth it. We would have loved to go to the museum but it was closed on a monday.

1000 Years of Art. The long, beautiful walk up to the museum from Plaza Espanya makes you look forward to something special - and it is really out of this world. Every inch of the museum is artistic, right from its painted dome to the musicians playing outside. Roman frescoes a thousand years old...coins from the time money was minted...and all the works of the artists from Catalonia - this museum is a rare and amazing treat for art lovers.
I love art galleries. and this one is definitely worth visiting. Restored frescos, architecture from demolished buildings, a great collection of art and the building itself... great
Worth a visit. The views from this building are very impressive. Single entry ticket is 10 euros and worth the price. Very varied art and cleverly displayed.

The outside is really the best part. The walk up to this amazing building is over 250 steps and worth taking each one if your health so obliges. Stopping at each landing to take a few snapshots will leave you with a beautiful collection and once you get to the top the view of the entire city is breathtaking. Hope you camera has a panoramic setting! The inside is like any art museum. I was partial to the dome in the center of the building and the auditorium....the artwork was nice too. :)

Star of Barcelona. Free entry for EU over 65s but not clearly labelled on entry fees.Auditorium[from 1929 expo] massive and not to be missed,with a huge and sadly neglected pipe organ.Art works varied and catalonian but little spectacular

Buy the articket!. The articket costs 30â¬ and is valid for 7 art museums and you don't need to stad in line.
Audioguide recommanded!

Should not be missed.. If you like art, painting, ancient history and of course architecture then this is a must see place. Easy to get to from anywhere in Barcelona. It was walking distance from our rented apartment in La Espanya.

Nice stroll through the museum. Interesting religious works; certainly a nice collection of Catalan art. Gorgeous views of Barcelona-- enjoy a beverage and snack from the outdoor snack carts, take in the view, and live in the moment!

Astonishing Romanesque Collection!. Friends told us about the early frescoes taken from churches in the northern part of Catalunya. They are just breathtaking. Beautifully presented. Also, we decided to have lunch in the restaurant at the museum. It was one of the best meals we had in Spain. A lovely table by the window, overlooking Barcelona. Great service. And the food was terrific. I had the most delicious steak. My family shared assorted tapas of shrimp, cheese, tomoato bread, olives, etc. All was great.

Best views of Barcelona. If you want the best views of Barcelona visit this museum. From the front steps you can see for miles. Walk around the gardens and find the Olympic stadium and diving pool statium behind the museum. to get there take the fenicular railway up from the Metro to the stadium its free and saves your legs, then walk through the park to the museum.

Amazing views of the city. Up here, you are at one of the highest points of the city. Views are spectacular. We went on a free day.It is a big museum, so you can get pretty tired especially when it is hot out. It is a nice place to visit and hang!
A must. The "secret" museum of Barcelona, with a wonderful collection relatively unknown. Spectacular views of the city from the entrance also of the magic fountains.

Good collection. Most interesting stuff is the oldest, particularly older church altar-pieces. (Have to admit, though, they have so many I OD'ed on them.) The modern art is also striking - very little of it being the avant-garde stuff that puts many of us off. The 'modernista' internal design and decorative arts are definitely worth a look.

It is a surprisingly wonderful collection!. Especially, concerning Spanish (Catalan) medieval arts! Flabbergasting! Jaume Huguet, Lluis Dalmau, Jaume Ferrer and Bartolomé Bermejo are among the greatest discoveries in my life. They have been somewhere in a dark corner of the depth of my mind overshadowed - perfectly unjustly - by the artists of the Low Countries and to a lesser degree of Italy. They are marvellous! As for Zurbaran, Ribera or Greco....they are the household names whose art is also amply represented here.And about the view, which - for some - seems overwhelmingly more relevant than the actual collection on the other side: it is undoubtedly a "bird's-eye view" and as such its only merit is the height! (Not counting the fact, that the gangs of the feverishly working pickpockets and robbers of the city are not visible from here! )

A amazing aerial view of barcelona. This is a must visit place while in barcelona. A nice museum but the the best part about this place is the breathtaking view you get from this place. Since this place is on a slight height and there are spots from where you can see a beautiful panoramic view of the beautiful city Barcelona. So if are visiting barcelona under no circumstances this place can be missed.
Overpriced. While the Museum of Art in New York is free (there's a recommended entrance fee) the MNAC isn't free, there's no recommended entrance fee and it isn't free for students either!!

Fantastic Art Collection. This is a wonderful building set high above the city with great views and an even better collection of art fro many different periods, beautifully curated.Not far from the Fundacion Miro so you can do both in a day and if you are walking they have thoughtfully provided escalators which help you get there and still be in a fit state to enjoy the art!
Unique!. If you wish to see something very unique and like art history it is a MUST! Gaudi works - good marketing only but this is a real diamond

Great place to relax and get some art. Fantastic building and views of Barcelona. Explore around the palace too. The collection is quite varied. At least when we went there were no crowds, so was brilliant to just unwind without fighting crowds.

Great free views. Sit on the steps in front of the MNAC in the shade and take in the wonderful views of Barcelona while listening to the buskers. It's a lovely place to chill out and is on some of the tour bus routes. We didn't go around the museum itself but did visit the lovely Oleum restaurant (book in advance for a window table) which allowed you to see some of the wonderful architecture inside the MNAC.

A beautiful buliding with good and variable exhibitions.. A good layout, and a fair aircondition in the hot summer. Can be crowded in the afternoon, plan an early visit. It can best ne rached from Placa Espanyia (Metro)
Once you get past the religious art. There are some interesting works once you get pass all the religious art. Take a break on the inside coffee shop.

Most excellent food and service with amazing views. Went here during a business trip, but would go back for social too. The restaurant food, service and views were amazing. I think you need to book and it can take a while in a taxi to get up this hill. If you are driving there is a carpark at the top of the hill. The atmosphere outside is so great too. People just chilling out and playing music, all enjoying the views. Go when light to see dusk.Didn't get to go into the museum, as we went just for dinner.

I fell in love!. I actually didn't go in so my comment in based on the outside and its surroundings. This place is beautiful. Just spend some time taking in how magnificent the museum is and people watching. There is so much happening in this location. The magic fountain is right there as well. I visited during the day and at night when it is lit up. Please put this on your agenda!

The best museum in town. This is an excellent museum, which we highly recommend. It has a huge collection of paintings of all periods. The first part is also the most beautiful: it is dedicated to Romanic and it boasts a great collection of medieval frescoes coming from small churches in the Pyrenees mountains, shown in a recent layout curated by Italian architect Gae Aulenti.Also very interesting the Gothic, Renaissance, Baroque and Modern art collections, with many Catalan artists, as well international renowed ones.

A must see. A wealth of artistic collections, incredible local Romanesque aand Gothic art. Paintings by Renaissance and Baroque masters and some fantastic modern art by Josep Llimona and Ramon Casas among others. The Gaudi collection however was relatively small, I think the Modernisme Museum was for this.A nice cafe was situated on the terrace and in the auditorium. I would use this over the restaurants as we felt the menu choice poor.

totaly art. It was one of the greatest museums not only for its great collection and its variety in exiblits but also its place its own architecture. Painting of El Greco, Diego Velasquez, Josep de Ribera, Romanesquew and Gothic art exibits, Peter Rubens, Ramon Casas, Gaudi exibits , Dali and Picaso paintings, numismatic, photograf and drawing collections.... and all that are only the soem of the stable exibits... DONT MISS IT FOR ALL

a history lesson in great scale. The Nacional Museum is a treasure onto itself in just the architecture of the building an gardens next door.The 2nd floor restaurant OLEUM is a must.The VIEW is fantastic and we suggest you make reservations well in advance.YOU'LL LOVE IT
Wonderful afternoon. This is a great place to spend an afternoon walking around, taking in the culture and appreciating the people of Barcelona.

Great place for an art lover. Visited this place as my 14 year daughter loves art. It has a superb collection of 1000 years of Roman, Gothic , baroque and modern catalan art. Roman art are preserved in an incredible way, which can be seen in a short film. Entrance fee is about 10 euro per person. Children enter free. Barcelona sightseen bus gives a voucher for 2 euro discount. Keen visitors can hire an audio guide which can be carried while exploring, for an aditional cost.Has a cafe at the site. Plenty of toilet facilities inside the MNAC.A must if you are an art lover.
Amazing. Full of the most amazing art from Catalan artists. You will see paintings from Baroque to modern surrealism. Very much worth a visit.
Nice. Very impressive, a lot of paintings, a lot of catalan, othodox and catholic artifacts, not properly signalized, not a cleat line of visit.

Best Romanesque art in the world. I've been all over and I've never seen anything like this. Spectacular display of Romanesque paintings removed from churches throughout the Pyrenees and reconstructed in the museum. Breathtakingly beautiful. Don't miss it.
Fair attraction to be in. Another barca museum, nice, at least from the outside. very pricy, If you are in the area, there are many other attractions to see.

I don't spend this much time in an art Musuem!. The MNAC as it is called in Barcelona was a very impressive museum. Touting 1000 years of art, it doesn't disappoint. You walked through every major movement of art but it is the frescos transferred from aging churches in Spain that captivated me.

Extremely boring. I suppose, if you like looking at old paintings of Jesus in a room then you might enjoy it. The only bit I found interesting was the small coin collection from 2000 years ago but otherwise it was very hot and very dull
Fantastic.. Stopped off here while we were doing a very enjoyable hop on hop off bus trip. Fabulous morning, some incredible art and sculptures, definitely worth a visit if you are into art.

Fascinating!. The main auditorium in this museum is amazing. We did ot pay to enter e building, however there were six galleries with exhibitions which had entry fees. However the building is worth a visit as it sits above Barcelona with excellent views. It also has enough in the free section to I've some idea of the history of Catalunya.

So worth it.... It's a lovely place to wander and the exhibits are somewhat different than most museums. The "Romanesque" wing has actual frescoes from Catalan churches that have been removed and reconstructed, with information on how it was done. I enjoyed cooling off there on a very warm day. The big 'plus' was discovering their excellent cafe by the deli area on lower level, with a nicely priced and very good 'menu del dia.'

The Museum is a real piece of art but its collections are not extraordinary. I was so impressed by the museum arhitecture, it is so impressive ! But I was not impressed by the collections of arts. However, I recommend to visit it to see the extraordinary arhitecture of the musem from inside. It is magic.

High point was lunch at Oleum. Imposing building but a bit light on content when compared to the great museums of Europe. It does not rate in the same league as the British Museum, Louvre, or Uffizi but is a pleasant way to spend a few hours. This was our fourth stop using the "Articket BCN" pass so it was essentially free.The lunch at Oleum - the onsite restaurant, was excellent - reviewed separatelyAfter the visit it was a picturesque walk down the grand staircase with some outdoor escalators to the city and connection to the subway system
beautifull. If you buy the Barcelona card, the entry of that Museu is free...so enjoy!It is a beautiful place even if, you are not found of arts (I am not and I really appreciate the visit)
You should join the tour. The tour explains the history and every detail of the hall guiding you through floors. You can even listen to pipe organ performance. Beautiful building.

Splendid Art. We spent 4 hours in here and could have spent more time as there is so much to see. A very nice coffee shop inside the gallery and you will need a break. All air conditioned so a good place to visit on a very hot day, remember it closes at 2.30pm on Sundays

stunning collection. Not only does this museum have an incredible location on a mountain overlooking the northern part of Barcelona, but it also has a phenomenal collection. The museum is reached from the Placa d' Espagna metro station and the height is aided with outdoor escalators! Perhaps the most impressive, is the manner in which barrel-vaults were constructed within the museum to display original frescoes removed from a church that was demolished in the Pyrennes of northern Spain. The museum is beautifully laid out. One can experience one time period in the history of art, at a time. There is a lovely outdoor cafe, and a restaurant with a balcony. How civilized is that?

beautiful setting especially at dusk with light and watershow. This is a must see in Barcelona even if only to sit outside at dusk. You can watch the sun set while a light and water-show provides entertainment. Sweeping vistas of the city and the MNAC entrance are breathtaking!

As good as any. Clean, cool, well laid out. English self tours. It was a good break from the hot day outside. We took about an hour looking into the exhibits. They have an express version, which I like, the 40 or so most popular attractions. Right next to Olympic stadium. Bus will come right here.

Excellent Collection, Cool Location. Museum is divided into wings holding Romanesque, Medieval & Renaissance, and Modern collections. I enjoyed all but found the Romanesque particularly interesting. It mostly consists of large murals from ancient churches. In order to avoid their theft or destruction, several institutions pooled resources to have the murals removed and reconstructed at MNAC, and apparently it's the largest collection of its kind in the world. Worth a visit just for that, but there is some great stuff in the other collections as well. Museum is on the Montjuic hilltop, so great views from the plaza and museum restaurant.

An awful lot of walking up stairs, even though there are escalators some of the way.. The view is GREAT, stop and look back frequently as you are making your way up. It shuts rather early so do it first thing in the day, as you want to spend time here once you've made the effort to get up to it. The artwork is wonderful, the cafe outside on the terrace is not too friendly though. If you have knee or hip problems, or sore feet, give this a miss, or get a taxi up there.
Huge and beautiful. Spend time here this place is very large,Many art collections to see also the views from the city are fantastic. the location is near the olimpic park.

Architecture of building!. Stunning building, particularly the central area. From the outside the views are incomparable, over Barcelona and should not be missed, even if you do not go inside. Coming from central Scotland where museum entrance remains free for the time being, the entrance fee did seem heavty, however the building itself is worth it. As for the exhibitions, I was not all that impressed, not really to my taste, but would visit again just to experience the building.Coffee in the cafe was VG, especially sitting in the central area.

Barcelona at its feet!. Beautiful building with wonderful art collections and the views of Barcelona from its terraces are stunning! Don't try to do in a day. Pick a theme (or maybe two) to do this justice.

Give yourself time!. It's an excellent Gallery, but we didn't have enough time to see it all, so we took in just the Gothic and the Modern sections for contrast, both very interesting and a nice mix of Paintings and sculpture. Free entertainment by an excellent guitarist busking outside as well, we went up on the tourist bus, but you can get there by escalators, that go up the mountainside, excellent but mad looking idea!

Plan most of the day for this one. I have made a mistake going in after 2 pm and just finished one hall, so came back the next day. this is not something you miss while you are in Barcelona. Audio guide was okay, but unfortunately not too descriptive. I would prefer more historical background of the art items described. Before going in ask for a pamphlet and read it through, although names are mentioned, only a few paintings are displayed here (Picasso, Dali, etc.). Still well worth a visit.

1000 years of Art!. Mind blowing and endless! Was much more history than I thought. Enjoyed a slide show explaining the processess used to remove murals from old castles and churches and recreate them in the museum. Do your homework though - we were looking for Picasso, but there was only one painting here. He is in another Museum! But would thouroughly recommend the MNAC to all interested in history and art!

amazing place. a very nice place for people who are interested in arts, but better to visit on weekends to be able to watch the incredible dancing fountain infront of it.. you can record videos for this colored dancing fountain, take pictures and have fun.. also there is some street restaurants there, but I did n't like any of them
Well worth a visit!. Great value- 2 Euros student price! And the views are incredible!

Really pleased that we made the trip.. Dont go on a Monday if you want to get in as it is closed. Despite initially going on a Monday it was worth it for the view alone. The museum itself is Grand with many galleries which were of interest but it is a cool place to pass a few hours and get out of the heat. from the central lobby area I took some stunning photos of the ceiling from the very comfortable sofas that just happen to be there for the comfort of tired tourists.Went to the cafe in the museum which was over priced and very tasteless served by surly member of staff who spent her time on the mobile while she was serving. Needless to say my tostada gave me heartburn. Your ticket lasts for 2 days so you dont need to overdose on the picture gallery. All in all I am glad that we visited the museum.

Nice Museum With Great Collection. I had a guided tour in this Museum. This Museum has a really nice collection of paintings and statues.The building itself is outstanding with very spacious rooms and great views.

Top place. Wonderfull view. We visited this place both day and night. We never got in the museum. Only went there for walking around the place, admire the view. Choose to go there Thursday, Friday or Saturday to also enjoy the founden show with music that lasts about an hour. Stay at the begging of the stairs to have a top seat.

Out of the heat!. The gallery is divided into 4 massive chambers - and of course fully airconditioned. We are not art lovers, but thoroughly enjoyed our 2 hour wander around the exhibits. The architecture is stunning. The laserlight water display starts at 10.30pm and only on 3 or 4 days per week.

I did not go into this but watched the fountain exhibition. About 9 every night a stunning display of water,light and music set to the ambiance of a truly spectacular building and promenade. Really is a must see and there is no charge

Don't bother. This is free with the BCN card and it still costs too much. Such a dissappointment. The best part was the grey vinyl sofa under the stairs where we rested, but even that was hot and lacking air flow.
Excellent views over the City. Missed the art gallery as it was closed but enjoyed taking in the view and looking around the area. Lovely palace from the outside.
Awesome Romanesque & Gothic. Enormous collection of really good medieval religious art, creatively presented. And the views from the terrace are amazing!

Excellent Art Museum. Unlike some of the museums in Barcelona that we visited, this one is well worthwhile. There is a terrific collection, most of which you will rarely, if ever see in art history books.

Spectacular Building, spectacular views!. Dominating the Barcelona hillside this building is well worth the trip up the hill to see the views from it down the main avenue to the Bull ring which has been converted into a shopping mall, as well as the general panorama of Barcelona. Interesting art is exhibited and the main hall is worth a walk around. Highly recommend the limon slush sold on the forecourt too whilst sitting watching the city below.

simply beautiful. the place was booked exclusively for us. A romantic ambience was created with dim colourful lighting and a violin playing orchestra. The view from MNAC was simply breathtaking. Wine, dining, music and chocolates for desserts ! A truly unforgetful experience !

Magnificent views and architecture. Didn't do the museum, no time. Still highly recommend the beautiful building, the grand plaza and the magnificent fountains at night. The entire Plaza Espana is a great architectural marvel. There is a large convention center here and if you are here for it then you are in the middle of it. Otherwise take the metro to Espana stop and when you come out you will see it. The fountains are turned on at night and they are beautiful. Beware of pick pockets though.
Fantastic museum with great collection. I had a guided tour in this museum. I suggest everyone to use such an opportunity. Very interesting collection and variety of art pieces.

Good collection, good treat for art lovers.. This place has a collection of very good paintings and statues. If you have visited Picasso museum or Prado Museum in Madrid, you may skip this place and you really have less or no interest in visiting art museums you may skip this place and head to Pablao Espanyol instead.

Extensive and varied collections, excellent value on days with free entry.. We went on the first Sunday of the month, and it was free! It's EUR10 otherwise, which in retrospect I think I would pay as even someone who is not really into art (like me) can easily spend half a day here.
What a collection!. The building itself is a palace, the views amazing from the outdoor cafe, and the art is sublime...

Nice to see but didn't change my life.. This museum is nice to see and has the most beautiful views. It cost seven euro to enter but this was a student rate and without the audio guide. In my opinion the audio guides are essential for this museum as without it I was a bit lost with the history of the paintings as the signs are either in Spanish or Catalan. Its quite big so wear comfortable shoes.

Great view from here of Barcelona!. We went here because it was a museum of modern art. It included quite a bit of older works as well, but it specialized in the modern art done by Spanish artists: Picasso, Gaudi and others. Very enjoyable!
Great Museum. Spacious, modern.. Loved this spacious modern museum, with fantastic views from the front cafe right outside.

Brilliant View of Barcelona. This museum is located at a height and offers a great panoramic view of the city. Although we did not enter the museum due to shortage of time, it is a nice location to sit down and relax in the evening. Also, the musical fountain that runs between 19 Hrs and 21 Hrs is a pleasure to watch

Loved it!. Loved it loved it loved it!
What a place stunning views, amazing art and a beautiful building.
Not too crowded either - a real gem

Get medieval. The museum website gives you a good sense of what they have. The regional Romanesque and Gothic collections are what set this museum apart from all others. And unlike places like the Prado and Uffizi which have just a few complete altarpieces, here you get dozens of them, often huge. The colorfulness and vigor of the Gothic is an eye-opener if you think of Gothic as severe and restrained. The Romanesque collection is distinguished by recreations of chapel interiors and stunning carvings. Give it time to soak in: these are not collections for zooming in, seeing a few greatest hits, and zooming back out. If you want a few high-impact paintings, your needs will be better met by the small but excellent collection on loan from the Thyssen-Bornemisza. More modern stuff is upstairs.Works have labels but only about 1/4 have further written explanation, in Catalan and Spanish. The explanations are smart but leave you wanting more. This is one place where I might consider the audioguides.The two cafes, one inside at the back and one out front, are expensive and disappointing even by the standards of museum cafes. I would pack lunch; the steps/plaza out front is an ideal picnic spot. There's also a cheaper cafe in the parking lot to the side.

Worth a look!. With so much to see in Barcelona, the contemporary museum is often overlooked. Its worth just taking in the contemporary style of the building which sits in the heart of one of the older parts of Barcelona.We really enjoyed the exhibits on display and the museum wasn't too crowded when we visited.

Excellent museum with amazing views. Not as crowded as we expected it to be. The escalators saved time (and possibly a heart attack) as we walked up from the Place D'Espana....we didn't know you get up there by bus! Worth the visit for the views alone...day or night.

Art and beautiful views!. The location of this museum is pretty awesome. From the front steps you get a beautiful view of plaza espana (and the light show at night is amazing). Nice collection, lovely building. I spent a very nice morning here.
What a building - worth it for that alone. Lots and lots of steps to access but a gorgeous space. Better art elsewhere in Spain, but worth a visit

Lovely way to spend a morning. The museum is quite large so wear comfy shoes. There was so much to see there that I was unable to see it all. They have several large wings and then several smaller areas to visit as well. The walk there from Placa d'Espagna was a nice walk with great views once you get to the top area where the museum is. I felt that that the price was reasonable and there was so much to see. I spent almost 4 hrs and had to walk away when I started feeling art fatigue.

Good Museum. This is a fun place to visit, beautiful building/museum building. The art is nothing like the Louvre or the Met in NY, but nice. It is mostly Spainish artists, and most of them paint religious pictures of the virgin Mary or Jesus, but there are a few other interesting pieces. I would say not to miss it if you are vacationing in BCN.
a good day out. Great views of the city, brilliant musician outside (even bought the CD) and a tremendous building. and that's before you look at the artwork.
Marvelous views. Grand building, grander collection and fantastic location. Provides a view of the city and the lighting at night is a thing to watch out for!
MNAC. Great place for curious art-lovers. Special days are for free.
Terrible staff. Loved the museum but the staff were awful, especially in the coffe shop and in the cafe at the front.
Amazing. Largest collection of Romanesque art in the world. They took apart churches and brought entire walls and altars back for display. It's spectacular.
To Barcelona from Shanghai. Nice collection, but was under our expectations. however after the visit, it worthy to stay at the main entry of the MNAC and have a rest with the best view of barcelona.

Best romanic and gothic peinture on wood. Including the best romanesque painted wood coming from X to XIV century mountain temples of Catalonia, MNAC offers you a whole picture of the history of the catalan art. Don't miss the absis of the pyrenees temples transfered in the 30's
Worth the visit. Interesting venue and refreshingly uncrowned standing above the city and away from the masses. A good collection and well maintained.
Great musuem!!. Great views from here and definitely a great mix of old, roman and new. You dont have to spend too much time here but definitely a good couple of hours worth.

Nice museum, but you have to like religious art. This museum was high on my list of things to do, as i love art museums specially the older art. This museum made some amazing conservation efforts to safe paintings on church walls dating back to the late Roman times 1100s, very impressive. Further more it has a vast collection with religious art (more than half of the museum space) of which most, but not all are from Spanish artists.For me the best part of the collection was the other half, a lot of Spanish artist, but only one Picasso, not his best painting.I liked the museum, it's collection and spent several hours there... Absolutely worth a visit.

Great!. Fantastic museum! The building and location itself was great. The altar pieces were amazing, and dating to over 1000 years old. One section was closed when we were there, which was disappointing, but still had a great time. Wear good walking shoes! There are places to sit along the way, but you'll still be on your feet a lot.
Neat. In one portion they had a church reconstructed partially in order to display the art. My only complaint is nothing was in English, so sometimes we were guessing as to what we were looking at.

Great medieval collection. Stylish museum with a great collection of medieval frescos and also lots of other classical art. Wonderful large airy building. Also a very nice restaurant with great views, we did however not eat tehre.
Vast. This is a majestic and very large museum. You need a long time here. We were very tired by the time we arrived and only viewed the modern art section. Allow a lot of time.

The highlight of Barcelona. From the large entrance patio there is a stunning view across Barcelona, but what's inside is even more stunning! The Romanesque frescos, rescued from churches in small villages in the Pyrenees, left me speechless. They are, without a doubt, a world class collection. And more than the Gaudi sites, the Picasso Museum, the Miro, and Montjuic, the highlight, for me, of Barcelona.
wonderful view from the top!. Visited 2007. What a great way to spend a lazy afternoon sitting on the grounds of the museum.Bring some snack and admire the view. Also close to a metro stop

Nice grounds. Beautiful grounds with a beautiful view of the city and the magic fountain. If you continue walking you will get to the Olympic Stadium. We went inside for just a few minutes as they were closing for the day so I can't really comment in the artwork,
westipswich. brilliant - we spent a good few hours there - the staff were very sensitive about us touching objects
Superb Collections of Art. The number of priceless art gems is overwhelming. While visiting the MNAC, go to the other attractions on the 'hill'.

Great collections, nice views from outside. Lovely place in Montjuic park, we got in for free with our Barcelona cards (metro pass) and had a good wander around. We didn't want to spend all day so looked at the temporary exhibition, the Gothic art section and the Modern section, but there was plenty more there.Lovely building too, and great views of the city from outside. Word of warning - take drinks with you if you don't want to be ripped off...we paid £2.50 for a single can of coke from the kiosk by the carpark - ouch!

Fantastic. Amazing building with great views over the city. Once inside the highlight for me were the works of art from derelict churches in the Pyrenees, so beautifully displayed. Excellent restaurant and a bonus for me - free entrance for Seniors!
unbelievable treasures. Do not skip anything! Both the permanent collection and the exhibit are fantastic!

Beautiful museum in a great area. Good view of the city from the top. Permanent collection consists of religious art typical to most Spanish museums with a few good pieces amidst the multitude. Some very good temporary exhibits come through so make sure to check out their website!
watershow. only in town for one night and went to the national museum of art in Spain and saw the watershow. hope this is the right place. Great show. 294.MP4 Barcelona watershow on youtube

Fabulous. We took the Hop on Hop Off bus which dropped us off at the Placa below the MNAC and walked up to the museum. The view from up there is great, we had lunch outside. Unfortunately we didn't have time to go through the museum as we ran out of time, but just wandering around the gardens was great.
Need to see. Excellent visit,good national collections will do it again

My favorite stop in Barcelona. This huge museum has a variety of excellent art collections, especially strong in early Christian and late modernisme art. I spend several hours here each time I visit Barcelona, and finish the day with a visit to the Caiza Forum art shows down the stairs and the "magic fountains" free twilight son&lumiere show near Placa de Espana.From the MNAC one can also walk to the Miro Museum or take the Montjuic bus (#193?) up to the Castell for even more spectacular views of the city and sea.
Great museum. The Romanesque artwork is some of the best I have ever seen.

A Pleasant Museum. Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya (MNAC) is sited on the Montjuïc hill in Barcelona, Spain. It was built for the 1929 International Exhibition of Barcelona as the main pavilion. It has been the National Art Gallery of Catalonia since 1934.Originally, the collection mainly focused on Catalan art and artists. After years of expansion, it now has a wide diversity of collections from Romanesque to modern art. The museum now has many collections including the ones below: ◎Romanesque art collection ◎Gothic art collection ◎Renaissance and Baroque art collection ◎Modern Art collection ◎Photography collection ◎Department of Drawings and Prints ◎Gabinet Numismàtic de Catalunya (Coinage)You can go there by riding subway L1 and L3 (Pl. Espanya) and walking about 1 mile. Due to the uphill incline and some steps, you need around 20 to 30 minutes to reach the museum. Once you are there, you can look down from the hill at the magnificent view of the city and the Magic Fountains of Montjuic. The architecture itself is a piece of art, and the sunset makes it even more attractive. You will need to allot many hours to enjoy the fine art inside the museum. The 17,200 sq-foot multifunction Oval Hall is a huge indoor space for social events. The daylight comes from the doom of the hall and makes it a very pleasant place to have all kinds of activities.

A FABULOUS MUSEUM. This museum showcases Catalonian art specifically. Located atop a hill, it is situated alongside one of the beautiful parks in Barcelona. The exhibits are magnificent, particularly the Romanesque in which frescoes from the Pyrnees are exquisitely displayed. There is also a video depicting the elaborate process of acquiring, cleaning, preserving and finally mounting these precious frescoes. Many other beautiful exhibit halls. A must for any visitor
the best. It is the best museum in Barcelona.Everybody should visit it.
didn't go in. I didn't go into this museum, but from the outside it's a beautiful building in a STUNNING location. Def a great photo opportunity.

Art collection. A chance to see art of Spain, you need plenty of time or more than one visit to truly appreciate it. Great views of the city too. We also came in the evening to see the fountains which were floodlit and timed to music. The food was a bit pricey if you chose separate items though there is a set meal deal.

Night time wonder. Didn't visit the interior however the night time light and fountain shows were amazing, so good we travelled again the following night to see them again. Can get crowded so get there early. Light shows from 9pm to 11 during summertime.
Awesome museum and views. The gothic section was amazing. Also, bring some snacks for a picnic on the front steps with a breathtaking view of Barcelona.

Catalan Romanesque Art. Although this museum houses art from other periods, its outstanding pieces are the Romanesque frescoes that it preserves from old Catalan village churches. A film shows how the original art has been lifted off crumbling ceilings and transferred onto replica ceilings within the museum. Absolutely amazing process.Well worth a visit! We walked up to it via the grand walkway from Placa d'Espanya.

There are better museums in Barcelona.... The exterior is absolutely wonderful and the views from there as well...We did not like the exhibitions though...there are better museums in Barcelona! They have a very stupid rule that you need to show your ticket at the entry of each PERMANENT exhibition...so really stick to your ticket. We also tried the restaurant, which was absolutely delicious (although the waiters are a bit up-tight...) All in all, if we did not have the Barcelona card, which granted free access, we would have been very sorry for the 10 eur entrance fee....
Great sanctuary on a rainy day. We spent a happy couple of hours wandering round the museum's vast collections. We particularly enjoyed the temporary exhibit 'International Gothic'.
beautiful designed. Just walking here was a joy, and a workout. Quit a few steps to the top. Lots of varity art renisance, picaso and more. Come back at night for light and water show.
must see. it is nice museum in great district on Monjuic with other nice places, that worth seing around

Wonderful Museum. Just the views from the Palace are worth a visit. On the hill of Montjuich (Mountain of the jews), it's an impressive palace overlooking Barcelona to the North, The romanesque frescoes are so beautiful that they take you back to the 12 and 13 centuries. Lots of history and iconic representations. Good learning!

Beautiful Architecture. We did not go inside the museum on our trip, but the views from outside are amazing. The architecture of this building is amazing. It also overlooks the Magical Fountain. If you are staying in the Barcelona city center, I would venture out a little west to see this location.

A symbol of the 1929 International Exhibition. The museum has a distinguished collection of Roman, Gothic, Renaissance & Modern Art, which pays homage to the region's architects & furniture makers as well as artists, but its the actual BUILDING itself - the Palau Nacionale - that is amazing!Restored since the 1929 International Exhibition its seriously impressive & you cant miss the thing really!There are about 100 steps that go to the actual front/doors of this building and when you get to the top, the view (on a nice sunny day!), is BREATHTAKING!!! There's a little area people can take photos.Don't miss the magic coloured fountains outside.MNAC is in Montjuic Park - a green space worth a separate day trip. The park is also home to the OLYMPIC Stadium, along with other sports facilities built for the 1992 Olympic Games. Well worth a walk around on a beautiful summers day.

What a pleasant suprise. I went here on a whim. I hadn't read anything about it before I went in and wow was I suprised. I had just been to the Prado and the Reina Sofia in Madrid, so I wasn't expecting much, but this place shoudl also be on your list if you enjoy art.. The Gothic Section was remarkable and certainly the highlight. The various Catholic Church remnants were beautifully preserved and amazing to sit and contemplate.

Museum Overload. Admittedly, I'm not really a museum person. But this museum seemed to go on and on, with little change from exhibit to exhibit. We paid for the audio tour which only served to add more information than you really wanted or needed to know. There were no works from anyone that you would really recognize - except Antoni Gaudi - unless you are well-versed in Catalan History

Light show on Fountains. Visited this massive art collection during the day just fabulous but requires plenty of time. Then returned to attend a free performance of music and light fantastia in front of the Palau Nacional. Parc de Montjuic. This occurs on Friday Saturday nights but check locally to get exact details. Definitely worth seeing

Fabulous art in a gorgeous palace. Very easy to access from Placa d'Espanya. Nice light, bright and large building to view the art so you don't feel hassled. I particulary loved the Romanesque and Gothic but it is all excellent. After your visit you can walk up to see the Olympic Stadium and Csaell de Montjuic.

Great collection, definitely worth the visit. MNAC is a huge collection and housed in a beautiful location towering over the Placa Espanya. There is some type of art for everyone, definitely a must-see in Barcelona.
Modernista art. There is a large range of genres in this gallery. Being time restricted we chose to view the modern art.

Very interesting collection. Particularly liked the section where murals had been lifted off old building walls and reinstated in the museum in exact reproductions of their original sites. Incredible!
The other exhibits were pretty good too, Tintoretto, Fragonard, Goya etc etc.

We didnt go in the actual gallery. However a walk around the grounds is a must see. The building it's self is fantasticly grand but the view is the best part. Standing at the top you can see right down to the Magic Fountain which was my favourite thing in the whole of Barcelona. Go in the daytime to admire the building but make sure you return after dark to view the musical show around the fountain.

Must see!!. Incredible!! Don't miss it. Nice views and lot of history and gothic originals you can't find any where else. Very imressive setting for the palace building. going and coming back is easy if you plan and take the funicular and visit other museums on the hill.

Stunning art museum!. MNAC has a stunning exhibit of 10th to 12th century wall paintings and frescoes rescued from small churches in Catalunya, and displayed on walls, ceilings and arches that replicate the original site. There's also a great exhibit of 19th and 20th century are by Catalunya artists. The site is spectacular, on the slope of Montjuic overlooking Placa de Espanya and the entire city. Sitting on the patio in front of the museum, sipping a Sangria and watching the late afternoon sun moving toward the horizon was a high point of our visit.

Nice on the outside, average on the inside. There are some quiet noce pieces of art in the museum but the collections are totally irrelevant because there is no bond within modern-byzantine art-and catalonian.Plus, the guy in the restaurant was rude!!!
WHAT A VIEW!!. if you want to see Barcelona in all its splendour you have to go to the MNAC. The Panoramic view of the city is Breathtaking. Well worth the visit, sitting and chilling out.

For lovers of Romanesque. This lovely museum has the most amazing collection of Romanesque frescoes rescued from ruined churches. Went straight from there to the Moderns - didn't make it round the whole museum. You'd need to dedicate a few hours to do it justice.

Amazing palace makes a good museum. The MNAC has an excellent collection of religious art, altarpieces and even scale rebuilding of church murals. It also contains original furniture by Gaudi and some unique Catalan works. No world renowned masterpieces but an excellent collection of paintings overall.

The foremost collection of Romanesque art in the world. To discover the heart and soul of the Catalan people, you must go to MNAC to see the fabulous Romanesque art that's been gathered from all over Catalunya to protect and preserve it. The installation is superb and the art itself glows with gilt and rich color. The works seem so contemporary yet they date from hundreds and hundreds of year ago. A must see collection.
Take a look.... For people interested in art and that want a beautiful view for Font Mágica in the enda of the day...

Must do. This is an incredibly beautiful museum. It is high up and besides having an impressive art collection, the view of Barcelona and the Mediterranean from the terrace is breathtaking. Like everywhere else in Barcelona, there is always some live music and the whole environment is just magical. I would not suggest taking kids to this museum and is quite a walk for anyone so be prepared with comfortable shoes. There are escalators on the way up and down but there are still some steps to be climbed.

Lucky I had a special evening view. Our conference dinner was held at the MNAC. Driving into the palace at dusk was simply breath-taking, the fountain was alive! Then of course the interior of this historic building was simply gorgeous. There are a large collection of Catalan artwork - most of which are catholic based. We all walked into the inner hall where the dinner was held with awe - magnificent and grand, it felt as if we should be in period costume and dancing the waltz...

Impressive building, nice location and a magnificent art collection. We loved this museum and only wished to have had more time to wander through its galleries. The exhibits are a great mix of gothic, baroque, renaissance, modern pieces of art. We very much appreciated the numismatic collection.The beautiful building of Palau Nacional and its interiors is definitely a must see in Barcelona if your time budget is over 3 nights.

Important and lovely site. The palace in which this museum is located deserves to be seen a a magnificent building. The central hall under the dome is breathtaking. And, the view from the steps is worth the trip. We only had time to see the gothic murals which are masterpieces almost lost from old churches, but were ingeniously rescued.

Great!. We almost didn't go to the Montjuic area and it is great! The excellent Museum of Art was in a beautiful building and has a lovely view of Barcelona.... we needed more time to explore the other museums, the 1992 Olympic area and MUCH MORE:) Have to go back.....
Great Visit. A Great collection of art. Could of spent two days in here but had to leave after 3 hours.

Spectacular. This is the most beautiful art building in the city with stunning veiws of the national fair and the city. The founteens are magnificent and the night spectical of the lights and water is must see.The art colection is Grande and very rich with 1400 years behind there is a lot to see. Make it a day trip to the Fonts de Monjuich and the museu. See and enjoy the beautiful gartend arown. It feels like Sun City in South Africa.
Nice Museum!. Nice building in modern style decorated with 3 levels. We were really impressed with local art and the view from museum look down to lake and park totally incredible.

An important gallery of international standard. Very well laid out, with separate sections for Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance and modern art works. The location is wonderful, in a high part with views over the city. Go on the 50 or 61 bus to save a climb to the top of the hill.
Good exercise!. Whilst we didn't go in the museum, we loved walking up to it and admiring the views. Well worth the climb.

The most comprehensive Presentation of Catalan Romanesque you will see anywhere. They never told us in school what a treasure of 10th-12th C material Catalonia has. This museum has it all and so very well displayed. I visit here every time I come to Barcelona. You have NO idea what a lively, colorful visual art expression. These people had. It's like the lively beautiful people who live in Catalunia today. Don't miss it

Outstanding museum, don't miss it. A stunning building with awesome views and a great collection. We could not understand why it was so uncrowded - everyone seemed to be over at the Miro museum. Rent an audiotour and have lunch at the fine dining restaurant ( a little pricey but absolutely worth it for the delicious food and setting)

Very good collection. We really enjoyed this museum, especially its high-quality collection of post-impressionist works. Located in beautiful montjuic park with great views of the city from its plaza.
An amazing collection. The Romanesque art is especially strong and unique. A real eye opener!

The Catalan Louvre. Holding a part of the Thyssen Bornemisza collection, the best assemblance of romanesque and gothic in all Europe and a huge selection of catalan pieces of all times, this museum always has something good to offer to visitors, and they let take pictures!
Cool!. It is a beautiful building but the collection is smaller and more confined to Spanish artists. The architecture alone is worth the trip.
Absolutely Beautiful!!!!. My only complaint was that we were not allowed to take photos inside to enoy after! Beautiful and worth a tour!
To visit in barcelona. Wait to see the magic fountain show at night.amazin avenue and colours
Great setting and views. Even if you are experiencing art museum fatigue don't pass on this one. The building and grounds are beautiful and the views magnificent.

Beautiful architecture, impressive collections. This imposing edifice in Montjuic houses an impressive collection of Renaissance and Impressionist works. Large enough to never feel crowded.If you purchase an Articket, it is easy to visit this museum and the Fundacio Joan Miro on the same day and cover a broad spectrum of artistic styles.

The walk on the way is better. I should really give this a 3.5 stars as the museum isn't that bad. But the walk to it is amazing - grand building and view from the underground station with discrete escalators. Suggest you plan to plan a half day at MANC and then wander to the Olympic park behind.
Amazing & impressive collection. Wonderful displays of Medieval wall painting and altars taken from Pyrenese churches; fabulous European collection - too much to see in one day.

excelent. Absolutely fab! I must get back. spent more time there. I went on 1st of April and it was first sunday of the month so I went in for free. I recommend reserving at least 5 hours to see it thoughout.

Beautiful place!. The palace is a work of art itself! We bought the 7 museum ticket so it was included. There were no lines or too much people so we enjoyed it a lot. We loved especially the first floor with the modern paintings and art works. Discovered new Spanish painters (new for us anyway) which we loved! Highly recommend it!

Fantastic frescoes. Saw a wealth of Spanish art, but the best was the collection of Romanesque frescoes removed from churches in the Pyrenees and installed in the museum to create the feel of being in the churches.

Astounding site!. You don't need to go in to get the full experience, though admission is cheap but it is a must see and be prepared to climb ALOT of stairs to reach the top. Save your $ for the Picasso Museum.

Building worth a trip in itself. Beautiful view of the city from the top of the stairs leading to the main entrance, and the collection of Catalan arts and roman period collection are worth the visit.
Must see. The view from the front of the museum looking down on the park and lake is absolutely amazing!!!

Great museum - better views of the city and port of Barcelona. This place is great.
Adjacent to the Olympic Stadium as well.
The Museum has some interesting displays.
The outside grounds have wonderful views of the city and the port of Barcelona.
It is a nice place to visit
great art.. very interesting, very big.seniors get in for free. the grounds are beautiful.

Beautifully located with a stunning panoramic view. This museum is in a beautiful location. From this vantage point there is a stunning view of Barcelona. It is also an easy walk from here to the Olympic Stadium. There is no fee to enter the museum. You pay only for the exhibitions you wish to see.

Catalan art. A wow place, lots of fabulous art on view. Bit shocked when they announced the museum to close in 15 mins, an hour after we arrived. This was a mistake, but no announcement to say so. Fantastic views of the city, especially from the restaurant.
Beautiful palatial building!. Beautiful palace style building with great running fountains. Plus the Magic Fountain is right in front of it!
Modern art not modern:1800 - 1940!!. Modern art not modern:1800 - 1940. Not worth the trip and entry if you like anything Modern.

Music to be enjoyed. You can only visit here if you join one of their tours. We wanted to see the place so much that we joined the tour in the Catalan language. It was well worth doing so. A beautiful concert hall and building. Not to be missed.

Brilliant. The Museum was full of art relevant to Barcelona and the region over time. From Miro and Dali to religious art to Gaudi, all were represented here. It had alot to see in it but there were places to have a seat and rest a moment and take in the beauty of what you were looking at. The views from the front of the museum were breath taking although be prepared for a walk from the metro station uphill (there is escalators!)
Outstanding museum. We enjoyed the wonderful views from this museum and the amazing art. We spent a good four hours in the museum, well worth it!

A brilliant collection. The building itself is impressive, but step inside to see some wonderful pieces of Romanesque art. Some of the murals have been painstakingly lifted from decaying churches in the Catalonian countryside, and then reassembled and fitted into the arches and hallways of the MNAC. I recommend that you schedule three-quarters of a day to do justice to your visit.

Nice building... Poor PR. The museum is in a very modern and nice building and the exposition is displayed on three levels. The only thing is that all explanations, signs, etc., are in catalan only. If you don't know Catalan, half of the information will never reach you.

Good museum with showing different eras in history. A big part of the museum is about the local art in different eras in history. I thought it would be more about modern culture. However a lot of nice things to see. I liked the visit!

Worth visiting for the views alone. Beautiful building in a stunning location on the hill overlooking Barcelona. We only visited the modern art gallery, of which No.2 was particularly worth visiting, with its impressionists and later artists and some furniture by Gaudi and one of his gates that matches those at Guell Park.

Wonderful Art in a stunning building. My friends and I wanted to visit this Museu as, both times I've been to Barcelona before, it has always had amazing art exhibitions. The building, itself, is wonderful and, if you approach it from the bottom, on Placa de Espana then you get to walk up the wonderful avenue towards it. We had enough time to visit 2 of the exhibition rooms and they were filled with some of the most amazing works of art we've ever seen. Also at the Placa there is the Bull Ring which is also worthy of a visit.

Hilltop palace and museum? What more do you need?. Imagine beauty on top of beauty. This is a really good art museum on top of a hill overlooking a beautiful city. The views are spectacular and the museum itself is wonderful. I wish we had more time but after we were done with taking in the views, we had little time to really explore the museum. We got here on the hop-on-hop-off bus so we were time pressured and it is a bit of a hike to get here via mass transit. If you have time to go up to Montjuic, include this along with the gardens.

The presentations will astound you!. This was great and it was free Dmission for senior citizens! (however it would have been well worth the admission fee!). I wanted to skip the early rt and go directly to modern but was out voted and glad that I was! The frescos were amazing. The best presentation of work that I have seen. They built naves and windows and arches replicating the original structures and placed the frescos as they were done originally. The colors were so vivid it is difficult to imagine how they could be this well preserved. We tend to associate Barcelona with Gaudi, Picasso and Dali but the early eras have incredible stories to share with the visitor. Gift shop is good, restaurant pricey and slow but small cafeteria snack shop available too. You should allow at least 4 hours to see the exhibits.

Interesting museum with great views!. Though we took the subway, the museum is walkable from the AC Hotel Sants -- which we discovered only after taking the subway! Just taking the escalators up the hill and enjoying the magnificient view of the city is worth the journey. The museum exhibits are a bit confusing as the plan bore little resemblance to the actual layout. However, the entire visit is worthwhile if one only sees the 12C-13C frescoes.

The building and views is worth the visit alone.. Start at the bottom and walk up - yes walk, but there are escalators as well. The building looks amazing from the park at the bottom. The whole place is kept clean and all greenery was well looked after. As you go up - turn and see the city grow before you, look to your right and Sagrada Familia is visable.I was there around 4 o'clock - the sky was clear and the place was busy, but the outisde space is worth the trip alone. I found the building itself as inspiring as the art inside. Too be honest - it's no Rennie Sofia (which is in Madrid) but the place inside is cool and well air conditioned. The biggest thing I take away is the outisde space - I love Spanish outside spaces - only go in if you are generally interested in Modern Art.

Great old art. The ramanesque art is superb and fairly unique outside of Italy so it should be high on your list. The gothic stuff is good, and even though you can see it in the churches nearby, it is easier to access and generally better preserved here. The modern art has a few good pieces (including a temporary Picasso room with borrowed items), but it is not a strength of this museum. The views of the city are awesome in the front of the building and in the upscale restaurant on the second floor.

Good museum to see Catalunya artists. Had limited time so I was rushed to go through the entire museum. Photography policy was inconsistent. Some part of the museum, you are allowed and others are not allowed.If you are to pay double price of their one time entrance fee, it allows you to have unlimited visits through the entire year. However, for most tourists, that is not viable option.
modern art and stuff. All about modern art, nothing out of the ordinary. The building itself is quite 'normal', the art OK.

Wonderful Art Museum high atop Montjuïc. Very nice collection of art. Buy the 6 museum ARTicket to save money and avoid the line. Spend a whole day on Montjuïc and time your depature to see the colored fountains.

Fabulous experience. Amazing museum with an abundance of art throughout. There was a lot to see and in such a beautiful setting complete with domes, architectual details and most of all a setting high on top of Barcelona.
Fantastic. Fantastic buillding high on the hill and on bus tour route

A must whilst visiting Barcelona. Great building. Wide variety of art. The Romanesque section is particularly impressive, we really liked the way the church frescoes were displayed as well as the paintings. The Modern Art section was also very well worth a visit. The cafe is good for a snack & drink. Helpful staff.
Great value and fantastic views. MNAC was a great stop on the hop on hop off bus and the view of the city from the tip were fantastic

Nice museum with large number of collection!. You can spent few euros to see a large collections of display related to cultures and arts of Catalan.
Nice one!
a great treat. It is a wonderful museum with a great view of the city as well

lots of collection, the place for paintings-lovers. The outside was terrific! the building is like a castle. Climbing up is worthy (look for the elevator! it might be slightly hidden on the side of the building). Great view of BCN. The ticket is valid for 2days, so it's def worth it! take your time to stroll as it is a huge place! I didn't have time to finish the whole place. Bring student card if you have, 30% discount (7euro instead of 10).

The outside is almost as interesting as the inside art. We enjoyed our visit here. The art spans a great amount of time. We enjoyed sitting on the front stairs listening to a guitar muscian as well. The view also cannot be beat!

I like the building itself. For me the building was the most amazing in this Museum, and the location as well (Monjtuic is so nice). The exhibits were mostly not my type of things, but i think it worth to visit.

Magestic views. set in one of the nicest parts of barcelona this museum rises like a pheonix,with spectacular views across all barcelona reaching out to the ports and beyond.beautifull grounds with fountains and waterfalls and no walking down steep banks as there are several escalaters strategically placed.You can get dropped off outside the museum on the many open top bus tours which pass her every 10 minutes.The museum is everything you would expect, set out beautifully and very informative.well worth a visit.
Amazing. Loved the structure and had great view of the city, speacially during night with all lights in the background.
Very educational. The beautiful paintings here will be a high point in anyones life, art lover or not. Spans the history of Spain. and Europe. All the greats are here. Breath taking.

Treasures but no English translation. This museum is full of treasure to discover. If you buy a general ticket it's valid for two days alone. However you will definitely need the voice guide or you have to know Spanish very well. All of the showcases explanation are in Spanish. However, paying 3.5 Euro for the voice guide can lead you a full spiritual experience. Definitely go there again.There is a restaurant in upper floor. Make sure you visit there for a lunch or dinner!

romanesque.. If you see nothing else here, see the romanesque collection, a stunning display space designed by Gae Aulente, and a collection of early masterpieces in a format you have never seen before....
a palace opens as an art museum. the collection of paintings, images, and especially sculptures - is overwhelming; the setting and the displays fantastic - Bravo
Very nice. The exposition has been made very nice, the building itself is beautiful. Tickets are for 10€.
fantastic bulging and view of cty. free entry to building but entry fee to each gallery
Metropolitan Museum. O.K., this museum reminded me in many ways of the Met, to really take in all of it would reuire 2-3 days, non-stop.
fun. stop here if you take the hop on / hop off bus tours
Palace on a Hill. We visited MNAC as part of the city tour bus. Some great pieces of art housed in a building which is well the visit in it's own right. Great view of Barcelona also.

So much to love. I've studied art history and never had a great love for Romanesque or Gothic art... all that has changed now. I've never seen such a spectacular collection. But, equally, Renaissance, Baroque and Modern periods as well. If you buy the super moneysaving Articket BCN (http://www.articketbcn.org/en/infogral), this museum is included and you can visit it TWICE on the card... recommended! if you are a real art lover. The building itself is spectacular, great gift shop, beautiful and delicious restaurant Oleum on the first floor overlooking Barcelona.

Great collection of artwork. My husband and I purchased the art-ticket, which includes admission into seven art museums. If you love modern art, it is a good value. If you do not, I'd say its better to skip it.This was our favorite of the museums on the art-ticket by far!It is large and has a wide variety of artwork but all is top quality. There are many wonderful sculptures as well, simply beautiful. They have a lot of murals from temples and churches from the 14th-15th century and statues as well. Some very interesting stuff!The view from the building is also incredible. You can even see Sagrada Familia! During winter the magic fountain is closed.
Interesting display of church wall art. Allow time to go through the whole musuem. Get a discount booklet of things to see and do in Barcelona, available at hotels.

Massive gallery.. Beautiful gallery in a fantastic location. The view over Barcelona is fabulous, while the gallery is located next to the Olympic Stadium. The gallery itself houses fantastic pieces of art and it was free to enter while we were there. Not sure about charges during the summer months.
Very unique. This is well worth a visit. Well travelled art lovers will find the art in this building truly unique and well worth a couple of hours visit at least.

Great building, interesting art and seniors get in free!. This is a great space; make sure you have a coffee at the end of your visit.The artwork is interesting, but we liked the building best.And Seniors get in free
fantastic museum. Not to be missed by anyone with an interest in art and history. The Romanesque and Gothic galleries are spectacular -- and vast.

Displays were very interesting..... The displays and historical information housed here are worth a visit. To learn a little of Spanish history while in Spain is important - try this museum, it was perfect.

Gorgeous views, lovely historical building. Loved the architecture and the views especially at sunset. It's atop a small hill so be prepared to walk up flights of stairs. There is only one set of escalators, and most of it is stone steps.
Modern Arts and Iconic City View. Modern art and the place where you can view the entire Barcelona from the top.

One of the best views of the city. The other great view of the city is from the restaurant of the Museu Nacional d'Art de Catlunya. The art itself is mediocre, and to me, a little dated (especially compared to the Madrid Art Galleries). However, the one thing to die for is the view from the restaurant overlooking the city. Eating lunch may be one of the best purchases in life!
Highlight. Good museum and worth a 1/2 day. Save your feet for other sites as well

...and the art wasn't bad too. A balmy afternoon, a sunny bench from which to watch the whole city pass by, one (or several) glasses of cava to make the time float past effortlessly as the buskers serenade you. Lovely

A fascinating art collection in an impressive building. This is one of those art galleries like the National in London, Louvre in Paris and Prado in Madrid that are an essential part of any visit to the city. Most styles of art, apart from contemporary, are represented and you need a whole day to do it justice. And not only is the art well displayed, but some of the rooms are quite spectacular. Well worth the relatively modest entrance fee.

Something for everyone. We went early in the morning, but by the time we left around 1 it was wall-to-wall people. If you go on a Sunday and are a "pensioner" admission is free and the audio tour equipment is .3 Euros instead of 3 Euros. The exhibitions are well worth the trip up the stairs but you can get a taxi, or take the furnicular. There is also a couple of cafes outside the museum where lots and lots of people sit around and enjoy the view to downtown Barcelona.
good museum. worth noting that disabled people/helper are granted free admission on production of documentation

Wait for the Prado.... This museum was just okay. There are a few artworks of the masters here but overall, most of the artwork are not from artists which most people would be familiar. There are so many other things to do in Barcelona that my recommendation would be to skip the MNAC and head to Madrid for the Prado. It's incredible.

Very romantic!. We did not go inside the museum, but we watched the sunset from its foot steps with an amazing view of the city and a great guitar player in the background. Very beautiful place to visit and enjoy the outside garden and amazing views.

Use your Barcelona card and escalators. Great view from the top of the museum. A lot of stairs to walk up or you can use escalators. If you already have a Barcelona card, the booklet includes a voucher to visit the museum for free. A great collection of paintings and sculptures!

Great museum. We were pleasantly surprised by our visit to MNAC. Great timeline of art - from Romanesque to the present. We did not get the audio guide - just wanted to cruise through at a reasonable pace in order to see it all. Loved the 20th century art the best, but great to see Spanish art going back centuries. I would have loved to see more information about how they came to the decisions to removed the frescos from the small churches around Spain - who made this decision, how did the villages feel about it. What has happened to these churches. Perhaps it was too controversial! If you use the hop on hop off bus then ask at your hotel for a discount packet.
Gorgeous building!. Allow yourself PLENTY of time - so much to see here. We got a museum pass and made the most of it.
Museum on Montjuic. Good museum to go if you like art history. I found it a bit boring. You can get there by Metro from Montjuic or Espanya station.
