reserve yourself 2 day. to see it all; tickets are valid for 2 days so you have a chance to see it all; the place is huge! it looks even better from the inside.
For me important was that the gift shop was offering nice gadgets so I finally found some nice (and not looking cheap and ugly) sovenirs for my family and friends.
Lots of religion.. also more modern art and a very interesting visit.

Check times.... The museum is amazing and has a wide colection of art from different perdiods. Note that on Sundays it is only open til 2 and it is closed on Mondays... Also, it takes a lot of time and walking... but it's worth it. I recomend also to take the explanation headphones, otherwise it's just walking around...

Must See in Barcelona!!. The museum is located in Montjuic and in addition to having an impressive art collection, the views of the city are spectacular. It also has an outdoor terrace with good coffee and pastries.

HUGE!!!. This has got to be the best art gallery I have ever been in - absolutely loads of art to see - our ticket lasted for 2 days and to be honest, you probably need 2 days to see everything properly. Unfortunately it was our last day so we rushed round to see as much as possible and were a bit 'arted out' by the end - but that was our fault for not taking more time to see such wonderful works of art.

Comprehensive museum. If you're interested in Catalunya at all - this is a great place to see where it all fits in to the big picture. Highlights include the Catalan Romanesque (with entire apses in the museum) and Catalan Modernism (Gaudi's contemporaries). Definitely plan a few hours for a visit, and remember there are escalators to get up there from Placa Espanya, so don't let yourself be discouraged from a visit by the hill!

Extraordinary Romanesque frescoes. There is quite a trek up a steep hill to arrive at the Museum, but once there, there was a great deal to see including the world's greatest collection of romanesque and early medieval frescoes from churches all over Spain.
ART. Spent part of Sunday here and it was not busy. Lots of different zones but some of the films were just too long and entrance into the film zones was very poorly lit.
Words can't describe. They covered part of the exterior since our first visit there, but this is the most beautiful building I've ever been inside.
An amazing collection of religious art. We went on a Friday. It was pretty much empty and it was lovely to have it all to ourselves and you get a great view of Barcelona from the front.
Worth a look. Loved this. Even if you don't pay to see the exhibitions just go insde and take a look.

Outstanding, and large, collections - gird your loins and enjoy!. We were awestruck at the scale and size of the collections and really only looked at the Romanesque and Modern collections. The former is very well displayed if a bit overpowering in the sense of the quantity of high quality stuff on display. Much of what you see is church wall paintings painstaking removed from their original locations in order to better conserve and study them - they are wonderfully displayed in reproductions of their original settings.The 'Modern' collection seems to start in the 16th Century! However we persisted and were surprised at the number of (unknown to me, but then I am a scientist not an art historian) Catalan players in the late 19th/early 20th Century movements (Impressionism, Cubism, Pointillisme, etc.).The whole place is devoted to Catalan art and was a treat. As were the views over the city from the terrace - next time we will get there for lunch in one of the most spectacularly situated restaurants in the city.BTW, we went on the Articket (a great saving if you are going to visit a few of Barcelona's classic sites).
Wow!. Spacious, comfortable, and good value. Particularly enjoyed the exhibition of "lost" photographs from the Spanish Civil War.
Do not miss.. I only had opportunity to see the exterior of the building and surrounding area.

Location and view tower over the art!. The location and view from the MNAC make it worth the visit, we stayed close by so were frequent visitors to the site although only entering the MNAC once. The building is beautiful and most of the best photos will be of the inside decoration rather than the art on display. Romanesque and Gothic sections sap the life, although I am sure they will appeal to some. The modern art section was by far the most interesting, but maybe because we knew a few of the artists on show. Beware that although photography is allowed, it is not permitted in the Picasso area! Also worth going on the Turistic bus to get 20% discount here.
Special exhibition on the Mexicana maletta. Very emotional exhibition on pictures from the civil war. I visited this exhibtion with some friends who had known the Franco period: very emotional

A palace setting for early Romanesque frescos. The Museu Nacional d’ Art is housed in the expansive Palau Nacional built in 1929. It is high on a hill and I approached it after visiting Montjuic Castle. It is downhill from the castle but still a 15 minute walk. The building is massive. The ticket cost is 8.50 euros but good for two days. I took advantage of both days. The primary focus here are on the 12th century frescos. Although they are mostly two dimensional and often (at least to me) the figures look almost identical, I try to place myself as a villager staring at these religious piece of art that were meant to be used as instructional. Some people have compared this museum to the Cloisters in New York. But that is a very long stretch. Make sure you walk into the massive central hall with its pipe organ. You can take non-flash photos of anything in the museum. To exit, I walked down a combination of escalators and many many many steps to the Placa d Espanya where there is a metro. The building and the outside terraces are filled with tourists and I even came across a wedding party taking advantage of the photographic views.

A massive museum set at the crest of a hill, in a gorgeous park.. The physical plant of the museum is massive, and there are interesting collections within the museum, but the building itself, built for an exposition in the late 20's, is a great piece of architectural kitsch.
The location is the best part. The surrounding fountain and parks are the best part. But the actual museu is just so so for a average art follower.
Worth a visit.. Great art work, and the view is fantastic. (Don't buy drinks outside, they are half the price inside).

Fabulous museum. Some great paintings by Catalan artists such as Maria Fortuny. My favorite part was the Modern/Baroque part. The Roman art was not very exciting. The building itself is also worth exploring, and it's location on top of the Montjuic offers some great views of Barcelona. Your ticket is valid for TWO visits within one month. I went on November 11th, so I have untill December 11th to visit a second time. Keep in mind that there are no backpacks allowed in the museum. Audioguides were €1 extra, I didn't bother to get one. The only thing is was missing throughout the museum were benches! I love to sit for a while, to study a painting in more detail.

If you care about Romanesque art, don't miss this!. Amazing, world class--no, unique!--collection of Romanesque church frescoes collected from churches in the Catalan Pyrenees. Beautifully, thoughtfully displayed. Went to a special exhibit of Moderniste jewelry last year and it was excellent.

Too much to see in one go.... This is really 7 art museums in one, we managed just two which took two hours. Had we stayed in Barcelona longer, we probably would have visited at least once more. From the MNAC we walked up the hill to the Olympic Park, then caught the funicular down towards the harbour area finishing on the Rambla de Mar which made for a very pleasant mornings exercise.
Beautiful Views Inside and Out!. Definitely worth the time to visit this site. The art work is great and stunning views from the outside of the building.
outstanding. Well worth the visit just to see the displays of Romanesque Art-brillant!
Wow!!. You have to visit this at night time! It is lit up and looks fantastic, with amazing views over Barcelona. Please visit!!!
Sonar de Día. A lot of new music, new artist, strange and nice people, interesting architecture

Enjoy the sunny day. go to Placa espanya and walk to MNAc, you can visit museum - entrance 8 eur, at the top there is snack bar and bus turistic station. From there you can walk to bothanical gardens, olympic site and a bit further you reach Miro museum. Nice , relaxed and not so crowded area like center

MNAC. Spectacular views above Plaza de Espana
Very extensive collection of Arte Romanico, taken from churches throughout Spain.

ok, take this review with a glass of cava. actually, my wife and i, arrived at the top step of the museum at 6:50, not knowing that the museum closes at 7. actually, it was still very light out and i had no idea it was almost 7. anyway, i have never been to a museum where there were so many steps. there were more steps than the museum that Rocky traversed in the first rocky movie. the good thing is that the first set of steep steps can be skipped by taking the escalater up. well, once we got to the top we were greeted with a spectacular view of barcelona. there is a huge landing with outdoor tables and chairs and benches to soak in that view. since the museum was closing, we decided to stay and order a couple of glasses of cava and sit at one of the tables and soak up the view. a couple of glasses turned into a whole lot of glasses. still light out when we arrived, we left after dark, all the while sitting at the table and sipping glass after glass of cava. what a great place. it was cool out, but i would not recommend this in the heat since i didn't really notice a whole lot of umbrellas, but there were a few to sit under, i believe. i'm sure the inside of the museum would have been nice too if you're into that sort of thing.

A Great Storehouse of Art. Every time I go to Barcelona, I have to see the MNAC because I love art, and this museum is filled with beautiful art. First there is Romanesque art with the largest collection in Europe. Many of the murals are not perfect, with many pieces missing, but of course they were painted hundreds of years ago and suffered much destruction with time. Still they are fascinating.Then there is the medieval art of the Gothic age. There are beautiful sculptures from that time and many retables with colorful figures. All of the art in this museum has been restored to the best level possible and the Gothic collection is really superb.Then we can see the great masters of the Renaissance and Baroque ages. I love the El Greco paintings, the serious ones of Zurbaran, and the wonderful ones of Velazquez. Each had his own style, but they all painted in Spain and each left his own mark in the art history.The Modernist collection interests me more now because I am getting acquainted with it only now. There are pieces of furniture, paintings, stained glass and sculpture that is world class. There is plenty of Guaid furniture. Gaudi really amazes me because he was an artistic genius, highly original. I enjoy the bookstore because I have found wonderful art books there, more than in most museums. This museum is really one I admire and enjoy.

Execellent- a revelation.. Spent the whole day here, with excellent lunch at restaurant with the best view possible of Barcelona. Exhibits particularly well shown and curated, especially the Romanesque, Gothic and Renaissance galleries. Highlight oof our trip to Barcelona

Unique collection of Murals from Spanish churches.. The Romanesque collection was amazing - 11 and 12th century murals from inside churches all around Spain were transferred to canvas then to the museum walls in the 1920's. Fascinating.

Glad we decided to visit. We weren't sure if we were going to have time to visit the Museu but we are very glad we did. The Roman art that they have recovered and reconstructed in the museum is simply amazing. You are left in awe of some of the old art constructed as it was found. The other collections of artwork and sculptures are wonderful as well.

Ancient art to modern art.. There is a free bag check at the entrance since you can't take bags in to museums in Barcelona. Also, the employees speak English, Spanish, and Catalon. This is a great museum because not only does it have beautiful art pieces, they also have signs for each art piece in all three languages. The food on the first floor is great too, just expensive. There are also beautiful gardens and other museums right next door. Spend the morning looking at the museum and then take pictures in the park and explore.

History and Art comes together under this roof. Top of the hill looking down at the fountain from the entrance, this amazing site is full of delicious beauty and delectable history. I wish I had more time to spend in this glorious monument.

If you love art history.... We decided to visit the National Art Museum of Catalonia after the Magic Fountain show. The building looked very impressive and we wanted to explore the treasures hidden inside. Frankly speaking, it was a bit disappointing. We roamed about four halls housing Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance and Baroque art collections with audio guides but the info sounded dry – pure facts and numbers. The way the expositions look is worth praising but the number of objects seemed limited to me, probably after Rome and Florence. Yet, the coffee shop and souvenirs were good!

I you have a day to loose. I would not rate this as top attraction for me, but for art lovers is a must or if you have at least half a day to kill, you must go and see it. I went for the Romanesc, Gothic and Baroque tours - and, at least in the Romanesc side I got tired of all the religious paintings and stuff, but in complete fairness I have seen them a lot in my life, so I wasn't that impressed. What I was impressed about, was the way they knew how to promote it to tourists. For that I have to give them a 10 or A+. Lots of art pieces some of them, magnificent and stunning. I state it once more, for art lovers, artist etc. is a must, for everybody else don't miss it if you have some spare time.
A museum not to be missed. You'll need some time to view all the different galleries. Renaissance and Baroque, Romanesque and Gothic. Various other changing exhibits. Very well done and easy to view.
Loved the museum. Lots and lots to see-something for everyone's taste. Good collection and well-presented. The best museum in Barcelona in my opinion.

most displays don't have english description. it's really a big museum with lots of interesting pieces to see. one problem though is that most of the displays only have spanish and catalan description, so if you don't know those language, you won't understand a thing.

Very Nice Museum.... I have been to a lot of museums around the world and this one was one of the nicest I have seen. Well lit, spaced and categorized. Some very interesting pieces. You can take pictures everywhere except the Picasso section. Only about 8 pieces from him anyways. Check out the Picasso Museum in town if you are a fan.

Interesting modern art collection. While best known for earlier work, don't miss the modern art collection. Much of it seems a "browner" Catalan interpretation of what was then happening in Paris, but there are some standouts, including Gaudi, Dali, Gollofre and Picasso. The Oleum restaurant is also a great place to escape for a 2 hour lunch.

well worth a visit. This is a very well organised and interesting museum. The location is terrific with the views over Barcelona stunning. We sat outside at the little cafe listening to guitar music looking over Barcelona-perfect.
We did not allow enough time to see everything so hope to return one day.

Beautiful museum, a must if you like Gothic and/or Romanesque art. Quite simply, this museum has the best collection of Gothic art I've seen anywhere. There are many beautiful large altarpieces, and some works with rather surprising color palettes. I was brought to tears a few times. Gorgeous. And the collection is absolutely HUGE.The Romanesque section is also not to be missed, with an amazing display of frescoes removed from a Catalan church dating to the 11th Century. The frescoes aren't perfectly intact, as you might expect, but they are numerous, beautiful and enlightening.There is also a very good collection of works from Baroque to Modern periods, including some very interesting Modernista stuff (including Gaudí) that you're unlikely to see elsewhere.On top of that, you can enjoy the view of Plaça Espanya and Tibidabo after your visit with a nice glass of wine or beer on the terrace at the front.Admission is covered with your Articket card. Highly recommended!

Beautiful Museum. We spent about 4 hours in the MNAC.Although there is a fee, it was free for us thanks to the Barcelona Card.The building (Palau Nacional) is a very nice building. The design of the museum (periods, chronology, presentation of works) are really professional and a delight to visit.Photographs of the Civil War, works of Gaspar Homar, Picasso and the classical masters are nicely displayed.The coffee house serves nice pastry and coffee - visit it before you leave.

It is true- it's the world's best romanesque art (fresco) collection. MNAC is a lot more than just a museum, from the outside it is a spectacle for the eye, when you climb the stairs to the main entrance it is a again a spectacle for the eye as you have a great panorama view over the Barcelona (there is a cafe bar there to refresh if you get tired climbing- escalators will help you move up the hill), and when you enter you get to see the best romanesque art ever and it doesn't stop there- the collection holds Catalonian art from the mentioned early times all the way to Gaudi's furniture and Picasso paintings, so barock and renaissance lovers, there is some great art for you too!!First Sunday of every month the entrance is free.
Get off the bus!. Hop off the tour bus here, and grab a glass of cava while taking in a magnificent view of the city. Honestly, we didn't even go in, but just the view was worth the stop!

Beautifull Building, Amazing Collection. The view of the site from Plaça Espanya is majestic, the collection includes Romanic, Gothic, Reinassence and Modern pieces of art. If you go to Barcelona, this is a most.

very good catalan art museum. the best introduction to the catalan art as it cover all the historical periods of the art.
however the section for the modern art is closed for renovation. becouse of this you are entitled for a nother visit to the museum using the same ticket. the audio guide is of great help.

Wonderful art and great views of Barcelona.. This was one of my favorite attractions on our visit to Barcelona,we stopped here with our tour bus and spent a short time looking through the wonderful mix of Baroque,Romanesque,Gothic,and modern art.I think the entrance fee was about 8 Euros.Outside many people congregated on the steps,and the views of Barcelona are magnificent.It's also a short walk to the oyympic stadium.

An amazing and user-friendly art gallery. This gallery has six huge collections and you will need at least one day to look through it. Fortunately, the tickets last for two days, which is not always made clear, so hold onto yours in case you want to go back. Photographs are permitted and it is possible to get right up to most of the exhibits. They are displayed in a very cool, clean white space and not too densely hung most of the time, so it's possible to appreciate them individually. The collections are in air-conditioned rooms that lead on from one another and there is a sofa-lined hall upstairs for bored spouses. The loos are hidden away at one side of the main hall downstairs, there is a small shop but no overt attempts at marketing. The restaurant looked very civilised and too expensive for a quick sandwich but you can buy drinks outside on the terrace in front of the building. Watch the prices! Far better to take a drink with you or walk a little further down to the cafes. The walk from the Metro station seems a very long way in the sun and there are escalators that eventually lead to a lot of steps, so be prepared to carry small children. An excellent day out for art lovers - we had two trips out there.

It's great!. The MNAC is a good place to visit on holidays because it has a lot of pictures, sculptures, monuments and art in general made by fantastic artists of Barcelona. Sometimes it has pictures by famous artists, for example Joaquin Sorolla. Surrounding MNAC is Montjuic. It’s very nice because it has an amazing forest and the views are very beautiful, you can see all Barcelona ( “Torre de Collserola”, Tibidabo etc.) but it is a little tiring because it has a lot of stairs but you can take the escalator.

Centuries of art (including modernist pieces) housed in a palace!. Among the best museums, if not the best, that I've visited anywhere in the world. The MNAC is housed in a beautiful palace on Montjuic (recommend skipping the funicular and walking up the steps from Placa Espana instead; faster, easier, and more direct). Huge variety of art genres, periods, and media -- something for everyone. Your ticket is good for two days, so you can go back for a second visit if you don't have time to catch everything the first time. Try to time your visit(s) so that you're there at sunset: The Magic Fountain is right below the MNAC (near the base of the steps that you walk up to get to MNAC), and you'll have a great view of the sunset show.

Plaza de España and Museu Nacional d`Art de Catalunya. Plaza de España - one of the largest squares of the city, was built to the International Exhibition in 1929 at the foot of Montjuic near Sants-Montjuic. That's the view from the mountain to the area you are now and see. In the center - a fountain designed by Josep Maria Jujol, member of Antoni Gaudi, and sculptures by his side created by Miquel Blay. Buildings were designed by Nicolau Maria Rubio and Tuduri. Next, see Venetian tower. The museum itself is behind me.Their height is 47 m. They point the way to the National Museum of Catalan Art across the street, Avinguda de la Reina Maria Cristina.Who cares, the history of the area in the abridged version: the square was built on the site, which was previously used for public executions. Following the establishment in 1715 the fortress citadel, to date destroyed, the gallows were moved into the castle. The area was designed in 1915, and was built in 1929 and was ready to take the World's Fair in 1929 In 1928, the dictator Miguel Primo de Rivera, who at the time headed the Spanish government ordered the dismantling four Ionic columns, known as Les quatre columns. These pillars symbolizing the four bands on the flag of Catalonia, and the decree of Miguel Primo de Rivera on their dismantling part of its policy of total prohibition of the Catalan character.Reaching the square fastest on the subway. Spain station (lines L1, L3, L8).And this is the Plaza de Toros. The old arena for bullfights. Tuned to the mall. Bullfighting in Catalonia is not popular.National Art Museum of Catalonia or MNAC - Museum of Catalan Art, is the main museum in Barcelona, he is in the National Palace, built for the International Exhibition of 1929.It is situated on a hill Montjuïc at the end of the Avinguda de la Reina Maria Cristina, the palace was renovated for the Summer Olympic Games in 1992.The museum houses an amazing collection of Romanesque art (eg, wall painting in the Romanesque churches and chapels near Catalonia, which has been moved to the museum), Gothic Art (Catalan Art XIII-XV centuries), the art of the Renaissance, Baroque and contemporary art. tdel drawings and prints, photography and numismatics department: coins, medals and paper money from the VI century BC. er. and to this day.Hours: Mon-Sat 10.00-19.00, Sun and holidays 10.00-14.30, closed on 1 January, 1 May and 25 DecemberTicket price: Tue-Wed, Fri-Sun 05.08?, temporary exhibitions Tue-Wed, Fri-Sun 5evro, museum and temporary exhibitions Tue-Wed, Fri-Sun 12evro, Fri after 18.00, for children aged 7 to 21 years and persons over 65 years Tue-Sun 30% discount, the first Thursday of the month admission is free.

Worth a visit for the exhibits and the sunset view. Nice collection. Museum closes at 19:00 and I had only 45 mins to see some of the master pieces selected in a hurry from the printed guide. Despite the late entrance there is no discounted ticket. Nevertheless you may be able to use your ticket at a later date (that info was given by an inspector but was is not verified). Some of the staff do not understand English at all. It is unacceptable to ask and point at the photo of the exhibit and be instructed to a wrong floor/hall. Photo's are allowed at some areas but some other not (e.g. Picasso's artwork).
Insiping art, fantastic building.. A great showcase of the best of Catalan art in a insperational building.Also contains an auditorium.Closes very early 2-3pm on Sundays.

not a Art lover but the Building and the views are excellent. I really loved the building and the view of “Plaza de Espanya”. Inside you have several painting styles scattered in several rooms. If you’d like to see the expositions for sure this place it will be delighted for you.

Great Museum But.... We visited in mid March 2010 and found this place incredible. Even the walk up to it was incredible. The Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya sits above the Magic Fountains and at night when everything is lit up it is spectacular. Inside there is four separate sections on display. The Romanesque which is actual displays of art work that was painted on the walls of old churches throughout the countryside that were being torn down and a lot of the art that could be salvaged is on display here. Then there was the Modern art section which we decided not to see as it was getting late and we wanted to see the Renaissance section. After a light snack in the snack shop we set off for the Renaissance section only to find out that it was closed. This was not mentioned when we purchased our tickets 2 hours earlier and there was no discount given because this whole section was closed. Don't get us wrong we thought the museum was incredible and we would definitely go again but you will want to make sure that all the sections are available for viewing before you go just to avoid disappointment. The fourth section is whatever temporary exhibition is happening at the time but there is an additional fee to get into this section.

more like a historic museum. The Romanic and Medieval sections double as historic museums, with mostly religious paintings from church interiors.Moving on to the more "modern" sections, the art work became more and more varied.Yes, Picasso and Gaudi replicas are featured.One can go in the afternoon to get away from the heat outside, then hang around for the magic fountain show!

Great, packed with little jewels and great awesome view from the cafe. What I liked? Great art, medieval, modern, Picasso, Gaudi. Great way to know more about catalan culture.What I loved? Stop by at the café, really, incredible views with Barcelona at your feet and live Spanish guitar. Just Vicki Cristina Barcelona.

Frescoes and more. When in Barcelona don't miss the Museu Nacional d`Art de Catalunya - MNAC. The museum itself is located atop Montjuic, a hill overlooking the city centre and this allows for fine views.The selection of medieval frescoes and carvings from the Pyrenees and Catalonia is impressive. Also, check out the Modern Art section with Ramon Casas' tandem bicyle painting. A nice museum; spacious and modern.

Excellent, a must see for nature and art lovers. The palace itself and the nature surrounding it is worth the visit. Just go up the escalators or climb the stairs to the top and admire the view of the city below. The fountain below is spectacular and the fountain show is amazing. The palace lights are stunning. The museum has a great selection of different Spanish artwork and displays an excellent array of Spanish history and culture. You could spend two days in this museum, and the ticket can be used for two consecutive days, in fact. The museum inside is beautiful, beyond the artwork and artifacts themselves. You can go walking around the outside of the national palace and look at the nature, it's relaxing and pretty. Also have a look at the olympic arena just behind the palace; the views are amazing. You could spend a whole afternoon here.

Overrrated. I got the impression from the guidebooks that this was a lot more impressive than it was. There are so many wonderful things to see in Barcelona that this really warrants only a quick stop, in my opinion, unless you are really crazy about medieval art.

Art is ok, place is wonderful. The art is ok, as noted by a previous reviewer, doesn't compare to the Thyssen or Prado, imho.The building itself is pretty, I thought. I approached it both from above and below, and it's pretty to look at. If you're approaching from above (the Park), MNAC peeks through the trees. Take the tram up (it's located in the subway, it's part of the subway so it's a free transfer), at the top, you can go up to the Castle or walk toward Miro, and MNAC is just a little further down. The Park is very pretty near the Miro. The building is also pretty cool from the inside.The "Magic Fountain" is on the grounds. I never figured out the time schedule, but it was going off in the weekday morning (or part of it). It was very nice. I can see that it would be spectacular if all the fountains went off, esp. at night.Worth a gander, if not just to walk around outside.

Not the best museum in Spain. The MNAC was strongly recommended in the guide books. Most of the presentation seemed to be oriented to the Catalan history, which I appreciate is a source of local pride. I suppose the highlight of our visit was the exceptional view from the front steps. Standing there, one can see the whole of Barcelona city. The museum itself was so-so, but we had just been to the Prado, Thiessen, etc., so perhaps were expecting more.

Amazing....... Ok, im not into visting museums much, but its the actual BUILDING itself that is amazing!Seriously, its as impressive as the Taj Mahal and looks like a palace! You cant miss the thing really!There are about 100 steps that go to the actual front/doors of this building (its where they used to store hundred of famous paintings from across the world, but now i THINK there is a new museum built). When you get to the top of the steps, the view (on a nice sunny day!), is BREATHTAKING!!!I went to this building NYE about 3 years ago, as i heard from local spanish people its the place people go to celebrate, so, i did! Everyone walks up around 11:45pm with bottles of champagne (i had Lambrini, kidding...haha), and party streamers, and then around midnight at the top of the steps (theres like a little area people can take photos), the place explodes! At the back of this building are parks and where the OLYMPIC stadium is, well worth a walk around on a beautiful summers day.To get to the National art Museum, get the Metro to PLACA DE ESPANYA.
